M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was about\r\nto reprehend this breach of the rules of etiquette, when he felt the\r\nhand of Athos, who had rallied all his energies to contend against\r\npain, at length overcome by it, fell upon the floor as if he were dead.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA surgeon!\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cmine! The king\xe2\x80\x99s! The best! A\r\nsurgeon! Or, s\xe2\x80\x99blood, my brave Athos will die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the cries of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, the whole assemblage rushed into the\r\ncabinet, he not thinking to shut the door against anyone, and all\r\ncrowded round the wounded man. But all this eager attention might have\r\nbeen useless if the doctor so loudly called for had not chanced to be\r\nin the h\xc3\xb4tel. He pushed through the crowd, approached Athos, still\r\ninsensible, and as all this noise and commotion inconvenienced him\r\ngreatly, he required, as the first and most urgent thing, that the\r\nMusketeer should be carried into an adjoining chamber. Immediately M.\r\nde Tr\xc3\xa9ville opened and pointed the way to Porthos and Aramis, who bore\r\ntheir comrade in their arms. Behind this group walked the surgeon; and\r\nbehind the surgeon the door closed.\r\n\r\nThe cabinet of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, generally held so sacred, became in an\r\ninstant the annex of the antechamber. Everyone spoke, harangued, and\r\nvociferated, swearing, cursing, and consigning the cardinal and his\r\nGuards to all the devils.\r\n\r\nAn instant after, Porthos and Aramis re-entered, the surgeon and M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville alone remaining with the wounded.\r\n\r\nAt length, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville himself returned. The injured man had\r\nrecovered his senses. The surgeon declared that the situation of the\r\nMusketeer had nothing in it to render his friends uneasy, his weakness\r\nhaving been purely and simply caused by loss of blood.\r\n\r\nThen M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville made a sign with his hand, and all retired except\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who did not forget that he had an audience, and with the\r\ntenacity of a Gascon remained in his place.\r\n\r\nWhen all had gone out and the door was closed, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, on\r\nturning round, found himself alone with the young man. The event which\r\nhad occurred had in some degree broken the thread of his ideas. He\r\ninquired what was the will of his persevering visitor. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan then\r\nrepeated his name, and in an instant recovering all his remembrances of\r\nthe present and the past, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville grasped the situation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cpardon me my dear compatriot, but I had\r\nwholly forgotten you. But what help is there for it! A captain is\r\nnothing but a father of a family, charged with even a greater\r\nresponsibility than the father of an ordinary family. Soldiers are big\r\nchildren; but as I maintain that the orders of the king, and more\r\nparticularly the orders of the cardinal, should be executed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could not restrain a smile. By this smile M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\r\njudged that he had not to deal with a fool, and changing the\r\nconversation, came straight to the point.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI respected your father very much,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat can I do for the\r\nson? Tell me quickly; my time is not my own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9con quitting Tarbes and coming hither, it\r\nwas my intention to request of you, in remembrance of the friendship\r\nwhich you have not forgotten, the uniform of a Musketeer; but after all\r\nthat I have seen during the last two hours, I comprehend that such a\r\nfavor is enormous, and tremble lest I should not merit it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is indeed a favor, young man,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it may\r\nnot be so far beyond your hopes as you believe, or rather as you appear\r\nto believe. But his majesty\xe2\x80\x99s decision is always necessary; and I\r\ninform you with regret that no one becomes a Musketeer without the\r\npreliminary ordeal of several campaigns, certain brilliant actions, or\r\na service of two years in some other regiment less favored than ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan bowed without replying, feeling his desire to don the\r\nMusketeer\xe2\x80\x99s uniform vastly increased by the great difficulties which\r\npreceded the attainment of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, fixing upon his compatriot a look so\r\npiercing that it might be said he wished to read the thoughts of his\r\nheart, \xe2\x80\x9con account of my old companion, your father, as I have said, I\r\nwill do something for you, young man. Our recruits from B\xc3\xa9arn are not\r\ngenerally very rich, and I have no reason to think matters have much\r\nchanged in this respect since I left the province. I dare say you have\r\nnot brought too large a stock of money with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan drew himself up with a proud air which plainly said, \xe2\x80\x9cI ask\r\nalms of no man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s very well, young man,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nall very well. I know these airs; I myself came to Paris with four\r\ncrowns in my purse, and would have fought with anyone who dared to tell\r\nme I was not in a condition to purchase the Louvre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s bearing became still more imposing. Thanks to the sale of\r\nhis horse, he commenced his career with four more crowns than M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville possessed at the commencement of his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought, I say, then, to husband the means you have, however large\r\nthe sum may be; but you ought also to endeavor to perfect yourself in\r\nthe exercises becoming a gentleman. I will write a letter today to the\r\nDirector of the Royal Academy, and tomorrow he will admit you without\r\nany expense to yourself. Do not refuse this little service. Our\r\nbest-born and richest gentlemen sometimes solicit it without being able\r\nto obtain it. You will learn horsemanship, swordsmanship in all its\r\nbranches, and dancing. You will make some desirable acquaintances; and\r\nfrom time to time you can call upon me, just to tell me how you are\r\ngetting on, and to say whether I can be of further service to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, stranger as he was to all the manners of a court, could not\r\nbut perceive a little coldness in this reception.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot but perceive how sadly I miss the\r\nletter of introduction which my father gave me to present to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI certainly am surprised,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you should\r\nundertake so long a journey without that necessary passport, the sole\r\nresource of us poor B\xc3\xa9arnese.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had one, sir, and, thank God, such as I could wish,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it was perfidiously stolen from me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then related the adventure of Meung, described the unknown gentleman\r\nwith the greatest minuteness, and all with a warmth and truthfulness\r\nthat delighted M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is all very strange,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, after meditating a\r\nminute; \xe2\x80\x9cyou mentioned my name, then, aloud?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, I certainly committed that imprudence; but why should I have\r\ndone otherwise? A name like yours must be as a buckler to me on my way.\r\nJudge if I should not put myself under its protection.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFlattery was at that period very current, and M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville loved\r\nincense as well as a king, or even a cardinal. He could not refrain\r\nfrom a smile of visible satisfaction; but this smile soon disappeared,\r\nand returning to the adventure of Meung, \xe2\x80\x9cTell me,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9chad\r\nnot this gentlemen a slight scar on his cheek?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, such a one as would be made by the grazing of a ball.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he not a fine-looking man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf lofty stature.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf pale complexion and brown hair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, that is he; how is it, sir, that you are acquainted with\r\nthis man? If I ever find him again\xe2\x80\x94and I will find him, I swear, were\r\nit in hell!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was waiting for a woman,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe departed immediately after having conversed for a minute with her\r\nwhom he awaited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know not the subject of their conversation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe gave her a box, told her not to open it except in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas this woman English?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe called her Milady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he; it must be he!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Tr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cI believed him still at\r\nBrussels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir, if you know who this man is,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me who\r\nhe is, and whence he is. I will then release you from all your\r\npromises\xe2\x80\x94even that of procuring my admission into the Musketeers; for\r\nbefore everything, I wish to avenge myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware, young man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Tr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you see him coming on one side\r\nof the street, pass by on the other. Do not cast yourself against such\r\na rock; he would break you like glass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will not prevent me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cif ever I find him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the meantime,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cseek him not\xe2\x80\x94if I have a right to\r\nadvise you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll at once the captain stopped, as if struck by a sudden suspicion.\r\nThis great hatred which the young traveler manifested so loudly for\r\nthis man, who\xe2\x80\x94a rather improbable thing\xe2\x80\x94had stolen his father\xe2\x80\x99s letter\r\nfrom him\xe2\x80\x94was there not some perfidy concealed under this hatred? Might\r\nnot this young man be sent by his Eminence? Might he not have come for\r\nthe purpose of laying a snare for him? This pretended D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x94was he\r\nnot an emissary of the cardinal, whom the cardinal sought to introduce\r\ninto Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s house, to place near him, to win his confidence, and\r\nafterward to ruin him as had been done in a thousand other instances?\r\nHe fixed his eyes upon D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan even more earnestly than before. He\r\nwas moderately reassured, however, by the aspect of that countenance,\r\nfull of astute intelligence and affected humility. \xe2\x80\x9cI know he is a\r\nGascon,\xe2\x80\x9d reflected he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut he may be one for the cardinal as well as\r\nfor me. Let us try him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, slowly, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish, as the son of an ancient\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x94for I consider this story of the lost letter perfectly true\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwish, I say, in order to repair the coldness you may have remarked in\r\nmy reception of you, to discover to you the secrets of our policy. The\r\nking and the cardinal are the best of friends; their apparent\r\nbickerings are only feints to deceive fools. I am not willing that a\r\ncompatriot, a handsome cavalier, a brave youth, quite fit to make his\r\nway, should become the dupe of all these artifices and fall into the\r\nsnare after the example of so many others who have been ruined by it.\r\nBe assured that I am devoted to both these all-powerful masters, and\r\nthat my earnest endeavors have no other aim than the service of the\r\nking, and also the cardinal\xe2\x80\x94one of the most illustrious geniuses that\r\nFrance has ever produced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, young man, regulate your conduct accordingly; and if you\r\nentertain, whether from your family, your relations, or even from your\r\ninstincts, any of these enmities which we see constantly breaking out\r\nagainst the cardinal, bid me adieu and let us separate. I will aid you\r\nin many ways, but without attaching you to my person. I hope that my\r\nfrankness at least will make you my friend; for you are the only young\r\nman to whom I have hitherto spoken as I have done to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville said to himself: \xe2\x80\x9cIf the cardinal has set this young fox upon\r\nme, he will certainly not have failed\xe2\x80\x94he, who knows how bitterly I\r\nexecrate him\xe2\x80\x94to tell his spy that the best means of making his court to\r\nme is to rail at him. Therefore, in spite of all my protestations, if\r\nit be as I suspect, my cunning gossip will assure me that he holds his\r\nEminence in horror.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt, however, proved otherwise. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan answered, with the greatest\r\nsimplicity: \xe2\x80\x9cI came to Paris with exactly such intentions. My father\r\nadvised me to stoop to nobody but the king, the cardinal, and\r\nyourself\xe2\x80\x94whom he considered the first three personages in France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan added M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville to the others, as may be perceived; but\r\nhe thought this addition would do no harm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the greatest veneration for the cardinal,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nthe most profound respect for his actions. So much the better for me,\r\nsir, if you speak to me, as you say, with frankness\xe2\x80\x94for then you will\r\ndo me the honor to esteem the resemblance of our opinions; but if you\r\nhave entertained any doubt, as naturally you may, I feel that I am\r\nruining myself by speaking the truth. But I still trust you will not\r\nesteem me the less for it, and that is my object beyond all others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was surprised to the greatest degree. So much\r\npenetration, so much frankness, created admiration, but did not\r\nentirely remove his suspicions. The more this young man was superior to\r\nothers, the more he was to be dreaded if he meant to deceive him.\r\nNevertheless, he pressed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and said to him: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\r\nan honest youth; but at the present moment I can only do for you that\r\nwhich I just now offered. My h\xc3\xb4tel will be always open to you.\r\nHereafter, being able to ask for me at all hours, and consequently to\r\ntake advantage of all opportunities, you will probably obtain that\r\nwhich you desire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you will wait until I have\r\nproved myself worthy of it. Well, be assured,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, with the\r\nfamiliarity of a Gascon, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall not wait long.\xe2\x80\x9d And he bowed in\r\norder to retire, and as if he considered the future in his own hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut wait a minute,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, stopping him. \xe2\x80\x9cI promised you\r\na letter for the director of the Academy. Are you too proud to accept\r\nit, young gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand I will guard it so carefully that I\r\nwill be sworn it shall arrive at its address, and woe be to him who\r\nshall attempt to take it from me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville smiled at this flourish; and leaving his young man\r\ncompatriot in the embrasure of the window, where they had talked\r\ntogether, he seated himself at a table in order to write the promised\r\nletter of recommendation. While he was doing this, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, having\r\nno better employment, amused himself with beating a march upon the\r\nwindow and with looking at the Musketeers, who went away, one after\r\nanother, following them with his eyes until they disappeared.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, after having written the letter, sealed it, and rising,\r\napproached the young man in order to give it to him. But at the very\r\nmoment when D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stretched out his hand to receive it, M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville was highly astonished to see his _prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9_ make a sudden\r\nspring, become crimson with passion, and rush from the cabinet crying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x99blood, he shall not escape me this time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe, my thief!\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, the traitor!\xe2\x80\x9d and he\r\ndisappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil take the madman!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cunless,\xe2\x80\x9d added\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a cunning mode of escaping, seeing that he had failed in\r\nhis purpose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IV.\r\nTHE SHOULDER OF ATHOS, THE BALDRIC OF PORTHOS AND THE HANDKERCHIEF OF\r\nARAMIS\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in a state of fury, crossed the antechamber at three\r\nbounds, and was darting toward the stairs, which he reckoned upon\r\ndescending four at a time, when, in his heedless course, he ran head\r\nforemost against a Musketeer who was coming out of one of M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s private rooms, and striking his shoulder violently, made him\r\nutter a cry, or rather a howl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, endeavoring to resume his course, \xe2\x80\x9cexcuse\r\nme, but I am in a hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nScarcely had he descended the first stair, when a hand of iron seized\r\nhim by the belt and stopped him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are in a hurry?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeer, as pale as a sheet. \xe2\x80\x9cUnder\r\nthat pretense you run against me! You say, \xe2\x80\x98Excuse me,\xe2\x80\x99 and you believe\r\nthat is sufficient? Not at all, my young man. Do you fancy because you\r\nhave heard Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville speak to us a little cavalierly today\r\nthat other people are to treat us as he speaks to us? Undeceive\r\nyourself, comrade, you are not Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith!\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, recognizing Athos, who, after the\r\ndressing performed by the doctor, was returning to his own apartment.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not do it intentionally, and not doing it intentionally, I said\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Excuse me.\xe2\x80\x99 It appears to me that this is quite enough. I repeat to\r\nyou, however, and this time on my word of honor\xe2\x80\x94I think perhaps too\r\noften\xe2\x80\x94that I am in haste, great haste. Leave your hold, then, I beg of\r\nyou, and let me go where my business calls me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, letting him go, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are not polite; it is easy\r\nto perceive that you come from a distance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had already strode down three or four stairs, but at Athos\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlast remark he stopped short.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Morbleu_, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chowever far I may come, it is not you\r\nwho can give me a lesson in good manners, I warn you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! If I were not in such haste, and if I were not running after\r\nsomeone,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Man-in-a-hurry, you can find me without running\xe2\x80\x94_me_, you\r\nunderstand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where, I pray you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNear the Carmes-Deschaux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout noon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout noon? That will do; I will be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEndeavor not to make me wait; for at quarter past twelve I will cut\r\noff your ears as you run.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI will be there ten minutes before twelve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd he set off running as if the devil possessed him, hoping that he\r\nmight yet find the stranger, whose slow pace could not have carried him\r\nfar.\r\n\r\nBut at the street gate, Porthos was talking with the soldier on guard.\r\nBetween the two talkers there was just enough room for a man to pass.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought it would suffice for him, and he sprang forward like\r\na dart between them. But D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had reckoned without the wind. As\r\nhe was about to pass, the wind blew out Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s long cloak, and\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rushed straight into the middle of it. Without doubt,\r\nPorthos had reasons for not abandoning this part of his vestments, for\r\ninstead of quitting his hold on the flap in his hand, he pulled it\r\ntoward him, so that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rolled himself up in the velvet by a\r\nmovement of rotation explained by the persistency of Porthos.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, hearing the Musketeer swear, wished to escape from the\r\ncloak, which blinded him, and sought to find his way from under the\r\nfolds of it. He was particularly anxious to avoid marring the freshness\r\nof the magnificent baldric we are acquainted with; but on timidly\r\nopening his eyes, he found himself with his nose fixed between the two\r\nshoulders of Porthos\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, exactly upon the baldric.\r\n\r\nAlas, like most things in this world which have nothing in their favor\r\nbut appearances, the baldric was glittering with gold in the front, but\r\nwas nothing but simple buff behind. Vainglorious as he was, Porthos\r\ncould not afford to have a baldric wholly of gold, but had at least\r\nhalf. One could comprehend the necessity of the cold and the urgency of\r\nthe cloak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos, making strong efforts to disembarrass\r\nhimself of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was wriggling about his back; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must be\r\nmad to run against people in this manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, reappearing under the shoulder of the\r\ngiant, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I am in such haste\xe2\x80\x94I was running after someone and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you always forget your eyes when you run?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, piqued, \xe2\x80\x9cand thanks to my eyes, I can see\r\nwhat other people cannot see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhether Porthos understood him or did not understand him, giving way to\r\nhis anger, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou stand a chance of getting\r\nchastised if you rub Musketeers in this fashion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChastised, Monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthe expression is strong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is one that becomes a man accustomed to look his enemies in the\r\nface.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _pardieu!_ I know full well that you don\xe2\x80\x99t turn your back to\r\nyours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the young man, delighted with his joke, went away laughing loudly.\r\n\r\nPorthos foamed with rage, and made a movement to rush after D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPresently, presently,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you haven\xe2\x80\x99t your cloak\r\non.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, then, behind the Luxembourg.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, at one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, then,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, turning the\r\nangle of the street.\r\n\r\nBut neither in the street he had passed through, nor in the one which\r\nhis eager glance pervaded, could he see anyone; however slowly the\r\nstranger had walked, he was gone on his way, or perhaps had entered\r\nsome house. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan inquired of everyone he met with, went down to\r\nthe ferry, came up again by the Rue de Seine, and the Red Cross; but\r\nnothing, absolutely nothing! This chase was, however, advantageous to\r\nhim in one sense, for in proportion as the perspiration broke from his\r\nforehead, his heart began to cool.\r\n\r\nHe began to reflect upon the events that had passed; they were numerous\r\nand inauspicious. It was scarcely eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, and\r\nyet this morning had already brought him into disgrace with M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, who could not fail to think the manner in which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nhad left him a little cavalier.\r\n\r\nBesides this, he had drawn upon himself two good duels with two men,\r\neach capable of killing three D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnans\xe2\x80\x94with two Musketeers, in\r\nshort, with two of those beings whom he esteemed so greatly that he\r\nplaced them in his mind and heart above all other men.\r\n\r\nThe outlook was sad. Sure of being killed by Athos, it may easily be\r\nunderstood that the young man was not very uneasy about Porthos. As\r\nhope, however, is the last thing extinguished in the heart of man, he\r\nfinished by hoping that he might survive, even though with terrible\r\nwounds, in both these duels; and in case of surviving, he made the\r\nfollowing reprehensions upon his own conduct:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a madcap I was, and what a stupid fellow I am! That brave and\r\nunfortunate Athos was wounded on that very shoulder against which I\r\nmust run head foremost, like a ram. The only thing that astonishes me\r\nis that he did not strike me dead at once. He had good cause to do so;\r\nthe pain I gave him must have been atrocious. As to Porthos\xe2\x80\x94oh, as to\r\nPorthos, faith, that\xe2\x80\x99s a droll affair!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd in spite of himself, the young man began to laugh aloud, looking\r\nround carefully, however, to see that his solitary laugh, without a\r\ncause in the eyes of passers-by, offended no one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to Porthos, that is certainly droll; but I am not the less a giddy\r\nfool. Are people to be run against without warning? No! And have I any\r\nright to go and peep under their cloaks to see what is not there? He\r\nwould have pardoned me, he would certainly have pardoned me, if I had\r\nnot said anything to him about that cursed baldric\xe2\x80\x94in ambiguous words,\r\nit is true, but rather drolly ambiguous. Ah, cursed Gascon that I am, I\r\nget from one hobble into another. Friend D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he,\r\nspeaking to himself with all the amenity that he thought due himself,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif you escape, of which there is not much chance, I would advise you\r\nto practice perfect politeness for the future. You must henceforth be\r\nadmired and quoted as a model of it. To be obliging and polite does not\r\nnecessarily make a man a coward. Look at Aramis, now; Aramis is\r\nmildness and grace personified. Well, did anybody ever dream of calling\r\nAramis a coward? No, certainly not, and from this moment I will\r\nendeavor to model myself after him. Ah! That\xe2\x80\x99s strange! Here he is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, walking and soliloquizing, had arrived within a few steps\r\nof the h\xc3\xb4tel d\xe2\x80\x99Arguillon and in front of that h\xc3\xb4tel perceived Aramis,\r\nchatting gaily with three gentlemen; but as he had not forgotten that\r\nit was in presence of this young man that M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville had been so\r\nangry in the morning, and as a witness of the rebuke the Musketeers had\r\nreceived was not likely to be at all agreeable, he pretended not to see\r\nhim. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, on the contrary, quite full of his plans of\r\nconciliation and courtesy, approached the young men with a profound\r\nbow, accompanied by a most gracious smile. All four, besides,\r\nimmediately broke off their conversation.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not so dull as not to perceive that he was one too many;\r\nbut he was not sufficiently broken into the fashions of the gay world\r\nto know how to extricate himself gallantly from a false position, like\r\nthat of a man who begins to mingle with people he is scarcely\r\nacquainted with and in a conversation that does not concern him. He was\r\nseeking in his mind, then, for the least awkward means of retreat, when\r\nhe remarked that Aramis had let his handkerchief fall, and by mistake,\r\nno doubt, had placed his foot upon it. This appeared to be a favorable\r\nopportunity to repair his intrusion. He stooped, and with the most\r\ngracious air he could assume, drew the handkerchief from under the foot\r\nof the Musketeer in spite of the efforts the latter made to detain it,\r\nand holding it out to him, said, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe, monsieur, that this is a\r\nhandkerchief you would be sorry to lose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe handkerchief was indeed richly embroidered, and had a coronet and\r\narms at one of its corners. Aramis blushed excessively, and snatched\r\nrather than took the handkerchief from the hand of the Gascon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of the Guards, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you persist in saying, most\r\ndiscreet Aramis, that you are not on good terms with Madame de\r\nBois-Tracy, when that gracious lady has the kindness to lend you one of\r\nher handkerchiefs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis darted at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan one of those looks which inform a man that\r\nhe has acquired a mortal enemy. Then, resuming his mild air, \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\r\ndeceived, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthis handkerchief is not mine, and I\r\ncannot fancy why Monsieur has taken it into his head to offer it to me\r\nrather than to one of you; and as a proof of what I say, here is mine\r\nin my pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo saying, he pulled out his own handkerchief, likewise a very elegant\r\nhandkerchief, and of fine cambric\xe2\x80\x94though cambric was dear at the\r\nperiod\xe2\x80\x94but a handkerchief without embroidery and without arms, only\r\nornamented with a single cipher, that of its proprietor.\r\n\r\nThis time D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not hasty. He perceived his mistake; but the\r\nfriends of Aramis were not at all convinced by his denial, and one of\r\nthem addressed the young Musketeer with affected seriousness. \xe2\x80\x9cIf it\r\nwere as you pretend it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI should be forced, my dear\r\nAramis, to reclaim it myself; for, as you very well know, Bois-Tracy is\r\nan intimate friend of mine, and I cannot allow the property of his wife\r\nto be sported as a trophy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou make the demand badly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cand while acknowledging\r\nthe justice of your reclamation, I refuse it on account of the form.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is,\xe2\x80\x9d hazarded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, timidly, \xe2\x80\x9cI did not see the\r\nhandkerchief fall from the pocket of Monsieur Aramis. He had his foot\r\nupon it, that is all; and I thought from having his foot upon it the\r\nhandkerchief was his.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you were deceived, my dear sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, coldly, very\r\nlittle sensible to the reparation. Then turning toward that one of the\r\nguards who had declared himself the friend of Bois-Tracy, \xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued he, \xe2\x80\x9cI have reflected, my dear intimate of Bois-Tracy, that I\r\nam not less tenderly his friend than you can possibly be; so that\r\ndecidedly this handkerchief is as likely to have fallen from your\r\npocket as mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, upon my honor!\xe2\x80\x9d cried his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s Guardsman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are about to swear upon your honor and I upon my word, and then it\r\nwill be pretty evident that one of us will have lied. Now, here,\r\nMontaran, we will do better than that\xe2\x80\x94let each take a half.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the handkerchief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly just,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the other two Guardsmen, \xe2\x80\x9cthe judgment of King\r\nSolomon! Aramis, you certainly are full of wisdom!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young men burst into a laugh, and as may be supposed, the affair\r\nhad no other sequel. In a moment or two the conversation ceased, and\r\nthe three Guardsmen and the Musketeer, after having cordially shaken\r\nhands, separated, the Guardsmen going one way and Aramis another.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow is my time to make peace with this gallant man,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nto himself, having stood on one side during the whole of the latter\r\npart of the conversation; and with this good feeling drawing near to\r\nAramis, who was departing without paying any attention to him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will excuse me, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cpermit me to observe to you that\r\nyou have not acted in this affair as a gallant man ought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand do you suppose\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose, monsieur, that you are not a fool, and that you knew very\r\nwell, although coming from Gascony, that people do not tread upon\r\nhandkerchiefs without a reason. What the devil! Paris is not paved with\r\ncambric!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, you act wrongly in endeavoring to mortify me,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in whom the natural quarrelsome spirit began to speak more\r\nloudly than his pacific resolutions. \xe2\x80\x9cI am from Gascony, it is true;\r\nand since you know it, there is no occasion to tell you that Gascons\r\nare not very patient, so that when they have begged to be excused once,\r\nwere it even for a folly, they are convinced that they have done\r\nalready at least as much again as they ought to have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, what I say to you about the matter,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cis not\r\nfor the sake of seeking a quarrel. Thank God, I am not a bravo! And\r\nbeing a Musketeer but for a time, I only fight when I am forced to do\r\nso, and always with great repugnance; but this time the affair is\r\nserious, for here is a lady compromised by you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy _us_, you mean!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you so maladroitly restore me the handkerchief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you so awkwardly let it fall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have said, monsieur, and I repeat, that the handkerchief did not\r\nfall from my pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd thereby you have lied twice, monsieur, for I saw it fall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you take it with that tone, do you, Master Gascon? Well, I will\r\nteach you how to behave yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I will send you back to your Mass book, Master Abb\xc3\xa9. Draw, if you\r\nplease, and instantly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, if you please, my good friend\xe2\x80\x94not here, at least. Do you not\r\nperceive that we are opposite the H\xc3\xb4tel d\xe2\x80\x99Arguillon, which is full of\r\nthe cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s creatures? How do I know that this is not his Eminence\r\nwho has honored you with the commission to procure my head? Now, I\r\nentertain a ridiculous partiality for my head, it seems to suit my\r\nshoulders so correctly. I wish to kill you, be at rest as to that, but\r\nto kill you quietly in a snug, remote place, where you will not be able\r\nto boast of your death to anybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI agree, monsieur; but do not be too confident. Take your\r\nhandkerchief; whether it belongs to you or another, you may perhaps\r\nstand in need of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur is a Gascon?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Monsieur does not postpone an interview through prudence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrudence, monsieur, is a virtue sufficiently useless to Musketeers, I\r\nknow, but indispensable to churchmen; and as I am only a Musketeer\r\nprovisionally, I hold it good to be prudent. At two o\xe2\x80\x99clock I shall\r\nhave the honor of expecting you at the h\xc3\xb4tel of Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\nThere I will indicate to you the best place and time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two young men bowed and separated, Aramis ascending the street\r\nwhich led to the Luxembourg, while D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, perceiving the appointed\r\nhour was approaching, took the road to the Carmes-Deschaux, saying to\r\nhimself, \xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly I can\xe2\x80\x99t draw back; but at least, if I am killed, I\r\nshall be killed by a Musketeer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter V.\r\nTHE KING\xe2\x80\x99S MUSKETEERS AND THE CARDINAL\xe2\x80\x99S GUARDS\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was acquainted with nobody in Paris. He went therefore to\r\nhis appointment with Athos without a second, determined to be satisfied\r\nwith those his adversary should choose. Besides, his intention was\r\nformed to make the brave Musketeer all suitable apologies, but without\r\nmeanness or weakness, fearing that might result from this duel which\r\ngenerally results from an affair of this kind, when a young and\r\nvigorous man fights with an adversary who is wounded and weakened\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nconquered, he doubles the triumph of his antagonist; if a conqueror, he\r\nis accused of foul play and want of courage.\r\n\r\nNow, we must have badly painted the character of our adventure seeker,\r\nor our readers must have already perceived that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not an\r\nordinary man; therefore, while repeating to himself that his death was\r\ninevitable, he did not make up his mind to die quietly, as one less\r\ncourageous and less restrained might have done in his place. He\r\nreflected upon the different characters of those with whom he was going\r\nto fight, and began to view his situation more clearly. He hoped, by\r\nmeans of loyal excuses, to make a friend of Athos, whose lordly air and\r\naustere bearing pleased him much. He flattered himself he should be\r\nable to frighten Porthos with the adventure of the baldric, which he\r\nmight, if not killed upon the spot, relate to everybody a recital\r\nwhich, well managed, would cover Porthos with ridicule. As to the\r\nastute Aramis, he did not entertain much dread of him; and supposing he\r\nshould be able to get so far, he determined to dispatch him in good\r\nstyle or at least, by hitting him in the face, as C\xc3\xa6sar recommended his\r\nsoldiers do to those of Pompey, to damage forever the beauty of which\r\nhe was so proud.\r\n\r\nIn addition to this, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan possessed that invincible stock of\r\nresolution which the counsels of his father had implanted in his heart:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEndure nothing from anyone but the king, the cardinal, and Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d He flew, then, rather than walked, toward the convent of the\r\nCarmes D\xc3\xa9chauss\xc3\xa9s, or rather Deschaux, as it was called at that period,\r\na sort of building without a window, surrounded by barren fields\xe2\x80\x94an\r\naccessory to the Preaux-Clercs, and which was generally employed as the\r\nplace for the duels of men who had no time to lose.\r\n\r\nWhen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan arrived in sight of the bare spot of ground which\r\nextended along the foot of the monastery, Athos had been waiting about\r\nfive minutes, and twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock was striking. He was, then, as\r\npunctual as the Samaritan woman, and the most rigorous casuist with\r\nregard to duels could have nothing to say.\r\n\r\nAthos, who still suffered grievously from his wound, though it had been\r\ndressed anew by M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s surgeon, was seated on a post and\r\nwaiting for his adversary with hat in hand, his feather even touching\r\nthe ground.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI have engaged two of my friends as seconds;\r\nbut these two friends are not yet come, at which I am astonished, as it\r\nis not at all their custom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no seconds on my part, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cfor having\r\nonly arrived yesterday in Paris, I as yet know no one but Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, to whom I was recommended by my father, who has the honor to\r\nbe, in some degree, one of his friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos reflected for an instant. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know no one but Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, I know only him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but then,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos, speaking half to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cif I kill\r\nyou, I shall have the air of a boy-slayer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot too much so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with a bow that was not\r\ndeficient in dignity, \xe2\x80\x9csince you do me the honor to draw a sword with\r\nme while suffering from a wound which is very inconvenient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery inconvenient, upon my word; and you hurt me devilishly, I can\r\ntell you. But I will take the left hand\xe2\x80\x94it is my custom in such\r\ncircumstances. Do not fancy that I do you a favor; I use either hand\r\neasily. And it will be even a disadvantage to you; a left-handed man is\r\nvery troublesome to people who are not prepared for it. I regret I did\r\nnot inform you sooner of this circumstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have truly, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, bowing again, \xe2\x80\x9ca courtesy,\r\nfor which, I assure you, I am very grateful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou confuse me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, with his gentlemanly air; \xe2\x80\x9clet us talk\r\nof something else, if you please. Ah, s\xe2\x80\x99blood, how you have hurt me! My\r\nshoulder quite burns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you would permit me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with timidity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a miraculous balsam for wounds\xe2\x80\x94a balsam given to me by my\r\nmother and of which I have made a trial upon myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am sure that in less than three days this balsam would cure\r\nyou; and at the end of three days, when you would be cured\xe2\x80\x94well, sir,\r\nit would still do me a great honor to be your man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan spoke these words with a simplicity that did honor to his\r\ncourtesy, without throwing the least doubt upon his courage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu_, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a proposition that pleases\r\nme; not that I can accept it, but a league off it savors of the\r\ngentleman. Thus spoke and acted the gallant knights of the time of\r\nCharlemagne, in whom every cavalier ought to seek his model.\r\nUnfortunately, we do not live in the times of the great emperor, we\r\nlive in the times of the cardinal; and three days hence, however well\r\nthe secret might be guarded, it would be known, I say, that we were to\r\nfight, and our combat would be prevented. I think these fellows will\r\nnever come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you are in haste, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with the same\r\nsimplicity with which a moment before he had proposed to him to put off\r\nthe duel for three days, \xe2\x80\x9cand if it be your will to dispatch me at\r\nonce, do not inconvenience yourself, I pray you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is another word which pleases me,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, with a gracious\r\nnod to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cThat did not come from a man without a heart.\r\nMonsieur, I love men of your kidney; and I foresee plainly that if we\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t kill each other, I shall hereafter have much pleasure in your\r\nconversation. We will wait for these gentlemen, so please you; I have\r\nplenty of time, and it will be more correct. Ah, here is one of them, I\r\nbelieve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, at the end of the Rue Vaugirard the gigantic Porthos appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cis your first witness Monsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that disturbs you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy no means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd here is the second.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan turned in the direction pointed to by Athos, and perceived\r\nAramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, in an accent of greater astonishment than before,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyour second witness is Monsieur Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless! Are you not aware that we are never seen one without the\r\nothers, and that we are called among the Musketeers and the Guards, at\r\ncourt and in the city, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, or the Three\r\nInseparables? And yet, as you come from Dax or Pau\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Tarbes,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is probable you are ignorant of this little fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith!\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are well named, gentlemen; and my\r\nadventure, if it should make any noise, will prove at least that your\r\nunion is not founded upon contrasts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, Porthos had come up, waved his hand to Athos, and then\r\nturning toward D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, stood quite astonished.\r\n\r\nLet us say in passing that he had changed his baldric and relinquished\r\nhis cloak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat does this mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the gentleman I am going to fight with,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, pointing\r\nto D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with his hand and saluting him with the same gesture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it is with him I am also going to fight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not before one o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I also am to fight with this gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, coming in\r\nhis turn onto the place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not until two o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with the same calmness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what are you going to fight about, Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaith! I don\xe2\x80\x99t very well know. He hurt my shoulder. And you, Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFaith! I am going to fight\xe2\x80\x94because I am going to fight,\xe2\x80\x9d answered\r\nPorthos, reddening.\r\n\r\nAthos, whose keen eye lost nothing, perceived a faintly sly smile pass\r\nover the lips of the young Gascon as he replied, \xe2\x80\x9cWe had a short\r\ndiscussion upon dress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, ours is a theological quarrel,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, making a sign to\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to keep secret the cause of their duel.\r\n\r\nAthos indeed saw a second smile on the lips of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; a passage of St. Augustine, upon which we could not agree,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe Gascon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly, this is a clever fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now you are assembled, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cpermit me to\r\noffer you my apologies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this word _apologies_, a cloud passed over the brow of Athos, a\r\nhaughty smile curled the lip of Porthos, and a negative sign was the\r\nreply of Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not understand me, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, throwing up his\r\nhead, the sharp and bold lines of which were at the moment gilded by a\r\nbright ray of the sun. \xe2\x80\x9cI asked to be excused in case I should not be\r\nable to discharge my debt to all three; for Monsieur Athos has the\r\nright to kill me first, which must much diminish the face-value of your\r\nbill, Monsieur Porthos, and render yours almost null, Monsieur Aramis.\r\nAnd now, gentlemen, I repeat, excuse me, but on that account only,\r\nand\xe2\x80\x94on guard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words, with the most gallant air possible, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan drew his\r\nsword.\r\n\r\nThe blood had mounted to the head of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and at that moment he\r\nwould have drawn his sword against all the Musketeers in the kingdom as\r\nwillingly as he now did against Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.\r\n\r\nIt was a quarter past midday. The sun was in its zenith, and the spot\r\nchosen for the scene of the duel was exposed to its full ardor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very hot,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, drawing his sword in its turn, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet I\r\ncannot take off my doublet; for I just now felt my wound begin to bleed\r\nagain, and I should not like to annoy Monsieur with the sight of blood\r\nwhich he has not drawn from me himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, Monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand whether drawn by\r\nmyself or another, I assure you I shall always view with regret the\r\nblood of so brave a gentleman. I will therefore fight in my doublet,\r\nlike yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, enough of such compliments!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cRemember, we\r\nare waiting for our turns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak for yourself when you are inclined to utter such incongruities,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ninterrupted Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cFor my part, I think what they say is very well\r\nsaid, and quite worthy of two gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you please, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, putting himself on guard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI waited your orders,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, crossing swords.\r\n\r\nBut scarcely had the two rapiers clashed, when a company of the Guards\r\nof his Eminence, commanded by M. de Jussac, turned the corner of the\r\nconvent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guards!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis and Porthos at the same time.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSheathe your swords, gentlemen, sheathe your swords!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut it was too late. The two combatants had been seen in a position\r\nwhich left no doubt of their intentions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalloo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Jussac, advancing toward them and making a sign to his\r\nmen to do so likewise, \xe2\x80\x9challoo, Musketeers? Fighting here, are you? And\r\nthe edicts? What is become of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very generous, gentlemen of the Guards,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, full of\r\nrancor, for Jussac was one of the aggressors of the preceding day. \xe2\x80\x9cIf\r\nwe were to see you fighting, I can assure you that we would make no\r\neffort to prevent you. Leave us alone, then, and you will enjoy a\r\nlittle amusement without cost to yourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jussac, \xe2\x80\x9cit is with great regret that I pronounce the\r\nthing impossible. Duty before everything. Sheathe, then, if you please,\r\nand follow us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, parodying Jussac, \xe2\x80\x9cit would afford us great\r\npleasure to obey your polite invitation if it depended upon ourselves;\r\nbut unfortunately the thing is impossible\xe2\x80\x94Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville has\r\nforbidden it. Pass on your way, then; it is the best thing to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis raillery exasperated Jussac. \xe2\x80\x9cWe will charge upon you, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nhe, \xe2\x80\x9cif you disobey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are five of them,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, half aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cand we are but\r\nthree; we shall be beaten again, and must die on the spot, for, on my\r\npart, I declare I will never appear again before the captain as a\r\nconquered man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos, Porthos, and Aramis instantly drew near one another, while\r\nJussac drew up his soldiers.\r\n\r\nThis short interval was sufficient to determine D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan on the part\r\nhe was to take. It was one of those events which decide the life of a\r\nman; it was a choice between the king and the cardinal\xe2\x80\x94the choice made,\r\nit must be persisted in. To fight, that was to disobey the law, that\r\nwas to risk his head, that was to make at one blow an enemy of a\r\nminister more powerful than the king himself. All this the young man\r\nperceived, and yet, to his praise we speak it, he did not hesitate a\r\nsecond. Turning towards Athos and his friends, \xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9callow me to correct your words, if you please. You said you were but\r\nthree, but it appears to me we are four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are not one of us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI have not the uniform, but I have\r\nthe spirit. My heart is that of a Musketeer; I feel it, monsieur, and\r\nthat impels me on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithdraw, young man,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Jussac, who doubtless, by his gestures and\r\nthe expression of his countenance, had guessed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s design.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may retire; we consent to that. Save your skin; begone quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not budge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly, you are a brave fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, pressing the young\r\nman\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, choose your part,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Jussac.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos to Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must do something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur is full of generosity,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\nBut all three reflected upon the youth of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and dreaded his\r\ninexperience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe should only be three, one of whom is wounded, with the addition of\r\na boy,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cand yet it will not be the less said we were\r\nfour men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but to yield!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat _is_ difficult,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan comprehended their irresolution.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTry me, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand I swear to you by my honor that I\r\nwill not go hence if we are conquered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your name, my brave fellow?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Athos, Porthos, Aramis, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, forward!\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, gentlemen, have you decided?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Jussac for the third time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is done, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is your choice?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Jussac.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are about to have the honor of charging you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis,\r\nlifting his hat with one hand and drawing his sword with the other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! You resist, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Jussac.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x99blood; does that astonish you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the nine combatants rushed upon each other with a fury which\r\nhowever did not exclude a certain degree of method.\r\n\r\nAthos fixed upon a certain Cahusac, a favorite of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nPorthos had Bicarat, and Aramis found himself opposed to two\r\nadversaries. As to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he sprang toward Jussac himself.\r\n\r\nThe heart of the young Gascon beat as if it would burst through his\r\nside\xe2\x80\x94not from fear, God be thanked, he had not the shade of it, but\r\nwith emulation; he fought like a furious tiger, turning ten times round\r\nhis adversary, and changing his ground and his guard twenty times.\r\nJussac was, as was then said, a fine blade, and had had much practice;\r\nnevertheless it required all his skill to defend himself against an\r\nadversary who, active and energetic, departed every instant from\r\nreceived rules, attacking him on all sides at once, and yet parrying\r\nlike a man who had the greatest respect for his own epidermis.\r\n\r\nThis contest at length exhausted Jussac\xe2\x80\x99s patience. Furious at being\r\nheld in check by one whom he had considered a boy, he became warm and\r\nbegan to make mistakes. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who though wanting in practice had\r\na sound theory, redoubled his agility. Jussac, anxious to put an end to\r\nthis, springing forward, aimed a terrible thrust at his adversary, but\r\nthe latter parried it; and while Jussac was recovering himself, glided\r\nlike a serpent beneath his blade, and passed his sword through his\r\nbody. Jussac fell like a dead mass.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan then cast an anxious and rapid glance over the field of\r\nbattle.\r\n\r\nAramis had killed one of his adversaries, but the other pressed him\r\nwarmly. Nevertheless, Aramis was in a good situation, and able to\r\ndefend himself.\r\n\r\nBicarat and Porthos had just made counterhits. Porthos had received a\r\nthrust through his arm, and Bicarat one through his thigh. But neither\r\nof these two wounds was serious, and they only fought more earnestly.\r\n\r\nAthos, wounded anew by Cahusac, became evidently paler, but did not\r\ngive way a foot. He only changed his sword hand, and fought with his\r\nleft hand.\r\n\r\nAccording to the laws of dueling at that period, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was at\r\nliberty to assist whom he pleased. While he was endeavoring to find out\r\nwhich of his companions stood in greatest need, he caught a glance from\r\nAthos. The glance was of sublime eloquence. Athos would have died\r\nrather than appeal for help; but he could look, and with that look ask\r\nassistance. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan interpreted it; with a terrible bound he sprang\r\nto the side of Cahusac, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cTo me, Monsieur Guardsman; I will slay\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCahusac turned. It was time; for Athos, whose great courage alone\r\nsupported him, sank upon his knee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS\xe2\x80\x99blood!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not kill him, young man, I beg\r\nof you. I have an old affair to settle with him when I am cured and\r\nsound again. Disarm him only\xe2\x80\x94make sure of his sword. That\xe2\x80\x99s it! Very\r\nwell done!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe exclamation was drawn from Athos by seeing the sword of Cahusac fly\r\ntwenty paces from him. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Cahusac sprang forward at the\r\nsame instant, the one to recover, the other to obtain, the sword; but\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, being the more active, reached it first and placed his foot\r\nupon it.\r\n\r\nCahusac immediately ran to the Guardsman whom Aramis had killed, seized\r\nhis rapier, and returned toward D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; but on his way he met\r\nAthos, who during his relief which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had procured him had\r\nrecovered his breath, and who, for fear that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan would kill his\r\nenemy, wished to resume the fight.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan perceived that it would be disobliging Athos not to leave\r\nhim alone; and in a few minutes Cahusac fell, with a sword thrust\r\nthrough his throat.\r\n\r\nAt the same instant Aramis placed his sword point on the breast of his\r\nfallen enemy, and forced him to ask for mercy.\r\n\r\nThere only then remained Porthos and Bicarat. Porthos made a thousand\r\nflourishes, asking Bicarat what o\xe2\x80\x99clock it could be, and offering him\r\nhis compliments upon his brother\xe2\x80\x99s having just obtained a company in\r\nthe regiment of Navarre; but, jest as he might, he gained nothing.\r\nBicarat was one of those iron men who never fell dead.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, it was necessary to finish. The watch might come up and\r\ntake all the combatants, wounded or not, royalists or cardinalists.\r\nAthos, Aramis, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan surrounded Bicarat, and required him to\r\nsurrender. Though alone against all and with a wound in his thigh,\r\nBicarat wished to hold out; but Jussac, who had risen upon his elbow,\r\ncried out to him to yield. Bicarat was a Gascon, as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was; he\r\nturned a deaf ear, and contented himself with laughing, and between two\r\nparries finding time to point to a spot of earth with his sword,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, parodying a verse of the Bible, \xe2\x80\x9chere will Bicarat\r\ndie; for I only am left, and they seek my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut there are four against you; leave off, I command you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if you command me, that\xe2\x80\x99s another thing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bicarat. \xe2\x80\x9cAs you\r\nare my commander, it is my duty to obey.\xe2\x80\x9d And springing backward, he\r\nbroke his sword across his knee to avoid the necessity of surrendering\r\nit, threw the pieces over the convent wall, and crossed his arms,\r\nwhistling a cardinalist air.\r\n\r\nBravery is always respected, even in an enemy. The Musketeers saluted\r\nBicarat with their swords, and returned them to their sheaths.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did the same. Then, assisted by Bicarat, the only one left\r\nstanding, they bore Jussac, Cahusac, and one of Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s adversaries\r\nwho was only wounded, under the porch of the convent. The fourth, as we\r\nhave said, was dead. They then rang the bell, and carrying away four\r\nswords out of five, they took their road, intoxicated with joy, toward\r\nthe h\xc3\xb4tel of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\nThey walked arm in arm, occupying the whole width of the street and\r\ntaking in every Musketeer they met, so that in the end it became a\r\ntriumphal march. The heart of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan swam in delirium; he marched\r\nbetween Athos and Porthos, pressing them tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I am not yet a Musketeer,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to his new friends, as he passed\r\nthrough the gateway of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s h\xc3\xb4tel, \xe2\x80\x9cat least I have entered\r\nupon my apprenticeship, haven\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VI.\r\nHIS MAJESTY KING LOUIS XIII.\r\n\r\n\r\nThis affair made a great noise. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville scolded his Musketeers\r\nin public, and congratulated them in private; but as no time was to be\r\nlost in gaining the king, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville hastened to report himself at\r\nthe Louvre. It was already too late. The king was closeted with the\r\ncardinal, and M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was informed that the king was busy and\r\ncould not receive him at that moment. In the evening M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\r\nattended the king\xe2\x80\x99s gaming table. The king was winning; and as he was\r\nvery avaricious, he was in an excellent humor. Perceiving M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville at a distance\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome here, Monsieur Captain,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ccome here, that I may growl at\r\nyou. Do you know that his Eminence has been making fresh complaints\r\nagainst your Musketeers, and that with so much emotion, that this\r\nevening his Eminence is indisposed? Ah, these Musketeers of yours are\r\nvery devils\xe2\x80\x94fellows to be hanged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who saw at the first glance how things\r\nwould go, \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary, they are good creatures, as meek as lambs,\r\nand have but one desire, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be their warranty. And that is that their\r\nswords may never leave their scabbards but in your majesty\xe2\x80\x99s service.\r\nBut what are they to do? The Guards of Monsieur the Cardinal are\r\nforever seeking quarrels with them, and for the honor of the corps\r\neven, the poor young men are obliged to defend themselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9clisten to him! Would\r\nnot one say he was speaking of a religious community? In truth, my dear\r\nCaptain, I have a great mind to take away your commission and give it\r\nto Mademoiselle de Chemerault, to whom I promised an abbey. But don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nfancy that I am going to take you on your bare word. I am called Louis\r\nthe Just, Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, and by and by, by and by we will see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, sire; it is because I confide in that justice that I shall wait\r\npatiently and quietly the good pleasure of your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, then, monsieur, wait,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9cI will not detain you\r\nlong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, fortune changed; and as the king began to lose what he had\r\nwon, he was not sorry to find an excuse for playing Charlemagne\xe2\x80\x94if we\r\nmay use a gaming phrase of whose origin we confess our ignorance. The\r\nking therefore arose a minute after, and putting the money which lay\r\nbefore him into his pocket, the major part of which arose from his\r\nwinnings, \xe2\x80\x9cLa Vieuville,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ctake my place; I must speak to\r\nMonsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville on an affair of importance. Ah, I had eighty louis\r\nbefore me; put down the same sum, so that they who have lost may have\r\nnothing to complain of. Justice before everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen turning toward M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville and walking with him toward the\r\nembrasure of a window, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou say it is\r\nhis Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s Guards who have sought a quarrel with your Musketeers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire, as they always do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how did the thing happen? Let us see, for you know, my dear\r\nCaptain, a judge must hear both sides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord! In the most simple and natural manner possible. Three of my\r\nbest soldiers, whom your Majesty knows by name, and whose devotedness\r\nyou have more than once appreciated, and who have, I dare affirm to the\r\nking, his service much at heart\xe2\x80\x94three of my best soldiers, I say,\r\nAthos, Porthos, and Aramis, had made a party of pleasure with a young\r\nfellow from Gascony, whom I had introduced to them the same morning.\r\nThe party was to take place at St. Germain, I believe, and they had\r\nappointed to meet at the Carmes-Deschaux, when they were disturbed by\r\nde Jussac, Cahusac, Bicarat, and two other Guardsmen, who certainly did\r\nnot go there in such a numerous company without some ill intention\r\nagainst the edicts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah! You incline me to think so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is no doubt\r\nthey went thither to fight themselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not accuse them, sire; but I leave your Majesty to judge what\r\nfive armed men could possibly be going to do in such a deserted place\r\nas the neighborhood of the Convent des Carmes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you are right, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, you are right!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, upon seeing my Musketeers they changed their minds, and forgot\r\ntheir private hatred for partisan hatred; for your Majesty cannot be\r\nignorant that the Musketeers, who belong to the king and nobody but the\r\nking, are the natural enemies of the Guardsmen, who belong to the\r\ncardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, in a melancholy tone; \xe2\x80\x9cand it is\r\nvery sad, believe me, to see thus two parties in France, two heads to\r\nroyalty. But all this will come to an end, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, will come to an\r\nend. You say, then, that the Guardsmen sought a quarrel with the\r\nMusketeers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say that it is probable that things have fallen out so, but I will\r\nnot swear to it, sire. You know how difficult it is to discover the\r\ntruth; and unless a man be endowed with that admirable instinct which\r\ncauses Louis XIII. to be named the Just\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, Tr\xc3\xa9ville; but they were not alone, your Musketeers.\r\nThey had a youth with them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire, and one wounded man; so that three of the king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMusketeers\xe2\x80\x94one of whom was wounded\xe2\x80\x94and a youth not only maintained\r\ntheir ground against five of the most terrible of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGuardsmen, but absolutely brought four of them to earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this is a victory!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king, all radiant, \xe2\x80\x9ca complete\r\nvictory!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire; as complete as that of the Bridge of Ce.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour men, one of them wounded, and a youth, say you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne hardly a young man; but who, however, behaved himself so admirably\r\non this occasion that I will take the liberty of recommending him to\r\nyour Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow does he call himself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, sire; he is the son of one of my oldest friends\xe2\x80\x94the son of\r\na man who served under the king your father, of glorious memory, in the\r\ncivil war.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you say this young man behaved himself well? Tell me how,\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x94you know how I delight in accounts of war and fighting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Louis XIII. twisted his mustache proudly, placing his hand upon his\r\nhip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cas I told you, Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is little\r\nmore than a boy; and as he has not the honor of being a Musketeer, he\r\nwas dressed as a citizen. The Guards of the cardinal, perceiving his\r\nyouth and that he did not belong to the corps, invited him to retire\r\nbefore they attacked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you may plainly see, Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the king, \xe2\x80\x9cit was they\r\nwho attacked?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, sire; there can be no more doubt on that head. They\r\ncalled upon him then to retire; but he answered that he was a Musketeer\r\nat heart, entirely devoted to your Majesty, and that therefore he would\r\nremain with Messieurs the Musketeers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrave young man!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, he did remain with them; and your Majesty has in him so firm a\r\nchampion that it was he who gave Jussac the terrible sword thrust which\r\nhas made the cardinal so angry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe who wounded Jussac!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king, \xe2\x80\x9che, a boy! Tr\xc3\xa9ville, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nimpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is as I have the honor to relate it to your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJussac, one of the first swordsmen in the kingdom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sire, for once he found his master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will see this young man, Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x94I will see him; and if anything\r\ncan be done\xe2\x80\x94well, we will make it our business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will your Majesty deign to receive him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, at midday, Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I bring him alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, bring me all four together. I wish to thank them all at once.\r\nDevoted men are so rare, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, by the back staircase. It is useless\r\nto let the cardinal know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou understand, Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x94an edict is still an edict, it is forbidden\r\nto fight, after all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this encounter, sire, is quite out of the ordinary conditions of a\r\nduel. It is a brawl; and the proof is that there were five of the\r\ncardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guardsmen against my three Musketeers and Monsieur\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9cbut never mind, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, come still by\r\nthe back staircase.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville smiled; but as it was indeed something to have prevailed upon\r\nthis child to rebel against his master, he saluted the king\r\nrespectfully, and with this agreement, took leave of him.\r\n\r\nThat evening the three Musketeers were informed of the honor accorded\r\nthem. As they had long been acquainted with the king, they were not\r\nmuch excited; but D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with his Gascon imagination, saw in it\r\nhis future fortune, and passed the night in golden dreams. By eight\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning he was at the apartment of Athos.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan found the Musketeer dressed and ready to go out. As the hour\r\nto wait upon the king was not till twelve, he had made a party with\r\nPorthos and Aramis to play a game at tennis in a tennis court situated\r\nnear the stables of the Luxembourg. Athos invited D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to follow\r\nthem; and although ignorant of the game, which he had never played, he\r\naccepted, not knowing what to do with his time from nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\nmorning, as it then scarcely was, till twelve.\r\n\r\nThe two Musketeers were already there, and were playing together.\r\nAthos, who was very expert in all bodily exercises, passed with\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to the opposite side and challenged them; but at the first\r\neffort he made, although he played with his left hand, he found that\r\nhis wound was yet too recent to allow of such exertion. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nremained, therefore, alone; and as he declared he was too ignorant of\r\nthe game to play it regularly they only continued giving balls to one\r\nanother without counting. But one of these balls, launched by Porthos\xe2\x80\x99\r\nherculean hand, passed so close to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s face that he thought\r\nthat if, instead of passing near, it had hit him, his audience would\r\nhave been probably lost, as it would have been impossible for him to\r\npresent himself before the king. Now, as upon this audience, in his\r\nGascon imagination, depended his future life, he saluted Aramis and\r\nPorthos politely, declaring that he would not resume the game until he\r\nshould be prepared to play with them on more equal terms, and went and\r\ntook his place near the cord and in the gallery.\r\n\r\nUnfortunately for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, among the spectators was one of his\r\nEminence\xe2\x80\x99s Guardsmen, who, still irritated by the defeat of his\r\ncompanions, which had happened only the day before, had promised\r\nhimself to seize the first opportunity of avenging it. He believed this\r\nopportunity was now come and addressed his neighbor: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not\r\nastonishing that that young man should be afraid of a ball, for he is\r\ndoubtless a Musketeer apprentice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan turned round as if a serpent had stung him, and fixed his\r\neyes intensely upon the Guardsman who had just made this insolent\r\nspeech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu_,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the latter, twisting his mustache, \xe2\x80\x9clook at me as\r\nlong as you like, my little gentleman! I have said what I have said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as since that which you have said is too clear to require any\r\nexplanation,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg you to follow\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Guardsman, with the same jeering air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt once, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you know who I am, without doubt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? I am completely ignorant; nor does it much disquiet me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re in the wrong there; for if you knew my name, perhaps you would\r\nnot be so pressing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBernajoux, at your service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, Monsieur Bernajoux,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, tranquilly, \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nwait for you at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, monsieur, I will follow you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not hurry yourself, monsieur, lest it be observed that we go out\r\ntogether. You must be aware that for our undertaking, company would be\r\nin the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Guardsman, astonished that his name had not\r\nproduced more effect upon the young man.\r\n\r\nIndeed, the name of Bernajoux was known to all the world, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nalone excepted, perhaps; for it was one of those which figured most\r\nfrequently in the daily brawls which all the edicts of the cardinal\r\ncould not repress.\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis were so engaged with their game, and Athos was\r\nwatching them with so much attention, that they did not even perceive\r\ntheir young companion go out, who, as he had told the Guardsman of his\r\nEminence, stopped outside the door. An instant after, the Guardsman\r\ndescended in his turn. As D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had no time to lose, on account of\r\nthe audience of the king, which was fixed for midday, he cast his eyes\r\naround, and seeing that the street was empty, said to his adversary,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith! It is fortunate for you, although your name is Bernajoux, to\r\nhave only to deal with an apprentice Musketeer. Never mind; be content,\r\nI will do my best. On guard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said he whom D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thus provoked, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears to me that\r\nthis place is badly chosen, and that we should be better behind the\r\nAbbey St. Germain or in the Pr\xc3\xa9-aux-Clercs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you say is full of sense,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut unfortunately\r\nI have very little time to spare, having an appointment at twelve\r\nprecisely. On guard, then, monsieur, on guard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBernajoux was not a man to have such a compliment paid to him twice. In\r\nan instant his sword glittered in his hand, and he sprang upon his\r\nadversary, whom, thanks to his great youthfulness, he hoped to\r\nintimidate.\r\n\r\nBut D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had on the preceding day served his apprenticeship.\r\nFresh sharpened by his victory, full of hopes of future favor, he was\r\nresolved not to recoil a step.
