So the two swords were crossed close to\r\nthe hilts, and as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stood firm, it was his adversary who made\r\nthe retreating step; but D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan seized the moment at which, in this\r\nmovement, the sword of Bernajoux deviated from the line. He freed his\r\nweapon, made a lunge, and touched his adversary on the shoulder.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan immediately made a step backward and raised his sword; but\r\nBernajoux cried out that it was nothing, and rushing blindly upon him,\r\nabsolutely spitted himself upon D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s sword. As, however, he did\r\nnot fall, as he did not declare himself conquered, but only broke away\r\ntoward the h\xc3\xb4tel of M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, in whose service he had a\r\nrelative, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was ignorant of the seriousness of the last wound\r\nhis adversary had received, and pressing him warmly, without doubt\r\nwould soon have completed his work with a third blow, when the noise\r\nwhich arose from the street being heard in the tennis court, two of the\r\nfriends of the Guardsman, who had seen him go out after exchanging some\r\nwords with D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, rushed, sword in hand, from the court, and fell\r\nupon the conqueror. But Athos, Porthos, and Aramis quickly appeared in\r\ntheir turn, and the moment the two Guardsmen attacked their young\r\ncompanion, drove them back. Bernajoux now fell, and as the Guardsmen\r\nwere only two against four, they began to cry, \xe2\x80\x9cTo the rescue! The\r\nH\xc3\xb4tel de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille!\xe2\x80\x9d At these cries, all who were in the h\xc3\xb4tel\r\nrushed out and fell upon the four companions, who on their side cried\r\naloud, \xe2\x80\x9cTo the rescue, Musketeers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis cry was generally heeded; for the Musketeers were known to be\r\nenemies of the cardinal, and were beloved on account of the hatred they\r\nbore to his Eminence. Thus the soldiers of other companies than those\r\nwhich belonged to the Red Duke, as Aramis had called him, often took\r\npart with the king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers in these quarrels. Of three Guardsmen\r\nof the company of M. Dessessart who were passing, two came to the\r\nassistance of the four companions, while the other ran toward the h\xc3\xb4tel\r\nof M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cTo the rescue, Musketeers! To the rescue!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAs usual, this h\xc3\xb4tel was full of soldiers of this company, who hastened\r\nto the succor of their comrades. The _m\xc3\xaal\xc3\xa9e_ became general, but\r\nstrength was on the side of the Musketeers. The cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guards and\r\nM. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille\xe2\x80\x99s people retreated into the h\xc3\xb4tel, the doors of\r\nwhich they closed just in time to prevent their enemies from entering\r\nwith them. As to the wounded man, he had been taken in at once, and, as\r\nwe have said, in a very bad state.\r\n\r\nExcitement was at its height among the Musketeers and their allies, and\r\nthey even began to deliberate whether they should not set fire to the\r\nh\xc3\xb4tel to punish the insolence of M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille\xe2\x80\x99s domestics in\r\ndaring to make a _sortie_ upon the king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers. The proposition\r\nhad been made, and received with enthusiasm, when fortunately eleven\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock struck. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and his companions remembered their\r\naudience, and as they would very much have regretted that such an\r\nopportunity should be lost, they succeeded in calming their friends,\r\nwho contented themselves with hurling some paving stones against the\r\ngates; but the gates were too strong. They soon tired of the sport.\r\nBesides, those who must be considered the leaders of the enterprise had\r\nquit the group and were making their way toward the h\xc3\xb4tel of M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, who was waiting for them, already informed of this fresh\r\ndisturbance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuick to the Louvre,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cto the Louvre without losing an\r\ninstant, and let us endeavor to see the king before he is prejudiced by\r\nthe cardinal. We will describe the thing to him as a consequence of the\r\naffair of yesterday, and the two will pass off together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, accompanied by the four young fellows, directed his\r\ncourse toward the Louvre; but to the great astonishment of the captain\r\nof the Musketeers, he was informed that the king had gone stag hunting\r\nin the forest of St. Germain. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville required this intelligence\r\nto be repeated to him twice, and each time his companions saw his brow\r\nbecome darker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad his Majesty,\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, \xe2\x80\x9cany intention of holding this hunting\r\nparty yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, your Excellency,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the valet de chambre, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Master of the\r\nHounds came this morning to inform him that he had marked down a stag.\r\nAt first the king answered that he would not go; but he could not\r\nresist his love of sport, and set out after dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the king has seen the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn all probability he has,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the valet, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I saw the horses\r\nharnessed to his Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s carriage this morning, and when I asked\r\nwhere he was going, they told me, \xe2\x80\x98To St. Germain.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is beforehand with us,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, I will see\r\nthe king this evening; but as to you, I do not advise you to risk doing\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis advice was too reasonable, and moreover came from a man who knew\r\nthe king too well, to allow the four young men to dispute it. M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville recommended everyone to return home and wait for news.\r\n\r\nOn entering his h\xc3\xb4tel, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville thought it best to be first in\r\nmaking the complaint. He sent one of his servants to M. de la\r\nTr\xc3\xa9mouille with a letter in which he begged of him to eject the\r\ncardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guardsmen from his house, and to reprimand his people for\r\ntheir audacity in making _sortie_ against the king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers. But M.\r\nde la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille\xe2\x80\x94already prejudiced by his esquire, whose relative, as\r\nwe already know, Bernajoux was\xe2\x80\x94replied that it was neither for M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville nor the Musketeers to complain, but, on the contrary, for him,\r\nwhose people the Musketeers had assaulted and whose h\xc3\xb4tel they had\r\nendeavored to burn. Now, as the debate between these two nobles might\r\nlast a long time, each becoming, naturally, more firm in his own\r\nopinion, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville thought of an expedient which might terminate\r\nit quietly. This was to go himself to M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille.\r\n\r\nHe repaired, therefore, immediately to his h\xc3\xb4tel, and caused himself to\r\nbe announced.\r\n\r\nThe two nobles saluted each other politely, for if no friendship\r\nexisted between them, there was at least esteem. Both were men of\r\ncourage and honor; and as M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille\xe2\x80\x94a Protestant, and seeing\r\nthe king seldom\xe2\x80\x94was of no party, he did not, in general, carry any bias\r\ninto his social relations. This time, however, his address, although\r\npolite, was cooler than usual.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cwe fancy that we have each cause to\r\ncomplain of the other, and I am come to endeavor to clear up this\r\naffair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no objection,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I warn you\r\nthat I am well informed, and all the fault is with your Musketeers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are too just and reasonable a man, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cnot\r\nto accept the proposal I am about to make to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMake it, monsieur, I listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is Monsieur Bernajoux, your esquire\xe2\x80\x99s relative?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, monsieur, very ill indeed! In addition to the sword thrust in his\r\narm, which is not dangerous, he has received another right through his\r\nlungs, of which the doctor says bad things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut has the wounded man retained his senses?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he talk?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith difficulty, but he can speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur, let us go to him. Let us adjure him, in the name of\r\nthe God before whom he must perhaps appear, to speak the truth. I will\r\ntake him for judge in his own cause, monsieur, and will believe what he\r\nwill say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille reflected for an instant; then as it was difficult\r\nto suggest a more reasonable proposal, he agreed to it.\r\n\r\nBoth descended to the chamber in which the wounded man lay. The latter,\r\non seeing these two noble lords who came to visit him, endeavored to\r\nraise himself up in his bed; but he was too weak, and exhausted by the\r\neffort, he fell back again almost senseless.\r\n\r\nM. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille approached him, and made him inhale some salts,\r\nwhich recalled him to life. Then M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, unwilling that it\r\nshould be thought that he had influenced the wounded man, requested M.\r\nde la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille to interrogate him himself.\r\n\r\nThat happened which M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville had foreseen. Placed between life\r\nand death, as Bernajoux was, he had no idea for a moment of concealing\r\nthe truth; and he described to the two nobles the affair exactly as it\r\nhad passed.\r\n\r\nThis was all that M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville wanted. He wished Bernajoux a speedy\r\nconvalescence, took leave of M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, returned to his\r\nh\xc3\xb4tel, and immediately sent word to the four friends that he awaited\r\ntheir company at dinner.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville entertained good company, wholly anticardinalist,\r\nthough. It may easily be understood, therefore, that the conversation\r\nduring the whole of dinner turned upon the two checks that his\r\nEminence\xe2\x80\x99s Guardsmen had received. Now, as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had been the hero\r\nof these two fights, it was upon him that all the felicitations fell,\r\nwhich Athos, Porthos, and Aramis abandoned to him, not only as good\r\ncomrades, but as men who had so often had their turn that they could\r\nvery well afford him his.\r\n\r\nToward six o\xe2\x80\x99clock M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville announced that it was time to go to\r\nthe Louvre; but as the hour of audience granted by his Majesty was\r\npast, instead of claiming the _entr\xc3\xa9e_ by the back stairs, he placed\r\nhimself with the four young men in the antechamber. The king had not\r\nyet returned from hunting. Our young men had been waiting about half an\r\nhour, amid a crowd of courtiers, when all the doors were thrown open,\r\nand his Majesty was announced.\r\n\r\nAt his announcement D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan felt himself tremble to the very marrow\r\nof his bones. The coming instant would in all probability decide the\r\nrest of his life. His eyes therefore were fixed in a sort of agony upon\r\nthe door through which the king must enter.\r\n\r\nLouis XIII. appeared, walking fast. He was in hunting costume covered\r\nwith dust, wearing large boots, and holding a whip in his hand. At the\r\nfirst glance, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan judged that the mind of the king was stormy.\r\n\r\nThis disposition, visible as it was in his Majesty, did not prevent the\r\ncourtiers from ranging themselves along his pathway. In royal\r\nantechambers it is worth more to be viewed with an angry eye than not\r\nto be seen at all. The three Musketeers therefore did not hesitate to\r\nmake a step forward. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan on the contrary remained concealed\r\nbehind them; but although the king knew Athos, Porthos, and Aramis\r\npersonally, he passed before them without speaking or looking\xe2\x80\x94indeed,\r\nas if he had never seen them before. As for M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, when the\r\neyes of the king fell upon him, he sustained the look with so much\r\nfirmness that it was the king who dropped his eyes; after which his\r\nMajesty, grumbling, entered his apartment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMatters go but badly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cand we shall not be made\r\nChevaliers of the Order this time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait here ten minutes,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; \xe2\x80\x9cand if at the expiration\r\nof ten minutes you do not see me come out, return to my h\xc3\xb4tel, for it\r\nwill be useless for you to wait for me longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four young men waited ten minutes, a quarter of an hour, twenty\r\nminutes; and seeing that M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville did not return, went away very\r\nuneasy as to what was going to happen.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville entered the king\xe2\x80\x99s cabinet boldly, and found his Majesty\r\nin a very ill humor, seated on an armchair, beating his boot with the\r\nhandle of his whip. This, however, did not prevent his asking, with the\r\ngreatest coolness, after his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s health.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBad, monsieur, bad!\xe2\x80\x9d replied the king; \xe2\x80\x9cI am bored.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was, in fact, the worst complaint of Louis XIII., who would\r\nsometimes take one of his courtiers to a window and say, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur\r\nSo-and-so, let us weary ourselves together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow! Your Majesty is bored? Have you not enjoyed the pleasures of the\r\nchase today?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fine pleasure, indeed, monsieur! Upon my soul, everything\r\ndegenerates; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know whether it is the game which leaves no\r\nscent, or the dogs that have no noses. We started a stag of ten\r\nbranches. We chased him for six hours, and when he was near being\r\ntaken\xe2\x80\x94when St. Simon was already putting his horn to his mouth to sound\r\nthe _halali_\xe2\x80\x94crack, all the pack takes the wrong scent and sets off\r\nafter a two-year-older. I shall be obliged to give up hunting, as I\r\nhave given up hawking. Ah, I am an unfortunate king, Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville! I had but one gerfalcon, and he died day before yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, sire, I wholly comprehend your disappointment. The misfortune\r\nis great; but I think you have still a good number of falcons, sparrow\r\nhawks, and tiercels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd not a man to instruct them. Falconers are declining. I know no one\r\nbut myself who is acquainted with the noble art of venery. After me it\r\nwill all be over, and people will hunt with gins, snares, and traps. If\r\nI had but the time to train pupils! But there is the cardinal always at\r\nhand, who does not leave me a moment\xe2\x80\x99s repose; who talks to me about\r\nSpain, who talks to me about Austria, who talks to me about England!\r\nAh! _\xc3\xa0 propos_ of the cardinal, Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, I am vexed with\r\nyou!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was the chance at which M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville waited for the king. He\r\nknew the king of old, and he knew that all these complaints were but a\r\npreface\xe2\x80\x94a sort of excitation to encourage himself\xe2\x80\x94and that he had now\r\ncome to his point at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in what have I been so unfortunate as to displease your Majesty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, feigning the most profound astonishment.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it thus you perform your charge, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the king,\r\nwithout directly replying to de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s question. \xe2\x80\x9cIs it for this I\r\nname you captain of my Musketeers, that they should assassinate a man,\r\ndisturb a whole quarter, and endeavor to set fire to Paris, without\r\nyour saying a word? But yet,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the king, \xe2\x80\x9cundoubtedly my haste\r\naccuses you wrongfully; without doubt the rioters are in prison, and\r\nyou come to tell me justice is done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, calmly, \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary, I come to\r\ndemand it of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd against whom?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgainst calumniators,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! This is something new,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the king. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you tell me that\r\nyour three damned Musketeers, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, and your\r\nyoungster from B\xc3\xa9arn, have not fallen, like so many furies, upon poor\r\nBernajoux, and have not maltreated him in such a fashion that probably\r\nby this time he is dead? Will you tell me that they did not lay siege\r\nto the h\xc3\xb4tel of the Duc de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, and that they did not\r\nendeavor to burn it?\xe2\x80\x94which would not, perhaps, have been a great\r\nmisfortune in time of war, seeing that it is nothing but a nest of\r\nHuguenots, but which is, in time of peace, a frightful example. Tell\r\nme, now, can you deny all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who told you this fine story, sire?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Tr\xc3\xa9ville, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho has told me this fine story, monsieur? Who should it be but he who\r\nwatches while I sleep, who labors while I amuse myself, who conducts\r\neverything at home and abroad\xe2\x80\x94in France as in Europe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Majesty probably refers to God,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I know\r\nno one except God who can be so far above your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur; I speak of the prop of the state, of my only servant, of\r\nmy only friend\xe2\x80\x94of the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis Eminence is not his holiness, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by that, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat it is only the Pope who is infallible, and that this\r\ninfallibility does not extend to cardinals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean to say that he deceives me; you mean to say that he betrays\r\nme? You accuse him, then? Come, speak; avow freely that you accuse\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire, but I say that he deceives himself. I say that he is\r\nill-informed. I say that he has hastily accused your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMusketeers, toward whom he is unjust, and that he has not obtained his\r\ninformation from good sources.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe accusation comes from Monsieur de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, from the duke\r\nhimself. What do you say to that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might answer, sire, that he is too deeply interested in the question\r\nto be a very impartial witness; but so far from that, sire, I know the\r\nduke to be a royal gentleman, and I refer the matter to him\xe2\x80\x94but upon\r\none condition, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is that your Majesty will make him come here, will interrogate him\r\nyourself, _t\xc3\xaate-\xc3\xa0-t\xc3\xaate_, without witnesses, and that I shall see your\r\nMajesty as soon as you have seen the duke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, then! You will bind yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king, \xe2\x80\x9cby what Monsieur\r\nde la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille shall say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will accept his judgment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will submit to the reparation he may require?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa Chesnaye,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king. \xe2\x80\x9cLa Chesnaye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLouis XIII.\xe2\x80\x99s confidential valet, who never left the door, entered in\r\nreply to the call.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLa Chesnaye,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9clet someone go instantly and find\r\nMonsieur de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille; I wish to speak with him this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Majesty gives me your word that you will not see anyone between\r\nMonsieur de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille and myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNobody, by the faith of a gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, then, sire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what o\xe2\x80\x99clock, please your Majesty?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any hour you will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in coming too early I should be afraid of awakening your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAwaken me! Do you think I ever sleep, then? I sleep no longer,\r\nmonsieur. I sometimes dream, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Come, then, as early as you\r\nlike\xe2\x80\x94at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock; but beware, if you and your Musketeers are\r\nguilty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf my Musketeers are guilty, sire, the guilty shall be placed in your\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s hands, who will dispose of them at your good pleasure. Does\r\nyour Majesty require anything further? Speak, I am ready to obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, no; I am not called Louis the Just without reason.\r\nTomorrow, then, monsieur\xe2\x80\x94tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill then, God preserve your Majesty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHowever ill the king might sleep, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville slept still worse. He\r\nhad ordered his three Musketeers and their companion to be with him at\r\nhalf past six in the morning. He took them with him, without\r\nencouraging them or promising them anything, and without concealing\r\nfrom them that their luck, and even his own, depended upon the cast of\r\nthe dice.\r\n\r\nArrived at the foot of the back stairs, he desired them to wait. If the\r\nking was still irritated against them, they would depart without being\r\nseen; if the king consented to see them, they would only have to be\r\ncalled.\r\n\r\nOn arriving at the king\xe2\x80\x99s private antechamber, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville found La\r\nChesnaye, who informed him that they had not been able to find M. de la\r\nTr\xc3\xa9mouille on the preceding evening at his h\xc3\xb4tel, that he returned too\r\nlate to present himself at the Louvre, that he had only that moment\r\narrived and that he was at that very hour with the king.\r\n\r\nThis circumstance pleased M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville much, as he thus became\r\ncertain that no foreign suggestion could insinuate itself between M. de\r\nla Tr\xc3\xa9mouille\xe2\x80\x99s testimony and himself.\r\n\r\nIn fact, ten minutes had scarcely passed away when the door of the\r\nking\xe2\x80\x99s closet opened, and M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville saw M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille come\r\nout. The duke came straight up to him, and said: \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\r\nhis Majesty has just sent for me in order to inquire respecting the\r\ncircumstances which took place yesterday at my h\xc3\xb4tel. I have told him\r\nthe truth; that is to say, that the fault lay with my people, and that\r\nI was ready to offer you my excuses. Since I have the good fortune to\r\nmeet you, I beg you to receive them, and to hold me always as one of\r\nyour friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur the Duke,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cI was so confident of your\r\nloyalty that I required no other defender before his Majesty than\r\nyourself. I find that I have not been mistaken, and I thank you that\r\nthere is still one man in France of whom may be said, without\r\ndisappointment, what I have said of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well said,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king, who had heard all these compliments\r\nthrough the open door; \xe2\x80\x9conly tell him, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, since he wishes to be\r\nconsidered your friend, that I also wish to be one of his, but he\r\nneglects me; that it is nearly three years since I have seen him, and\r\nthat I never do see him unless I send for him. Tell him all this for\r\nme, for these are things which a king cannot say for himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, sire, thanks,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke; \xe2\x80\x9cbut your Majesty may be assured\r\nthat it is not those\xe2\x80\x94I do not speak of Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x94whom your\r\nMajesty sees at all hours of the day that are most devoted to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! You have heard what I said? So much the better, Duke, so much the\r\nbetter,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, advancing toward the door. \xe2\x80\x9cAh! It is you,\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville. Where are your Musketeers? I told you the day before\r\nyesterday to bring them with you; why have you not done so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are below, sire, and with your permission La Chesnaye will bid\r\nthem come up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, let them come up immediately. It is nearly eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\r\nand at nine I expect a visit. Go, Monsieur Duke, and return often. Come\r\nin, Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Duke saluted and retired. At the moment he opened the door, the\r\nthree Musketeers and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, conducted by La Chesnaye, appeared at\r\nthe top of the staircase.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, my braves,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9ccome in; I am going to scold\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Musketeers advanced, bowing, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan following closely behind\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d continued the king. \xe2\x80\x9cSeven of his Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s Guards\r\nplaced _hors de combat_ by you four in two days! That\xe2\x80\x99s too many,\r\ngentlemen, too many! If you go on so, his Eminence will be forced to\r\nrenew his company in three weeks, and I to put the edicts in force in\r\nall their rigor. One now and then I don\xe2\x80\x99t say much about; but seven in\r\ntwo days, I repeat, it is too many, it is far too many!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore, sire, your Majesty sees that they are come, quite contrite\r\nand repentant, to offer you their excuses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite contrite and repentant! Hem!\xe2\x80\x9d said the king. \xe2\x80\x9cI place no\r\nconfidence in their hypocritical faces. In particular, there is one\r\nyonder of a Gascon look. Come hither, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who understood that it was to him this compliment was\r\naddressed, approached, assuming a most deprecating air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you told me he was a young man? This is a boy, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, a mere\r\nboy! Do you mean to say that it was he who bestowed that severe thrust\r\nat Jussac?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd those two equally fine thrusts at Bernajoux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout reckoning,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if he had not rescued me from\r\nthe hands of Cahusac, I should not now have the honor of making my very\r\nhumble reverence to your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy he is a very devil, this B\xc3\xa9arnais! _Ventre-saint-gris_, Monsieur\r\nde Tr\xc3\xa9ville, as the king my father would have said. But at this sort of\r\nwork, many doublets must be slashed and many swords broken. Now,\r\nGascons are always poor, are they not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I can assert that they have hitherto discovered no gold mines in\r\ntheir mountains; though the Lord owes them this miracle in recompense\r\nfor the manner in which they supported the pretensions of the king your\r\nfather.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich is to say that the Gascons made a king of me, myself, seeing\r\nthat I am my father\xe2\x80\x99s son, is it not, Tr\xc3\xa9ville? Well, happily, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nsay nay to it. La Chesnaye, go and see if by rummaging all my pockets\r\nyou can find forty pistoles; and if you can find them, bring them to\r\nme. And now let us see, young man, with your hand upon your conscience,\r\nhow did all this come to pass?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related the adventure of the preceding day in all its\r\ndetails; how, not having been able to sleep for the joy he felt in the\r\nexpectation of seeing his Majesty, he had gone to his three friends\r\nthree hours before the hour of audience; how they had gone together to\r\nthe tennis court, and how, upon the fear he had manifested lest he\r\nreceive a ball in the face, he had been jeered at by Bernajoux, who had\r\nnearly paid for his jeer with his life, and M. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, who\r\nhad nothing to do with the matter, with the loss of his h\xc3\xb4tel.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is all very well,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the king, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, this is just the\r\naccount the duke gave me of the affair. Poor cardinal! Seven men in two\r\ndays, and those of his very best! But that\xe2\x80\x99s quite enough, gentlemen;\r\nplease to understand, that\xe2\x80\x99s enough. You have taken your revenge for\r\nthe Rue F\xc3\xa9rou, and even exceeded it; you ought to be satisfied.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf your Majesty is so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; I am,\xe2\x80\x9d added the king, taking a handful of gold from La\r\nChesnaye, and putting it into the hand of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cis a proof of my satisfaction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this epoch, the ideas of pride which are in fashion in our days did\r\nnot prevail. A gentleman received, from hand to hand, money from the\r\nking, and was not the least in the world humiliated. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan put his\r\nforty pistoles into his pocket without any scruple\xe2\x80\x94on the contrary,\r\nthanking his Majesty greatly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, looking at a clock, \xe2\x80\x9cthere, now, as it is half\r\npast eight, you may retire; for as I told you, I expect someone at\r\nnine. Thanks for your devotedness, gentlemen. I may continue to rely\r\nupon it, may I not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sire!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the four companions, with one voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwe would allow\r\nourselves to be cut to pieces in your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well, but keep whole; that will be better, and you will be more\r\nuseful to me. Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\xe2\x80\x9d added the king, in a low voice, as the others\r\nwere retiring, \xe2\x80\x9cas you have no room in the Musketeers, and as we have\r\nbesides decided that a novitiate is necessary before entering that\r\ncorps, place this young man in the company of the Guards of Monsieur\r\nDessessart, your brother-in-law. Ah, _pardieu_, Tr\xc3\xa9ville! I enjoy\r\nbeforehand the face the cardinal will make. He will be furious; but I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t care. I am doing what is right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king waved his hand to Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who left him and rejoined the\r\nMusketeers, whom he found sharing the forty pistoles with D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal, as his Majesty had said, was really furious, so furious\r\nthat during eight days he absented himself from the king\xe2\x80\x99s gaming\r\ntable. This did not prevent the king from being as complacent to him as\r\npossible whenever he met him, or from asking in the kindest tone,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Monsieur Cardinal, how fares it with that poor Jussac and that\r\npoor Bernajoux of yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VII.\r\nTHE INTERIOR OF THE MUSKETEERS\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was out of the Louvre, and consulted his friends upon\r\nthe use he had best make of his share of the forty pistoles, Athos\r\nadvised him to order a good repast at the Pomme-de-Pin, Porthos to\r\nengage a lackey, and Aramis to provide himself with a suitable\r\nmistress.\r\n\r\nThe repast was carried into effect that very day, and the lackey waited\r\nat table. The repast had been ordered by Athos, and the lackey\r\nfurnished by Porthos. He was a Picard, whom the glorious Musketeer had\r\npicked up on the Bridge Tournelle, making rings and plashing in the\r\nwater.\r\n\r\nPorthos pretended that this occupation was proof of a reflective and\r\ncontemplative organization, and he had brought him away without any\r\nother recommendation. The noble carriage of this gentleman, for whom he\r\nbelieved himself to be engaged, had won Planchet\xe2\x80\x94that was the name of\r\nthe Picard. He felt a slight disappointment, however, when he saw that\r\nthis place was already taken by a compeer named Mousqueton, and when\r\nPorthos signified to him that the state of his household, though great,\r\nwould not support two servants, and that he must enter into the service\r\nof D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. Nevertheless, when he waited at the dinner given by his\r\nmaster, and saw him take out a handful of gold to pay for it, he\r\nbelieved his fortune made, and returned thanks to heaven for having\r\nthrown him into the service of such a Cr\xc5\x93sus. He preserved this\r\nopinion even after the feast, with the remnants of which he repaired\r\nhis own long abstinence; but when in the evening he made his master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbed, the chimeras of Planchet faded away. The bed was the only one in\r\nthe apartment, which consisted of an antechamber and a bedroom.\r\nPlanchet slept in the antechamber upon a coverlet taken from the bed of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan from that time made shift to do\r\nwithout.\r\n\r\nAthos, on his part, had a valet whom he had trained in his service in a\r\nthoroughly peculiar fashion, and who was named Grimaud. He was very\r\ntaciturn, this worthy signor. Be it understood we are speaking of\r\nAthos. During the five or six years that he had lived in the strictest\r\nintimacy with his companions, Porthos and Aramis, they could remember\r\nhaving often seen him smile, but had never heard him laugh. His words\r\nwere brief and expressive, conveying all that was meant, and no more;\r\nno embellishments, no embroidery, no arabesques. His conversation was a\r\nmatter of fact, without a single romance.\r\n\r\nAlthough Athos was scarcely thirty years old, and was of great personal\r\nbeauty and intelligence of mind, no one knew whether he had ever had a\r\nmistress. He never spoke of women. He certainly did not prevent others\r\nfrom speaking of them before him, although it was easy to perceive that\r\nthis kind of conversation, in which he only mingled by bitter words and\r\nmisanthropic remarks, was very disagreeable to him. His reserve, his\r\nroughness, and his silence made almost an old man of him. He had, then,\r\nin order not to disturb his habits, accustomed Grimaud to obey him upon\r\na simple gesture or upon a simple movement of his lips. He never spoke\r\nto him, except under the most extraordinary occasions.\r\n\r\nSometimes, Grimaud, who feared his master as he did fire, while\r\nentertaining a strong attachment to his person and a great veneration\r\nfor his talents, believed he perfectly understood what he wanted, flew\r\nto execute the order received, and did precisely the contrary. Athos\r\nthen shrugged his shoulders, and, without putting himself in a passion,\r\nthrashed Grimaud. On these days he spoke a little.\r\n\r\nPorthos, as we have seen, had a character exactly opposite to that of\r\nAthos. He not only talked much, but he talked loudly, little caring, we\r\nmust render him that justice, whether anybody listened to him or not.\r\nHe talked for the pleasure of talking and for the pleasure of hearing\r\nhimself talk. He spoke upon all subjects except the sciences, alleging\r\nin this respect the inveterate hatred he had borne to scholars from his\r\nchildhood. He had not so noble an air as Athos, and the commencement of\r\ntheir intimacy often rendered him unjust toward that gentleman, whom he\r\nendeavored to eclipse by his splendid dress. But with his simple\r\nMusketeer\xe2\x80\x99s uniform and nothing but the manner in which he threw back\r\nhis head and advanced his foot, Athos instantly took the place which\r\nwas his due and consigned the ostentatious Porthos to the second rank.\r\nPorthos consoled himself by filling the antechamber of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\r\nand the guardroom of the Louvre with the accounts of his love scrapes,\r\nafter having passed from professional ladies to military ladies, from\r\nthe lawyer\xe2\x80\x99s dame to the baroness, there was question of nothing less\r\nwith Porthos than a foreign princess, who was enormously fond of him.\r\n\r\nAn old proverb says, \xe2\x80\x9cLike master, like man.\xe2\x80\x9d Let us pass, then, from\r\nthe valet of Athos to the valet of Porthos, from Grimaud to Mousqueton.\r\n\r\nMousqueton was a Norman, whose pacific name of Boniface his master had\r\nchanged into the infinitely more sonorous name of Mousqueton. He had\r\nentered the service of Porthos upon condition that he should only be\r\nclothed and lodged, though in a handsome manner; but he claimed two\r\nhours a day to himself, consecrated to an employment which would\r\nprovide for his other wants. Porthos agreed to the bargain; the thing\r\nsuited him wonderfully well. He had doublets cut out of his old clothes\r\nand cast-off cloaks for Mousqueton, and thanks to a very intelligent\r\ntailor, who made his clothes look as good as new by turning them, and\r\nwhose wife was suspected of wishing to make Porthos descend from his\r\naristocratic habits, Mousqueton made a very good figure when attending\r\non his master.\r\n\r\nAs for Aramis, of whom we believe we have sufficiently explained the\r\ncharacter\xe2\x80\x94a character which, like that of his companions, we shall be\r\nable to follow in its development\xe2\x80\x94his lackey was called Bazin. Thanks\r\nto the hopes which his master entertained of someday entering into\r\norders, he was always clothed in black, as became the servant of a\r\nchurchman. He was a Berrichon, thirty-five or forty years old, mild,\r\npeaceable, sleek, employing the leisure his master left him in the\r\nperusal of pious works, providing rigorously for two a dinner of few\r\ndishes, but excellent. For the rest, he was dumb, blind, and deaf, and\r\nof unimpeachable fidelity.\r\n\r\nAnd now that we are acquainted, superficially at least, with the\r\nmasters and the valets, let us pass on to the dwellings occupied by\r\neach of them.\r\n\r\nAthos dwelt in the Rue F\xc3\xa9rou, within two steps of the Luxembourg. His\r\napartment consisted of two small chambers, very nicely fitted up, in a\r\nfurnished house, the hostess of which, still young and still really\r\nhandsome, cast tender glances uselessly at him. Some fragments of past\r\nsplendor appeared here and there upon the walls of this modest lodging;\r\na sword, for example, richly embossed, which belonged by its make to\r\nthe times of Francis I, the hilt of which alone, encrusted with\r\nprecious stones, might be worth two hundred pistoles, and which,\r\nnevertheless, in his moments of greatest distress Athos had never\r\npledged or offered for sale. It had long been an object of ambition for\r\nPorthos. Porthos would have given ten years of his life to possess this\r\nsword.\r\n\r\nOne day, when he had an appointment with a duchess, he endeavored even\r\nto borrow it of Athos. Athos, without saying anything, emptied his\r\npockets, got together all his jewels, purses, aiguillettes, and gold\r\nchains, and offered them all to Porthos; but as to the sword, he said\r\nit was sealed to its place and should never quit it until its master\r\nshould himself quit his lodgings. In addition to the sword, there was a\r\nportrait representing a nobleman of the time of Henry III., dressed with\r\nthe greatest elegance, and who wore the Order of the Holy Ghost; and\r\nthis portrait had certain resemblances of lines with Athos, certain\r\nfamily likenesses which indicated that this great noble, a knight of\r\nthe Order of the King, was his ancestor.\r\n\r\nBesides these, a casket of magnificent goldwork, with the same arms as\r\nthe sword and the portrait, formed a middle ornament to the\r\nmantelpiece, and assorted badly with the rest of the furniture. Athos\r\nalways carried the key of this coffer about him; but he one day opened\r\nit before Porthos, and Porthos was convinced that this coffer contained\r\nnothing but letters and papers\xe2\x80\x94love letters and family papers, no\r\ndoubt.\r\n\r\nPorthos lived in an apartment, large in size and of very sumptuous\r\nappearance, in the Rue du Vieux-Colombier. Every time he passed with a\r\nfriend before his windows, at one of which Mousqueton was sure to be\r\nplaced in full livery, Porthos raised his head and his hand, and said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is my abode!\xe2\x80\x9d But he was never to be found at home; he never\r\ninvited anybody to go up with him, and no one could form an idea of\r\nwhat his sumptuous apartment contained in the shape of real riches.\r\n\r\nAs to Aramis, he dwelt in a little lodging composed of a boudoir, an\r\neating room, and a bedroom, which room, situated, as the others were,\r\non the ground floor, looked out upon a little fresh green garden, shady\r\nand impenetrable to the eyes of his neighbors.\r\n\r\nWith regard to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, we know how he was lodged, and we have\r\nalready made acquaintance with his lackey, Master Planchet.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was by nature very curious\xe2\x80\x94as people generally are who\r\npossess the genius of intrigue\xe2\x80\x94did all he could to make out who Athos,\r\nPorthos, and Aramis really were (for under these pseudonyms each of\r\nthese young men concealed his family name)\xe2\x80\x94Athos in particular, who, a\r\nleague away, savored of nobility. He addressed himself then to Porthos\r\nto gain information respecting Athos and Aramis, and to Aramis in order\r\nto learn something of Porthos.\r\n\r\nUnfortunately Porthos knew nothing of the life of his silent companion\r\nbut what revealed itself. It was said Athos had met with great crosses\r\nin love, and that a frightful treachery had forever poisoned the life\r\nof this gallant man. What could this treachery be? All the world was\r\nignorant of it.\r\n\r\nAs to Porthos, except his real name (as was the case with those of his\r\ntwo comrades), his life was very easily known. Vain and indiscreet, it\r\nwas as easy to see through him as through a crystal. The only thing to\r\nmislead the investigator would have been belief in all the good things\r\nhe said of himself.\r\n\r\nWith respect to Aramis, though having the air of having nothing secret\r\nabout him, he was a young fellow made up of mysteries, answering little\r\nto questions put to him about others, and having learned from him the\r\nreport which prevailed concerning the success of the Musketeer with a\r\nprincess, wished to gain a little insight into the amorous adventures\r\nof his interlocutor. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, my dear companion,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou speak\r\nof the baronesses, countesses, and princesses of others?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ I spoke of them because Porthos talked of them himself,\r\nbecause he had paraded all these fine things before me. But be assured,\r\nmy dear Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, that if I had obtained them from any other\r\nsource, or if they had been confided to me, there exists no confessor\r\nmore discreet than myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it seems to me that\r\nyou are tolerably familiar with coats of arms\xe2\x80\x94a certain embroidered\r\nhandkerchief, for instance, to which I owe the honor of your\r\nacquaintance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time Aramis was not angry, but assumed the most modest air and\r\nreplied in a friendly tone, \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend, do not forget that I wish\r\nto belong to the Church, and that I avoid all mundane opportunities.\r\nThe handkerchief you saw had not been given to me, but it had been\r\nforgotten and left at my house by one of my friends. I was obliged to\r\npick it up in order not to compromise him and the lady he loves. As for\r\nmyself, I neither have, nor desire to have, a mistress, following in\r\nthat respect the very judicious example of Athos, who has none any more\r\nthan I have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what the devil! You are not a priest, you are a Musketeer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA Musketeer for a time, my friend, as the cardinal says, a Musketeer\r\nagainst my will, but a churchman at heart, believe me. Athos and\r\nPorthos dragged me into this to occupy me. I had, at the moment of\r\nbeing ordained, a little difficulty with\xe2\x80\x94But that would not interest\r\nyou, and I am taking up your valuable time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all; it interests me very much,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand at this\r\nmoment I have absolutely nothing to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but I have my breviary to repeat,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cthen some\r\nverses to compose, which Madame d\xe2\x80\x99Aiguillon begged of me. Then I must\r\ngo to the Rue St. Honor\xc3\xa9 in order to purchase some rouge for Madame de\r\nChevreuse. So you see, my dear friend, that if you are not in a hurry,\r\nI am very much in a hurry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis held out his hand in a cordial manner to his young companion,\r\nand took leave of him.\r\n\r\nNotwithstanding all the pains he took, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was unable to learn\r\nany more concerning his three new-made friends. He formed, therefore,\r\nthe resolution of believing for the present all that was said of their\r\npast, hoping for more certain and extended revelations in the future.\r\nIn the meanwhile, he looked upon Athos as an Achilles, Porthos as an\r\nAjax, and Aramis as a Joseph.\r\n\r\nAs to the rest, the life of the four young friends was joyous enough.\r\nAthos played, and that as a rule unfortunately. Nevertheless, he never\r\nborrowed a sou of his companions, although his purse was ever at their\r\nservice; and when he had played upon honor, he always awakened his\r\ncreditor by six o\xe2\x80\x99clock the next morning to pay the debt of the\r\npreceding evening.\r\n\r\nPorthos had his fits. On the days when he won he was insolent and\r\nostentatious; if he lost, he disappeared completely for several days,\r\nafter which he reappeared with a pale face and thinner person, but with\r\nmoney in his purse.\r\n\r\nAs to Aramis, he never played. He was the worst Musketeer and the most\r\nunconvivial companion imaginable. He had always something or other to\r\ndo. Sometimes in the midst of dinner, when everyone, under the\r\nattraction of wine and in the warmth of conversation, believed they had\r\ntwo or three hours longer to enjoy themselves at table, Aramis looked\r\nat his watch, arose with a bland smile, and took leave of the company,\r\nto go, as he said, to consult a casuist with whom he had an\r\nappointment. At other times he would return home to write a treatise,\r\nand requested his friends not to disturb him.\r\n\r\nAt this Athos would smile, with his charming, melancholy smile, which\r\nso became his noble countenance, and Porthos would drink, swearing that\r\nAramis would never be anything but a village _cur\xc3\xa9_.\r\n\r\nPlanchet, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s valet, supported his good fortune nobly. He\r\nreceived thirty sous per day, and for a month he returned to his\r\nlodgings gay as a chaffinch, and affable toward his master. When the\r\nwind of adversity began to blow upon the housekeeping of the Rue des\r\nFossoyeurs\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, when the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII.\r\nwere consumed or nearly so\xe2\x80\x94he commenced complaints which Athos thought\r\nnauseous, Porthos indecent, and Aramis ridiculous. Athos counseled\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to dismiss the fellow; Porthos was of the opinion that he\r\nshould give him a good thrashing first; and Aramis contended that a\r\nmaster should never attend to anything but the civilities paid to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is all very easy for you to say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cfor you,\r\nAthos, who live like a dumb man with Grimaud, who forbid him to speak,\r\nand consequently never exchange ill words with him; for you, Porthos,\r\nwho carry matters in such a magnificent style, and are a god to your\r\nvalet, Mousqueton; and for you, Aramis, who, always abstracted by your\r\ntheological studies, inspire your servant, Bazin, a mild, religious\r\nman, with a profound respect; but for me, who am without any settled\r\nmeans and without resources\xe2\x80\x94for me, who am neither a Musketeer nor even\r\na Guardsman, what am I to do to inspire either the affection, the\r\nterror, or the respect in Planchet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is serious,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the three friends; \xe2\x80\x9cit is a family affair.\r\nIt is with valets as with wives, they must be placed at once upon the\r\nfooting in which you wish them to remain. Reflect upon it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did reflect, and resolved to thrash Planchet provisionally;\r\nwhich he did with the conscientiousness that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan carried into\r\neverything. After having well beaten him, he forbade him to leave his\r\nservice without his permission. \xe2\x80\x9cFor,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe future cannot\r\nfail to mend; I inevitably look for better times. Your fortune is\r\ntherefore made if you remain with me, and I am too good a master to\r\nallow you to miss such a chance by granting you the dismissal you\r\nrequire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis manner of acting roused much respect for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s policy among\r\nthe Musketeers. Planchet was equally seized with admiration, and said\r\nno more about going away.\r\n\r\nThe life of the four young men had become fraternal. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who\r\nhad no settled habits of his own, as he came from his province into the\r\nmidst of a world quite new to him, fell easily into the habits of his\r\nfriends.\r\n\r\nThey rose about eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the winter, about six in summer, and\r\nwent to take the countersign and see how things went on at M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, although he was not a Musketeer, performed the\r\nduty of one with remarkable punctuality. He went on guard because he\r\nalways kept company with whoever of his friends was on duty. He was\r\nwell known at the H\xc3\xb4tel of the Musketeers, where everyone considered\r\nhim a good comrade. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who had appreciated him at the\r\nfirst glance and who bore him a real affection, never ceased\r\nrecommending him to the king.\r\n\r\nOn their side, the three Musketeers were much attached to their young\r\ncomrade. The friendship which united these four men, and the need they\r\nfelt of seeing another three or four times a day, whether for dueling,\r\nbusiness, or pleasure, caused them to be continually running after one\r\nanother like shadows; and the Inseparables were constantly to be met\r\nwith seeking one another, from the Luxembourg to the Place St. Sulpice,\r\nor from the Rue du Vieux-Colombier to the Luxembourg.\r\n\r\nIn the meanwhile the promises of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville went on prosperously.\r\nOne fine morning the king commanded M. de Chevalier Dessessart to admit\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan as a cadet in his company of Guards. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with a\r\nsigh, donned his uniform, which he would have exchanged for that of a\r\nMusketeer at the expense of ten years of his existence. But M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville promised this favor after a novitiate of two years\xe2\x80\x94a novitiate\r\nwhich might besides be abridged if an opportunity should present itself\r\nfor D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to render the king any signal service, or to distinguish\r\nhimself by some brilliant action. Upon this promise D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nwithdrew, and the next day he began service.\r\n\r\nThen it became the turn of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis to mount guard\r\nwith D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan when he was on duty. The company of M. le Chevalier\r\nDessessart thus received four instead of one when it admitted\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter VIII.\r\nCONCERNING A COURT INTRIGUE\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, the forty pistoles of King Louis XIII., like all other\r\nthings of this world, after having had a beginning had an end, and\r\nafter this end our four companions began to be somewhat embarrassed. At\r\nfirst, Athos supported the association for a time with his own means.\r\n\r\nPorthos succeeded him; and thanks to one of those disappearances to\r\nwhich he was accustomed, he was able to provide for the wants of all\r\nfor a fortnight. At last it became Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s turn, who performed it with\r\na good grace and who succeeded\xe2\x80\x94as he said, by selling some theological\r\nbooks\xe2\x80\x94in procuring a few pistoles.\r\n\r\nThen, as they had been accustomed to do, they had recourse to M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, who made some advances on their pay; but these advances could\r\nnot go far with three Musketeers who were already much in arrears and a\r\nGuardsman who as yet had no pay at all.\r\n\r\nAt length when they found they were likely to be really in want, they\r\ngot together, as a last effort, eight or ten pistoles, with which\r\nPorthos went to the gaming table. Unfortunately he was in a bad vein;\r\nhe lost all, together with twenty-five pistoles for which he had given\r\nhis word.\r\n\r\nThen the inconvenience became distress. The hungry friends, followed by\r\ntheir lackeys, were seen haunting the quays and Guard rooms, picking up\r\namong their friends abroad all the dinners they could meet with; for\r\naccording to the advice of Aramis, it was prudent to sow repasts right\r\nand left in prosperity, in order to reap a few in time of need.\r\n\r\nAthos was invited four times, and each time took his friends and their\r\nlackeys with him. Porthos had six occasions, and contrived in the same\r\nmanner that his friends should partake of them; Aramis had eight of\r\nthem. He was a man, as must have been already perceived, who made but\r\nlittle noise, and yet was much sought after.\r\n\r\nAs to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who as yet knew nobody in the capital, he only found\r\none chocolate breakfast at the house of a priest of his own province,\r\nand one dinner at the house of a cornet of the Guards. He took his army\r\nto the priest\xe2\x80\x99s, where they devoured as much provision as would have\r\nlasted him for two months, and to the cornet\xe2\x80\x99s, who performed wonders;\r\nbut as Planchet said, \xe2\x80\x9cPeople do not eat at once for all time, even\r\nwhen they eat a good deal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thus felt himself humiliated in having only procured one\r\nmeal and a half for his companions\xe2\x80\x94as the breakfast at the priest\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncould only be counted as half a repast\xe2\x80\x94in return for the feasts which\r\nAthos, Porthos, and Aramis had procured him. He fancied himself a\r\nburden to the society, forgetting in his perfectly juvenile good faith\r\nthat he had fed this society for a month; and he set his mind actively\r\nto work. He reflected that this coalition of four young, brave,\r\nenterprising, and active men ought to have some other object than\r\nswaggering walks, fencing lessons, and practical jokes, more or less\r\nwitty.\r\n\r\nIn fact, four men such as they were\xe2\x80\x94four men devoted to one another,\r\nfrom their purses to their lives; four men always supporting one\r\nanother, never yielding, executing singly or together the resolutions\r\nformed in common; four arms threatening the four cardinal points, or\r\nturning toward a single point\xe2\x80\x94must inevitably, either subterraneously,\r\nin open day, by mining, in the trench, by cunning, or by force, open\r\nthemselves a way toward the object they wished to attain, however well\r\nit might be defended, or however distant it may seem. The only thing\r\nthat astonished D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was that his friends had never thought of\r\nthis.\r\n\r\nHe was thinking by himself, and even seriously racking his brain to\r\nfind a direction for this single force four times multiplied, with\r\nwhich he did not doubt, as with the lever for which Archimedes sought,\r\nthey should succeed in moving the world, when someone tapped gently at\r\nhis door. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan awakened Planchet and ordered him to open it.\r\n\r\nFrom this phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan awakened Planchet,\xe2\x80\x9d the reader must not\r\nsuppose it was night, or that day was hardly come. No, it had just\r\nstruck four. Planchet, two hours before, had asked his master for some\r\ndinner, and he had answered him with the proverb, \xe2\x80\x9cHe who sleeps,\r\ndines.\xe2\x80\x9d And Planchet dined by sleeping.\r\n\r\nA man was introduced of simple mien, who had the appearance of a\r\ntradesman. Planchet, by way of dessert, would have liked to hear the\r\nconversation; but the citizen declared to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that, what he had\r\nto say being important and confidential, he desired to be left alone\r\nwith him.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan dismissed Planchet, and requested his visitor to be seated.\r\nThere was a moment of silence, during which the two men looked at each\r\nother, as if to make a preliminary acquaintance, after which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nbowed, as a sign that he listened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan spoken of as a very brave young man,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the citizen; \xe2\x80\x9cand this reputation which he justly enjoys had\r\ndecided me to confide a secret to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, monsieur, speak,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who instinctively scented\r\nsomething advantageous.\r\n\r\nThe citizen made a fresh pause and continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI have a wife who is\r\nseamstress to the queen, monsieur, and who is not deficient in either\r\nvirtue or beauty. I was induced to marry her about three years ago,\r\nalthough she had but very little dowry, because Monsieur Laporte, the\r\nqueen\xe2\x80\x99s cloak bearer, is her godfather, and befriends her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the citizen, \xe2\x80\x9cwell, monsieur, my wife was abducted\r\nyesterday morning, as she was coming out of her workroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by whom was your wife abducted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing surely, monsieur, but I suspect someone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who is the person whom you suspect?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man who has pursued her a long time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut allow me to tell you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the citizen, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I am\r\nconvinced that there is less love than politics in all this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLess love than politics,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with a reflective air;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand what do you suspect?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know whether I ought to tell you what I suspect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I beg you to observe that I ask you absolutely nothing. It\r\nis you who have come to me. It is you who have told me that you had a\r\nsecret to confide in me. Act, then, as you think proper; there is still\r\ntime to withdraw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, no; you appear to be an honest young man, and I will\r\nhave confidence in you. I believe, then, that it is not on account of\r\nany intrigues of her own that my wife has been arrested, but because of\r\nthose of a lady much greater than herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah! Can it be on account of the amours of Madame de Bois-Tracy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, wishing to have the air, in the eyes of the citizen,\r\nof being posted as to court affairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigher, monsieur, higher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Madame d\xe2\x80\x99Aiguillon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill higher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Madame de Chevreuse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigher, much higher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan checked himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the terrified citizen, in a tone so low that\r\nhe was scarcely audible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd with whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith whom can it be, if not the Duke of\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Duke of\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the citizen, giving a still fainter intonation\r\nto his voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how do you know all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do I know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, how do you know it? No half-confidence, or\xe2\x80\x94you understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it from my wife, monsieur\xe2\x80\x94from my wife herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho learns it from whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Monsieur Laporte. Did I not tell you that she was the goddaughter\r\nof Monsieur Laporte, the confidential man of the queen? Well, Monsieur\r\nLaporte placed her near her Majesty in order that our poor queen might\r\nat least have someone in whom she could place confidence, abandoned as\r\nshe is by the king, watched as she is by the cardinal, betrayed as she\r\nis by everybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah! It begins to develop itself,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my wife came home four days ago, monsieur. One of her conditions\r\nwas that she should come and see me twice a week; for, as I had the\r\nhonor to tell you, my wife loves me dearly\xe2\x80\x94my wife, then, came and\r\nconfided to me that the queen at that very moment entertained great\r\nfears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. The cardinal, as it appears, pursues her and persecutes her more\r\nthan ever. He cannot pardon her the history of the Saraband. You know\r\nthe history of the Saraband?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ Know it!\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who knew nothing about it,\r\nbut who wished to appear to know everything that was going on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that now it is no longer hatred, but vengeance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the queen believes\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what does the queen believe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe believes that someone has written to the Duke of Buckingham in her\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the queen\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to make him come to Paris; and when once come to Paris, to draw\r\nhim into some snare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! But your wife, monsieur, what has she to do with all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer devotion to the queen is known; and they wish either to remove her\r\nfrom her mistress, or to intimidate her, in order to obtain her\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s secrets, or to seduce her and make use of her as a spy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is likely,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut the man who has abducted her\xe2\x80\x94do\r\nyou know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have told you that I believe I know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not know that; what I do know is that he is a creature of the\r\ncardinal, his evil genius.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have seen him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my wife pointed him out to me one day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he anything remarkable about him by which one may recognize him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, certainly; he is a noble of very lofty carriage, black hair,\r\nswarthy complexion, piercing eye, white teeth, and has a scar on his\r\ntemple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA scar on his temple!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand with that, white teeth,\r\na piercing eye, dark complexion, black hair, and haughty carriage\xe2\x80\x94why,\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s my man of Meung.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is your man, do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; but that has nothing to do with it. No, I am wrong. On the\r\ncontrary, that simplifies the matter greatly. If your man is mine, with\r\none blow I shall obtain two revenges, that\xe2\x80\x99s all; but where to find\r\nthis man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you no information as to his abiding place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone. One day, as I was conveying my wife back to the Louvre, he was\r\ncoming out as she was going in, and she showed him to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! The devil!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9call this is vague enough.\r\nFrom whom have you learned of the abduction of your wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Monsieur Laporte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he give you any details?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knew none himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have learned nothing from any other quarter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have received\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear I am committing a great imprudence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou always come back to that; but I must make you see this time that\r\nit is too late to retreat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not retreat, _mordieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d cried the citizen, swearing in order to\r\nrouse his courage. \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, by the faith of Bonacieux\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou call yourself Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is my name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said, then, by the word of Bonacieux. Pardon me for interrupting\r\nyou, but it appears to me that that name is familiar to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly, monsieur. I am your landlord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, half rising and bowing; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are my\r\nlandlord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, yes. And as it is three months since you have been\r\nhere, and though, distracted as you must be in your important\r\noccupations, you have forgotten to pay me my rent\xe2\x80\x94as, I say, I have not\r\ntormented you a single instant, I thought you would appreciate my\r\ndelicacy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can it be otherwise, my dear Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctrust me, I am fully grateful for such unparalleled conduct, and if,\r\nas I told you, I can be of any service to you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you, monsieur, I believe you; and as I was about to say, by\r\nthe word of Bonacieux, I have confidence in you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFinish, then, what you were about to say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe citizen took a paper from his pocket, and presented it to\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA letter?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich I received this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan opened it, and as the day was beginning to decline, he\r\napproached the window to read it. The citizen followed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Do not seek your wife,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d read D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98she will be restored to\r\nyou when there is no longer occasion for her. If you make a single step\r\nto find her you are lost.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s pretty positive,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut after all, it is\r\nbut a menace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but that menace terrifies me. I am not a fighting man at all,\r\nmonsieur, and I am afraid of the Bastille.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHum!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI have no greater regard for the Bastille than\r\nyou. If it were nothing but a sword thrust, why then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have counted upon you on this occasion, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeeing you constantly surrounded by Musketeers of a very superb\r\nappearance, and knowing that these Musketeers belong to Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, and were consequently enemies of the cardinal, I thought that\r\nyou and your friends, while rendering justice to your poor queen, would\r\nbe pleased to play his Eminence an ill turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then I have thought that considering three months\xe2\x80\x99 lodging, about\r\nwhich I have said nothing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; you have already given me that reason, and I find it\r\nexcellent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReckoning still further, that as long as you do me the honor to remain\r\nin my house I shall never speak to you about rent\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery kind!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd adding to this, if there be need of it, meaning to offer you fifty\r\npistoles, if, against all probability, you should be short at the\r\npresent moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdmirable! You are rich then, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am comfortably off, monsieur, that\xe2\x80\x99s all; I have scraped together\r\nsome such things as an income of two or three thousand crowns in the\r\nhaberdashery business, but more particularly in venturing some funds in\r\nthe last voyage of the celebrated navigator Jean Moquet; so that you\r\nunderstand, monsieur\xe2\x80\x94But!\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d cried the citizen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do I see yonder?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the street, facing your window, in the embrasure of that door\xe2\x80\x94a man\r\nwrapped in a cloak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and the citizen at the same time, each\r\nhaving recognized his man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, this time,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, springing to his sword, \xe2\x80\x9cthis time\r\nhe will not escape me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDrawing his sword from its scabbard, he rushed out of the apartment. On\r\nthe staircase he met Athos and Porthos, who were coming to see him.\r\nThey separated, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rushed between them like a dart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPah! Where are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the two Musketeers in a breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man of Meung!\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and disappeared.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had more than once related to his friends his adventure with\r\nthe stranger, as well as the apparition of the beautiful foreigner, to\r\nwhom this man had confided some important missive.\r\n\r\nThe opinion of Athos was that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had lost his letter in the\r\nskirmish. A gentleman, in his opinion\xe2\x80\x94and according to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nportrait of him, the stranger must be a gentleman\xe2\x80\x94would be incapable of\r\nthe baseness of stealing a letter.\r\n\r\nPorthos saw nothing in all this but a love meeting, given by a lady to\r\na cavalier, or by a cavalier to a lady, which had been disturbed by the\r\npresence of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and his yellow horse.\r\n\r\nAramis said that as these sorts of affairs were mysterious, it was\r\nbetter not to fathom them.\r\n\r\nThey understood, then, from the few words which escaped from\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, what affair was in hand, and as they thought that\r\novertaking his man, or losing sight of him, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan would return to\r\nhis rooms, they kept on their way.\r\n\r\nWhen they entered D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s chamber, it was empty; the landlord,\r\ndreading the consequences of the encounter which was doubtless about to\r\ntake place between the young man and the stranger, had, consistent with\r\nthe character he had given himself, judged it prudent to decamp.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter IX.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99ARTAGNAN SHOWS HIMSELF\r\n\r\n\r\nAs Athos and Porthos had foreseen, at the expiration of a half hour,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan returned. He had again missed his man, who had disappeared\r\nas if by enchantment. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had run, sword in hand, through all\r\nthe neighboring streets, but had found nobody resembling the man he\r\nsought for. Then he came back to the point where, perhaps, he ought to\r\nhave begun, and that was to knock at the door against which the\r\nstranger had leaned; but this proved useless\xe2\x80\x94for though he knocked ten\r\nor twelve times in succession, no one answered, and some of the\r\nneighbors, who put their noses out of their windows or were brought to\r\ntheir doors by the noise, had assured him that that house, all the\r\nopenings of which were tightly closed, had not been inhabited for six\r\nmonths.\r\n\r\nWhile D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was running through the streets and knocking at doors,\r\nAramis had joined his companions; so that on returning home D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nfound the reunion complete.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the three Musketeers all together, on seeing D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nenter with his brow covered with perspiration and his countenance upset\r\nwith anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, throwing his sword upon the bed, \xe2\x80\x9cthis man must be\r\nthe devil in person; he has disappeared like a phantom, like a shade,\r\nlike a specter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you believe in apparitions?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos of Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never believe in anything I have not seen, and as I never have seen\r\napparitions, I don\xe2\x80\x99t believe in them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Bible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cmakes our belief in them a law; the ghost of\r\nSamuel appeared to Saul, and it is an article of faith that I should be\r\nvery sorry to see any doubt thrown upon, Porthos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt all events, man or devil, body or shadow, illusion or reality, this\r\nman is born for my damnation; for his flight has caused us to miss a\r\nglorious affair, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94an affair by which there were a hundred\r\npistoles, and perhaps more, to be gained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos and Aramis in a breath.\r\n\r\nAs to Athos, faithful to his system of reticence, he contented himself\r\nwith interrogating D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan by a look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to his domestic, who just then insinuated\r\nhis head through the half-open door in order to catch some fragments of\r\nthe conversation, \xe2\x80\x9cgo down to my landlord, Monsieur Bonacieux, and ask\r\nhim to send me half a dozen bottles of Beaugency wine; I prefer that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah! You have credit with your landlord, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom this very day; and mind, if the wine\r\nis bad, we will send him to find better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must use, and not abuse,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, sententiously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI always said that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had the longest head of the four,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos, who, having uttered his opinion, to which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan replied\r\nwith a bow, immediately resumed his accustomed silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut come, what is this about?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cimpart it to us, my dear friend, unless the honor\r\nof any lady be hazarded by this confidence; in that case you would do\r\nbetter to keep it to yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cthe honor of no one will have\r\ncause to complain of what I have to tell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe then related to his friends, word for word, all that had passed\r\nbetween him and his host, and how the man who had abducted the wife of\r\nhis worthy landlord was the same with whom he had had the difference at\r\nthe hostelry of the Jolly Miller.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour affair is not bad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, after having tasted like a\r\nconnoisseur and indicated by a nod of his head that he thought the wine\r\ngood; \xe2\x80\x9cand one may draw fifty or sixty pistoles from this good man.\r\nThen there only remains to ascertain whether these fifty or sixty\r\npistoles are worth the risk of four heads.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut observe,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthat there is a woman in the affair\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nwoman carried off, a woman who is doubtless threatened, tortured\r\nperhaps, and all because she is faithful to her mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, beware,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cYou grow a little too warm,\r\nin my opinion, about the fate of Madame Bonacieux. Woman was created\r\nfor our destruction, and it is from her we inherit all our miseries.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this speech of Aramis, the brow of Athos became clouded and he bit\r\nhis lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not Madame Bonacieux about whom I am anxious,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut the queen, whom the king abandons, whom the cardinal persecutes,\r\nand who sees the heads of all her friends fall, one after the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy does she love what we hate most in the world, the Spaniards and\r\nthe English?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpain is her country,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand it is very natural\r\nthat she should love the Spanish, who are the children of the same soil\r\nas herself. As to the second reproach, I have heard it said that she\r\ndoes not love the English, but an Englishman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and by my faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cit must be acknowledged that this\r\nEnglishman is worthy of being loved. I never saw a man with a nobler\r\nair than his.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout reckoning that he dresses as nobody else can,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was at the Louvre on the day when he scattered his pearls; and,\r\n_pardieu_, I picked up two that I sold for ten pistoles each. Do you\r\nknow him, Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs well as you do, gentlemen; for I was among those who seized him in\r\nthe garden at Amiens, into which Monsieur Putange, the queen\xe2\x80\x99s equerry,\r\nintroduced me.
