I was at school at the time, and the adventure appeared\r\nto me to be cruel for the king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich would not prevent me,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cif I knew where the\r\nDuke of Buckingham was, from taking him by the hand and conducting him\r\nto the queen, were it only to enrage the cardinal, and if we could find\r\nmeans to play him a sharp turn, I vow that I would voluntarily risk my\r\nhead in doing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did the mercer*,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Athos, \xe2\x80\x9ctell you, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, that the\r\nqueen thought that Buckingham had been brought over by a forged\r\nletter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n* Haberdasher\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is afraid so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait a minute, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, while I endeavor to recall circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now I am convinced,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this abduction of the\r\nqueen\xe2\x80\x99s woman is connected with the events of which we are speaking,\r\nand perhaps with the presence of Buckingham in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Gascon is full of ideas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, with admiration.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like to hear him talk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9chis dialect amuses me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9clisten to this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said his three friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYesterday I was at the house of a doctor of theology, whom I sometimes\r\nconsult about my studies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe resides in a quiet quarter,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9chis tastes and his\r\nprofession require it. Now, at the moment when I left his house\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Aramis paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d cried his auditors; \xe2\x80\x9cat the moment you left his house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis appeared to make a strong inward effort, like a man who, in the\r\nfull relation of a falsehood, finds himself stopped by some unforeseen\r\nobstacle; but the eyes of his three companions were fixed upon him,\r\ntheir ears were wide open, and there were no means of retreat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis doctor has a niece,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, he has a niece!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA very respectable lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\nThe three friends burst into laughter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if you laugh, if you doubt me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall know\r\nnothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe believe like Mohammedans, and are as mute as tombstones,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will continue, then,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cThis niece comes sometimes to\r\nsee her uncle; and by chance was there yesterday at the same time that\r\nI was, and it was my duty to offer to conduct her to her carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! She has a carriage, then, this niece of the doctor?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\r\nPorthos, one of whose faults was a great looseness of tongue. \xe2\x80\x9cA nice\r\nacquaintance, my friend!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPorthos,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI have had the occasion to observe to you\r\nmore than once that you are very indiscreet; and that is injurious to\r\nyou among the women.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who began to get a glimpse of\r\nthe result of the adventure, \xe2\x80\x9cthe thing is serious. Let us try not to\r\njest, if we can. Go on Aramis, go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll at once, a tall, dark gentleman\xe2\x80\x94just like yours, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPossibly,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9ccame toward me, accompanied by five or\r\nsix men who followed about ten paces behind him; and in the politest\r\ntone, \xe2\x80\x98Monsieur Duke,\xe2\x80\x99 said he to me, \xe2\x80\x98and you madame,\xe2\x80\x99 continued he,\r\naddressing the lady on my arm\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe doctor\xe2\x80\x99s niece?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are insupportable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\xe2\x80\x94will you enter this carriage, and that without offering the least\r\nresistance, without making the least noise?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe took you for Buckingham!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the lady?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe took her for the queen!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Gascon is the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cnothing escapes him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cAramis is of the same height, and\r\nsomething of the shape of the duke; but it nevertheless appears to me\r\nthat the dress of a Musketeer\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wore an enormous cloak,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the month of July? The devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cIs the doctor afraid\r\nthat you may be recognized?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can comprehend that the spy may have been deceived by the person;\r\nbut the face\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had a large hat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, good lord,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat precautions for the study of\r\ntheology!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not let us lose our time\r\nin jesting. Let us separate, and let us seek the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s wife\xe2\x80\x94that is\r\nthe key of the intrigue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA woman of such inferior condition! Can you believe so?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos,\r\nprotruding his lips with contempt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is goddaughter to Laporte, the confidential valet of the queen.\r\nHave I not told you so, gentlemen? Besides, it has perhaps been her\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s calculation to seek on this occasion for support so lowly.\r\nHigh heads expose themselves from afar, and the cardinal is\r\nlongsighted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cin the first place make a bargain with the\r\nmercer, and a good bargain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s useless,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I believe if he does not pay\r\nus, we shall be well enough paid by another party.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment a sudden noise of footsteps was heard upon the stairs;\r\nthe door was thrown violently open, and the unfortunate mercer rushed\r\ninto the chamber in which the council was held.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSave me, gentlemen, for the love of heaven, save me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\r\nare four men come to arrest me. Save me! Save me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis arose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA moment,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, making them a sign to replace in the\r\nscabbard their half-drawn swords. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not courage that is needed; it\r\nis prudence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will not leave\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will leave D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to act as he thinks proper,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\r\nhas, I repeat, the longest head of the four, and for my part I declare\r\nthat I will obey him. Do as you think best, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the four Guards appeared at the door of the antechamber,\r\nbut seeing four Musketeers standing, and their swords by their sides,\r\nthey hesitated about going farther.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in, gentlemen, come in,\xe2\x80\x9d called D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are here in my\r\napartment, and we are all faithful servants of the king and cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, gentlemen, you will not oppose our executing the orders we have\r\nreceived?\xe2\x80\x9d asked one who appeared to be the leader of the party.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, gentlemen, we would assist you if it were necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does he say?\xe2\x80\x9d grumbled Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a simpleton,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you promised me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d whispered the poor mercer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe can only save you by being free ourselves,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in\r\na rapid, low tone; \xe2\x80\x9cand if we appear inclined to defend you, they will\r\narrest us with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems, nevertheless\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, gentlemen, come!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, aloud; \xe2\x80\x9cI have no motive for\r\ndefending Monsieur. I saw him today for the first time, and he can tell\r\nyou on what occasion; he came to demand the rent of my lodging. Is that\r\nnot true, Monsieur Bonacieux? Answer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is the very truth,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the mercer; \xe2\x80\x9cbut Monsieur does not tell\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, with respect to me, silence, with respect to my friends;\r\nsilence about the queen, above all, or you will ruin everybody without\r\nsaving yourself! Come, come, gentlemen, remove the fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan pushed the half-stupefied mercer among the Guards, saying to\r\nhim, \xe2\x80\x9cYou are a shabby old fellow, my dear. You come to demand money of\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94of a Musketeer! To prison with him! Gentlemen, once more, take him\r\nto prison, and keep him under key as long as possible; that will give\r\nme time to pay him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe officers were full of thanks, and took away their prey. As they\r\nwere going down D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan laid his hand on the shoulder of their\r\nleader.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I not drink to your health, and you to mine?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nfilling two glasses with the Beaugency wine which he had obtained from\r\nthe liberality of M. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do me great honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said the leader of the posse, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\naccept thankfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen to yours, monsieur\xe2\x80\x94what is your name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoisrenard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Boisrenard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo yours, my gentlemen! What is your name, in your turn, if you\r\nplease?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo yours, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd above all others,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, as if carried away by his\r\nenthusiasm, \xe2\x80\x9cto that of the king and the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe leader of the posse would perhaps have doubted the sincerity of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan if the wine had been bad; but the wine was good, and he was\r\nconvinced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat diabolical villainy you have performed here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, when\r\nthe officer had rejoined his companions and the four friends found\r\nthemselves alone. \xe2\x80\x9cShame, shame, for four Musketeers to allow an\r\nunfortunate fellow who cried for help to be arrested in their midst!\r\nAnd a gentleman to hobnob with a bailiff!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPorthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cAthos has already told you that you are a\r\nsimpleton, and I am quite of his opinion. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, you are a great\r\nman; and when you occupy Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s place, I will come and\r\nask your influence to secure me an abbey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I am in a maze,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cdo _you_ approve of what\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan has done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu!_ Indeed I do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cI not only approve of what he\r\nhas done, but I congratulate him upon it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, without stopping to explain his\r\nconduct to Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cAll for one, one for all\xe2\x80\x94that is our motto, is it\r\nnot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold out your hand and swear!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos and Aramis at once.\r\n\r\nOvercome by example, grumbling to himself, nevertheless, Porthos\r\nstretched out his hand, and the four friends repeated with one voice\r\nthe formula dictated by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll for one, one for all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well! Now let us everyone retire to his own home,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, as if he had done nothing but command all his life; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nattention! For from this moment we are at feud with the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter X.\r\nA MOUSETRAP IN THE SEVENTEENTH CENTURY\r\n\r\n\r\nThe invention of the mousetrap does not date from our days; as soon as\r\nsocieties, in forming, had invented any kind of police, that police\r\ninvented mousetraps.\r\n\r\nAs perhaps our readers are not familiar with the slang of the Rue de\r\nJerusalem, and as it is fifteen years since we applied this word for\r\nthe first time to this thing, allow us to explain to them what is a\r\nmousetrap.\r\n\r\nWhen in a house, of whatever kind it may be, an individual suspected of\r\nany crime is arrested, the arrest is held secret. Four or five men are\r\nplaced in ambuscade in the first room. The door is opened to all who\r\nknock. It is closed after them, and they are arrested; so that at the\r\nend of two or three days they have in their power almost all the\r\n_habitu\xc3\xa9s_ of the establishment. And that is a mousetrap.\r\n\r\nThe apartment of M. Bonacieux, then, became a mousetrap; and whoever\r\nappeared there was taken and interrogated by the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s people. It\r\nmust be observed that as a separate passage led to the first floor, in\r\nwhich D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan lodged, those who called on him were exempted from\r\nthis detention.\r\n\r\nBesides, nobody came thither but the three Musketeers; they had all\r\nbeen engaged in earnest search and inquiries, but had discovered\r\nnothing. Athos had even gone so far as to question M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nthing which, considering the habitual reticence of the worthy\r\nMusketeer, had very much astonished his captain. But M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\r\nknew nothing, except that the last time he had seen the cardinal, the\r\nking, and the queen, the cardinal looked very thoughtful, the king\r\nuneasy, and the redness of the queen\xe2\x80\x99s eyes donated that she had been\r\nsleepless or tearful. But this last circumstance was not striking, as\r\nthe queen since her marriage had slept badly and wept much.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville requested Athos, whatever might happen, to be observant\r\nof his duty to the king, but particularly to the queen, begging him to\r\nconvey his desires to his comrades.\r\n\r\nAs to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he did not budge from his apartment. He converted his\r\nchamber into an observatory. From his windows he saw all the visitors\r\nwho were caught. Then, having removed a plank from his floor, and\r\nnothing remaining but a simple ceiling between him and the room\r\nbeneath, in which the interrogatories were made, he heard all that\r\npassed between the inquisitors and the accused.\r\n\r\nThe interrogatories, preceded by a minute search operated upon the\r\npersons arrested, were almost always framed thus: \xe2\x80\x9cHas Madame Bonacieux\r\nsent anything to you for her husband, or any other person? Has Monsieur\r\nBonacieux sent anything to you for his wife, or for any other person?\r\nHas either of them confided anything to you by word of mouth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf they knew anything, they would not question people in this manner,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, what is it they want to know? Why,\r\nthey want to know if the Duke of Buckingham is in Paris, and if he has\r\nhad, or is likely to have, an interview with the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan held onto this idea, which, from what he had heard, was not\r\nwanting in probability.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, the mousetrap continued in operation, and likewise\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s vigilance.\r\n\r\nOn the evening of the day after the arrest of poor Bonacieux, as Athos\r\nhad just left D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to report at M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s, as nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nhad just struck, and as Planchet, who had not yet made the bed, was\r\nbeginning his task, a knocking was heard at the street door. The door\r\nwas instantly opened and shut; someone was taken in the mousetrap.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan flew to his hole, laid himself down on the floor at full\r\nlength, and listened.\r\n\r\nCries were soon heard, and then moans, which someone appeared to be\r\nendeavoring to stifle. There were no questions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cIt seems like a woman! They\r\nsearch her; she resists; they use force\xe2\x80\x94the scoundrels!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn spite of his prudence, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan restrained himself with great\r\ndifficulty from taking a part in the scene that was going on below.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I tell you that I am the mistress of the house, gentlemen! I tell\r\nyou I am Madame Bonacieux; I tell you I belong to the queen!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\nunfortunate woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Bonacieux!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cCan I be so lucky as to find\r\nwhat everybody is seeking for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice became more and more indistinct; a tumultuous movement shook\r\nthe partition. The victim resisted as much as a woman could resist four\r\nmen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon, gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94par\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the voice, which could now only be\r\nheard in inarticulate sounds.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are binding her; they are going to drag her away,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself, springing up from the floor. \xe2\x80\x9cMy sword! Good, it\r\nis by my side! Planchet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRun and seek Athos, Porthos and Aramis. One of the three will\r\ncertainly be at home, perhaps all three. Tell them to take arms, to\r\ncome here, and to run! Ah, I remember, Athos is at Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where are you going, monsieur, where are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going down by the window, in order to be there the sooner,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cYou put back the boards, sweep the floor, go out at the\r\ndoor, and run as I told you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur! Monsieur! You will kill yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Planchet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, stupid fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; and laying hold of\r\nthe casement, he let himself gently down from the first story, which\r\nfortunately was not very elevated, without doing himself the slightest\r\ninjury.\r\n\r\nHe then went straight to the door and knocked, murmuring, \xe2\x80\x9cI will go\r\nmyself and be caught in the mousetrap, but woe be to the cats that\r\nshall pounce upon such a mouse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe knocker had scarcely sounded under the hand of the young man before\r\nthe tumult ceased, steps approached, the door was opened, and\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, sword in hand, rushed into the rooms of M. Bonacieux, the\r\ndoor of which, doubtless acted upon by a spring, closed after him.\r\n\r\nThen those who dwelt in Bonacieux\xe2\x80\x99s unfortunate house, together with\r\nthe nearest neighbors, heard loud cries, stamping of feet, clashing of\r\nswords, and breaking of furniture. A moment after, those who, surprised\r\nby this tumult, had gone to their windows to learn the cause of it, saw\r\nthe door open, and four men, clothed in black, not _come_ out of it,\r\nbut _fly_, like so many frightened crows, leaving on the ground and on\r\nthe corners of the furniture, feathers from their wings; that is to\r\nsay, patches of their clothes and fragments of their cloaks.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was conqueror\xe2\x80\x94without much effort, it must be confessed, for\r\nonly one of the officers was armed, and even he defended himself for\r\nform\xe2\x80\x99s sake. It is true that the three others had endeavored to knock\r\nthe young man down with chairs, stools, and crockery; but two or three\r\nscratches made by the Gascon\xe2\x80\x99s blade terrified them. Ten minutes\r\nsufficed for their defeat, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remained master of the field\r\nof battle.\r\n\r\nThe neighbors who had opened their windows, with the coolness peculiar\r\nto the inhabitants of Paris in these times of perpetual riots and\r\ndisturbances, closed them again as soon as they saw the four men in\r\nblack flee\xe2\x80\x94their instinct telling them that for the time all was over.\r\nBesides, it began to grow late, and then, as today, people went to bed\r\nearly in the quarter of the Luxembourg.\r\n\r\nOn being left alone with Mme. Bonacieux, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan turned toward her;\r\nthe poor woman reclined where she had been left, half-fainting upon an\r\narmchair. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan examined her with a rapid glance.\r\n\r\nShe was a charming woman of twenty-five or twenty-six years, with dark\r\nhair, blue eyes, and a nose slightly turned up, admirable teeth, and a\r\ncomplexion marbled with rose and opal. There, however, ended the signs\r\nwhich might have confounded her with a lady of rank. The hands were\r\nwhite, but without delicacy; the feet did not bespeak the woman of\r\nquality. Happily, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not yet acquainted with such niceties.\r\n\r\nWhile D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was examining Mme. Bonacieux, and was, as we have\r\nsaid, close to her, he saw on the ground a fine cambric handkerchief,\r\nwhich he picked up, as was his habit, and at the corner of which he\r\nrecognized the same cipher he had seen on the handkerchief which had\r\nnearly caused him and Aramis to cut each other\xe2\x80\x99s throat.\r\n\r\nFrom that time, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had been cautious with respect to\r\nhandkerchiefs with arms on them, and he therefore placed in the pocket\r\nof Mme. Bonacieux the one he had just picked up.\r\n\r\nAt that moment Mme. Bonacieux recovered her senses. She opened her\r\neyes, looked around her with terror, saw that the apartment was empty\r\nand that she was alone with her liberator. She extended her hands to\r\nhim with a smile. Mme. Bonacieux had the sweetest smile in the world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have saved me; permit me to thank you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI have only done what every gentleman would\r\nhave done in my place; you owe me no thanks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, monsieur, oh, yes; and I hope to prove to you that you have\r\nnot served an ingrate. But what could these men, whom I at first took\r\nfor robbers, want with me, and why is Monsieur Bonacieux not here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame, those men were more dangerous than any robbers could have\r\nbeen, for they are the agents of the cardinal; and as to your husband,\r\nMonsieur Bonacieux, he is not here because he was yesterday evening\r\nconducted to the Bastille.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy husband in the Bastille!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God! What\r\nhas he done? Poor dear man, he is innocence itself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd something like a faint smile lighted the still-terrified features\r\nof the young woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has he done, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe that his only\r\ncrime is to have at the same time the good fortune and the misfortune\r\nto be your husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, monsieur, you know then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that you have been abducted, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by whom? Do you know him? Oh, if you know him, tell me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy a man of from forty to forty-five years, with black hair, a dark\r\ncomplexion, and a scar on his left temple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is he, that is he; but his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, his name? I do not know that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did my husband know I had been carried off?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was informed of it by a letter, written to him by the abductor\r\nhimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd does he suspect,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, with some embarrassment,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe cause of this event?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe attributed it, I believe, to a political cause.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI doubted from the first; and now I think entirely as he does. Then my\r\ndear Monsieur Bonacieux has not suspected me a single instant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo far from it, madame, he was too proud of your prudence, and above\r\nall, of your love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA second smile, almost imperceptible, stole over the rosy lips of the\r\npretty young woman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9chow did you escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI took advantage of a moment when they left me alone; and as I had\r\nknown since morning the reason of my abduction, with the help of the\r\nsheets I let myself down from the window. Then, as I believed my\r\nhusband would be at home, I hastened hither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo place yourself under his protection?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, poor dear man! I knew very well that he was incapable of\r\ndefending me; but as he could serve us in other ways, I wished to\r\ninform him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is not my secret; I must not, therefore, tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cpardon me, madame, if, guardsman as I am,\r\nI remind you of prudence\xe2\x80\x94besides, I believe we are not here in a very\r\nproper place for imparting confidences. The men I have put to flight\r\nwill return reinforced; if they find us here, we are lost. I have sent\r\nfor three of my friends, but who knows whether they were at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! You are right,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the affrighted Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9clet us\r\nfly! Let us save ourselves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words she passed her arm under that of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and urged\r\nhim forward eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut whither shall we fly\xe2\x80\x94whither escape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us first withdraw from this house; afterward we shall see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young woman and the young man, without taking the trouble to shut\r\nthe door after them, descended the Rue des Fossoyeurs rapidly, turned\r\ninto the Rue des Foss\xc3\xa9s-Monsieur-le-Prince, and did not stop till they\r\ncame to the Place St. Sulpice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now what are we to do, and where do you wish me to conduct you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am at quite a loss how to answer you, I admit,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy intention was to inform Monsieur Laporte, through my husband, in\r\norder that Monsieur Laporte might tell us precisely what had taken\r\nplace at the Louvre in the last three days, and whether there is any\r\ndanger in presenting myself there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ccan go and inform Monsieur Laporte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt you could, only there is one misfortune, and that is that\r\nMonsieur Bonacieux is known at the Louvre, and would be allowed to\r\npass; whereas you are not known there, and the gate would be closed\r\nagainst you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, bah!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have at some wicket of the Louvre a\r\n_concierge_ who is devoted to you, and who, thanks to a password,\r\nwould\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux looked earnestly at the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I give you this password,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cwould you forget it as\r\nsoon as you used it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my honor, by the faith of a gentleman!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with an\r\naccent so truthful that no one could mistake it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I believe you. You appear to be a brave young man; besides, your\r\nfortune may perhaps be the result of your devotedness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will do, without a promise and voluntarily, all that I can do to\r\nserve the king and be agreeable to the queen. Dispose of me, then, as a\r\nfriend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I\xe2\x80\x94where shall I go meanwhile?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there nobody from whose house Monsieur Laporte can come and fetch\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I can trust nobody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cwe are near Athos\xe2\x80\x99s door. Yes, here it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is this Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of my friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he should be at home and see me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not at home, and I will carry away the key, after having placed\r\nyou in his apartment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he should return?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he won\xe2\x80\x99t return; and if he should, he will be told that I have\r\nbrought a woman with me, and that woman is in his apartment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that will compromise me sadly, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what consequence? Nobody knows you. Besides, we are in a situation\r\nto overlook ceremony.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then, let us go to your friend\xe2\x80\x99s house. Where does he live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRue F\xc3\xa9rou, two steps from here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth resumed their way. As D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had foreseen, Athos was not\r\nwithin. He took the key, which was customarily given him as one of the\r\nfamily, ascended the stairs, and introduced Mme. Bonacieux into the\r\nlittle apartment of which we have given a description.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are at home,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cRemain here, fasten the door inside, and\r\nopen it to nobody unless you hear three taps like this;\xe2\x80\x9d and he tapped\r\nthrice\xe2\x80\x94two taps close together and pretty hard, the other after an\r\ninterval, and lighter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, in my turn, let me give you\r\nmy instructions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPresent yourself at the wicket of the Louvre, on the side of the Rue\r\nde l\xe2\x80\x99Echelle, and ask for Germain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will ask you what you want, and you will answer by these two words,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Tours\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98Bruxelles.\xe2\x80\x99 He will at once put himself at your orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what shall I command him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo go and fetch Monsieur Laporte, the queen\xe2\x80\x99s _valet de chambre_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when he shall have informed him, and Monsieur Laporte is come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will send him to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is well; but where and how shall I see you again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you wish to see me again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let that care be mine, and be at ease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI depend upon your word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan bowed to Mme. Bonacieux, darting at her the most loving\r\nglance that he could possibly concentrate upon her charming little\r\nperson; and while he descended the stairs, he heard the door closed and\r\ndouble-locked. In two bounds he was at the Louvre; as he entered the\r\nwicket of L\xe2\x80\x99Echelle, ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock struck. All the events we have\r\ndescribed had taken place within a half hour.\r\n\r\nEverything fell out as Mme. Bonacieux prophesied. On hearing the\r\npassword, Germain bowed. In a few minutes, Laporte was at the lodge; in\r\ntwo words D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan informed him where Mme. Bonacieux was. Laporte\r\nassured himself, by having it twice repeated, of the accurate address,\r\nand set off at a run. Hardly, however, had he taken ten steps before he\r\nreturned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYoung man,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ca suggestion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may get into trouble by what has taken place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou believe so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. Have you any friend whose clock is too slow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo and call upon him, in order that he may give evidence of your\r\nhaving been with him at half past nine. In a court of justice that is\r\ncalled an alibi.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan found his advice prudent. He took to his heels, and was soon\r\nat M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s; but instead of going into the saloon with the rest\r\nof the crowd, he asked to be introduced to M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s office. As\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan so constantly frequented the h\xc3\xb4tel, no difficulty was made\r\nin complying with his request, and a servant went to inform M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville that his young compatriot, having something important to\r\ncommunicate, solicited a private audience. Five minutes after, M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville was asking D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan what he could do to serve him, and what\r\ncaused his visit at so late an hour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had profited by the moment\r\nhe had been left alone to put back M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s clock\r\nthree-quarters of an hour, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I thought, as it was yet only\r\ntwenty-five minutes past nine, it was not too late to wait upon you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-five minutes past nine!\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, looking at the\r\nclock; \xe2\x80\x9cwhy, that\xe2\x80\x99s impossible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook, rather, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthe clock shows it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; \xe2\x80\x9cI believed it later. But what can\r\nI do for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan told M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville a long history about the queen. He\r\nexpressed to him the fears he entertained with respect to her Majesty;\r\nhe related to him what he had heard of the projects of the cardinal\r\nwith regard to Buckingham, and all with a tranquillity and candor of\r\nwhich M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was the more the dupe, from having himself, as we\r\nhave said, observed something fresh between the cardinal, the king, and\r\nthe queen.\r\n\r\nAs ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock was striking, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan left M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who\r\nthanked him for his information, recommended him to have the service of\r\nthe king and queen always at heart, and returned to the saloon; but at\r\nthe foot of the stairs, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remembered he had forgotten his\r\ncane. He consequently sprang up again, re-entered the office, with a\r\nturn of his finger set the clock right again, that it might not be\r\nperceived the next day that it had been put wrong, and certain from\r\nthat time that he had a witness to prove his alibi, he ran downstairs\r\nand soon found himself in the street.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XI.\r\nIN WHICH THE PLOT THICKENS\r\n\r\n\r\nHis visit to M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville being paid, the pensive D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took the\r\nlongest way homeward.\r\n\r\nOn what was D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thinking, that he strayed thus from his path,\r\ngazing at the stars of heaven, and sometimes sighing, sometimes\r\nsmiling?\r\n\r\nHe was thinking of Mme. Bonacieux. For an apprentice Musketeer the\r\nyoung woman was almost an ideal of love. Pretty, mysterious, initiated\r\nin almost all the secrets of the court, which reflected such a charming\r\ngravity over her pleasing features, it might be surmised that she was\r\nnot wholly unmoved; and this is an irresistible charm to novices in\r\nlove. Moreover, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had delivered her from the hands of the\r\ndemons who wished to search and ill treat her; and this important\r\nservice had established between them one of those sentiments of\r\ngratitude which so easily assume a more tender character.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan already fancied himself, so rapid is the flight of our\r\ndreams upon the wings of imagination, accosted by a messenger from the\r\nyoung woman, who brought him some billet appointing a meeting, a gold\r\nchain, or a diamond. We have observed that young cavaliers received\r\npresents from their king without shame. Let us add that in these times\r\nof lax morality they had no more delicacy with respect to the\r\nmistresses; and that the latter almost always left them valuable and\r\ndurable remembrances, as if they essayed to conquer the fragility of\r\ntheir sentiments by the solidity of their gifts.\r\n\r\nWithout a blush, men made their way in the world by the means of women\r\nblushing. Such as were only beautiful gave their beauty, whence,\r\nwithout doubt, comes the proverb, \xe2\x80\x9cThe most beautiful girl in the world\r\ncan only give what she has.\xe2\x80\x9d Such as were rich gave in addition a part\r\nof their money; and a vast number of heroes of that gallant period may\r\nbe cited who would neither have won their spurs in the first place, nor\r\ntheir battles afterward, without the purse, more or less furnished,\r\nwhich their mistress fastened to the saddle bow.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan owned nothing. Provincial diffidence, that slight varnish,\r\nthe ephemeral flower, that down of the peach, had evaporated to the\r\nwinds through the little orthodox counsels which the three Musketeers\r\ngave their friend. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, following the strange custom of the\r\ntimes, considered himself at Paris as on a campaign, neither more nor\r\nless than if he had been in Flanders\xe2\x80\x94Spain yonder, woman here. In each\r\nthere was an enemy to contend with, and contributions to be levied.\r\n\r\nBut, we must say, at the present moment D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was ruled by a\r\nfeeling much more noble and disinterested. The mercer had said that he\r\nwas rich; the young man might easily guess that with so weak a man as\r\nM. Bonacieux; and interest was almost foreign to this commencement of\r\nlove, which had been the consequence of it. We say _almost_, for the\r\nidea that a young, handsome, kind, and witty woman is at the same time\r\nrich takes nothing from the beginning of love, but on the contrary\r\nstrengthens it.\r\n\r\nThere are in affluence a crowd of aristocratic cares and caprices which\r\nare highly becoming to beauty. A fine and white stocking, a silken\r\nrobe, a lace kerchief, a pretty slipper on the foot, a tasty ribbon on\r\nthe head do not make an ugly woman pretty, but they make a pretty woman\r\nbeautiful, without reckoning the hands, which gain by all this; the\r\nhands, among women particularly, to be beautiful must be idle.\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, as the reader, from whom we have not concealed the\r\nstate of his fortune, very well knows\xe2\x80\x94D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not a millionaire;\r\nhe hoped to become one someday, but the time which in his own mind he\r\nfixed upon for this happy change was still far distant. In the\r\nmeanwhile, how disheartening to see the woman one loves long for those\r\nthousands of nothings which constitute a woman\xe2\x80\x99s happiness, and be\r\nunable to give her those thousands of nothings. At least, when the\r\nwoman is rich and the lover is not, that which he cannot offer she\r\noffers to herself; and although it is generally with her husband\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmoney that she procures herself this indulgence, the gratitude for it\r\nseldom reverts to him.\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, disposed to become the most tender of lovers, was at\r\nthe same time a very devoted friend. In the midst of his amorous\r\nprojects for the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s wife, he did not forget his friends. The\r\npretty Mme. Bonacieux was just the woman to walk with in the Plain St.\r\nDenis or in the fair of St. Germain, in company with Athos, Porthos,\r\nand Aramis, to whom D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had often remarked this. Then one could\r\nenjoy charming little dinners, where one touches on one side the hand\r\nof a friend, and on the other the foot of a mistress. Besides, on\r\npressing occasions, in extreme difficulties, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan would become\r\nthe preserver of his friends.\r\n\r\nAnd M. Bonacieux, whom D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had pushed into the hands of the\r\nofficers, denying him aloud although he had promised in a whisper to\r\nsave him? We are compelled to admit to our readers that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nthought nothing about him in any way; or that if he did think of him,\r\nit was only to say to himself that he was very well where he was,\r\nwherever it might be. Love is the most selfish of all the passions.\r\n\r\nLet our readers reassure themselves. If D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan forgets his host, or\r\nappears to forget him, under the pretense of not knowing where he has\r\nbeen carried, we will not forget him, and we know where he is. But for\r\nthe moment, let us do as did the amorous Gascon; we will see after the\r\nworthy mercer later.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, reflecting on his future amours, addressing himself to the\r\nbeautiful night, and smiling at the stars, ascended the Rue\r\nCherish-Midi, or Chase-Midi, as it was then called. As he found himself\r\nin the quarter in which Aramis lived, he took it into his head to pay\r\nhis friend a visit in order to explain the motives which had led him to\r\nsend Planchet with a request that he would come instantly to the\r\nmousetrap. Now, if Aramis had been at home when Planchet came to his\r\nabode, he had doubtless hastened to the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and finding\r\nnobody there but his other two companions perhaps, they would not be\r\nable to conceive what all this meant. This mystery required an\r\nexplanation; at least, so D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan declared to himself.\r\n\r\nHe likewise thought this was an opportunity for talking about pretty\r\nlittle Mme. Bonacieux, of whom his head, if not his heart, was already\r\nfull. We must never look for discretion in first love. First love is\r\naccompanied by such excessive joy that unless the joy be allowed to\r\noverflow, it will stifle you.\r\n\r\nParis for two hours past had been dark, and seemed a desert. Eleven\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock sounded from all the clocks of the Faubourg St. Germain. It was\r\ndelightful weather. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was passing along a lane on the spot\r\nwhere the Rue d\xe2\x80\x99Assas is now situated, breathing the balmy emanations\r\nwhich were borne upon the wind from the Rue de Vaugirard, and which\r\narose from the gardens refreshed by the dews of evening and the breeze\r\nof night. From a distance resounded, deadened, however, by good\r\nshutters, the songs of the tipplers, enjoying themselves in the\r\ncabarets scattered along the plain. Arrived at the end of the lane,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan turned to the left. The house in which Aramis dwelt was\r\nsituated between the Rue Cassette and the Rue Servandoni.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had just passed the Rue Cassette, and already perceived the\r\ndoor of his friend\xe2\x80\x99s house, shaded by a mass of sycamores and clematis\r\nwhich formed a vast arch opposite the front of it, when he perceived\r\nsomething like a shadow issuing from the Rue Servandoni. This something\r\nwas enveloped in a cloak, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at first believed it was a\r\nman; but by the smallness of the form, the hesitation of the walk, and\r\nthe indecision of the step, he soon discovered that it was a woman.\r\nFurther, this woman, as if not certain of the house she was seeking,\r\nlifted up her eyes to look around her, stopped, went backward, and then\r\nreturned again. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was perplexed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I go and offer her my services?\xe2\x80\x9d thought he. \xe2\x80\x9cBy her step she\r\nmust be young; perhaps she is pretty. Oh, yes! But a woman who wanders\r\nin the streets at this hour only ventures out to meet her lover. If I\r\nshould disturb a rendezvous, that would not be the best means of\r\ncommencing an acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeantime the young woman continued to advance, counting the houses and\r\nwindows. This was neither long nor difficult. There were but three\r\nh\xc3\xb4tels in this part of the street; and only two windows looking toward\r\nthe road, one of which was in a pavilion parallel to that which Aramis\r\noccupied, the other belonging to Aramis himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself, to whose mind the niece of the\r\ntheologian reverted, \xe2\x80\x9c_pardieu_, it would be droll if this belated dove\r\nshould be in search of our friend\xe2\x80\x99s house. But on my soul, it looks so.\r\nAh, my dear Aramis, this time I shall find you out.\xe2\x80\x9d And D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nmaking himself as small as he could, concealed himself in the darkest\r\nside of the street near a stone bench placed at the back of a niche.\r\n\r\nThe young woman continued to advance; and in addition to the lightness\r\nof her step, which had betrayed her, she emitted a little cough which\r\ndenoted a sweet voice. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan believed this cough to be a signal.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, whether the cough had been answered by a similar signal\r\nwhich had fixed the irresolution of the nocturnal seeker, or whether\r\nwithout this aid she saw that she had arrived at the end of her\r\njourney, she resolutely drew near to Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s shutter, and tapped, at\r\nthree equal intervals, with her bent finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is all very fine, dear Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cAh,\r\nMonsieur Hypocrite, I understand how you study theology.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three blows were scarcely struck, when the inside blind was opened\r\nand a light appeared through the panes of the outside shutter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said the listener, \xe2\x80\x9cnot through doors, but through windows!\r\nAh, this visit was expected. We shall see the windows open, and the\r\nlady enter by escalade. Very pretty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut to the great astonishment of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, the shutter remained\r\nclosed. Still more, the light which had shone for an instant\r\ndisappeared, and all was again in obscurity.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought this could not last long, and continued to look with\r\nall his eyes and listen with all his ears.\r\n\r\nHe was right; at the end of some seconds two sharp taps were heard\r\ninside. The young woman in the street replied by a single tap, and the\r\nshutter was opened a little way.\r\n\r\nIt may be judged whether D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan looked or listened with avidity.\r\nUnfortunately the light had been removed into another chamber; but the\r\neyes of the young man were accustomed to the night. Besides, the eyes\r\nof the Gascons have, as it is asserted, like those of cats, the faculty\r\nof seeing in the dark.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan then saw that the young woman took from her pocket a white\r\nobject, which she unfolded quickly, and which took the form of a\r\nhandkerchief. She made her interlocutor observe the corner of this\r\nunfolded object.\r\n\r\nThis immediately recalled to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s mind the handkerchief which\r\nhe had found at the feet of Mme. Bonacieux, which had reminded him of\r\nthat which he had dragged from under the feet of Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil could that handkerchief signify?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPlaced where he was, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could not perceive the face of Aramis.\r\nWe say Aramis, because the young man entertained no doubt that it was\r\nhis friend who held this dialogue from the interior with the lady of\r\nthe exterior. Curiosity prevailed over prudence; and profiting by the\r\npreoccupation into which the sight of the handkerchief appeared to have\r\nplunged the two personages now on the scene, he stole from his hiding\r\nplace, and quick as lightning, but stepping with utmost caution, he ran\r\nand placed himself close to the angle of the wall, from which his eye\r\ncould pierce the interior of Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s room.\r\n\r\nUpon gaining this advantage D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was near uttering a cry of\r\nsurprise; it was not Aramis who was conversing with the nocturnal\r\nvisitor, it was a woman! D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, however, could only see enough to\r\nrecognize the form of her vestments, not enough to distinguish her\r\nfeatures.\r\n\r\nAt the same instant the woman inside drew a second handkerchief from\r\nher pocket, and exchanged it for that which had just been shown to her.\r\nThen some words were spoken by the two women. At length the shutter\r\nclosed. The woman who was outside the window turned round, and passed\r\nwithin four steps of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, pulling down the hood of her mantle;\r\nbut the precaution was too late, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had already recognized Mme.\r\nBonacieux.\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux! The suspicion that it was she had crossed the mind of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan when she drew the handkerchief from her pocket; but what\r\nprobability was there that Mme. Bonacieux, who had sent for M. Laporte\r\nin order to be reconducted to the Louvre, should be running about the\r\nstreets of Paris at half past eleven at night, at the risk of being\r\nabducted a second time?\r\n\r\nThis must be, then, an affair of importance; and what is the most\r\nimportant affair to a woman of twenty-five! Love.\r\n\r\nBut was it on her own account, or on account of another, that she\r\nexposed herself to such hazards? This was a question the young man\r\nasked himself, whom the demon of jealousy already gnawed, being in\r\nheart neither more nor less than an accepted lover.\r\n\r\nThere was a very simple means of satisfying himself whither Mme.\r\nBonacieux was going; that was to follow her. This method was so simple\r\nthat D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan employed it quite naturally and instinctively.\r\n\r\nBut at the sight of the young man, who detached himself from the wall\r\nlike a statue walking from its niche, and at the noise of the steps\r\nwhich she heard resound behind her, Mme. Bonacieux uttered a little cry\r\nand fled.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan ran after her. It was not difficult for him to overtake a\r\nwoman embarrassed with her cloak. He came up with her before she had\r\ntraversed a third of the street. The unfortunate woman was exhausted,\r\nnot by fatigue, but by terror, and when D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan placed his hand upon\r\nher shoulder, she sank upon one knee, crying in a choking voice, \xe2\x80\x9cKill\r\nme, if you please, you shall know nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan raised her by passing his arm round her waist; but as he\r\nfelt by her weight she was on the point of fainting, he made haste to\r\nreassure her by protestations of devotedness. These protestations were\r\nnothing for Mme. Bonacieux, for such protestations may be made with the\r\nworst intentions in the world; but the voice was all. Mme. Bonacieux\r\nthought she recognized the sound of that voice; she reopened her eyes,\r\ncast a quick glance upon the man who had terrified her so, and at once\r\nperceiving it was D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, she uttered a cry of joy, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, it is you,\r\nit is you! Thank God, thank God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is I,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cit is I, whom God has sent to watch\r\nover you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it with that intention you followed me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young woman,\r\nwith a coquettish smile, whose somewhat bantering character resumed its\r\ninfluence, and with whom all fear had disappeared from the moment in\r\nwhich she recognized a friend in one she had taken for an enemy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cno, I confess it. It was chance that threw me\r\nin your way; I saw a woman knocking at the window of one of my\r\nfriends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of your friends?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt; Aramis is one of my best friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAramis! Who is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, you won\xe2\x80\x99t tell me you don\xe2\x80\x99t know Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the first time I ever heard his name pronounced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the first time, then, that you ever went to that house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you did not know that it was inhabited by a young man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy a Musketeer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was not he, then, you came to seek?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the least in the world. Besides, you must have seen that the\r\nperson to whom I spoke was a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true; but this woman is a friend of Aramis\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94since she lodges with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat does not concern me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is not my secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Madame Bonacieux, you are charming; but at the same time you\r\nare one of the most mysterious women.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo I lose by that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you are, on the contrary, adorable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me your arm, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost willingly. And now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow escort me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere I am going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where are you going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will see, because you will leave me at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I wait for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be useless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will return alone, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps yes, perhaps no.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut will the person who shall accompany you afterward be a man or a\r\nwoman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I will know it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will wait until you come out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, adieu.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not want you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have claimed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe aid of a gentleman, not the watchfulness of a spy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe word is rather hard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are they called who follow others in spite of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are indiscreet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe word is too mild.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, madame, I perceive I must do as you wish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you deprive yourself of the merit of doing so at once?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there no merit in repentance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you really repent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know nothing about it myself. But what I know is that I promise to\r\ndo all you wish if you allow me to accompany you where you are going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will leave me then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout waiting for my coming out again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWord of honor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the faith of a gentleman. Take my arm, and let us go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan offered his arm to Mme. Bonacieux, who willingly took it,\r\nhalf laughing, half trembling, and both gained the top of Rue de la\r\nHarpe. Arriving there, the young woman seemed to hesitate, as she had\r\nbefore done in the Rue Vaugirard. She seemed, however, by certain\r\nsigns, to recognize a door, and approaching that door, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\r\nmonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cit is here I have business; a thousand thanks for\r\nyour honorable company, which has saved me from all the dangers to\r\nwhich, alone, I was exposed. But the moment is come to keep your word;\r\nI have reached my destination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will have nothing to fear on your return?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall have nothing to fear but robbers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat could they take from me? I have not a penny about me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou forget that beautiful handkerchief with the coat of arms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat which I found at your feet, and replaced in your pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, imprudent man! Do you wish to destroy me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see very plainly that there is still danger for you, since a\r\nsingle word makes you tremble; and you confess that if that word were\r\nheard you would be ruined. Come, come, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nseizing her hands, and surveying her with an ardent glance, \xe2\x80\x9ccome, be\r\nmore generous. Confide in me. Have you not read in my eyes that there\r\nis nothing but devotion and sympathy in my heart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9ctherefore, ask my own secrets, and I\r\nwill reveal them to you; but those of others\xe2\x80\x94that is quite another\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall discover them; as these secrets\r\nmay have an influence over your life, these secrets must become mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware of what you do!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young woman, in a manner so serious\r\nas to make D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan start in spite of himself. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, meddle in nothing\r\nwhich concerns me. Do not seek to assist me in that which I am\r\naccomplishing. This I ask of you in the name of the interest with which\r\nI inspire you, in the name of the service you have rendered me and\r\nwhich I never shall forget while I have life. Rather, place faith in\r\nwhat I tell you. Have no more concern about me; I exist no longer for\r\nyou, any more than if you had never seen me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMust Aramis do as much as I, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, deeply piqued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the second or third time, monsieur, that you have repeated\r\nthat name, and yet I have told you that I do not know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not know the man at whose shutter you have just knocked?\r\nIndeed, madame, you believe me too credulous!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConfess that it is for the sake of making me talk that you invent this\r\nstory and create this personage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI invent nothing, madame; I create nothing. I only speak that exact\r\ntruth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you say that one of your friends lives in that house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say so, and I repeat it for the third time; that house is one\r\ninhabited by my friend, and that friend is Aramis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this will be cleared up at a later period,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the young\r\nwoman; \xe2\x80\x9cno, monsieur, be silent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you could see my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would there read so\r\nmuch curiosity that you would pity me and so much love that you would\r\ninstantly satisfy my curiosity. We have nothing to fear from those who\r\nlove us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak very suddenly of love, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman,\r\nshaking her head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is because love has come suddenly upon me, and for the first\r\ntime; and because I am only twenty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young woman looked at him furtively.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen; I am already upon the scent,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cAbout three\r\nmonths ago I was near having a duel with Aramis concerning a\r\nhandkerchief resembling the one you showed to the woman in his\r\nhouse\xe2\x80\x94for a handkerchief marked in the same manner, I am sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9cyou weary me very much, I assure\r\nyou, with your questions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you, madame, prudent as you are, think, if you were to be arrested\r\nwith that handkerchief, and that handkerchief were to be seized, would\r\nyou not be compromised?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what way? The initials are only mine\xe2\x80\x94C. B., Constance Bonacieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr Camille de Bois-Tracy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, monsieur! Once again, silence! Ah, since the dangers I incur\r\non my own account cannot stop you, think of those you may yourself\r\nrun!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; there is peril of imprisonment, risk of life in knowing me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I will not leave you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, supplicating him and clasping her\r\nhands together, \xe2\x80\x9cmonsieur, in the name of heaven, by the honor of a\r\nsoldier, by the courtesy of a gentleman, depart! There, there midnight\r\nsounds! That is the hour when I am expected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, bowing; \xe2\x80\x9cI can refuse nothing asked of me\r\nthus. Be content; I will depart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you will not follow me; you will not watch me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will return home instantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, I was quite sure you were a good and brave young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme.\r\nBonacieux, holding out her hand to him, and placing the other upon the\r\nknocker of a little door almost hidden in the wall.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan seized the hand held out to him, and kissed it ardently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! I wish I had never seen you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with that\r\ningenuous roughness which women often prefer to the affectations of\r\npoliteness, because it betrays the depths of the thought and proves\r\nthat feeling prevails over reason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Mme. Bonacieux, in a voice almost caressing, and\r\npressing the hand of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had not relinquished hers, \xe2\x80\x9cwell:\r\nI will not say as much as you do; what is lost for today may not be\r\nlost forever. Who knows, when I shall be at liberty, that I may not\r\nsatisfy your curiosity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will you make the same promise to my love?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nbeside himself with joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, as to that, I do not engage myself. That depends upon the\r\nsentiments with which you may inspire me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen today, madame\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, today, I am no further than gratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! You are too charming,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, sorrowfully; \xe2\x80\x9cand you\r\nabuse my love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I use your generosity, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. But be of good cheer; with\r\ncertain people, everything comes round.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you render me the happiest of men! Do not forget this evening\xe2\x80\x94do\r\nnot forget that promise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied. In the proper time and place I will remember everything.\r\nNow then, go, go, in the name of heaven! I was expected at sharp\r\nmidnight, and I am late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy five minutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but in certain circumstances five minutes are five ages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen one loves.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! And who told you I had no affair with a lover?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a man, then, who expects you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cA man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe discussion is going to begin again!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, with a\r\nhalf-smile which was not exempt from a tinge of impatience.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no; I go, I depart! I believe in you, and I would have all the\r\nmerit of my devotion, even if that devotion were stupidity. Adieu,\r\nmadame, adieu!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd as if he only felt strength to detach himself by a violent effort\r\nfrom the hand he held, he sprang away, running, while Mme. Bonacieux\r\nknocked, as at the shutter, three light and regular taps. When he had\r\ngained the angle of the street, he turned. The door had been opened,\r\nand shut again; the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s pretty wife had disappeared.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan pursued his way. He had given his word not to watch Mme.\r\nBonacieux, and if his life had depended upon the spot to which she was\r\ngoing or upon the person who should accompany her, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan would\r\nhave returned home, since he had so promised. Five minutes later he was\r\nin the Rue des Fossoyeurs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9che will never guess what all this means. He\r\nwill have fallen asleep waiting for me, or else he will have returned\r\nhome, where he will have learned that a woman had been there. A woman\r\nwith Athos! After all,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthere was certainly one\r\nwith Aramis. All this is very strange; and I am curious to know how it\r\nwill end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBadly, monsieur, badly!\xe2\x80\x9d replied a voice which the young man\r\nrecognized as that of Planchet; for, soliloquizing aloud, as very\r\npreoccupied people do, he had entered the alley, at the end of which\r\nwere the stairs which led to his chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, badly? What do you mean by that, you idiot?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll sorts of misfortunes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, Monsieur Athos is arrested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArrested! Athos arrested! What for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was found in your lodging; they took him for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by whom was he arrested?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Guards brought by the men in black whom you put to flight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did he not tell them his name? Why did he not tell them he knew\r\nnothing about this affair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe took care not to do so, monsieur; on the contrary, he came up to me\r\nand said, \xe2\x80\x98It is your master that needs his liberty at this moment and\r\nnot I, since he knows everything and I know nothing. They will believe\r\nhe is arrested, and that will give him time; in three days I will tell\r\nthem who I am, and they cannot fail to let me go.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo, Athos! Noble heart!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI know him well\r\nthere! And what did the officers do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour conveyed him away, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where\xe2\x80\x94to the Bastille or Fort\r\nl\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque. Two remained with the men in black, who rummaged every place\r\nand took all the papers. The last two mounted guard at the door during\r\nthis examination; then, when all was over, they went away, leaving the\r\nhouse empty and exposed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Porthos and Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could not find them; they did not come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they may come any moment, for you left word that I awaited them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, don\xe2\x80\x99t budge, then; if they come, tell them what has happened.\r\nLet them wait for me at the Pomme-de-Pin. Here it would be dangerous;\r\nthe house may be watched. I will run to Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville to tell\r\nthem all this, and will meet them there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you will remain; you are not afraid?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, coming back\r\nto recommend courage to his lackey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe easy, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet; \xe2\x80\x9cyou do not know me yet. I am brave\r\nwhen I set about it. It is all in beginning. Besides, I am a Picard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it is understood,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cyou would rather be killed\r\nthan desert your post?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur; and there is nothing I would not do to prove to\r\nMonsieur that I am attached to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself. \xe2\x80\x9cIt appears that the method I have\r\nadopted with this boy is decidedly the best. I shall use it again upon\r\noccasion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd with all the swiftness of his legs, already a little fatigued,\r\nhowever, with the perambulations of the day, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan directed his\r\ncourse toward M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was not at his h\xc3\xb4tel. His company was on guard at the\r\nLouvre; he was at the Louvre with his company.\r\n\r\nIt was necessary to reach M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; it was important that he\r\nshould be informed of what was passing. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan resolved to try and\r\nenter the Louvre. His costume of Guardsman in the company of M.\r\nDessessart ought to be his passport.\r\n\r\nHe therefore went down the Rue des Petits Augustins, and came up to the\r\nquay, in order to take the New Bridge. He had at first an idea of\r\ncrossing by the ferry; but on gaining the riverside, he had\r\nmechanically put his hand into his pocket, and perceived that he had\r\nnot wherewithal to pay his passage.\r\n\r\nAs he gained the top of the Rue Gu\xc3\xa9negaud, he saw two persons coming\r\nout of the Rue Dauphine whose appearance very much struck him. Of the\r\ntwo persons who composed this group, one was a man and the other a\r\nwoman. The woman had the outline of Mme. Bonacieux; the man resembled\r\nAramis so much as to be mistaken for him.\r\n\r\nBesides, the woman wore that black mantle which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could still\r\nsee outlined on the shutter of the Rue de Vaugirard and on the door of\r\nthe Rue de la Harpe; still further, the man wore the uniform of a\r\nMusketeer.\r\n\r\nThe woman\xe2\x80\x99s hood was pulled down, and the man held a handkerchief to\r\nhis face. Both, as this double precaution indicated, had an interest in\r\nnot being recognized.\r\n\r\nThey took the bridge. That was D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s road, as he was going to\r\nthe Louvre. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan followed them.\r\n\r\nHe had not gone twenty steps before he became convinced that the woman\r\nwas really Mme. Bonacieux and that the man was Aramis.\r\n\r\nHe felt at that instant all the suspicions of jealousy agitating his\r\nheart. He felt himself doubly betrayed, by his friend and by her whom\r\nhe already loved like a mistress. Mme. Bonacieux had declared to him,\r\nby all the gods, that she did not know Aramis; and a quarter of an hour\r\nafter having made this assertion, he found her hanging on the arm of\r\nAramis.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not reflect that he had only known the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s pretty\r\nwife for three hours; that she owed him nothing but a little gratitude\r\nfor having delivered her from the men in black, who wished to carry her\r\noff, and that she had promised him nothing. He considered himself an\r\noutraged, betrayed, and ridiculed lover. Blood and anger mounted to his\r\nface; he was resolved to unravel the mystery.\r\n\r\nThe young man and young woman perceived they were watched, and\r\nredoubled their speed. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan determined upon his course. He passed\r\nthem, then returned so as to meet them exactly before the Samaritaine,\r\nwhich was illuminated by a lamp which threw its light over all that\r\npart of the bridge.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stopped before them, and they stopped before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the Musketeer, recoiling a step,\r\nand with a foreign accent, which proved to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that he was\r\ndeceived in one of his conjectures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not Aramis!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, it is not Aramis; and by your exclamation I perceive you\r\nhave mistaken me for another, and pardon you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou pardon me?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cAllow me, then, to pass on, since it is\r\nnot with me you have anything to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, monsieur, it is not with you that I have anything to\r\ndo; it is with Madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith Madame! You do not know her,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are deceived, monsieur; I know her very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux; in a tone of reproach, \xe2\x80\x9cah, monsieur, I had\r\nyour promise as a soldier and your word as a gentleman. I hoped to be\r\nable to rely upon that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, embarrassed; \xe2\x80\x9cyou promised me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake my arm, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9cand let us continue our\r\nway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, however, stupefied, cast down, annihilated by all that\r\nhappened, stood, with crossed arms, before the Musketeer and Mme.\r\nBonacieux.\r\n\r\nThe Musketeer advanced two steps, and pushed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan aside with his\r\nhand. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan made a spring backward and drew his sword. At the same\r\ntime, and with the rapidity of lightning, the stranger drew his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of heaven, my Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux, throwing\r\nherself between the combatants and seizing the swords with her hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, enlightened by a sudden idea, \xe2\x80\x9cmy Lord!\r\nPardon me, monsieur, but you are not\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord the Duke of Buckingham,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, in an undertone;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand now you may ruin us all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, Madame, I ask a hundred pardons! But I love her, my Lord, and\r\nwas jealous. You know what it is to love, my Lord. Pardon me, and then\r\ntell me how I can risk my life to serve your Grace?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a brave young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Buckingham, holding out his hand to\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who pressed it respectfully. \xe2\x80\x9cYou offer me your services;\r\nwith the same frankness I accept them. Follow us at a distance of\r\ntwenty paces, as far as the Louvre, and if anyone watches us, slay\r\nhim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan placed his naked sword under his arm, allowed the duke and\r\nMme. Bonacieux to take twenty steps ahead, and then followed them,\r\nready to execute the instructions of the noble and elegant minister of\r\nCharles I.\r\n\r\nFortunately, he had no opportunity to give the duke this proof of his\r\ndevotion, and the young woman and the handsome Musketeer entered the\r\nLouvre by the wicket of the Echelle without any interference.\r\n\r\nAs for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he immediately repaired to the cabaret of the\r\nPomme-de-Pin, where he found Porthos and Aramis awaiting him. Without\r\ngiving them any explanation of the alarm and inconvenience he had\r\ncaused them, he told them that he had terminated the affair alone in\r\nwhich he had for a moment believed he should need their assistance.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, carried away as we are by our narrative, we must leave our\r\nthree friends to themselves, and follow the Duke of Buckingham and his\r\nguide through the labyrinths of the Louvre.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XII.\r\nGEORGE VILLIERS, DUKE OF BUCKINGHAM\r\n\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux and the duke entered the Louvre without difficulty. Mme.\r\nBonacieux was known to belong to the queen; the duke wore the uniform\r\nof the Musketeers of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who, as we have said, were that\r\nevening on guard. Besides, Germain was in the interests of the queen;\r\nand if anything should happen, Mme. Bonacieux would be accused of\r\nhaving introduced her lover into the Louvre, that was all. She took the\r\nrisk upon herself.
