Her reputation would be lost, it is true; but of\r\nwhat value in the world was the reputation of the little wife of a\r\nmercer?\r\n\r\nOnce within the interior of the court, the duke and the young woman\r\nfollowed the wall for the space of about twenty-five steps. This space\r\npassed, Mme. Bonacieux pushed a little servants\xe2\x80\x99 door, open by day but\r\ngenerally closed at night. The door yielded. Both entered, and found\r\nthemselves in darkness; but Mme. Bonacieux was acquainted with all the\r\nturnings and windings of this part of the Louvre, appropriated for the\r\npeople of the household. She closed the door after her, took the duke\r\nby the hand, and after a few experimental steps, grasped a balustrade,\r\nput her foot upon the bottom step, and began to ascend the staircase.\r\nThe duke counted two stories. She then turned to the right, followed\r\nthe course of a long corridor, descended a flight, went a few steps\r\nfarther, introduced a key into a lock, opened a door, and pushed the\r\nduke into an apartment lighted only by a lamp, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cRemain here, my\r\nLord Duke; someone will come.\xe2\x80\x9d She then went out by the same door,\r\nwhich she locked, so that the duke found himself literally a prisoner.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, isolated as he was, we must say that the Duke of\r\nBuckingham did not experience an instant of fear. One of the salient\r\npoints of his character was the search for adventures and a love of\r\nromance. Brave, rash, and enterprising, this was not the first time he\r\nhad risked his life in such attempts. He had learned that the pretended\r\nmessage from Anne of Austria, upon the faith of which he had come to\r\nParis, was a snare; but instead of regaining England, he had, abusing\r\nthe position in which he had been placed, declared to the queen that he\r\nwould not depart without seeing her. The queen had at first positively\r\nrefused; but at length became afraid that the duke, if exasperated,\r\nwould commit some folly. She had already decided upon seeing him and\r\nurging his immediate departure, when, on the very evening of coming to\r\nthis decision, Mme. Bonacieux, who was charged with going to fetch the\r\nduke and conducting him to the Louvre, was abducted. For two days no\r\none knew what had become of her, and everything remained in suspense;\r\nbut once free, and placed in communication with Laporte, matters\r\nresumed their course, and she accomplished the perilous enterprise\r\nwhich, but for her arrest, would have been executed three days earlier.\r\n\r\nBuckingham, left alone, walked toward a mirror. His Musketeer\xe2\x80\x99s uniform\r\nbecame him marvelously.\r\n\r\nAt thirty-five, which was then his age, he passed, with just title, for\r\nthe handsomest gentleman and the most elegant cavalier of France or\r\nEngland.\r\n\r\nThe favorite of two kings, immensely rich, all-powerful in a kingdom\r\nwhich he disordered at his fancy and calmed again at his caprice,\r\nGeorge Villiers, Duke of Buckingham, had lived one of those fabulous\r\nexistences which survive, in the course of centuries, to astonish\r\nposterity.\r\n\r\nSure of himself, convinced of his own power, certain that the laws\r\nwhich rule other men could not reach him, he went straight to the\r\nobject he aimed at, even were this object so elevated and so dazzling\r\nthat it would have been madness for any other even to have contemplated\r\nit. It was thus he had succeeded in approaching several times the\r\nbeautiful and proud Anne of Austria, and in making himself loved by\r\ndazzling her.\r\n\r\nGeorge Villiers placed himself before the glass, as we have said,\r\nrestored the undulations to his beautiful hair, which the weight of his\r\nhat had disordered, twisted his mustache, and, his heart swelling with\r\njoy, happy and proud at being near the moment he had so long sighed\r\nfor, he smiled upon himself with pride and hope.\r\n\r\nAt this moment a door concealed in the tapestry opened, and a woman\r\nappeared. Buckingham saw this apparition in the glass; he uttered a\r\ncry. It was the queen!\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria was then twenty-six or twenty-seven years of age; that\r\nis to say, she was in the full splendor of her beauty.\r\n\r\nHer carriage was that of a queen or a goddess; her eyes, which cast the\r\nbrilliancy of emeralds, were perfectly beautiful, and yet were at the\r\nsame time full of sweetness and majesty.\r\n\r\nHer mouth was small and rosy; and although her underlip, like that of\r\nall princes of the House of Austria, protruded slightly beyond the\r\nother, it was eminently lovely in its smile, but as profoundly\r\ndisdainful in its contempt.\r\n\r\nHer skin was admired for its velvety softness; her hands and arms were\r\nof surpassing beauty, all the poets of the time singing them as\r\nincomparable.\r\n\r\nLastly, her hair, which, from being light in her youth, had become\r\nchestnut, and which she wore curled very plainly, and with much powder,\r\nadmirably set off her face, in which the most rigid critic could only\r\nhave desired a little less rouge, and the most fastidious sculptor a\r\nlittle more fineness in the nose.\r\n\r\nBuckingham remained for a moment dazzled. Never had Anne of Austria\r\nappeared to him so beautiful, amid balls, f\xc3\xaates, or carousals, as she\r\nappeared to him at this moment, dressed in a simple robe of white\r\nsatin, and accompanied by Donna Estafania\xe2\x80\x94the only one of her Spanish\r\nwomen who had not been driven from her by the jealousy of the king or\r\nby the persecutions of Richelieu.\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria took two steps forward. Buckingham threw himself at her\r\nfeet, and before the queen could prevent him, kissed the hem of her\r\nrobe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuke, you already know that it is not I who caused you to be written\r\nto.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, madame! Yes, your Majesty!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the duke. \xe2\x80\x9cI know that I\r\nmust have been mad, senseless, to believe that snow would become\r\nanimated or marble warm; but what then! They who love believe easily in\r\nlove. Besides, I have lost nothing by this journey because I see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Anne, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you know why and how I see you; because,\r\ninsensible to all my sufferings, you persist in remaining in a city\r\nwhere, by remaining, you run the risk of your life, and make me run the\r\nrisk of my honor. I see you to tell you that everything separates\r\nus\xe2\x80\x94the depths of the sea, the enmity of kingdoms, the sanctity of vows.\r\nIt is sacrilege to struggle against so many things, my Lord. In short,\r\nI see you to tell you that we must never see each other again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak on, madame, speak on, Queen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Buckingham; \xe2\x80\x9cthe sweetness of\r\nyour voice covers the harshness of your words. You talk of sacrilege!\r\nWhy, the sacrilege is the separation of two hearts formed by God for\r\neach other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the queen, \xe2\x80\x9cyou forget that I have never said that I\r\nlove you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you have never told me that you did not love me; and truly, to\r\nspeak such words to me would be, on the part of your Majesty, too great\r\nan ingratitude. For tell me, where can you find a love like mine\xe2\x80\x94a love\r\nwhich neither time, nor absence, nor despair can extinguish, a love\r\nwhich contents itself with a lost ribbon, a stray look, or a chance\r\nword? It is now three years, madame, since I saw you for the first\r\ntime, and during those three years I have loved you thus. Shall I tell\r\nyou each ornament of your toilet? Mark! I see you now. You were seated\r\nupon cushions in the Spanish fashion; you wore a robe of green satin\r\nembroidered with gold and silver, hanging sleeves knotted upon your\r\nbeautiful arms\xe2\x80\x94those lovely arms\xe2\x80\x94with large diamonds. You wore a close\r\nruff, a small cap upon your head of the same color as your robe, and in\r\nthat cap a heron\xe2\x80\x99s feather. Hold! Hold! I shut my eyes, and I can see\r\nyou as you then were; I open them again, and I see what you are now\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nhundred times more beautiful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat folly,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Anne of Austria, who had not the courage to find\r\nfault with the duke for having so well preserved her portrait in his\r\nheart, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat folly to feed a useless passion with such remembrances!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd upon what then must I live? I have nothing but memory. It is my\r\nhappiness, my treasure, my hope. Every time I see you is a fresh\r\ndiamond which I enclose in the casket of my heart. This is the fourth\r\nwhich you have let fall and I have picked up; for in three years,\r\nmadame, I have only seen you four times\xe2\x80\x94the first, which I have\r\ndescribed to you; the second, at the mansion of Madame de Chevreuse;\r\nthe third, in the gardens of Amiens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDuke,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen, blushing, \xe2\x80\x9cnever speak of that evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, let us speak of it; on the contrary, let us speak of it! That is\r\nthe most happy and brilliant evening of my life! You remember what a\r\nbeautiful night it was? How soft and perfumed was the air; how lovely\r\nthe blue heavens and star-enameled sky! Ah, then, madame, I was able\r\nfor one instant to be alone with you. Then you were about to tell me\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94the isolation of your life, the griefs of your heart. You leaned\r\nupon my arm\xe2\x80\x94upon this, madame! I felt, in bending my head toward you,\r\nyour beautiful hair touch my cheek; and every time that it touched me I\r\ntrembled from head to foot. Oh, Queen! Queen! You do not know what\r\nfelicity from heaven, what joys from paradise, are comprised in a\r\nmoment like that. Take my wealth, my fortune, my glory, all the days I\r\nhave to live, for such an instant, for a night like that. For that\r\nnight, madame, that night you loved me, I will swear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, yes; it is possible that the influence of the place, the\r\ncharm of the beautiful evening, the fascination of your look\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nthousand circumstances, in short, which sometimes unite to destroy a\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x94were grouped around me on that fatal evening; but, my Lord, you\r\nsaw the queen come to the aid of the woman who faltered. At the first\r\nword you dared to utter, at the first freedom to which I had to reply,\r\nI called for help.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, that is true. And any other love but mine would have sunk\r\nbeneath this ordeal; but my love came out from it more ardent and more\r\neternal. You believed that you would fly from me by returning to Paris;\r\nyou believed that I would not dare to quit the treasure over which my\r\nmaster had charged me to watch. What to me were all the treasures in\r\nthe world, or all the kings of the earth! Eight days after, I was back\r\nagain, madame. That time you had nothing to say to me; I had risked my\r\nlife and favor to see you but for a second. I did not even touch your\r\nhand, and you pardoned me on seeing me so submissive and so repentant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but calumny seized upon all those follies in which I took no\r\npart, as you well know, my Lord. The king, excited by the cardinal,\r\nmade a terrible clamor. Madame de Vernet was driven from me, Putange\r\nwas exiled, Madame de Chevreuse fell into disgrace, and when you wished\r\nto come back as ambassador to France, the king himself\xe2\x80\x94remember, my\r\nlord\xe2\x80\x94the king himself opposed it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and France is about to pay for her king\xe2\x80\x99s refusal with a war. I\r\nam not allowed to see you, madame, but you shall every day hear of me.\r\nWhat object, think you, have this expedition to R\xc3\xa9 and this league with\r\nthe Protestants of La Rochelle which I am projecting? The pleasure of\r\nseeing you. I have no hope of penetrating, sword in hand, to Paris, I\r\nknow that well. But this war may bring round a peace; this peace will\r\nrequire a negotiator; that negotiator will be me. They will not dare to\r\nrefuse me then; and I will return to Paris, and will see you again, and\r\nwill be happy for an instant. Thousands of men, it is true, will have\r\nto pay for my happiness with their lives; but what is that to me,\r\nprovided I see you again! All this is perhaps folly\xe2\x80\x94perhaps insanity;\r\nbut tell me what woman has a lover more truly in love; what queen a\r\nservant more ardent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, my Lord, you invoke in your defense things which accuse you\r\nmore strongly. All these proofs of love which you would give me are\r\nalmost crimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you do not love me, madame! If you loved me, you would view\r\nall this otherwise. If you loved me, oh, if you loved me, that would be\r\ntoo great happiness, and I should run mad. Ah, Madame de Chevreuse was\r\nless cruel than you. Holland loved her, and she responded to his love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Chevreuse was not queen,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Anne of Austria,\r\novercome, in spite of herself, by the expression of so profound a\r\npassion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would love me, then, if you were not queen! Madame, say that you\r\nwould love me then! I can believe that it is the dignity of your rank\r\nalone which makes you cruel to me; I can believe that, had you been\r\nMadame de Chevreuse, poor Buckingham might have hoped. Thanks for those\r\nsweet words! Oh, my beautiful sovereign, a hundred times, thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my Lord! You have ill understood, wrongly interpreted; I did not\r\nmean to say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, silence!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the duke. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I am happy in an error, do not\r\nhave the cruelty to lift me from it. You have told me yourself, madame,\r\nthat I have been drawn into a snare; I, perhaps, may leave my life in\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94for, although it may be strange, I have for some time had a\r\npresentiment that I should shortly die.\xe2\x80\x9d And the duke smiled, with a\r\nsmile at once sad and charming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anne of Austria, with an accent of terror which\r\nproved how much greater an interest she took in the duke than she\r\nventured to tell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not tell you this, madame, to terrify you; no, it is even\r\nridiculous for me to name it to you, and, believe me, I take no heed of\r\nsuch dreams. But the words you have just spoken, the hope you have\r\nalmost given me, will have richly paid all\xe2\x80\x94were it my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne, \xe2\x80\x9cI also, duke, have had presentiments; I also\r\nhave had dreams. I dreamed that I saw you lying bleeding, wounded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the left side, was it not, and with a knife?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted\r\nBuckingham.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it was so, my Lord, it was so\xe2\x80\x94in the left side, and with a knife.\r\nWho can possibly have told you I had had that dream? I have imparted it\r\nto no one but my God, and that in my prayers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask for no more. You love me, madame; it is enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love you, I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes. Would God send the same dreams to you as to me if you did\r\nnot love me? Should we have the same presentiments if our existences\r\ndid not touch at the heart? You love me, my beautiful queen, and you\r\nwill weep for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anne of Austria, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is more than I can\r\nbear. In the name of heaven, Duke, leave me, go! I do not know whether\r\nI love you or love you not; but what I know is that I will not be\r\nperjured. Take pity on me, then, and go! Oh, if you are struck in\r\nFrance, if you die in France, if I could imagine that your love for me\r\nwas the cause of your death, I could not console myself; I should run\r\nmad. Depart then, depart, I implore you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, how beautiful you are thus! Oh, how I love you!\xe2\x80\x9d said Buckingham.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, go, I implore you, and return hereafter! Come back as ambassador,\r\ncome back as minister, come back surrounded with guards who will defend\r\nyou, with servants who will watch over you, and then I shall no longer\r\nfear for your days, and I shall be happy in seeing you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, is this true what you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, then, some pledge of your indulgence, some object which came from\r\nyou, and may remind me that I have not been dreaming; something you\r\nhave worn, and that I may wear in my turn\xe2\x80\x94a ring, a necklace, a chain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you depart\xe2\x80\x94will you depart, if I give you that you demand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis very instant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will leave France, you will return to England?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will, I swear to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, then, wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria re-entered her apartment, and came out again almost\r\nimmediately, holding a rosewood casket in her hand, with her cipher\r\nencrusted with gold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, my Lord, here,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9ckeep this in memory of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBuckingham took the casket, and fell a second time on his knees.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have promised me to go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I keep my word. Your hand, madame, your hand, and I depart!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria stretched forth her hand, closing her eyes, and leaning\r\nwith the other upon Estafania, for she felt that her strength was about\r\nto fail her.\r\n\r\nBuckingham pressed his lips passionately to that beautiful hand, and\r\nthen rising, said, \xe2\x80\x9cWithin six months, if I am not dead, I shall have\r\nseen you again, madame\xe2\x80\x94even if I have to overturn the world.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nfaithful to the promise he had made, he rushed out of the apartment.\r\n\r\nIn the corridor he met Mme. Bonacieux, who waited for him, and who,\r\nwith the same precautions and the same good luck, conducted him out of\r\nthe Louvre.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XIII.\r\nMONSIEUR BONACIEUX\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was in all this, as may have been observed, one personage\r\nconcerned, of whom, notwithstanding his precarious position, we have\r\nappeared to take but very little notice. This personage was M.\r\nBonacieux, the respectable martyr of the political and amorous\r\nintrigues which entangled themselves so nicely together at this gallant\r\nand chivalric period.\r\n\r\nFortunately, the reader may remember, or may not remember\xe2\x80\x94fortunately\r\nwe have promised not to lose sight of him.\r\n\r\nThe officers who arrested him conducted him straight to the Bastille,\r\nwhere he passed trembling before a party of soldiers who were loading\r\ntheir muskets. Thence, introduced into a half-subterranean gallery, he\r\nbecame, on the part of those who had brought him, the object of the\r\ngrossest insults and the harshest treatment. The officers perceived\r\nthat they had not to deal with a gentleman, and they treated him like a\r\nvery peasant.\r\n\r\nAt the end of half an hour or thereabouts, a clerk came to put an end\r\nto his tortures, but not to his anxiety, by giving the order to conduct\r\nM. Bonacieux to the Chamber of Examination. Ordinarily, prisoners were\r\ninterrogated in their cells; but they did not do so with M. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\nTwo guards attended the mercer who made him traverse a court and enter\r\na corridor in which were three sentinels, opened a door and pushed him\r\nunceremoniously into a low room, where the only furniture was a table,\r\na chair, and a commissary. The commissary was seated in the chair, and\r\nwas writing at the table.\r\n\r\nThe two guards led the prisoner toward the table, and upon a sign from\r\nthe commissary drew back so far as to be unable to hear anything.\r\n\r\nThe commissary, who had till this time held his head down over his\r\npapers, looked up to see what sort of person he had to do with. This\r\ncommissary was a man of very repulsive mien, with a pointed nose, with\r\nyellow and salient cheek bones, with eyes small but keen and\r\npenetrating, and an expression of countenance resembling at once the\r\npolecat and the fox. His head, supported by a long and flexible neck,\r\nissued from his large black robe, balancing itself with a motion very\r\nmuch like that of the tortoise thrusting his head out of his shell. He\r\nbegan by asking M. Bonacieux his name, age, condition, and abode.\r\n\r\nThe accused replied that his name was Jacques Michel Bonacieux, that he\r\nwas fifty-one years old, a retired mercer, and lived Rue des\r\nFossoyeurs, No. 14.\r\n\r\nThe commissary then, instead of continuing to interrogate him, made him\r\na long speech upon the danger there is for an obscure citizen to meddle\r\nwith public matters. He complicated this exordium by an exposition in\r\nwhich he painted the power and the deeds of the cardinal, that\r\nincomparable minister, that conqueror of past ministers, that example\r\nfor ministers to come\xe2\x80\x94deeds and power which none could thwart with\r\nimpunity.\r\n\r\nAfter this second part of his discourse, fixing his hawk\xe2\x80\x99s eye upon\r\npoor Bonacieux, he bade him reflect upon the gravity of his situation.\r\n\r\nThe reflections of the mercer were already made; he cursed the instant\r\nwhen M. Laporte formed the idea of marrying him to his goddaughter, and\r\nparticularly the moment when that goddaughter had been received as Lady\r\nof the Linen to her Majesty.\r\n\r\nAt bottom the character of M. Bonacieux was one of profound selfishness\r\nmixed with sordid avarice, the whole seasoned with extreme cowardice.\r\nThe love with which his young wife had inspired him was a secondary\r\nsentiment, and was not strong enough to contend with the primitive\r\nfeelings we have just enumerated. Bonacieux indeed reflected on what\r\nhad just been said to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Monsieur Commissary,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, calmly, \xe2\x80\x9cbelieve that I know and\r\nappreciate, more than anybody, the merit of the incomparable eminence\r\nby whom we have the honor to be governed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the commissary, with an air of doubt. \xe2\x80\x9cIf that is\r\nreally so, how came you in the Bastille?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow I came there, or rather why I am there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nis entirely impossible for me to tell you, because I don\xe2\x80\x99t know myself;\r\nbut to a certainty it is not for having, knowingly at least, disobliged\r\nMonsieur the Cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must, nevertheless, have committed a crime, since you are here and\r\nare accused of high treason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf high treason!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, terrified; \xe2\x80\x9cof high treason! How is\r\nit possible for a poor mercer, who detests Huguenots and who abhors\r\nSpaniards, to be accused of high treason? Consider, monsieur, the thing\r\nis absolutely impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said the commissary, looking at the accused as if\r\nhis little eyes had the faculty of reading to the very depths of\r\nhearts, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have a wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the mercer, in a tremble, feeling that it was\r\nat this point affairs were likely to become perplexing; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is to\r\nsay, I _had_ one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you \xe2\x80\x98_had_ one\xe2\x80\x99? What have you done with her, then, if you have\r\nher no longer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have abducted her, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have abducted her? Ah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux inferred from this \xe2\x80\x9cAh\xe2\x80\x9d that the affair grew more and more\r\nintricate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have abducted her,\xe2\x80\x9d added the commissary; \xe2\x80\x9cand do you know the\r\nman who has committed this deed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember that I affirm nothing, Monsieur the Commissary, and that I\r\nonly suspect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom do you suspect? Come, answer freely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Bonacieux was in the greatest perplexity possible. Had he better\r\ndeny everything or tell everything? By denying all, it might be\r\nsuspected that he must know too much to avow; by confessing all he\r\nmight prove his good will. He decided, then, to tell all.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suspect,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9ca tall, dark man, of lofty carriage, who has the\r\nair of a great lord. He has followed us several times, as I think, when\r\nI have waited for my wife at the wicket of the Louvre to escort her\r\nhome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe commissary now appeared to experience a little uneasiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd his name?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, as to his name, I know nothing about it; but if I were ever to\r\nmeet him, I should recognize him in an instant, I will answer for it,\r\nwere he among a thousand persons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe face of the commissary grew still darker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should recognize him among a thousand, say you?\xe2\x80\x9d continued he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, who saw he had taken a false step,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat is to say\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have answered that you should recognize him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the commissary.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is all very well, and enough for today; before we proceed\r\nfurther, someone must be informed that you know the ravisher of your\r\nwife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I have not told you that I know him!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, in despair.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you, on the contrary\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake away the prisoner,\xe2\x80\x9d said the commissary to the two guards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere must we place him?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded the chief.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn a dungeon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord! In the first one handy, provided it is safe,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncommissary, with an indifference which penetrated poor Bonacieux with\r\nhorror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, alas!\xe2\x80\x9d said he to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cmisfortune is over my head; my wife\r\nmust have committed some frightful crime. They believe me her\r\naccomplice, and will punish me with her. She must have spoken; she must\r\nhave confessed everything\xe2\x80\x94a woman is so weak! A dungeon! The first he\r\ncomes to! That\xe2\x80\x99s it! A night is soon passed; and tomorrow to the wheel,\r\nto the gallows! Oh, my God, my God, have pity on me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout listening the least in the world to the lamentations of M.\r\nBonacieux\xe2\x80\x94lamentations to which, besides, they must have been pretty\r\nwell accustomed\xe2\x80\x94the two guards took the prisoner each by an arm, and\r\nled him away, while the commissary wrote a letter in haste and\r\ndispatched it by an officer in waiting.\r\n\r\nBonacieux could not close his eyes; not because his dungeon was so very\r\ndisagreeable, but because his uneasiness was so great. He sat all night\r\non his stool, starting at the least noise; and when the first rays of\r\nthe sun penetrated into his chamber, the dawn itself appeared to him to\r\nhave taken funereal tints.\r\n\r\nAll at once he heard his bolts drawn, and made a terrified bound. He\r\nbelieved they were come to conduct him to the scaffold; so that when he\r\nsaw merely and simply, instead of the executioner he expected, only his\r\ncommissary of the preceding evening, attended by his clerk, he was\r\nready to embrace them both.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour affair has become more complicated since yesterday evening, my\r\ngood man, and I advise you to tell the whole truth; for your repentance\r\nalone can remove the anger of the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I am ready to tell everything,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cat least, all\r\nthat I know. Interrogate me, I entreat you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is your wife, in the first place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, did not I tell you she had been stolen from me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but yesterday at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon, thanks to you,\r\nshe escaped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy wife escaped!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, unfortunate creature!\r\nMonsieur, if she has escaped, it is not my fault, I swear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat business had you, then, to go into the chamber of Monsieur\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, your neighbor, with whom you had a long conference during\r\nthe day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes, Monsieur Commissary; yes, that is true, and I confess that I\r\nwas in the wrong. I did go to Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the aim of that visit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo beg him to assist me in finding my wife. I believed I had a right\r\nto endeavor to find her. I was deceived, as it appears, and I ask your\r\npardon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan reply?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan promised me his assistance; but I soon found out\r\nthat he was betraying me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou impose upon justice. Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan made a compact with you;\r\nand in virtue of that compact put to flight the police who had arrested\r\nyour wife, and has placed her beyond reach.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cM. d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan has abducted my wife! Come now, what are you telling\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortunately, Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is in our hands, and you shall be\r\nconfronted with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my faith, I ask no better,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cI shall not be sorry\r\nto see the face of an acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring in the Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said the commissary to the guards.\r\nThe two guards led in Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said the commissary, addressing Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cdeclare\r\nall that passed yesterday between you and Monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is not Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan whom you show\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Not Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the commissary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the least in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the commissary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you; I don\xe2\x80\x99t know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow! You don\xe2\x80\x99t know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you never see him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have seen him, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what he calls himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour name?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the commissary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Musketeer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not a man\xe2\x80\x99s name; that is the name of a mountain,\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nthe poor questioner, who began to lose his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is my name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you said that your name was D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomebody said to me, \xe2\x80\x98You are Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x99 I answered, \xe2\x80\x98You\r\nthink so?\xe2\x80\x99 My guards exclaimed that they were sure of it. I did not\r\nwish to contradict them; besides, I might be deceived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, you insult the majesty of justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, calmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, monsieur, that you say it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I tell you, Monsieur Commissary,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, in his turn,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthere is not the least doubt about the matter. Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is\r\nmy tenant, although he does not pay me my rent\xe2\x80\x94and even better on that\r\naccount ought I to know him. Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is a young man,\r\nscarcely nineteen or twenty, and this gentleman must be thirty at\r\nleast. Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is in Monsieur Dessessart\xe2\x80\x99s Guards, and this\r\ngentleman is in the company of Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers. Look\r\nat his uniform, Monsieur Commissary, look at his uniform!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the commissary; \xe2\x80\x9c_pardieu_, that\xe2\x80\x99s true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this moment the door was opened quickly, and a messenger, introduced\r\nby one of the gatekeepers of the Bastille, gave a letter to the\r\ncommissary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, unhappy woman!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the commissary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? What do you say? Of whom do you speak? It is not of my wife, I\r\nhope!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, it is of her. Yours is a pretty business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said the agitated mercer, \xe2\x80\x9cdo me the pleasure, monsieur, to tell\r\nme how my own proper affair can become worse by anything my wife does\r\nwhile I am in prison?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause that which she does is part of a plan concerted between you\xe2\x80\x94of\r\nan infernal plan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you, Monsieur Commissary, that you are in the profoundest\r\nerror, that I know nothing in the world about what my wife had to do,\r\nthat I am entirely a stranger to what she has done; and that if she has\r\ncommitted any follies, I renounce her, I abjure her, I curse her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos to the commissary, \xe2\x80\x9cif you have no more need of me,\r\nsend me somewhere. Your Monsieur Bonacieux is very tiresome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe commissary designated by the same gesture Athos and Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cLet\r\nthem be guarded more closely than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, with his habitual calmness, \xe2\x80\x9cif it be Monsieur\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan who is concerned in this matter, I do not perceive how I can\r\ntake his place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo as I bade you,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the commissary, \xe2\x80\x9cand preserve absolute\r\nsecrecy. You understand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos shrugged his shoulders, and followed his guards silently, while\r\nM. Bonacieux uttered lamentations enough to break the heart of a tiger.\r\n\r\nThey locked the mercer in the same dungeon where he had passed the\r\nnight, and left him to himself during the day. Bonacieux wept all day,\r\nlike a true mercer, not being at all a military man, as he himself\r\ninformed us. In the evening, about nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, at the moment he had\r\nmade up his mind to go to bed, he heard steps in his corridor. These\r\nsteps drew near to his dungeon, the door was thrown open, and the\r\nguards appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow me,\xe2\x80\x9d said an officer, who came up behind the guards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFollow you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cfollow you at this hour! Where, my\r\nGod?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere we have orders to lead you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not an answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, nevertheless, the only one we can give.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the poor mercer, \xe2\x80\x9cnow, indeed, I am\r\nlost!\xe2\x80\x9d And he followed the guards who came for him, mechanically and\r\nwithout resistance.\r\n\r\nHe passed along the same corridor as before, crossed one court, then a\r\nsecond side of a building; at length, at the gate of the entrance court\r\nhe found a carriage surrounded by four guards on horseback. They made\r\nhim enter this carriage, the officer placed himself by his side, the\r\ndoor was locked, and they were left in a rolling prison. The carriage\r\nwas put in motion as slowly as a funeral car. Through the closely\r\nfastened windows the prisoner could perceive the houses and the\r\npavement, that was all; but, true Parisian as he was, Bonacieux could\r\nrecognize every street by the milestones, the signs, and the lamps. At\r\nthe moment of arriving at St. Paul\xe2\x80\x94the spot where such as were\r\ncondemned at the Bastille were executed\xe2\x80\x94he was near fainting and\r\ncrossed himself twice. He thought the carriage was about to stop there.\r\nThe carriage, however, passed on.\r\n\r\nFarther on, a still greater terror seized him on passing by the\r\ncemetery of St. Jean, where state criminals were buried. One thing,\r\nhowever, reassured him; he remembered that before they were buried\r\ntheir heads were generally cut off, and he felt that his head was still\r\non his shoulders. But when he saw the carriage take the way to La\r\nGr\xc3\xaave, when he perceived the pointed roof of the H\xc3\xb4tel de Ville, and\r\nthe carriage passed under the arcade, he believed it was over with him.\r\nHe wished to confess to the officer, and upon his refusal, uttered such\r\npitiable cries that the officer told him that if he continued to deafen\r\nhim thus, he should put a gag in his mouth.\r\n\r\nThis measure somewhat reassured Bonacieux. If they meant to execute him\r\nat La Gr\xc3\xaave, it could scarcely be worth while to gag him, as they had\r\nnearly reached the place of execution. Indeed, the carriage crossed the\r\nfatal spot without stopping. There remained, then, no other place to\r\nfear but the Traitor\xe2\x80\x99s Cross; the carriage was taking the direct road\r\nto it.\r\n\r\nThis time there was no longer any doubt; it was at the Traitor\xe2\x80\x99s Cross\r\nthat lesser criminals were executed. Bonacieux had flattered himself in\r\nbelieving himself worthy of St. Paul or of the Place de Gr\xc3\xaave; it was\r\nat the Traitor\xe2\x80\x99s Cross that his journey and his destiny were about to\r\nend! He could not yet see that dreadful cross, but he felt somehow as\r\nif it were coming to meet him. When he was within twenty paces of it,\r\nhe heard a noise of people and the carriage stopped. This was more than\r\npoor Bonacieux could endure, depressed as he was by the successive\r\nemotions which he had experienced; he uttered a feeble groan which\r\nmight have been taken for the last sigh of a dying man, and fainted.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XIV.\r\nTHE MAN OF MEUNG\r\n\r\n\r\nThe crowd was caused, not by the expectation of a man to be hanged, but\r\nby the contemplation of a man who was hanged.\r\n\r\nThe carriage, which had been stopped for a minute, resumed its way,\r\npassed through the crowd, threaded the Rue St. Honor\xc3\xa9, turned into the\r\nRue des Bons Enfants, and stopped before a low door.\r\n\r\nThe door opened; two guards received Bonacieux in their arms from the\r\nofficer who supported him. They carried him through an alley, up a\r\nflight of stairs, and deposited him in an antechamber.\r\n\r\nAll these movements had been effected mechanically, as far as he was\r\nconcerned. He had walked as one walks in a dream; he had a glimpse of\r\nobjects as through a fog. His ears had perceived sounds without\r\ncomprehending them; he might have been executed at that moment without\r\nhis making a single gesture in his own defense or uttering a cry to\r\nimplore mercy.\r\n\r\nHe remained on the bench, with his back leaning against the wall and\r\nhis hands hanging down, exactly on the spot where the guards placed\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nOn looking around him, however, as he could perceive no threatening\r\nobject, as nothing indicated that he ran any real danger, as the bench\r\nwas comfortably covered with a well-stuffed cushion, as the wall was\r\nornamented with a beautiful Cordova leather, and as large red damask\r\ncurtains, fastened back by gold clasps, floated before the window, he\r\nperceived by degrees that his fear was exaggerated, and he began to\r\nturn his head to the right and the left, upward and downward.\r\n\r\nAt this movement, which nobody opposed, he resumed a little courage,\r\nand ventured to draw up one leg and then the other. At length, with the\r\nhelp of his two hands he lifted himself from the bench, and found\r\nhimself on his feet.\r\n\r\nAt this moment an officer with a pleasant face opened a door, continued\r\nto exchange some words with a person in the next chamber and then came\r\nup to the prisoner. \xe2\x80\x9cIs your name Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Monsieur Officer,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the mercer, more dead than alive,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cat your service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer.\r\n\r\nAnd he moved out of the way to let the mercer pass. The latter obeyed\r\nwithout reply, and entered the chamber, where he appeared to be\r\nexpected.\r\n\r\nIt was a large cabinet, close and stifling, with the walls furnished\r\nwith arms offensive and defensive, and in which there was already a\r\nfire, although it was scarcely the end of the month of September. A\r\nsquare table, covered with books and papers, upon which was unrolled an\r\nimmense plan of the city of La Rochelle, occupied the center of the\r\nroom.\r\n\r\nStanding before the chimney was a man of middle height, of a haughty,\r\nproud mien; with piercing eyes, a large brow, and a thin face, which\r\nwas made still longer by a _royal_ (or _imperial_, as it is now\r\ncalled), surmounted by a pair of mustaches. Although this man was\r\nscarcely thirty-six or thirty-seven years of age, hair, mustaches, and\r\nroyal, all began to be gray. This man, except a sword, had all the\r\nappearance of a soldier; and his buff boots, still slightly covered\r\nwith dust, indicated that he had been on horseback in the course of the\r\nday.\r\n\r\nThis man was Armand Jean Duplessis, Cardinal de Richelieu; not such as\r\nhe is now represented\xe2\x80\x94broken down like an old man, suffering like a\r\nmartyr, his body bent, his voice failing, buried in a large armchair as\r\nin an anticipated tomb; no longer living but by the strength of his\r\ngenius, and no longer maintaining the struggle with Europe but by the\r\neternal application of his thoughts\xe2\x80\x94but such as he really was at this\r\nperiod; that is to say, an active and gallant cavalier, already weak of\r\nbody, but sustained by that moral power which made of him one of the\r\nmost extraordinary men that ever lived, preparing, after having\r\nsupported the Duc de Nevers in his duchy of Mantua, after having taken\r\nN\xc3\xaemes, Castres, and Uzes, to drive the English from the Isle of R\xc3\xa9 and\r\nlay siege to La Rochelle.\r\n\r\nAt first sight, nothing denoted the cardinal; and it was impossible for\r\nthose who did not know his face to guess in whose presence they were.\r\n\r\nThe poor mercer remained standing at the door, while the eyes of the\r\npersonage we have just described were fixed upon him, and appeared to\r\nwish to penetrate even into the depths of the past.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this that Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, after a moment of silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the officer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well. Give me those papers, and leave us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe officer took from the table the papers pointed out, gave them to\r\nhim who asked for them, bowed to the ground, and retired.\r\n\r\nBonacieux recognized in these papers his interrogatories of the\r\nBastille. From time to time the man by the chimney raised his eyes from\r\nthe writings, and plunged them like poniards into the heart of the poor\r\nmercer.\r\n\r\nAt the end of ten minutes of reading and ten seconds of examination,\r\nthe cardinal was satisfied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat head has never conspired,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it matters not; we\r\nwill see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are accused of high treason,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, slowly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo I have been told already, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, giving his\r\ninterrogator the title he had heard the officer give him, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I swear\r\nto you that I know nothing about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal repressed a smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have conspired with your wife, with Madame de Chevreuse, and with\r\nmy Lord Duke of Buckingham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d responded the mercer, \xe2\x80\x9cI have heard her\r\npronounce all those names.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd on what occasion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe said that the Cardinal de Richelieu had drawn the Duke of\r\nBuckingham to Paris to ruin him and to ruin the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe said that?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the cardinal, with violence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur, but I told her she was wrong to talk about such\r\nthings; and that his Eminence was incapable\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue! You are stupid,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s exactly what my wife said, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know who carried off your wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have suspicions, nevertheless?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur; but these suspicions appeared to be disagreeable to\r\nMonsieur the Commissary, and I no longer have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour wife has escaped. Did you know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monseigneur. I learned it since I have been in prison, and that\r\nfrom the conversation of Monsieur the Commissary\xe2\x80\x94an amiable man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal repressed another smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you are ignorant of what has become of your wife since her\r\nflight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely, monseigneur; but she has most likely returned to the\r\nLouvre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt one o\xe2\x80\x99clock this morning she had not returned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God! What can have become of her, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall know, be assured. Nothing is concealed from the cardinal; the\r\ncardinal knows everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, monseigneur, do you believe the cardinal will be so kind\r\nas to tell me what has become of my wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps he may; but you must, in the first place, reveal to the\r\ncardinal all you know of your wife\xe2\x80\x99s relations with Madame de\r\nChevreuse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, monseigneur, I know nothing about them; I have never seen her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you went to fetch your wife from the Louvre, did you always\r\nreturn directly home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScarcely ever; she had business to transact with linen drapers, to\r\nwhose houses I conducted her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how many were there of these linen drapers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where did they live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne in Rue de Vaugirard, the other Rue de la Harpe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you go into these houses with her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever, monseigneur; I waited at the door.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what excuse did she give you for entering all alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe gave me none; she told me to wait, and I waited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a very complacent husband, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nthe cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe calls me his dear Monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the mercer to himself. \xe2\x80\x9c_Peste!_\r\nMatters are going all right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShould you know those doors again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know the numbers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. 25 in the Rue de Vaugirard; 75 in the Rue de la Harpe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\nAt these words he took up a silver bell, and rang it; the officer\r\nentered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in a subdued voice, \xe2\x80\x9cand find Rochefort. Tell him to\r\ncome to me immediately, if he has returned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count is here,\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer, \xe2\x80\x9cand requests to speak with your\r\nEminence instantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him come in, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, quickly.\r\n\r\nThe officer sprang out of the apartment with that alacrity which all\r\nthe servants of the cardinal displayed in obeying him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo your Eminence!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Bonacieux, rolling his eyes round in\r\nastonishment.\r\n\r\nFive seconds has scarcely elapsed after the disappearance of the\r\nofficer, when the door opened, and a new personage entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe! What he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe man who abducted my wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal rang a second time. The officer reappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlace this man in the care of his guards again, and let him wait till\r\nI send for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monseigneur, no, it is not he!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cno, I was\r\ndeceived. This is quite another man, and does not resemble him at all.\r\nMonsieur is, I am sure, an honest man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake away that fool!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\nThe officer took Bonacieux by the arm, and led him into the\r\nantechamber, where he found his two guards.\r\n\r\nThe newly introduced personage followed Bonacieux impatiently with his\r\neyes till he had gone out; and the moment the door closed, \xe2\x80\x9cThey have\r\nseen each other;\xe2\x80\x9d said he, approaching the cardinal eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho?\xe2\x80\x9d asked his Eminence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe and she.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe queen and the duke?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Richelieu.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the Louvre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Lannoy, who is devoted to your Eminence, as you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did she not let me know sooner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether by chance or mistrust, the queen made Madame de Surgis sleep\r\nin her chamber, and detained her all day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we are beaten! Now let us try to take our revenge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will assist you with all my heart, monseigneur; be assured of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did it come about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt half past twelve the queen was with her women\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn her bedchamber\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen someone came and brought her a handkerchief from her laundress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe queen immediately exhibited strong emotion; and despite the rouge\r\nwith which her face was covered evidently turned pale\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then, and then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe then arose, and with altered voice, \xe2\x80\x98Ladies,\xe2\x80\x99 said she, \xe2\x80\x98wait for\r\nme ten minutes, I shall soon return.\xe2\x80\x99 She then opened the door of her\r\nalcove, and went out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did not Madame de Lannoy come and inform you instantly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing was certain; besides, her Majesty had said, \xe2\x80\x98Ladies, wait for\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x99 and she did not dare to disobey the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long did the queen remain out of the chamber?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree-quarters of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone of her women accompanied her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly Donna Estafania.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she afterward return?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but only to take a little rosewood casket, with her cipher upon\r\nit, and went out again immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when she finally returned, did she bring that casket with her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes Madame de Lannoy know what was in that casket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; the diamond studs which his Majesty gave the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she came back without this casket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame de Lannoy, then, is of opinion that she gave them to\r\nBuckingham?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is sure of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can she be so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the course of the day Madame de Lannoy, in her quality of\r\ntire-woman of the queen, looked for this casket, appeared uneasy at not\r\nfinding it, and at length asked information of the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then the queen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe queen became exceedingly red, and replied that having in the\r\nevening broken one of those studs, she had sent it to her goldsmith to\r\nbe repaired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must be called upon, and so ascertain if the thing be true or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just been with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the goldsmith?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe goldsmith has heard nothing of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well! Rochefort, all is not lost; and perhaps\xe2\x80\x94perhaps everything\r\nis for the best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is that I do not doubt your Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s genius\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill repair the blunders of his agent\xe2\x80\x94is that it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is exactly what I was going to say, if your Eminence had let me\r\nfinish my sentence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMeanwhile, do you know where the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of\r\nBuckingham are now concealed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monseigneur; my people could tell me nothing on that head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, monseigneur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; or at least I guess. They were, one in the Rue de Vaugirard, No.\r\n25; the other in the Rue de la Harpe, No. 75.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes your Eminence command that they both be instantly arrested?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt will be too late; they will be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut still, we can make sure that they are so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake ten men of my Guardsmen, and search the two houses thoroughly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstantly, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d And Rochefort went hastily out of the\r\napartment.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal, being left alone, reflected for an instant and then rang\r\nthe bell a third time. The same officer appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBring the prisoner in again,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\nM. Bonacieux was introduced afresh, and upon a sign from the cardinal,\r\nthe officer retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have deceived me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, sternly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cI deceive your Eminence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour wife, in going to Rue de Vaugirard and Rue de la Harpe, did not\r\ngo to find linen drapers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why did she go, just God?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe went to meet the Duchesse de Chevreuse and the Duke of\r\nBuckingham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux, recalling all his remembrances of the\r\ncircumstances, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, that\xe2\x80\x99s it. Your Eminence is right. I told my wife\r\nseveral times that it was surprising that linen drapers should live in\r\nsuch houses as those, in houses that had no signs; but she always\r\nlaughed at me. Ah, monseigneur!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Bonacieux, throwing himself\r\nat his Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s feet, \xe2\x80\x9cah, how truly you are the cardinal, the great\r\ncardinal, the man of genius whom all the world reveres!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal, however contemptible might be the triumph gained over so\r\nvulgar a being as Bonacieux, did not the less enjoy it for an instant;\r\nthen, almost immediately, as if a fresh thought has occurred, a smile\r\nplayed upon his lips, and he said, offering his hand to the mercer,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRise, my friend, you are a worthy man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal has touched me with his hand! I have touched the hand of\r\nthe great man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cThe great man has called me his\r\nfriend!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my friend, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, with that paternal tone which\r\nhe sometimes knew how to assume, but which deceived none who knew him;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand as you have been unjustly suspected, well, you must be\r\nindemnified. Here, take this purse of a hundred pistoles, and pardon\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pardon you, monseigneur!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, hesitating to take the\r\npurse, fearing, doubtless, that this pretended gift was but a\r\npleasantry. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you are able to have me arrested, you are able to have\r\nme tortured, you are able to have me hanged; you are the master, and I\r\ncould not have the least word to say. Pardon you, monseigneur! You\r\ncannot mean that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, you are generous in this matter. I see\r\nit and I thank you for it. Thus, then, you will take this bag, and you\r\nwill go away without being too malcontent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI go away enchanted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, then, or rather, _au revoir_, for I hope we shall meet\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever Monseigneur wishes, I am always at at his Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will be frequently, I assure you, for I have found something\r\nextremely agreeable in your conversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Monseigneur!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Au revoir_, Monsieur Bonacieux, _au revoir!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the cardinal made him a sign with his hand, to which Bonacieux\r\nreplied by bowing to the ground. He then went out backward, and when he\r\nwas in the antechamber the cardinal heard him, in his enthusiasm,\r\ncrying aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cLong life to the Monseigneur! Long life to his Eminence!\r\nLong life to the great cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d The cardinal listened with a smile to\r\nthis vociferous manifestation of the feelings of M. Bonacieux; and\r\nthen, when Bonacieux\xe2\x80\x99s cries were no longer audible, \xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat man would henceforward lay down his life for me.\xe2\x80\x9d And the\r\ncardinal began to examine with the greatest attention the map of La\r\nRochelle, which, as we have said, lay open on the desk, tracing with a\r\npencil the line in which the famous dyke was to pass which, eighteen\r\nmonths later, shut up the port of the besieged city. As he was in the\r\ndeepest of his strategic meditations, the door opened, and Rochefort\r\nreturned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, eagerly, rising with a promptitude which\r\nproved the degree of importance he attached to the commission with\r\nwhich he had charged the count.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, \xe2\x80\x9ca young woman of about twenty-six or\r\ntwenty-eight years of age, and a man of from thirty-five to forty, have\r\nindeed lodged at the two houses pointed out by your Eminence; but the\r\nwoman left last night, and the man this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was they!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the cardinal, looking at the clock; \xe2\x80\x9cand now it is\r\ntoo late to have them pursued. The duchess is at Tours, and the duke at\r\nBoulogne. It is in London they must be found.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are your Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s orders?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a word of what has passed. Let the queen remain in perfect\r\nsecurity; let her be ignorant that we know her secret. Let her believe\r\nthat we are in search of some conspiracy or other. Send me the keeper\r\nof the seals, S\xc3\xa9guier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that man, what has your Eminence done with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat man?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat Bonacieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have done with him all that could be done. I have made him a spy\r\nupon his wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Comte de Rochefort bowed like a man who acknowledges the\r\nsuperiority of the master as great, and retired.\r\n\r\nLeft alone, the cardinal seated himself again and wrote a letter, which\r\nhe secured with his special seal. Then he rang. The officer entered for\r\nthe fourth time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell Vitray to come to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand tell him to get ready for a\r\njourney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn instant after, the man he asked for was before him, booted and\r\nspurred.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVitray,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will go with all speed to London. You must not\r\nstop an instant on the way. You will deliver this letter to Milady.\r\nHere is an order for two hundred pistoles; call upon my treasurer and\r\nget the money. You shall have as much again if you are back within six\r\ndays, and have executed your commission well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe messenger, without replying a single word, bowed, took the letter,\r\nwith the order for the two hundred pistoles, and retired.\r\n\r\nHere is what the letter contained:\r\n\r\nMILADY, Be at the first ball at which the Duke of Buckingham shall be\r\npresent. He will wear on his doublet twelve diamond studs; get as near\r\nto him as you can, and cut off two.\r\n\r\nAs soon as these studs shall be in your possession, inform me.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XV.\r\nMEN OF THE ROBE AND MEN OF THE SWORD\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the day after these events had taken place, Athos not having\r\nreappeared, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was informed by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Porthos of\r\nthe circumstance. As to Aramis, he had asked for leave of absence for\r\nfive days, and was gone, it was said, to Rouen on family business.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was the father of his soldiers. The lowest or the least\r\nknown of them, as soon as he assumed the uniform of the company, was as\r\nsure of his aid and support as if he had been his own brother.\r\n\r\nHe repaired, then, instantly to the office of the\r\n_lieutenant-criminel_. The officer who commanded the post of the Red\r\nCross was sent for, and by successive inquiries they learned that Athos\r\nwas then lodged in Fort l\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque.\r\n\r\nAthos had passed through all the examinations we have seen Bonacieux\r\nundergo.\r\n\r\nWe were present at the scene in which the two captives were confronted\r\nwith each other. Athos, who had till that time said nothing for fear\r\nthat D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, interrupted in his turn, should not have the time\r\nnecessary, from this moment declared that his name was Athos, and not\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. He added that he did not know either M. or Mme. Bonacieux;\r\nthat he had never spoken to the one or the other; that he had come, at\r\nabout ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, to pay a visit to his friend M.\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, but that till that hour he had been at M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nwhere he had dined. \xe2\x80\x9cTwenty witnesses,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9ccould attest the\r\nfact\xe2\x80\x9d; and he named several distinguished gentlemen, and among them was\r\nM. le Duc de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille.\r\n\r\nThe second commissary was as much bewildered as the first had been by\r\nthe simple and firm declaration of the Musketeer, upon whom he was\r\nanxious to take the revenge which men of the robe like at all times to\r\ngain over men of the sword; but the name of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, and that of\r\nM. de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille, commanded a little reflection.\r\n\r\nAthos was then sent to the cardinal; but unfortunately the cardinal was\r\nat the Louvre with the king.\r\n\r\nIt was precisely at this moment that M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, on leaving the\r\nresidence of the _lieutenant-criminel_ and the governor of Fort\r\nl\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque without being able to find Athos, arrived at the palace.\r\n\r\nAs captain of the Musketeers, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville had the right of entry at\r\nall times.\r\n\r\nIt is well known how violent the king\xe2\x80\x99s prejudices were against the\r\nqueen, and how carefully these prejudices were kept up by the cardinal,\r\nwho in affairs of intrigue mistrusted women infinitely more than men.\r\nOne of the grand causes of this prejudice was the friendship of Anne of\r\nAustria for Mme. de Chevreuse. These two women gave him more uneasiness\r\nthan the war with Spain, the quarrel with England, or the embarrassment\r\nof the finances. In his eyes and to his conviction, Mme. de Chevreuse\r\nnot only served the queen in her political intrigues, but, what\r\ntormented him still more, in her amorous intrigues.\r\n\r\nAt the first word the cardinal spoke of Mme. de Chevreuse\xe2\x80\x94who, though\r\nexiled to Tours and believed to be in that city, had come to Paris,\r\nremained there five days, and outwitted the police\xe2\x80\x94the king flew into a\r\nfurious passion. Capricious and unfaithful, the king wished to be\r\ncalled Louis the Just and Louis the Chaste. Posterity will find a\r\ndifficulty in understanding this character, which history explains only\r\nby facts and never by reason.\r\n\r\nBut when the cardinal added that not only Mme. de Chevreuse had been in\r\nParis, but still further, that the queen had renewed with her one of\r\nthose mysterious correspondences which at that time was named a\r\n_cabal;_ when he affirmed that he, the cardinal, was about to unravel\r\nthe most closely twisted thread of this intrigue; that at the moment of\r\narresting in the very act, with all the proofs about her, the queen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nemissary to the exiled duchess, a Musketeer had dared to interrupt the\r\ncourse of justice violently, by falling sword in hand upon the honest\r\nmen of the law, charged with investigating impartially the whole affair\r\nin order to place it before the eyes of the king\xe2\x80\x94Louis XIII. could not\r\ncontain himself, and he made a step toward the queen\xe2\x80\x99s apartment with\r\nthat pale and mute indignation which, when it broke out, led this\r\nprince to the commission of the most pitiless cruelty. And yet, in all\r\nthis, the cardinal had not yet said a word about the Duke of\r\nBuckingham.\r\n\r\nAt this instant M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville entered, cool, polite, and in\r\nirreproachable costume.\r\n\r\nInformed of what had passed by the presence of the cardinal and the\r\nalteration in the king\xe2\x80\x99s countenance, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville felt himself\r\nsomething like Samson before the Philistines.\r\n\r\nLouis XIII. had already placed his hand on the knob of the door; at the\r\nnoise of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s entrance he turned round. \xe2\x80\x9cYou arrive in good\r\ntime, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, who, when his passions were raised to a\r\ncertain point, could not dissemble; \xe2\x80\x9cI have learned some fine things\r\nconcerning your Musketeers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, coldly, \xe2\x80\x9cI have some pretty things to tell your\r\nMajesty concerning these gownsmen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, with hauteur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have the honor to inform your Majesty,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, in\r\nthe same tone, \xe2\x80\x9cthat a party of _procureurs_, commissaries, and men of\r\nthe police\xe2\x80\x94very estimable people, but very inveterate, as it appears,\r\nagainst the uniform\xe2\x80\x94have taken upon themselves to arrest in a house, to\r\nlead away through the open street, and throw into Fort l\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque, all\r\nupon an order which they have refused to show me, one of my, or rather\r\nyour Musketeers, sire, of irreproachable conduct, of an almost\r\nillustrious reputation, and whom your Majesty knows favorably, Monsieur\r\nAthos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, mechanically; \xe2\x80\x9cyes, certainly I know that\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet your Majesty remember,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Monsieur Athos is the\r\nMusketeer who, in the annoying duel which you are acquainted with, had\r\nthe misfortune to wound Monsieur de Cahusac so seriously. _A propos_,\r\nmonseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Tr\xc3\xa9ville, addressing the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de\r\nCahusac is quite recovered, is he not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, biting his lips with anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos, then, went to pay a visit to one of his friends absent at the\r\ntime,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cto a young B\xc3\xa9arnais, a cadet in his\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s Guards, the company of Monsieur Dessessart, but scarcely had\r\nhe arrived at his friend\xe2\x80\x99s and taken up a book, while waiting his\r\nreturn, when a mixed crowd of bailiffs and soldiers came and laid siege\r\nto the house, broke open several doors\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal made the king a sign, which signified, \xe2\x80\x9cThat was on\r\naccount of the affair about which I spoke to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe all know that,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the king; \xe2\x80\x9cfor all that was done for\r\nour service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cit was also for your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s service that one\r\nof my Musketeers, who was innocent, has been seized, that he has been\r\nplaced between two guards like a malefactor, and that this gallant man,\r\nwho has ten times shed his blood in your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s service and is ready\r\nto shed it again, has been paraded through the midst of an insolent\r\npopulace?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, who began to be shaken, \xe2\x80\x9cwas it so managed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, with the greatest phlegm,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdoes not tell your Majesty that this innocent Musketeer, this gallant\r\nman, had only an hour before attacked, sword in hand, four commissaries\r\nof inquiry, who were delegated by myself to examine into an affair of\r\nthe highest importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI defy your Eminence to prove it,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Tr\xc3\xa9ville, with his Gascon\r\nfreedom and military frankness; \xe2\x80\x9cfor one hour before, Monsieur Athos,\r\nwho, I will confide it to your Majesty, is really a man of the highest\r\nquality, did me the honor after having dined with me to be conversing\r\nin the saloon of my h\xc3\xb4tel, with the Duc de la Tr\xc3\xa9mouille and the Comte\r\nde Ch\xc3\xa2lus, who happened to be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king looked at the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA written examination attests it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, replying aloud\r\nto the mute interrogation of his Majesty; \xe2\x80\x9cand the ill-treated people\r\nhave drawn up the following, which I have the honor to present to your\r\nMajesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd is the written report of the gownsmen to be placed in comparison\r\nwith the word of honor of a swordsman?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tr\xc3\xa9ville haughtily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come, Tr\xc3\xa9ville, hold your tongue,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf his Eminence entertains any suspicion against one of my\r\nMusketeers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cthe justice of Monsieur the Cardinal is so\r\nwell known that I demand an inquiry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the house in which the judicial inquiry was made,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\nimpassive cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthere lodges, I believe, a young B\xc3\xa9arnais, a\r\nfriend of the Musketeer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Eminence means Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean a young man whom you patronize, Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your Eminence, it is the same.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not suspect this young man of having given bad counsel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Athos, to a man double his age?\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Tr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\r\nmonseigneur. Besides, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan passed the evening with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9ceverybody seems to have passed the evening\r\nwith you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes your Eminence doubt my word?\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, with a brow flushed\r\nwith anger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, God forbid,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9conly, at what hour was he with\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, as to that I can speak positively, your Eminence; for as he came\r\nin I remarked that it was but half past nine by the clock, although I\r\nhad believed it to be later.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what hour did he leave your h\xc3\xb4tel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt half past ten\xe2\x80\x94an hour after the event.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal, who could not for an instant suspect the\r\nloyalty of Tr\xc3\xa9ville, and who felt that the victory was escaping him,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwell, but Athos _was_ taken in the house in the Rue des Fossoyeurs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs one friend forbidden to visit another, or a Musketeer of my company\r\nto fraternize with a Guard of Dessessart\xe2\x80\x99s company?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, when the house where he fraternizes is suspected.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat house is suspected, Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps you did\r\nnot know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, sire, I did not. The house may be suspected; but I deny that\r\nit is so in the part of it inhabited by Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, for I can\r\naffirm, sire, if I can believe what he says, that there does not exist\r\na more devoted servant of your Majesty, or a more profound admirer of\r\nMonsieur the Cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it not this D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan who wounded Jussac one day, in that\r\nunfortunate encounter which took place near the Convent of the\r\nCarmes-D\xc3\xa9chauss\xc3\xa9s?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the king, looking at the cardinal, who\r\ncolored with vexation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the next day, Bernajoux. Yes, sire, yes, it is the same; and your\r\nMajesty has a good memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, how shall we decide?\xe2\x80\x9d said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat concerns your Majesty more than me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cI should\r\naffirm the culpability.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I deny it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cBut his Majesty has judges, and these\r\njudges will decide.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is best,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king. \xe2\x80\x9cSend the case before the judges; it is\r\ntheir business to judge, and they shall judge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cit is a sad thing that in the unfortunate\r\ntimes in which we live, the purest life, the most incontestable virtue,\r\ncannot exempt a man from infamy and persecution. The army, I will\r\nanswer for it, will be but little pleased at being exposed to rigorous\r\ntreatment on account of police affairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe expression was imprudent; but M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville launched it with\r\nknowledge of his cause. He was desirous of an explosion, because in\r\nthat case the mine throws forth fire, and fire enlightens.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPolice affairs!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king, taking up Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s words, \xe2\x80\x9cpolice\r\naffairs! And what do you know about them, Monsieur? Meddle with your\r\nMusketeers, and do not annoy me in this way. It appears, according to\r\nyour account, that if by mischance a Musketeer is arrested, France is\r\nin danger. What a noise about a Musketeer! I would arrest ten of them,\r\n_ventrebleu_, a hundred, even, all the company, and I would not allow a\r\nwhisper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the moment they are suspected by your Majesty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe Musketeers are guilty; therefore, you see me prepared to surrender\r\nmy sword\xe2\x80\x94for after having accused my soldiers, there can be no doubt\r\nthat Monsieur the Cardinal will end by accusing me.
