It is best to\r\nconstitute myself at once a prisoner with Athos, who is already\r\narrested, and with D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who most probably will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGascon-headed man, will you have done?\xe2\x80\x9d said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tr\xc3\xa9ville, without lowering his voice in the least,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ceither order my Musketeer to be restored to me, or let him be tried.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall be tried,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, so much the better; for in that case I shall demand of his\r\nMajesty permission to plead for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king feared an outbreak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf his Eminence,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdid not have personal motives\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal saw what the king was about to say and interrupted him:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut the instant your Majesty considers me a\r\nprejudiced judge, I withdraw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you swear, by my father, that Athos was at\r\nyour residence during the event and that he took no part in it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy your glorious father, and by yourself, whom I love and venerate\r\nabove all the world, I swear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe so kind as to reflect, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we release the\r\nprisoner thus, we shall never know the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos may always be found,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cready to answer, when\r\nit shall please the gownsmen to interrogate him. He will not desert,\r\nMonsieur the Cardinal, be assured of that; I will answer for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he will not desert,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9che can always be found, as\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville says. Besides,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, lowering his voice and looking with\r\na suppliant air at the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9clet us give them apparent security;\r\nthat is policy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis policy of Louis XIII. made Richelieu smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrder it as you please, sire; you possess the right of pardon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe right of pardoning only applies to the guilty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who\r\nwas determined to have the last word, \xe2\x80\x9cand my Musketeer is innocent. It\r\nis not mercy, then, that you are about to accord, sire, it is justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd he is in the Fort l\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque?\xe2\x80\x9d said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire, in solitary confinement, in a dungeon, like the lowest\r\ncriminal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the king; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat must be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSign an order for his release, and all will be said,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the\r\ncardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe with your Majesty that Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nguarantee is more than sufficient.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville bowed very respectfully, with a joy that was not unmixed with\r\nfear; he would have preferred an obstinate resistance on the part of\r\nthe cardinal to this sudden yielding.\r\n\r\nThe king signed the order for release, and Tr\xc3\xa9ville carried it away\r\nwithout delay. As he was about to leave the presence, the cardinal gave\r\nhim a friendly smile, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cA perfect harmony reigns, sire,\r\nbetween the leaders and the soldiers of your Musketeers, which must be\r\nprofitable for the service and honorable to all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will play me some dog\xe2\x80\x99s trick or other, and that immediately,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cOne has never the last word with such a man. But let us be\r\nquick\xe2\x80\x94the king may change his mind in an hour; and at all events it is\r\nmore difficult to replace a man in the Fort l\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque or the Bastille\r\nwho has got out, than to keep a prisoner there who is in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville made his entrance triumphantly into the Fort l\xe2\x80\x99Ev\xc3\xaaque,\r\nwhence he delivered the Musketeer, whose peaceful indifference had not\r\nfor a moment abandoned him.\r\n\r\nThe first time he saw D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have come off well,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to\r\nhim; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is your Jussac thrust paid for. There still remains that of\r\nBernajoux, but you must not be too confident.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs to the rest, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville had good reason to mistrust the cardinal\r\nand to think that all was not over, for scarcely had the captain of the\r\nMusketeers closed the door after him, than his Eminence said to the\r\nking, \xe2\x80\x9cNow that we are at length by ourselves, we will, if your Majesty\r\npleases, converse seriously. Sire, Buckingham has been in Paris five\r\ndays, and only left this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XVI.\r\nIN WHICH M. S\xc3\x89GUIER, KEEPER OF THE SEALS, LOOKS MORE THAN ONCE FOR THE\r\nBELL\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is impossible to form an idea of the impression these few words made\r\nupon Louis XIII. He grew pale and red alternately; and the cardinal saw\r\nat once that he had recovered by a single blow all the ground he had\r\nlost.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBuckingham in Paris!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cand why does he come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo conspire, no doubt, with your enemies, the Huguenots and the\r\nSpaniards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, _pardieu_, no! To conspire against my honor with Madame de\r\nChevreuse, Madame de Longueville, and the Cond\xc3\xa9s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sire, what an idea! The queen is too virtuous; and besides, loves\r\nyour Majesty too well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWoman is weak, Monsieur Cardinal,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king; \xe2\x80\x9cand as to loving me\r\nmuch, I have my own opinion as to that love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI not the less maintain,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the Duke of\r\nBuckingham came to Paris for a project wholly political.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am sure that he came for quite another purpose, Monsieur\r\nCardinal; but if the queen be guilty, let her tremble!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cwhatever repugnance I may have to\r\ndirecting my mind to such a treason, your Majesty compels me to think\r\nof it. Madame de Lannoy, whom, according to your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s command, I\r\nhave frequently interrogated, told me this morning that the night\r\nbefore last her Majesty sat up very late, that this morning she wept\r\nmuch, and that she was writing all day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the king; \xe2\x80\x9cto him, no doubt. Cardinal, I must have\r\nthe queen\xe2\x80\x99s papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how to take them, sire? It seems to me that it is neither your\r\nMajesty nor myself who can charge himself with such a mission.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did they act with regard to the Mar\xc3\xa9chale d\xe2\x80\x99Ancre?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\nking, in the highest state of choler; \xe2\x80\x9cfirst her closets were\r\nthoroughly searched, and then she herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Mar\xc3\xa9chale d\xe2\x80\x99Ancre was no more than the Mar\xc3\xa9chale d\xe2\x80\x99Ancre. A\r\nFlorentine adventurer, sire, and that was all; while the august spouse\r\nof your Majesty is Anne of Austria, Queen of France\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, one\r\nof the greatest princesses in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not the less guilty, Monsieur Duke! The more she has forgotten\r\nthe high position in which she was placed, the more degrading is her\r\nfall. Besides, I long ago determined to put an end to all these petty\r\nintrigues of policy and love. She has near her a certain Laporte.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho, I believe, is the mainspring of all this, I confess,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\ncardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think then, as I do, that she deceives me?\xe2\x80\x9d said the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe, and I repeat it to your Majesty, that the queen conspires\r\nagainst the power of the king, but I have not said against his honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x94I tell you against both. I tell you the queen does not love me;\r\nI tell you she loves another; I tell you she loves that infamous\r\nBuckingham! Why did you not have him arrested while in Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArrest the Duke! Arrest the prime minister of King Charles I.! Think\r\nof it, sire! What a scandal! And if the suspicions of your Majesty,\r\nwhich I still continue to doubt, should prove to have any foundation,\r\nwhat a terrible disclosure, what a fearful scandal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut as he exposed himself like a vagabond or a thief, he should have\r\nbeen\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLouis XIII. stopped, terrified at what he was about to say, while\r\nRichelieu, stretching out his neck, waited uselessly for the word which\r\nhad died on the lips of the king.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe should have been\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9cnothing. But all the time he was in Paris,\r\nyou, of course, did not lose sight of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did he lodge?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRue de la Harpe. No. 75.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the side of the Luxembourg.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are certain that the queen and he did not see each other?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe the queen to have too high a sense of her duty, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they have corresponded; it is to him that the queen has been\r\nwriting all the day. Monsieur Duke, I must have those letters!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, notwithstanding\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Duke, at whatever price it may be, I will have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would, however, beg your Majesty to observe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you, then, also join in betraying me, Monsieur Cardinal, by thus\r\nalways opposing my will? Are you also in accord with Spain and England,\r\nwith Madame de Chevreuse and the queen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal, sighing, \xe2\x80\x9cI believed myself secure from\r\nsuch a suspicion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Cardinal, you have heard me; I will have those letters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is but one way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat would be to charge Monsieur de S\xc3\xa9guier, the keeper of the seals,\r\nwith this mission. The matter enters completely into the duties of the\r\npost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him be sent for instantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is most likely at my h\xc3\xb4tel. I requested him to call, and when I\r\ncame to the Louvre I left orders if he came, to desire him to wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet him be sent for instantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s orders shall be executed; but\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the queen will perhaps refuse to obey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy orders?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if she is ignorant that these orders come from the king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that she may have no doubt on that head, I will go and inform\r\nher myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Majesty will not forget that I have done everything in my power\r\nto prevent a rupture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Duke, yes, I know you are very indulgent toward the queen, too\r\nindulgent, perhaps; we shall have occasion, I warn you, at some future\r\nperiod to speak of that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever it shall please your Majesty; but I shall be always happy and\r\nproud, sire, to sacrifice myself to the harmony which I desire to see\r\nreign between you and the Queen of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, Cardinal, very well; but, meantime, send for Monsieur the\r\nKeeper of the Seals. I will go to the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Louis XIII., opening the door of communication, passed into the\r\ncorridor which led from his apartments to those of Anne of Austria.\r\n\r\nThe queen was in the midst of her women\xe2\x80\x94Mme. de Guitaut, Mme. de Sable,\r\nMme. de Montbazon, and Mme. de Gu\xc3\xa9men\xc3\xa9. In a corner was the Spanish\r\ncompanion, Donna Estafania, who had followed her from Madrid. Mme.\r\nGu\xc3\xa9men\xc3\xa9 was reading aloud, and everybody was listening to her with\r\nattention with the exception of the queen, who had, on the contrary,\r\ndesired this reading in order that she might be able, while feigning to\r\nlisten, to pursue the thread of her own thoughts.\r\n\r\nThese thoughts, gilded as they were by a last reflection of love, were\r\nnot the less sad. Anne of Austria, deprived of the confidence of her\r\nhusband, pursued by the hatred of the cardinal, who could not pardon\r\nher for having repulsed a more tender feeling, having before her eyes\r\nthe example of the queen-mother whom that hatred had tormented all her\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94though Marie de M\xc3\xa9dicis, if the memoirs of the time are to be\r\nbelieved, had begun by according to the cardinal that sentiment which\r\nAnne of Austria always refused him\xe2\x80\x94Anne of Austria had seen her most\r\ndevoted servants fall around her, her most intimate confidants, her\r\ndearest favorites. Like those unfortunate persons endowed with a fatal\r\ngift, she brought misfortune upon everything she touched. Her\r\nfriendship was a fatal sign which called down persecution. Mme. de\r\nChevreuse and Mme. de Bernet were exiled, and Laporte did not conceal\r\nfrom his mistress that he expected to be arrested every instant.\r\n\r\nIt was at the moment when she was plunged in the deepest and darkest of\r\nthese reflections that the door of the chamber opened, and the king\r\nentered.\r\n\r\nThe reader hushed herself instantly. All the ladies rose, and there was\r\na profound silence. As to the king, he made no demonstration of\r\npoliteness, only stopping before the queen. \xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are\r\nabout to receive a visit from the chancellor, who will communicate\r\ncertain matters to you with which I have charged him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe unfortunate queen, who was constantly threatened with divorce,\r\nexile, and trial even, turned pale under her rouge, and could not\r\nrefrain from saying, \xe2\x80\x9cBut why this visit, sire? What can the chancellor\r\nhave to say to me that your Majesty could not say yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king turned upon his heel without reply, and almost at the same\r\ninstant the captain of the Guards, M. de Guitant, announced the visit\r\nof the chancellor.\r\n\r\nWhen the chancellor appeared, the king had already gone out by another\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\nThe chancellor entered, half smiling, half blushing. As we shall\r\nprobably meet with him again in the course of our history, it may be\r\nwell for our readers to be made at once acquainted with him.\r\n\r\nThis chancellor was a pleasant man. He was Des Roches le Masle, canon\r\nof Notre Dame, who had formerly been valet of a bishop, who introduced\r\nhim to his Eminence as a perfectly devout man. The cardinal trusted\r\nhim, and therein found his advantage.\r\n\r\nThere are many stories related of him, and among them this. After a\r\nwild youth, he had retired into a convent, there to expiate, at least\r\nfor some time, the follies of adolescence. On entering this holy place,\r\nthe poor penitent was unable to shut the door so close as to prevent\r\nthe passions he fled from entering with him. He was incessantly\r\nattacked by them, and the superior, to whom he had confided this\r\nmisfortune, wishing as much as in him lay to free him from them, had\r\nadvised him, in order to conjure away the tempting demon, to have\r\nrecourse to the bell rope, and ring with all his might. At the\r\ndenunciating sound, the monks would be rendered aware that temptation\r\nwas besieging a brother, and all the community would go to prayers.\r\n\r\nThis advice appeared good to the future chancellor. He conjured the\r\nevil spirit with abundance of prayers offered up by the monks. But the\r\ndevil does not suffer himself to be easily dispossessed from a place in\r\nwhich he has fixed his garrison. In proportion as they redoubled the\r\nexorcisms he redoubled the temptations; so that day and night the bell\r\nwas ringing full swing, announcing the extreme desire for mortification\r\nwhich the penitent experienced.\r\n\r\nThe monks had no longer an instant of repose. By day they did nothing\r\nbut ascend and descend the steps which led to the chapel; at night, in\r\naddition to complines and matins, they were further obliged to leap\r\ntwenty times out of their beds and prostrate themselves on the floor of\r\ntheir cells.\r\n\r\nIt is not known whether it was the devil who gave way, or the monks who\r\ngrew tired; but within three months the penitent reappeared in the\r\nworld with the reputation of being the most terrible _possessed_ that\r\never existed.\r\n\r\nOn leaving the convent he entered into the magistracy, became president\r\non the place of his uncle, embraced the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s party, which did not\r\nprove want of sagacity, became chancellor, served his Eminence with\r\nzeal in his hatred against the queen-mother and his vengeance against\r\nAnne of Austria, stimulated the judges in the affair of Calais,\r\nencouraged the attempts of M. de Laffemas, chief gamekeeper of France;\r\nthen, at length, invested with the entire confidence of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nconfidence which he had so well earned\xe2\x80\x94he received the singular\r\ncommission for the execution of which he presented himself in the\r\nqueen\xe2\x80\x99s apartments.\r\n\r\nThe queen was still standing when he entered; but scarcely had she\r\nperceived him then she reseated herself in her armchair, and made a\r\nsign to her women to resume their cushions and stools, and with an air\r\nof supreme hauteur, said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you desire, monsieur, and with what\r\nobject do you present yourself here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo make, madame, in the name of the king, and without prejudice to the\r\nrespect which I have the honor to owe to your Majesty a close\r\nexamination into all your papers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, monsieur, an investigation of my papers\xe2\x80\x94mine! Truly, this is an\r\nindignity!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe kind enough to pardon me, madame; but in this circumstance I am but\r\nthe instrument which the king employs. Has not his Majesty just left\r\nyou, and has he not himself asked you to prepare for this visit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSearch, then, monsieur! I am a criminal, as it appears. Estafania,\r\ngive up the keys of my drawers and my desks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFor form\xe2\x80\x99s sake the chancellor paid a visit to the pieces of furniture\r\nnamed; but he well knew that it was not in a piece of furniture that\r\nthe queen would place the important letter she had written that day.\r\n\r\nWhen the chancellor had opened and shut twenty times the drawers of the\r\nsecretaries, it became necessary, whatever hesitation he might\r\nexperience\xe2\x80\x94it became necessary, I say, to come to the conclusion of the\r\naffair; that is to say, to search the queen herself. The chancellor\r\nadvanced, therefore, toward Anne of Austria, and said with a very\r\nperplexed and embarrassed air, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd now it remains for me to make the\r\nprincipal examination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the queen, who did not understand, or rather was\r\nnot willing to understand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis majesty is certain that a letter has been written by you during\r\nthe day; he knows that it has not yet been sent to its address. This\r\nletter is not in your table nor in your secretary; and yet this letter\r\nmust be somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you dare to lift your hand to your queen?\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne of Austria,\r\ndrawing herself up to her full height, and fixing her eyes upon the\r\nchancellor with an expression almost threatening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a faithful subject of the king, madame, and all that his Majesty\r\ncommands I shall do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it is true!\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne of Austria; \xe2\x80\x9cand the spies of the\r\ncardinal have served him faithfully. I have written a letter today;\r\nthat letter is not yet gone. The letter is here.\xe2\x80\x9d And the queen laid\r\nher beautiful hand on her bosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen give me that letter, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the chancellor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will give it to none but the king, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Anne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the king had desired that the letter should be given to him,\r\nmadame, he would have demanded it of you himself. But I repeat to you,\r\nI am charged with reclaiming it; and if you do not give it up\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has, then, charged me to take it from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow! What do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat my orders go far, madame; and that I am authorized to seek for\r\nthe suspected paper, even on the person of your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat horror!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the queen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe kind enough, then, madame, to act more compliantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe conduct is infamously violent! Do you know that, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king commands it, madame; excuse me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not suffer it! No, no, I would rather die!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the queen, in\r\nwhom the imperious blood of Spain and Austria began to rise.\r\n\r\nThe chancellor made a profound reverence. Then, with the intention\r\nquite patent of not drawing back a foot from the accomplishment of the\r\ncommission with which he was charged, and as the attendant of an\r\nexecutioner might have done in the chamber of torture, he approached\r\nAnne of Austria, from whose eyes at the same instant sprang tears of\r\nrage.\r\n\r\nThe queen was, as we have said, of great beauty. The commission might\r\nwell be called delicate; and the king had reached, in his jealousy of\r\nBuckingham, the point of not being jealous of anyone else.\r\n\r\nWithout doubt the chancellor S\xc3\xa9guier looked about at that moment for\r\nthe rope of the famous bell; but not finding it he summoned his\r\nresolution, and stretched forth his hands toward the place where the\r\nqueen had acknowledged the paper was to be found.\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria took one step backward, became so pale that it might be\r\nsaid she was dying, and leaning with her left hand upon a table behind\r\nher to keep herself from falling, she with her right hand drew the\r\npaper from her bosom and held it out to the keeper of the seals.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, monsieur, there is that letter!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the queen, with a broken\r\nand trembling voice; \xe2\x80\x9ctake it, and deliver me from your odious\r\npresence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe chancellor, who, on his part, trembled with an emotion easily to be\r\nconceived, took the letter, bowed to the ground, and retired. The door\r\nwas scarcely closed upon him, when the queen sank, half fainting, into\r\nthe arms of her women.\r\n\r\nThe chancellor carried the letter to the king without having read a\r\nsingle word of it. The king took it with a trembling hand, looked for\r\nthe address, which was wanting, became very pale, opened it slowly,\r\nthen seeing by the first words that it was addressed to the King of\r\nSpain, he read it rapidly.\r\n\r\nIt was nothing but a plan of attack against the cardinal. The queen\r\npressed her brother and the Emperor of Austria to appear to be wounded,\r\nas they really were, by the policy of Richelieu\xe2\x80\x94the eternal object of\r\nwhich was the abasement of the house of Austria\xe2\x80\x94to declare war against\r\nFrance, and as a condition of peace, to insist upon the dismissal of\r\nthe cardinal; but as to love, there was not a single word about it in\r\nall the letter.\r\n\r\nThe king, quite delighted, inquired if the cardinal was still at the\r\nLouvre; he was told that his Eminence awaited the orders of his Majesty\r\nin the business cabinet.\r\n\r\nThe king went straight to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, Duke,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were right and I was wrong. The whole\r\nintrigue is political, and there is not the least question of love in\r\nthis letter; but, on the other hand, there is abundant question of\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal took the letter, and read it with the greatest attention;\r\nthen, when he had arrived at the end of it, he read it a second time.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, your Majesty,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see how far my enemies go; they\r\nmenace you with two wars if you do not dismiss me. In your place, in\r\ntruth, sire, I should yield to such powerful instance; and on my part,\r\nit would be a real happiness to withdraw from public affairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat say you, Duke?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, sire, that my health is sinking under these excessive struggles\r\nand these never-ending labors. I say that according to all probability\r\nI shall not be able to undergo the fatigues of the siege of La\r\nRochelle, and that it would be far better that you should appoint there\r\neither Monsieur de Cond\xc3\xa9, Monsieur de Bassopierre, or some valiant\r\ngentleman whose business is war, and not me, who am a churchman, and\r\nwho am constantly turned aside for my real vocation to look after\r\nmatters for which I have no aptitude. You would be the happier for it\r\nat home, sire, and I do not doubt you would be the greater for it\r\nabroad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Duke,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9cI understand you. Be satisfied, all\r\nwho are named in that letter shall be punished as they deserve, even\r\nthe queen herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say, sire? God forbid that the queen should suffer the\r\nleast inconvenience or uneasiness on my account! She has always\r\nbelieved me, sire, to be her enemy; although your Majesty can bear\r\nwitness that I have always taken her part warmly, even against you. Oh,\r\nif she betrayed your Majesty on the side of your honor, it would be\r\nquite another thing, and I should be the first to say, \xe2\x80\x98No grace,\r\nsire\xe2\x80\x94no grace for the guilty!\xe2\x80\x99 Happily, there is nothing of the kind,\r\nand your Majesty has just acquired a new proof of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, Monsieur Cardinal,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9cand you were right,\r\nas you always are; but the queen, not the less, deserves all my anger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is you, sire, who have now incurred hers. And even if she were to\r\nbe seriously offended, I could well understand it; your Majesty has\r\ntreated her with a severity\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is thus I will always treat my enemies and yours, Duke, however\r\nhigh they may be placed, and whatever peril I may incur in acting\r\nseverely toward them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe queen is my enemy, but is not yours, sire; on the contrary, she is\r\na devoted, submissive, and irreproachable wife. Allow me, then, sire,\r\nto intercede for her with your Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her humble herself, then, and come to me first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, sire, set the example. You have committed the first\r\nwrong, since it was you who suspected the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! I make the first advances?\xe2\x80\x9d said the king. \xe2\x80\x9cNever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire, I entreat you to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, in what manner can I make advances first?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy doing a thing which you know will be agreeable to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive a ball; you know how much the queen loves dancing. I will answer\r\nfor it, her resentment will not hold out against such an attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Cardinal, you know that I do not like worldly pleasures.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe queen will only be the more grateful to you, as she knows your\r\nantipathy for that amusement; besides, it will be an opportunity for\r\nher to wear those beautiful diamonds which you gave her recently on her\r\nbirthday and with which she has since had no occasion to adorn\r\nherself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see, Monsieur Cardinal, we shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, who, in\r\nhis joy at finding the queen guilty of a crime which he cared little\r\nabout, and innocent of a fault of which he had great dread, was ready\r\nto make up all differences with her, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall see, but upon my honor,\r\nyou are too indulgent toward her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cleave severity to your ministers. Clemency\r\nis a royal virtue; employ it, and you will find that you derive\r\nadvantage therein.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThereupon the cardinal, hearing the clock strike eleven, bowed low,\r\nasking permission of the king to retire, and supplicating him to come\r\nto a good understanding with the queen.\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria, who, in consequence of the seizure of her letter,\r\nexpected reproaches, was much astonished the next day to see the king\r\nmake some attempts at reconciliation with her. Her first movement was\r\nrepellent. Her womanly pride and her queenly dignity had both been so\r\ncruelly offended that she could not come round at the first advance;\r\nbut, overpersuaded by the advice of her women, she at last had the\r\nappearance of beginning to forget. The king took advantage of this\r\nfavorable moment to tell her that he had the intention of shortly\r\ngiving a f\xc3\xaate.\r\n\r\nA f\xc3\xaate was so rare a thing for poor Anne of Austria that at this\r\nannouncement, as the cardinal had predicted, the last trace of her\r\nresentment disappeared, if not from her heart, at least from her\r\ncountenance. She asked upon what day this f\xc3\xaate would take place, but\r\nthe king replied that he must consult the cardinal upon that head.\r\n\r\nIndeed, every day the king asked the cardinal when this f\xc3\xaate should\r\ntake place; and every day the cardinal, under some pretext, deferred\r\nfixing it. Ten days passed away thus.\r\n\r\nOn the eighth day after the scene we have described, the cardinal\r\nreceived a letter with the London stamp which only contained these\r\nlines: \xe2\x80\x9cI have them; but I am unable to leave London for want of money.\r\nSend me five hundred pistoles, and four or five days after I have\r\nreceived them I shall be in Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn the same day the cardinal received this letter the king put his\r\ncustomary question to him.\r\n\r\nRichelieu counted on his fingers, and said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cShe will\r\narrive, she says, four or five days after having received the money. It\r\nwill require four or five days for the transmission of the money, four\r\nor five days for her to return; that makes ten days. Now, allowing for\r\ncontrary winds, accidents, and a woman\xe2\x80\x99s weakness, there are twelve\r\ndays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Monsieur Duke,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9chave you made your\r\ncalculations?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire. Today is the twentieth of September. The aldermen of the\r\ncity give a f\xc3\xaate on the third of October. That will fall in wonderfully\r\nwell; you will not appear to have gone out of your way to please the\r\nqueen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen the cardinal added, \xe2\x80\x9c_A propos_, sire, do not forget to tell her\r\nMajesty the evening before the f\xc3\xaate that you should like to see how her\r\ndiamond studs become her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XVII.\r\nBONACIEUX AT HOME\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was the second time the cardinal had mentioned these diamond studs\r\nto the king. Louis XIII. was struck with this insistence, and began to\r\nfancy that this recommendation concealed some mystery.\r\n\r\nMore than once the king had been humiliated by the cardinal, whose\r\npolice, without having yet attained the perfection of the modern\r\npolice, were excellent, being better informed than himself, even upon\r\nwhat was going on in his own household. He hoped, then, in a\r\nconversation with Anne of Austria, to obtain some information from that\r\nconversation, and afterward to come upon his Eminence with some secret\r\nwhich the cardinal either knew or did not know, but which, in either\r\ncase, would raise him infinitely in the eyes of his minister.\r\n\r\nHe went then to the queen, and according to custom accosted her with\r\nfresh menaces against those who surrounded her. Anne of Austria lowered\r\nher head, allowed the torrent to flow on without replying, hoping that\r\nit would cease of itself; but this was not what Louis XIII. meant. Louis\r\nXIII. wanted a discussion from which some light or other might break,\r\nconvinced as he was that the cardinal had some afterthought and was\r\npreparing for him one of those terrible surprises which his Eminence\r\nwas so skillful in getting up. He arrived at this end by his\r\npersistence in accusation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anne of Austria, tired of these vague attacks, \xe2\x80\x9cbut, sire,\r\nyou do not tell me all that you have in your heart. What have I done,\r\nthen? Let me know what crime I have committed. It is impossible that\r\nyour Majesty can make all this ado about a letter written to my\r\nbrother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king, attacked in a manner so direct, did not know what to answer;\r\nand he thought that this was the moment for expressing the desire which\r\nhe was not going to have made until the evening before the f\xc3\xaate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with dignity, \xe2\x80\x9cthere will shortly be a ball at the\r\nH\xc3\xb4tel de Ville. I wish, in order to honor our worthy aldermen, you\r\nshould appear in ceremonial costume, and above all, ornamented with the\r\ndiamond studs which I gave you on your birthday. That is my answer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe answer was terrible. Anne of Austria believed that Louis XIII. knew\r\nall, and that the cardinal had persuaded him to employ this long\r\ndissimulation of seven or eight days, which, likewise, was\r\ncharacteristic. She became excessively pale, leaned her beautiful hand\r\nupon a _console_, which hand appeared then like one of wax, and looking\r\nat the king with terror in her eyes, she was unable to reply by a\r\nsingle syllable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou hear, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, who enjoyed the embarrassment to its\r\nfull extent, but without guessing the cause. \xe2\x80\x9cYou hear, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire, I hear,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the queen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will appear at this ball?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith those studs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe queen\xe2\x80\x99s paleness, if possible, increased; the king perceived it,\r\nand enjoyed it with that cold cruelty which was one of the worst sides\r\nof his character.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen that is agreed,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, \xe2\x80\x9cand that is all I had to say to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut on what day will this ball take place?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Anne of Austria.\r\n\r\nLouis XIII. felt instinctively that he ought not to reply to this\r\nquestion, the queen having put it in an almost dying voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, very shortly, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I do not precisely recollect\r\nthe date of the day. I will ask the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was the cardinal, then, who informed you of this f\xc3\xaate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the astonished king; \xe2\x80\x9cbut why do you ask that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was he who told you to invite me to appear with these studs?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, madame\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was he, sire, it was he!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and what does it signify whether it was he or I? Is there any\r\ncrime in this request?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you will appear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the king, retiring, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is well; I count upon\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe queen made a curtsy, less from etiquette than because her knees\r\nwere sinking under her. The king went away enchanted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am lost,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the queen, \xe2\x80\x9clost!\xe2\x80\x94for the cardinal knows all, and\r\nit is he who urges on the king, who as yet knows nothing but will soon\r\nknow everything. I am lost! My God, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe knelt upon a cushion and prayed, with her head buried between her\r\npalpitating arms.\r\n\r\nIn fact, her position was terrible. Buckingham had returned to London;\r\nMme. de Chevreuse was at Tours. More closely watched than ever, the\r\nqueen felt certain, without knowing how to tell which, that one of her\r\nwomen had betrayed her. Laporte could not leave the Louvre; she had not\r\na soul in the world in whom she could confide. Thus, while\r\ncontemplating the misfortune which threatened her and the abandonment\r\nin which she was left, she broke out into sobs and tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan I be of service to your Majesty?\xe2\x80\x9d said all at once a voice full of\r\nsweetness and pity.\r\n\r\nThe queen turned sharply round, for there could be no deception in the\r\nexpression of that voice; it was a friend who spoke thus.\r\n\r\nIn fact, at one of the doors which opened into the queen\xe2\x80\x99s apartment\r\nappeared the pretty Mme. Bonacieux. She had been engaged in arranging\r\nthe dresses and linen in a closet when the king entered; she could not\r\nget out and had heard all.\r\n\r\nThe queen uttered a piercing cry at finding herself surprised\xe2\x80\x94for in\r\nher trouble she did not at first recognize the young woman who had been\r\ngiven to her by Laporte.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, fear nothing, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, clasping her hands\r\nand weeping herself at the queen\xe2\x80\x99s sorrows; \xe2\x80\x9cI am your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s, body\r\nand soul, and however far I may be from you, however inferior may be my\r\nposition, I believe I have discovered a means of extricating your\r\nMajesty from your trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, oh, heaven, you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the queen; \xe2\x80\x9cbut look me in the face. I am\r\nbetrayed on all sides. Can I trust in you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young woman, falling on her knees; \xe2\x80\x9cupon my\r\nsoul, I am ready to die for your Majesty!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis expression sprang from the very bottom of the heart, and, like the\r\nfirst, there was no mistaking it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, there are traitors here; but by\r\nthe holy name of the Virgin, I swear that no one is more devoted to\r\nyour Majesty than I am. Those studs which the king speaks of, you gave\r\nthem to the Duke of Buckingham, did you not? Those studs were enclosed\r\nin a little rosewood box which he held under his arm? Am I deceived? Is\r\nit not so, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the queen, whose teeth chattered with\r\nfright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, those studs,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must have them back\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, without doubt, it is necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the queen; \xe2\x80\x9cbut how am I\r\nto act? How can it be effected?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomeone must be sent to the duke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who, who? In whom can I trust?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlace confidence in me, madame; do me that honor, my queen, and I will\r\nfind a messenger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I must write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; that is indispensable. Two words from the hand of your\r\nMajesty and your private seal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut these two words would bring about my condemnation, divorce,\r\nexile!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if they fell into infamous hands. But I will answer for these two\r\nwords being delivered to their address.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God! I must then place my life, my honor, my reputation, in\r\nyour hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, madame, you must; and I will save them all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how? Tell me at least the means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy husband had been at liberty these two or three days. I have not yet\r\nhad time to see him again. He is a worthy, honest man who entertains\r\nneither love nor hatred for anybody. He will do anything I wish. He\r\nwill set out upon receiving an order from me, without knowing what he\r\ncarries, and he will carry your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s letter, without even knowing\r\nit is from your Majesty, to the address which is on it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe queen took the two hands of the young woman with a burst of\r\nemotion, gazed at her as if to read her very heart, and, seeing nothing\r\nbut sincerity in her beautiful eyes, embraced her tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo that,\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, \xe2\x80\x9cand you will have saved my life, you will have\r\nsaved my honor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not exaggerate the service I have the happiness to render your\r\nMajesty. I have nothing to save for your Majesty; you are only the\r\nvictim of perfidious plots.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, that is true, my child,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are\r\nright.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me then, that letter, madame; time presses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe queen ran to a little table, on which were ink, paper, and pens.\r\nShe wrote two lines, sealed the letter with her private seal, and gave\r\nit to Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are forgetting one very necessary\r\nthing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux blushed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is true,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will confess to your Majesty that\r\nmy husband\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour husband has none. Is that what you would say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has some, but he is very avaricious; that is his fault.\r\nNevertheless, let not your Majesty be uneasy, we will find means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I have none, either,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen. Those who have read the\r\n_Memoirs_ of Mme. de Motteville will not be astonished at this reply.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut wait a minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnne of Austria ran to her jewel case.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a ring of great value, as I have been\r\nassured. It came from my brother, the King of Spain. It is mine, and I\r\nam at liberty to dispose of it. Take this ring; raise money with it,\r\nand let your husband set out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn an hour you shall be obeyed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see the address,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen, speaking so low that Mme.\r\nBonacieux could hardly hear what she said, \xe2\x80\x9cTo my Lord Duke of\r\nBuckingham, London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe letter shall be given to himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGenerous girl!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Anne of Austria.\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux kissed the hands of the queen, concealed the paper in\r\nthe bosom of her dress, and disappeared with the lightness of a bird.\r\n\r\nTen minutes afterward she was at home. As she told the queen, she had\r\nnot seen her husband since his liberation; she was ignorant of the\r\nchange that had taken place in him with respect to the cardinal\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nchange which had since been strengthened by two or three visits from\r\nthe Comte de Rochefort, who had become the best friend of Bonacieux,\r\nand had persuaded him, without much trouble, that no culpable\r\nsentiments had prompted the abduction of his wife, but that it was only\r\na political precaution.\r\n\r\nShe found M. Bonacieux alone; the poor man was recovering with\r\ndifficulty the order in his house, in which he had found most of the\r\nfurniture broken and the closets nearly emptied\xe2\x80\x94justice not being one\r\nof the three things which King Solomon names as leaving no traces of\r\ntheir passage. As to the servant, she had run away at the moment of her\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s arrest. Terror had had such an effect upon the poor girl that\r\nshe had never ceased walking from Paris till she reached Burgundy, her\r\nnative place.\r\n\r\nThe worthy mercer had, immediately upon re-entering his house, informed\r\nhis wife of his happy return, and his wife had replied by\r\ncongratulating him, and telling him that the first moment she could\r\nsteal from her duties should be devoted to paying him a visit.\r\n\r\nThis first moment had been delayed five days, which, under any other\r\ncircumstances, might have appeared rather long to M. Bonacieux; but he\r\nhad, in the visit he had made to the cardinal and in the visits\r\nRochefort had made him, ample subjects for reflection, and as everybody\r\nknows, nothing makes time pass more quickly than reflection.\r\n\r\nThis was the more so because Bonacieux\xe2\x80\x99s reflections were all\r\nrose-colored. Rochefort called him his friend, his dear Bonacieux, and\r\nnever ceased telling him that the cardinal had a great respect for him.\r\nThe mercer fancied himself already on the high road to honors and\r\nfortune.\r\n\r\nOn her side Mme. Bonacieux had also reflected; but, it must be\r\nadmitted, upon something widely different from ambition. In spite of\r\nherself her thoughts constantly reverted to that handsome young man who\r\nwas so brave and appeared to be so much in love. Married at eighteen to\r\nM. Bonacieux, having always lived among her husband\xe2\x80\x99s friends\xe2\x80\x94people\r\nlittle capable of inspiring any sentiment whatever in a young woman\r\nwhose heart was above her position\xe2\x80\x94Mme. Bonacieux had remained\r\ninsensible to vulgar seductions; but at this period the title of\r\ngentleman had great influence with the citizen class, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nwas a gentleman. Besides, he wore the uniform of the Guards, which,\r\nnext to that of the Musketeers, was most admired by the ladies. He was,\r\nwe repeat, handsome, young, and bold; he spoke of love like a man who\r\ndid love and was anxious to be loved in return. There was certainly\r\nenough in all this to turn a head only twenty-three years old, and Mme.\r\nBonacieux had just attained that happy period of life.\r\n\r\nThe couple, then, although they had not seen each other for eight days,\r\nand during that time serious events had taken place in which both were\r\nconcerned, accosted each other with a degree of preoccupation.\r\nNevertheless, Bonacieux manifested real joy, and advanced toward his\r\nwife with open arms. Madame Bonacieux presented her cheek to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us talk a little,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I have something of the highest importance to tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrue,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand I have some questions sufficiently serious to put\r\nto you. Describe to me your abduction, I pray you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s of no consequence just now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what does it concern, then\xe2\x80\x94my captivity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard of it the day it happened; but as you were not guilty of any\r\ncrime, as you were not guilty of any intrigue, as you, in short, knew\r\nnothing that could compromise yourself or anybody else, I attached no\r\nmore importance to that event than it merited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak very much at your ease, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, hurt at the\r\nlittle interest his wife showed in him. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you know that I was plunged\r\nduring a day and night in a dungeon of the Bastille?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a day and night soon pass away. Let us return to the object that\r\nbrings me here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, that which brings you home to me? Is it not the desire of seeing\r\na husband again from whom you have been separated for a week?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nthe mercer, piqued to the quick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that first, and other things afterward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a thing of the highest interest, and upon which our future\r\nfortune perhaps depends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe complexion of our fortune has changed very much since I saw you,\r\nMadame Bonacieux, and I should not be astonished if in the course of a\r\nfew months it were to excite the envy of many folks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, particularly if you follow the instructions I am about to give\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you. There is good and holy action to be performed, monsieur, and\r\nmuch money to be gained at the same time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux knew that in talking of money to her husband, she took\r\nhim on his weak side. But a man, were he even a mercer, when he had\r\ntalked for ten minutes with Cardinal Richelieu, is no longer the same\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch money to be gained?\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, protruding his lip.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout how much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand pistoles, perhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you demand of me is serious, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat must be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must go away immediately. I will give you a paper which you must\r\nnot part with on any account, and which you will deliver into the\r\nproper hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd whither am I to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI go to London? Go to! You jest! I have no business in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut others wish that you should go there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who are those others? I warn you that I will never again work in\r\nthe dark, and that I will know not only to what I expose myself, but\r\nfor whom I expose myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn illustrious person sends you; an illustrious person awaits you. The\r\nrecompense will exceed your expectations; that is all I promise you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore intrigues! Nothing but intrigues! Thank you, madame, I am aware\r\nof them now; Monsieur Cardinal has enlightened me on that head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you seen the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe sent for me,\xe2\x80\x9d answered the mercer, proudly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you responded to his bidding, you imprudent man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I can\xe2\x80\x99t say I had much choice of going or not going, for I was\r\ntaken to him between two guards. It is true also, that as I did not\r\nthen know his Eminence, if I had been able to dispense with the visit,\r\nI should have been enchanted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe ill-treated you, then; he threatened you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe gave me his hand, and called me his friend. His friend! Do you hear\r\nthat, madame? I am the friend of the great cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the great cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you would contest his right to that title, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would contest nothing; but I tell you that the favor of a minister\r\nis ephemeral, and that a man must be mad to attach himself to a\r\nminister. There are powers above his which do not depend upon a man or\r\nthe issue of an event; it is to these powers we should rally.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry for it, madame, but I acknowledge no other power but that\r\nof the great man whom I have the honor to serve.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou serve the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, madame; and as his servant, I will not allow you to be concerned\r\nin plots against the safety of the state, or to serve the intrigues of\r\na woman who is not French and who has a Spanish heart. Fortunately we\r\nhave the great cardinal; his vigilant eye watches over and penetrates\r\nto the bottom of the heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux was repeating, word for word, a sentence which he had heard\r\nfrom the Comte de Rochefort; but the poor wife, who had reckoned on her\r\nhusband, and who, in that hope, had answered for him to the queen, did\r\nnot tremble the less, both at the danger into which she had nearly cast\r\nherself and at the helpless state to which she was reduced.\r\nNevertheless, knowing the weakness of her husband, and more\r\nparticularly his cupidity, she did not despair of bringing him round to\r\nher purpose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you are a cardinalist, then, monsieur, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d cried she; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nyou serve the party of those who maltreat your wife and insult your\r\nqueen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrivate interests are as nothing before the interests of all. I am for\r\nthose who save the state,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, emphatically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you know about the state you talk of?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme.\r\nBonacieux, shrugging her shoulders. \xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied with being a plain,\r\nstraightforward citizen, and turn to that side which offers the most\r\nadvantages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, slapping a plump, round bag, which returned a\r\nsound a money; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you think of this, Madame Preacher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhence comes that money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not guess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom him, and from my friend the Comte de Rochefort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Comte de Rochefort! Why, it was he who carried me off!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat may be, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you receive silver from that man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not said that that abduction was entirely political?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but that abduction had for its object the betrayal of my\r\nmistress, to draw from me by torture confessions that might compromise\r\nthe honor, and perhaps the life, of my august mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cyour august mistress is a perfidious\r\nSpaniard, and what the cardinal does is well done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9cI know you to be cowardly,\r\navaricious, and foolish, but I never till now believed you infamous!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, who had never seen his wife in a passion, and\r\nwho recoiled before this conjugal anger, \xe2\x80\x9cmadame, what do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say you are a miserable creature!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mme. Bonacieux, who saw\r\nshe was regaining some little influence over her husband. \xe2\x80\x9cYou meddle\r\nwith politics, do you\xe2\x80\x94and still more, with cardinalist politics? Why,\r\nyou sell yourself, body and soul, to the demon, the devil, for money!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, to the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s the same thing,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young woman. \xe2\x80\x9cWho calls Richelieu\r\ncalls Satan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, hold your tongue, madame! You may be overheard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you are right; I should be ashamed for anyone to know your\r\nbaseness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what do you require of me, then? Let us see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have told you. You must depart instantly, monsieur. You must\r\naccomplish loyally the commission with which I deign to charge you, and\r\non that condition I pardon everything, I forget everything; and what is\r\nmore,\xe2\x80\x9d and she held out her hand to him, \xe2\x80\x9cI restore my love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux was cowardly and avaricious, but he loved his wife. He was\r\nsoftened. A man of fifty cannot long bear malice with a wife of\r\ntwenty-three. Mme. Bonacieux saw that he hesitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome! Have you decided?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my dear love, reflect a little upon what you require of me.\r\nLondon is far from Paris, very far, and perhaps the commission with\r\nwhich you charge me is not without dangers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat matters it, if you avoid them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold, Madame Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said the mercer, \xe2\x80\x9chold! I positively refuse;\r\nintrigues terrify me. I have seen the Bastille. My! Whew! That\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nfrightful place, that Bastille! Only to think of it makes my flesh\r\ncrawl. They threatened me with torture. Do you know what torture is?\r\nWooden points that they stick in between your legs till your bones\r\nstick out! No, positively I will not go. And, _morbleu_, why do you not\r\ngo yourself? For in truth, I think I have hitherto been deceived in\r\nyou. I really believe you are a man, and a violent one, too.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, you are a woman\xe2\x80\x94a miserable woman, stupid and brutal. You are\r\nafraid, are you? Well, if you do not go this very instant, I will have\r\nyou arrested by the queen\xe2\x80\x99s orders, and I will have you placed in the\r\nBastille which you dread so much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux fell into a profound reflection. He weighed the two angers in\r\nhis brain\xe2\x80\x94that of the cardinal and that of the queen; that of the\r\ncardinal predominated enormously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave me arrested on the part of the queen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x94I will\r\nappeal to his Eminence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt once Mme. Bonacieux saw that she had gone too far, and she was\r\nterrified at having communicated so much. She for a moment contemplated\r\nwith fright that stupid countenance, impressed with the invincible\r\nresolution of a fool that is overcome by fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, be it so!\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps, when all is considered, you are\r\nright. In the long run, a man knows more about politics than a woman,\r\nparticularly such as, like you, Monsieur Bonacieux, have conversed with\r\nthe cardinal. And yet it is very hard,\xe2\x80\x9d added she, \xe2\x80\x9cthat a man upon\r\nwhose affection I thought I might depend, treats me thus unkindly and\r\nwill not comply with any of my fancies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is because your fancies go too far,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the triumphant\r\nBonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cand I mistrust them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will give it up, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, sighing. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nwell as it is; say no more about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least you should tell me what I should have to do in London,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nreplied Bonacieux, who remembered a little too late that Rochefort had\r\ndesired him to endeavor to obtain his wife\xe2\x80\x99s secrets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is of no use for you to know anything about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young\r\nwoman, whom an instinctive mistrust now impelled to draw back. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was\r\nabout one of those purchases that interest women\xe2\x80\x94a purchase by which\r\nmuch might have been gained.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the more the young woman excused herself, the more important\r\nBonacieux thought the secret which she declined to confide to him. He\r\nresolved then to hasten immediately to the residence of the Comte de\r\nRochefort, and tell him that the queen was seeking for a messenger to\r\nsend to London.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me for quitting you, my dear Madame Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut,\r\nnot knowing you would come to see me, I had made an engagement with a\r\nfriend. I shall soon return; and if you will wait only a few minutes\r\nfor me, as soon as I have concluded my business with that friend, as it\r\nis growing late, I will come back and reconduct you to the Louvre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, monsieur, you are not brave enough to be of any use to me\r\nwhatever,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall return very safely to the\r\nLouvre all alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you please, Madame Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said the ex-mercer. \xe2\x80\x9cShall I see you\r\nagain soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNext week I hope my duties will afford me a little liberty, and I will\r\ntake advantage of it to come and put things in order here, as they must\r\nnecessarily be much deranged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; I shall expect you. You are not angry with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the least in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill then, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux kissed his wife\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and set off at a quick pace.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, when her husband had shut the street door\r\nand she found herself alone; \xe2\x80\x9cthat imbecile lacked but one thing: to\r\nbecome a cardinalist. And I, who have answered for him to the queen\xe2\x80\x94I,\r\nwho have promised my poor mistress\xe2\x80\x94ah, my God, my God! She will take me\r\nfor one of those wretches with whom the palace swarms and who are\r\nplaced about her as spies! Ah, Monsieur Bonacieux, I never did love you\r\nmuch, but now it is worse than ever. I hate you, and on my word you\r\nshall pay for this!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the moment she spoke these words a rap on the ceiling made her raise\r\nher head, and a voice which reached her through the ceiling cried,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Madame Bonacieux, open for me the little door on the alley, and I\r\nwill come down to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XVIII.\r\nLOVER AND HUSBAND\r\n\r\n\r\nAh, Madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, entering by the door which the young\r\nwoman opened for him, \xe2\x80\x9callow me to tell you that you have a bad sort of\r\na husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, then, overheard our conversation?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mme. Bonacieux,\r\neagerly, and looking at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with disquiet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe whole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how, my God?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy a mode of proceeding known to myself, and by which I likewise\r\noverheard the more animated conversation which he had with the\r\ncardinal\xe2\x80\x99s police.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did you understand by what we said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thousand things. In the first place, that, unfortunately, your\r\nhusband is a simpleton and a fool; in the next place, you are in\r\ntrouble, of which I am very glad, as it gives me an opportunity of\r\nplacing myself at your service, and God knows I am ready to throw\r\nmyself into the fire for you; finally, that the queen wants a brave,\r\nintelligent, devoted man to make a journey to London for her. I have at\r\nleast two of the three qualities you stand in need of, and here I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux made no reply; but her heart beat with joy and secret\r\nhope shone in her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what guarantee will you give me,\xe2\x80\x9d asked she, \xe2\x80\x9cif I consent to\r\nconfide this message to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy love for you. Speak! Command! What is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9cought I to confide such a\r\nsecret to you, monsieur? You are almost a boy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see that you require someone to answer for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI admit that would reassure me greatly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPorthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. Who are these gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree of the king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers. Do you know Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\r\ntheir captain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, him! I know him; not personally, but from having heard the\r\nqueen speak of him more than once as a brave and loyal gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not fear lest he should betray you to the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, certainly not!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, reveal your secret to him, and ask him whether, however\r\nimportant, however valuable, however terrible it may be, you may not\r\nconfide it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this secret is not mine, and I cannot reveal it in this manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou were about to confide it to Monsieur Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nwith chagrin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs one confides a letter to the hollow of a tree, to the wing of a\r\npigeon, to the collar of a dog.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet, me\xe2\x80\x94you see plainly that I love you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am an honorable man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a gallant fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am brave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am sure of that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, put me to the proof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux looked at the young man, restrained for a minute by a\r\nlast hesitation; but there was such an ardor in his eyes, such\r\npersuasion in his voice, that she felt herself constrained to confide\r\nin him. Besides, she found herself in circumstances where everything\r\nmust be risked for the sake of everything. The queen might be as much\r\ninjured by too much reticence as by too much confidence; and\xe2\x80\x94let us\r\nadmit it\xe2\x80\x94the involuntary sentiment which she felt for her young\r\nprotector decided her to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cI yield to your protestations, I yield to your\r\nassurances. But I swear to you, before God who hears us, that if you\r\nbetray me, and my enemies pardon me, I will kill myself, while accusing\r\nyou of my death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I\xe2\x80\x94I swear to you before God, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if I\r\nam taken while accomplishing the orders you give me, I will die sooner\r\nthan do anything that may compromise anyone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen the young woman confided in him the terrible secret of which\r\nchance had already communicated to him a part in front of the\r\nSamaritaine. This was their mutual declaration of love.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was radiant with joy and pride. This secret which he\r\npossessed, this woman whom he loved! Confidence and love made him a\r\ngiant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI go,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI go at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, you will go!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cand your regiment, your\r\ncaptain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy my soul, you had made me forget all that, dear Constance! Yes, you\r\nare right; a furlough is needful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill another obstacle,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mme. Bonacieux, sorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to that,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, after a moment of reflection, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall\r\nsurmount it, be assured.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go this very evening to Tr\xc3\xa9ville, whom I will request to ask\r\nthis favor for me of his brother-in-law, Monsieur Dessessart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut another thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, seeing that Mme. Bonacieux hesitated to\r\ncontinue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, perhaps, no money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Perhaps_ is too much,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mme. Bonacieux, opening a cupboard and taking from it\r\nthe very bag which a half hour before her husband had caressed so\r\naffectionately, \xe2\x80\x9ctake this bag.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, breaking into a loud laugh, he\r\nhaving heard, as may be remembered, thanks to the broken boards, every\r\nsyllable of the conversation between the mercer and his wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cYou see it makes a very\r\nrespectable appearance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu_,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cit will be a double amusing affair to\r\nsave the queen with the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s money!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are an amiable and charming young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cBe\r\nassured you will not find her Majesty ungrateful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am already grandly recompensed!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI love you;\r\nyou permit me to tell you that I do\xe2\x80\x94that is already more happiness than\r\nI dared to hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Yes, I recognize it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan ran to the door and pushed the bolt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall not come in before I am gone,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cand when I am gone,\r\nyou can open to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I ought to be gone, too. And the disappearance of his money; how\r\nam I to justify it if I am here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; we must go out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo out? How? He will see us if we go out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you must come up into my room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux pronounced these words with tears in her eyes.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan saw those tears, and much disturbed, softened, he threw\r\nhimself at her feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith me you will be as safe as in a temple; I give you my word of a\r\ngentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI place full confidence in you, my friend!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan drew back the bolt with precaution, and both, light as\r\nshadows, glided through the interior door into the passage, ascended\r\nthe stairs as quietly as possible, and entered D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s chambers.\r\n\r\nOnce there, for greater security, the young man barricaded the door.\r\nThey both approached the window, and through a slit in the shutter they\r\nsaw Bonacieux talking with a man in a cloak.\r\n\r\nAt sight of this man, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan started, and half drawing his sword,\r\nsprang toward the door.\r\n\r\nIt was the man of Meung.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cyou will ruin us\r\nall!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I have sworn to kill that man!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour life is devoted from this moment, and does not belong to you. In\r\nthe name of the queen I forbid you to throw yourself into any peril\r\nwhich is foreign to that of your journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you command nothing in your own name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, with great emotion, \xe2\x80\x9cin my name I\r\nbeg you! But listen; they appear to be speaking of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan drew near the window, and lent his ear.\r\n\r\nM. Bonacieux had opened his door, and seeing the apartment, had\r\nreturned to the man in the cloak, whom he had left alone for an\r\ninstant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is gone,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cshe must have returned to the Louvre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9cthat she did not suspect the\r\nintentions with which you went out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux, with a self-sufficient air, \xe2\x80\x9cshe is too\r\nsuperficial a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the young Guardsman at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not think he is; as you see, his shutter is closed, and you can\r\nsee no light shine through the chinks of the shutters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the same, it is well to be certain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy knocking at his door. Go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will ask his servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux re-entered the house, passed through the same door that had\r\nafforded a passage for the two fugitives, went up to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s door,\r\nand knocked.\r\n\r\nNo one answered. Porthos, in order to make a greater display, had that\r\nevening borrowed Planchet. As to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he took care not to give\r\nthe least sign of existence.\r\n\r\nThe moment the hand of Bonacieux sounded on the door, the two young\r\npeople felt their hearts bound within them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is nobody within,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind. Let us return to your apartment. We shall be safer there\r\nthan in the doorway.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall hear no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall hear better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan raised the three or four boards which made his chamber\r\nanother ear of Dionysius, spread a carpet on the floor, went upon his\r\nknees, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to stoop as he did toward the\r\nopening.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure there is nobody there?\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will answer for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you think that your wife\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas returned to the Louvre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout speaking to anyone but yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is an important point, do you understand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the news I brought you is of value?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe greatest, my dear Bonacieux; I don\xe2\x80\x99t conceal this from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the cardinal will be pleased with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no doubt of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe great cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you sure, in her conversation with you, that your wife mentioned\r\nno names?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe did not name Madame de Chevreuse, the Duke of Buckingham, or\r\nMadame de Vernet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; she only told me she wished to send me to London to serve the\r\ninterests of an illustrious personage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe traitor!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, taking her hand, which, without thinking of\r\nit, she abandoned to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the man in the cloak; \xe2\x80\x9cyou were a fool not to\r\nhave pretended to accept the mission. You would then be in present\r\npossession of the letter. The state, which is now threatened, would be\r\nsafe, and you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell you\xe2\x80\x94the cardinal would have given you letters of nobility.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he tell you so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know that he meant to afford you that agreeable surprise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cmy wife adores me, and there is yet\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ninny!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, pressing her hand more closely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is there still time?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the man in the cloak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI go to the Louvre; I ask for Mme. Bonacieux; I say that I have\r\nreflected; I renew the affair; I obtain the letter, and I run directly\r\nto the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go quickly! I will return soon to learn the result of your\r\ntrip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe stranger went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInfamous!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, addressing this epithet to her\r\nhusband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, pressing her hand still more warmly.\r\n\r\nA terrible howling interrupted these reflections of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Mme.\r\nBonacieux. It was her husband, who had discovered the disappearance of\r\nthe moneybag, and was crying \xe2\x80\x9cThieves!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9che will rouse the whole quarter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux called a long time; but as such cries, on account of their\r\nfrequency, brought nobody in the Rue des Fossoyeurs, and as lately the\r\nmercer\xe2\x80\x99s house had a bad name, finding that nobody came, he went out\r\ncontinuing to call, his voice being heard fainter and fainter as he\r\nwent in the direction of the Rue du Bac.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow he is gone, it is your turn to get out,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme.
