Bonacieux.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourage, my friend, but above all, prudence, and think what you owe to\r\nthe queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo her and to you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied, beautiful\r\nConstance. I shall become worthy of her gratitude; but shall I likewise\r\nreturn worthy of your love?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young woman only replied by the beautiful glow which mounted to her\r\ncheeks. A few seconds afterward D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan also went out enveloped in a\r\nlarge cloak, which ill-concealed the sheath of a long sword.\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux followed him with her eyes, with that long, fond look\r\nwith which he had turned the angle of the street, she fell on her\r\nknees, and clasping her hands, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God,\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, \xe2\x80\x9cprotect the\r\nqueen, protect me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XIX.\r\nPLAN OF CAMPAIGN\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went straight to M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s. He had reflected that in\r\na few minutes the cardinal would be warned by this cursed stranger, who\r\nappeared to be his agent, and he judged, with reason, he had not a\r\nmoment to lose.\r\n\r\nThe heart of the young man overflowed with joy. An opportunity\r\npresented itself to him in which there would be at the same time glory\r\nto be acquired, and money to be gained; and as a far higher\r\nencouragement, it brought him into close intimacy with a woman he\r\nadored. This chance did, then, for him at once more than he would have\r\ndared to ask of Providence.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was in his saloon with his habitual court of gentlemen.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was known as a familiar of the house, went straight to\r\nhis office, and sent word that he wished to see him on something of\r\nimportance.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had been there scarcely five minutes when M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\r\nentered. At the first glance, and by the joy which was painted on his\r\ncountenance, the worthy captain plainly perceived that something new\r\nwas on foot.\r\n\r\nAll the way along D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had been consulting with himself whether\r\nhe should place confidence in M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, or whether he should only\r\nask him to give him _carte blanche_ for some secret affair. But M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville had always been so thoroughly his friend, had always been so\r\ndevoted to the king and queen, and hated the cardinal so cordially,\r\nthat the young man resolved to tell him everything.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ask for me, my good friend?\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, lowering his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cand you will\r\npardon me, I hope, for having disturbed you when you know the\r\nimportance of my business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, then, I am all attention.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt concerns nothing less,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthan the honor, perhaps\r\nthe life of the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you say?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, glancing round to see if they\r\nwere surely alone, and then fixing his questioning look upon\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say, monsieur, that chance has rendered me master of a secret\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich you will guard, I hope, young man, as your life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut which I must impart to you, monsieur, for you alone can assist me\r\nin the mission I have just received from her Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this secret your own?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur; it is her Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you authorized by her Majesty to communicate it to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, for, on the contrary, I am desired to preserve the\r\nprofoundest mystery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, then, are you about to betray it to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, as I said, without you I can do nothing; and I am afraid you\r\nwill refuse me the favor I come to ask if you do not know to what end I\r\nask it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep your secret, young man, and tell me what you wish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish you to obtain for me, from Monsieur Dessessart, leave of\r\nabsence for fifteen days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis very night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou leave Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going on a mission.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay you tell me whither?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas anyone an interest in preventing your arrival there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal, I believe, would give the world to prevent my success.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are going alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case you will not get beyond Bondy. I tell you so, by the\r\nfaith of de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will be assassinated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I shall die in the performance of my duty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your mission will not be accomplished.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBelieve me,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cin enterprises of this kind, in\r\norder that one may arrive, four must set out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you are right, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you know Athos,\r\nPorthos, and Aramis, and you know if I can dispose of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout confiding to them the secret which I am not willing to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are sworn, once for all, to implicit confidence and devotedness\r\nagainst all proof. Besides, you can tell them that you have full\r\nconfidence in me, and they will not be more incredulous than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can send to each of them leave of absence for fifteen days, that is\r\nall\xe2\x80\x94to Athos, whose wound still makes him suffer, to go to the waters\r\nof Forges; to Porthos and Aramis to accompany their friend, whom they\r\nare not willing to abandon in such a painful condition. Sending their\r\nleave of absence will be proof enough that I authorize their journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, monsieur. You are a hundred times too good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegone, then, find them instantly, and let all be done tonight! Ha!\r\nBut first write your request to Dessessart. Perhaps you had a spy at\r\nyour heels; and your visit, if it should ever be known to the cardinal,\r\nwill thus seem legitimate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan drew up his request, and M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, on receiving it,\r\nassured him that by two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning the four leaves of\r\nabsence should be at the respective domiciles of the travelers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave the goodness to send mine to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s residence. I should dread\r\nsome disagreeable encounter if I were to go home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe easy. Adieu, and a prosperous voyage. _A propos_,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, calling him back.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan tapped the bag he had in his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough?\xe2\x80\x9d asked M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree hundred pistoles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, plenty! That would carry you to the end of the world. Begone,\r\nthen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan saluted M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who held out his hand to him;\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan pressed it with a respect mixed with gratitude. Since his\r\nfirst arrival at Paris, he had had constant occasion to honor this\r\nexcellent man, whom he had always found worthy, loyal, and great.\r\n\r\nHis first visit was to Aramis, at whose residence he had not been since\r\nthe famous evening on which he had followed Mme. Bonacieux. Still\r\nfurther, he had seldom seen the young Musketeer; but every time he had\r\nseen him, he had remarked a deep sadness imprinted on his countenance.\r\n\r\nThis evening, especially, Aramis was melancholy and thoughtful.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan asked some questions about this prolonged melancholy. Aramis\r\npleaded as his excuse a commentary upon the eighteenth chapter of St.\r\nAugustine, which he was forced to write in Latin for the following\r\nweek, and which preoccupied him a good deal.\r\n\r\nAfter the two friends had been chatting a few moments, a servant from\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville entered, bringing a sealed packet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe leave of absence Monsieur has asked for,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the lackey.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor me! I have asked for no leave of absence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue and take it!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, my friend,\r\nthere is a demipistole for your trouble; you will tell Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville that Monsieur Aramis is very much obliged to him. Go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe lackey bowed to the ground and departed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does all this mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPack up all you want for a journey of a fortnight, and follow me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I cannot leave Paris just now without knowing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is become of her? I suppose you mean\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecome of whom?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe woman who was here\xe2\x80\x94the woman with the embroidered handkerchief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you there was a woman here?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, becoming as pale\r\nas death.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you know who she is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe I can guess, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cSince you appear to know so many things, can\r\nyou tell me what is become of that woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI presume that she has returned to Tours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Tours? Yes, that may be. You evidently know her. But why did she\r\nreturn to Tours without telling me anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause she was in fear of being arrested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy has she not written to me, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause she was afraid of compromising you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, you restore me to life!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cI fancied myself\r\ndespised, betrayed. I was so delighted to see her again! I could not\r\nhave believed she would risk her liberty for me, and yet for what other\r\ncause could she have returned to Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the cause which today takes us to England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is this cause?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you\xe2\x80\x99ll know it someday, Aramis; but at present I must imitate the\r\ndiscretion of \xe2\x80\x98the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s niece.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis smiled, as he remembered the tale he had told his friends on a\r\ncertain evening. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, since she has left Paris, and you are\r\nsure of it, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, nothing prevents me, and I am ready to follow\r\nyou. You say we are going\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo see Athos now, and if you will come thither, I beg you to make\r\nhaste, for we have lost much time already. _A propos_, inform Bazin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill Bazin go with us?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps so. At all events, it is best that he should follow us to\r\nAthos\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis called Bazin, and, after having ordered him to join them at\r\nAthos\xe2\x80\x99s residence, said \xe2\x80\x9cLet us go then,\xe2\x80\x9d at the same time taking his\r\ncloak, sword, and three pistols, opening uselessly two or three drawers\r\nto see if he could not find stray coin. When well assured this search\r\nwas superfluous, he followed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, wondering to himself how this\r\nyoung Guardsman should know so well who the lady was to whom he had\r\ngiven hospitality, and that he should know better than himself what had\r\nbecome of her.\r\n\r\nOnly as they went out Aramis placed his hand upon the arm of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and looking at him earnestly, \xe2\x80\x9cYou have not spoken of this\r\nlady?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo nobody in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot even to Athos or Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not breathed a syllable to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood enough!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTranquil on this important point, Aramis continued his way with\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and both soon arrived at Athos\xe2\x80\x99s dwelling. They found him\r\nholding his leave of absence in one hand, and M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s note in\r\nthe other.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you explain to me what signify this leave of absence and this\r\nletter, which I have just received?\xe2\x80\x9d said the astonished Athos.\r\n\r\nMY DEAR ATHOS,\r\n    I wish, as your health absolutely requires it, that you should rest\r\n    for a fortnight. Go, then, and take the waters of Forges, or any\r\n    that may be more agreeable to you, and recuperate yourself as\r\n    quickly as possible.\r\n\r\n\r\nYours affectionate,\r\nDE TR\xc3\x89VILLE\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this leave of absence and that letter mean that you must follow\r\nme, Athos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the waters of Forges?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere or elsewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the king\xe2\x80\x99s service?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEither the king\xe2\x80\x99s or the queen\xe2\x80\x99s. Are we not their Majesties\xe2\x80\x99\r\nservants?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt that moment Porthos entered. \xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a\r\nstrange thing! Since when, I wonder, in the Musketeers, did they grant\r\nmen leave of absence without their asking for it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthey have friends who ask it for them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears there\xe2\x80\x99s something fresh here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we are going\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what country?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know much about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cAsk D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo London, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo London!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cand what the devil are we going to do in\r\nLondon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is what I am not at liberty to tell you, gentlemen; you must\r\ntrust to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in order to go to London,\xe2\x80\x9d added Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cmoney is needed, and I\r\nhave none.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, pulling out his treasure from his pocket,\r\nand placing it on the table. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are in this bag three hundred\r\npistoles. Let each take seventy-five; that is enough to take us to\r\nLondon and back. Besides, make yourselves easy; we shall not all arrive\r\nat London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, in all probability, some one of us will be left on the road.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this, then, a campaign upon which we are now entering?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of a most dangerous kind, I give you notice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! But if we do risk being killed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cat least I should\r\nlike to know what for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would be all the wiser,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI am somewhat of Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the king accustomed to give you such reasons? No. He says to you\r\njauntily, \xe2\x80\x98Gentlemen, there is fighting going on in Gascony or in\r\nFlanders; go and fight,\xe2\x80\x99 and you go there. Why? You need give\r\nyourselves no more uneasiness about this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9chere are our three leaves of\r\nabsence which came from Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, and here are three\r\nhundred pistoles which came from I don\xe2\x80\x99t know where. So let us go and\r\nget killed where we are told to go. Is life worth the trouble of so\r\nmany questions? D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, I am ready to follow you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd, indeed, I am not sorry to quit Paris;\r\nI had need of distraction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you will have distractions enough, gentlemen, be assured,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, now, when are we to go?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImmediately,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cwe have not a minute to lose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHello, Grimaud! Planchet! Mousqueton! Bazin!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the four young\r\nmen, calling their lackeys, \xe2\x80\x9cclean my boots, and fetch the horses from\r\nthe h\xc3\xb4tel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEach Musketeer was accustomed to leave at the general h\xc3\xb4tel, as at a\r\nbarrack, his own horse and that of his lackey. Planchet, Grimaud,\r\nMousqueton, and Bazin set off at full speed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow let us lay down the plan of campaign,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere do we\r\ngo first?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Calais,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is the most direct line to London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is my advice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour men traveling together would be suspected. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan will give\r\neach of us his instructions. I will go by the way of Boulogne to clear\r\nthe way; Athos will set out two hours after, by that of Amiens; Aramis\r\nwill follow us by that of Noyon; as to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he will go by what\r\nroute he thinks is best, in Planchet\xe2\x80\x99s clothes, while Planchet will\r\nfollow us like D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in the uniform of the Guards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cmy opinion is that it is not proper to allow\r\nlackeys to have anything to do in such an affair. A secret may, by\r\nchance, be betrayed by gentlemen; but it is almost always sold by\r\nlackeys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPorthos\xe2\x80\x99s plan appears to me to be impracticable,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cinasmuch as I am myself ignorant of what instructions I can give you.\r\nI am the bearer of a letter, that is all. I have not, and I cannot make\r\nthree copies of that letter, because it is sealed. We must, then, as it\r\nappears to me, travel in company. This letter is here, in this pocket,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand he pointed to the pocket which contained the letter. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I should\r\nbe killed, one of you must take it, and continue the route; if he be\r\nkilled, it will be another\xe2\x80\x99s turn, and so on\xe2\x80\x94provided a single one\r\narrives, that is all that is required.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, your opinion is mine,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cBesides, we\r\nmust be consistent; I am going to take the waters, you will accompany\r\nme. Instead of taking the waters of Forges, I go and take sea waters; I\r\nam free to do so. If anyone wishes to stop us, I will show Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s letter, and you will show your leaves of absence. If we are\r\nattacked, we will defend ourselves; if we are tried, we will stoutly\r\nmaintain that we were only anxious to dip ourselves a certain number of\r\ntimes in the sea. They would have an easy bargain of four isolated men;\r\nwhereas four men together make a troop. We will arm our four lackeys\r\nwith pistols and musketoons; if they send an army out against us, we\r\nwill give battle, and the survivor, as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan says, will carry the\r\nletter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell said,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cyou don\xe2\x80\x99t often speak, Athos, but when you\r\ndo speak, it is like St. John of the Golden Mouth. I agree to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nplan. And you, Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI agree to it, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cif D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan approves of it.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, being the bearer of the letter, is naturally the head of\r\nthe enterprise; let him decide, and we will execute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI decide that we should adopt Athos\xe2\x80\x99s plan,\r\nand that we set off in half an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgreed!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted the three Musketeers in chorus.\r\n\r\nEach one, stretching out his hand to the bag, took his seventy-five\r\npistoles, and made his preparations to set out at the time appointed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XX.\r\nTHE JOURNEY\r\n\r\n\r\nAt two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, our four adventurers left Paris by the\r\nBarri\xc3\xa8re St. Denis. As long as it was dark they remained silent; in\r\nspite of themselves they submitted to the influence of the obscurity,\r\nand apprehended ambushes on every side.\r\n\r\nWith the first rays of day their tongues were loosened; with the sun\r\ngaiety revived. It was like the eve of a battle; the heart beat, the\r\neyes laughed, and they felt that the life they were perhaps going to\r\nlose, was, after all, a good thing.\r\n\r\nBesides, the appearance of the caravan was formidable. The black horses\r\nof the Musketeers, their martial carriage, with the regimental step of\r\nthese noble companions of the soldier, would have betrayed the most\r\nstrict incognito. The lackeys followed, armed to the teeth.\r\n\r\nAll went well till they arrived at Chantilly, which they reached about\r\neight o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning. They needed breakfast, and alighted at\r\nthe door of an _auberge_, recommended by a sign representing St. Martin\r\ngiving half his cloak to a poor man. They ordered the lackeys not to\r\nunsaddle the horses, and to hold themselves in readiness to set off\r\nagain immediately.\r\n\r\nThey entered the common hall, and placed themselves at table. A\r\ngentleman, who had just arrived by the route of Dammartin, was seated\r\nat the same table, and was breakfasting. He opened the conversation\r\nabout rain and fine weather; the travelers replied. He drank to their\r\ngood health, and the travelers returned his politeness.\r\n\r\nBut at the moment Mousqueton came to announce that the horses were\r\nready, and they were arising from table, the stranger proposed to\r\nPorthos to drink the health of the cardinal. Porthos replied that he\r\nasked no better if the stranger, in his turn, would drink the health of\r\nthe king. The stranger cried that he acknowledged no other king but his\r\nEminence. Porthos called him drunk, and the stranger drew his sword.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have committed a piece of folly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cbut it can\xe2\x80\x99t be\r\nhelped; there is no drawing back. Kill the fellow, and rejoin us as\r\nsoon as you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll three remounted their horses, and set out at a good pace, while\r\nPorthos was promising his adversary to perforate him with all the\r\nthrusts known in the fencing schools.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere goes one!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, at the end of five hundred paces.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why did that man attack Porthos rather than any other one of us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, as Porthos was talking louder than the rest of us, he took\r\nhim for the chief,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI always said that this cadet from Gascony was a well of wisdom,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nmurmured Athos; and the travelers continued their route.\r\n\r\nAt Beauvais they stopped two hours, as well to breathe their horses a\r\nlittle as to wait for Porthos. At the end of two hours, as Porthos did\r\nnot come, not any news of him, they resumed their journey.\r\n\r\nAt a league from Beauvais, where the road was confined between two high\r\nbanks, they fell in with eight or ten men who, taking advantage of the\r\nroad being unpaved in this spot, appeared to be employed in digging\r\nholes and filling up the ruts with mud.\r\n\r\nAramis, not liking to soil his boots with this artificial mortar,\r\napostrophized them rather sharply. Athos wished to restrain him, but it\r\nwas too late. The laborers began to jeer the travelers and by their\r\ninsolence disturbed the equanimity even of the cool Athos, who urged on\r\nhis horse against one of them.\r\n\r\nThen each of these men retreated as far as the ditch, from which each\r\ntook a concealed musket; the result was that our seven travelers were\r\noutnumbered in weapons. Aramis received a ball which passed through his\r\nshoulder, and Mousqueton another ball which lodged in the fleshy part\r\nwhich prolongs the lower portion of the loins. Therefore Mousqueton\r\nalone fell from his horse, not because he was severely wounded, but not\r\nbeing able to see the wound, he judged it to be more serious than it\r\nreally was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was an ambuscade!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t waste a charge!\r\nForward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis, wounded as he was, seized the mane of his horse, which carried\r\nhim on with the others. Mousqueton\xe2\x80\x99s horse rejoined them, and galloped\r\nby the side of his companions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will serve us for a relay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather have had a hat,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cMine was carried\r\naway by a ball. By my faith, it is very fortunate that the letter was\r\nnot in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll kill poor Porthos when he comes up,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Porthos were on his legs, he would have rejoined us by this time,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cMy opinion is that on the ground the drunken man was not\r\nintoxicated.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey continued at their best speed for two hours, although the horses\r\nwere so fatigued that it was to be feared they would soon refuse\r\nservice.\r\n\r\nThe travelers had chosen crossroads in the hope that they might meet\r\nwith less interruption; but at Cr\xc3\xa8vec\xc5\x93ur, Aramis declared he could\r\nproceed no farther. In fact, it required all the courage which he\r\nconcealed beneath his elegant form and polished manners to bear him so\r\nfar. He grew more pale every minute, and they were obliged to support\r\nhim on his horse. They lifted him off at the door of a cabaret, left\r\nBazin with him, who, besides, in a skirmish was more embarrassing than\r\nuseful, and set forward again in the hope of sleeping at Amiens.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Morbleu_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, as soon as they were again in motion, \xe2\x80\x9creduced\r\nto two masters and Grimaud and Planchet! _Morbleu!_ I won\xe2\x80\x99t be their\r\ndupe, I will answer for it. I will neither open my mouth nor draw my\r\nsword between this and Calais. I swear by\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t waste time in swearing,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9clet us gallop, if our\r\nhorses will consent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the travelers buried their rowels in their horses\xe2\x80\x99 flanks, who thus\r\nvigorously stimulated recovered their energies. They arrived at Amiens\r\nat midnight, and alighted at the _auberge_ of the Golden Lily.\r\n\r\nThe host had the appearance of as honest a man as any on earth. He\r\nreceived the travelers with his candlestick in one hand and his cotton\r\nnightcap in the other. He wished to lodge the two travelers each in a\r\ncharming chamber; but unfortunately these charming chambers were at the\r\nopposite extremities of the h\xc3\xb4tel. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Athos refused them.\r\nThe host replied that he had no other worthy of their Excellencies; but\r\nthe travelers declared they would sleep in the common chamber, each on\r\na mattress which might be thrown upon the ground. The host insisted;\r\nbut the travelers were firm, and he was obliged to do as they wished.\r\n\r\nThey had just prepared their beds and barricaded their door within,\r\nwhen someone knocked at the yard shutter; they demanded who was there,\r\nand recognizing the voices of their lackeys, opened the shutter. It was\r\nindeed Planchet and Grimaud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud can take care of the horses,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you are\r\nwilling, gentlemen, I will sleep across your doorway, and you will then\r\nbe certain that nobody can reach you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd on what will you sleep?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is my bed,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Planchet, producing a bundle of straw.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are right. Mine host\xe2\x80\x99s face does\r\nnot please me at all; it is too gracious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor me either,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\nPlanchet mounted by the window and installed himself across the\r\ndoorway, while Grimaud went and shut himself up in the stable,\r\nundertaking that by five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning he and the four horses\r\nshould be ready.\r\n\r\nThe night was quiet enough. Toward two o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning somebody\r\nendeavored to open the door; but as Planchet awoke in an instant and\r\ncried, \xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there?\xe2\x80\x9d somebody replied that he was mistaken, and\r\nwent away.\r\n\r\nAt four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning they heard a terrible riot in the\r\nstables. Grimaud had tried to waken the stable boys, and the stable\r\nboys had beaten him. When they opened the window, they saw the poor lad\r\nlying senseless, with his head split by a blow with a pitchfork.\r\n\r\nPlanchet went down into the yard, and wished to saddle the horses; but\r\nthe horses were all used up. Mousqueton\xe2\x80\x99s horse which had traveled for\r\nfive or six hours without a rider the day before, might have been able\r\nto pursue the journey; but by an inconceivable error the veterinary\r\nsurgeon, who had been sent for, as it appeared, to bleed one of the\r\nhost\xe2\x80\x99s horses, had bled Mousqueton\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\nThis began to be annoying. All these successive accidents were perhaps\r\nthe result of chance; but they might be the fruits of a plot. Athos and\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went out, while Planchet was sent to inquire if there were\r\nnot three horses for sale in the neighborhood. At the door stood two\r\nhorses, fresh, strong, and fully equipped. These would just have suited\r\nthem. He asked where their masters were, and was informed that they had\r\npassed the night in the inn, and were then settling their bill with the\r\nhost.\r\n\r\nAthos went down to pay the reckoning, while D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Planchet\r\nstood at the street door. The host was in a lower and back room, to\r\nwhich Athos was requested to go.\r\n\r\nAthos entered without the least mistrust, and took out two pistoles to\r\npay the bill. The host was alone, seated before his desk, one of the\r\ndrawers of which was partly open. He took the money which Athos offered\r\nto him, and after turning and turning it over and over in his hands,\r\nsuddenly cried out that it was bad, and that he would have him and his\r\ncompanions arrested as forgers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou blackguard!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, going toward him, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll cut your ears\r\noff!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the same instant, four men, armed to the teeth, entered by side\r\ndoors, and rushed upon Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am taken!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted Athos, with all the power of his lungs. \xe2\x80\x9cGo on,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! Spur, spur!\xe2\x80\x9d and he fired two pistols.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Planchet did not require twice bidding; they unfastened\r\nthe two horses that were waiting at the door, leaped upon them, buried\r\ntheir spurs in their sides, and set off at full gallop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know what has become of Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan of Planchet,\r\nas they galloped on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw one fall at each of his two\r\nshots, and he appeared to me, through the glass door, to be fighting\r\nwith his sword with the others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrave Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand to think that we are compelled\r\nto leave him; maybe the same fate awaits us two paces hence. Forward,\r\nPlanchet, forward! You are a brave fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I told you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cPicards are found out by\r\nbeing used. Besides, I am here in my own country, and that excites me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd both, with free use of the spur, arrived at St. Omer without\r\ndrawing bit. At St. Omer they breathed their horses with the bridles\r\npassed under their arms for fear of accident, and ate a morsel from\r\ntheir hands on the stones of the street, after they departed again.\r\n\r\nAt a hundred paces from the gates of Calais, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s horse gave\r\nout, and could not by any means be made to get up again, the blood\r\nflowing from his eyes and his nose. There still remained Planchet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhorse; but he stopped short, and could not be made to move a step.\r\n\r\nFortunately, as we have said, they were within a hundred paces of the\r\ncity; they left their two nags upon the high road, and ran toward the\r\nquay. Planchet called his master\xe2\x80\x99s attention to a gentleman who had\r\njust arrived with his lackey, and only preceded them by about fifty\r\npaces. They made all speed to come up to this gentleman, who appeared\r\nto be in great haste. His boots were covered with dust, and he inquired\r\nif he could not instantly cross over to England.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing would be more easy,\xe2\x80\x9d said the captain of a vessel ready to set\r\nsail, \xe2\x80\x9cbut this morning came an order to let no one leave without\r\nexpress permission from the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have that permission,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman, drawing the paper from\r\nhis pocket; \xe2\x80\x9chere it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave it examined by the governor of the port,\xe2\x80\x9d said the shipmaster,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand give me the preference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere shall I find the governor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt his country house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is situated?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt a quarter of a league from the city. Look, you may see it from\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x94at the foot of that little hill, that slated roof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman. And, with his lackey, he took the road\r\nto the governor\xe2\x80\x99s country house.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Planchet followed the gentleman at a distance of five\r\nhundred paces. Once outside the city, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan overtook the gentleman\r\nas he was entering a little wood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, you appear to be in great haste?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one can be more so, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry for that,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cfor as I am in great haste\r\nlikewise, I wish to beg you to render me a service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo let me sail first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman; \xe2\x80\x9cI have traveled sixty leagues\r\nin forty hours, and by tomorrow at midday I must be in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have performed that same distance in forty hours, and by ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\nin the morning I must be in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery sorry, monsieur; but I was here first, and will not sail second.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry, too, monsieur; but I arrived second, and must sail first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe king\xe2\x80\x99s service!\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy own service!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this is a needless quarrel you seek with me, as it seems to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu!_ What do you desire it to be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I wish that order of which you are bearer, seeing that I\r\nhave not one of my own and must have one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou jest, I presume.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never jest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me pass!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall not pass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brave young man, I will blow out your brains. _Hola_, Lubin, my\r\npistols!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet,\xe2\x80\x9d called out D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ctake care of the lackey; I will\r\nmanage the master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPlanchet, emboldened by the first exploit, sprang upon Lubin; and being\r\nstrong and vigorous, he soon got him on the broad of his back, and\r\nplaced his knee upon his breast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on with your affair, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Planchet; \xe2\x80\x9cI have finished\r\nmine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeeing this, the gentleman drew his sword, and sprang upon D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan;\r\nbut he had too strong an adversary. In three seconds D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nwounded him three times, exclaiming at each thrust, \xe2\x80\x9cOne for Athos, one\r\nfor Porthos; and one for Aramis!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the third hit the gentleman fell like a log. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan believed him\r\nto be dead, or at least insensible, and went toward him for the purpose\r\nof taking the order; but the moment he extended his hand to search for\r\nit, the wounded man, who had not dropped his sword, plunged the point\r\ninto D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s breast, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cOne for you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd one for me\xe2\x80\x94the best for last!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, furious, nailing\r\nhim to the earth with a fourth thrust through his body.\r\n\r\nThis time the gentleman closed his eyes and fainted. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nsearched his pockets, and took from one of them the order for the\r\npassage. It was in the name of Comte de Wardes.\r\n\r\nThen, casting a glance on the handsome young man, who was scarcely\r\ntwenty-five years of age, and whom he was leaving in his gore, deprived\r\nof sense and perhaps dead, he gave a sigh for that unaccountable\r\ndestiny which leads men to destroy each other for the interests of\r\npeople who are strangers to them and who often do not even know that\r\nthey exist. But he was soon aroused from these reflections by Lubin,\r\nwho uttered loud cries and screamed for help with all his might.\r\n\r\nPlanchet grasped him by the throat, and pressed as hard as he could.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cas long as I hold him in this manner, he can\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ncry, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound; but as soon as I let go he will howl again. I know\r\nhim for a Norman, and Normans are obstinate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, tightly held as he was, Lubin endeavored still to cry out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStay!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; and taking out his handkerchief, he gagged\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9clet us bind him to a tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis being properly done, they drew the Comte de Wardes close to his\r\nservant; and as night was approaching, and as the wounded man and the\r\nbound man were at some little distance within the wood, it was evident\r\nthey were likely to remain there till the next day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cto the Governor\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are wounded, it seems,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s nothing! Let us attend to what is more pressing first, and\r\nthen we will attend to my wound; besides, it does not seem very\r\ndangerous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they both set forward as fast as they could toward the country\r\nhouse of the worthy functionary.\r\n\r\nThe Comte de Wardes was announced, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was introduced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have an order signed by the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d said the governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9chere it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah! It is quite regular and explicit,\xe2\x80\x9d said the governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost likely,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI am one of his most faithful\r\nservants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears that his Eminence is anxious to prevent someone from\r\ncrossing to England?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; a certain D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, a B\xc3\xa9arnese gentleman who left Paris in\r\ncompany with three of his friends, with the intention of going to\r\nLondon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know him personally?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the governor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDescribe him to me, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing more easy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan gave, feature for feature, a description of the Comte de\r\nWardes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he accompanied?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; by a lackey named Lubin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will keep a sharp lookout for them; and if we lay hands on them his\r\nEminence may be assured they will be reconducted to Paris under a good\r\nescort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd by doing so, Monsieur the Governor,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will\r\ndeserve well of the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you see him on your return, Monsieur Count?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout a doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him, I beg you, that I am his humble servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not fail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDelighted with this assurance the governor countersigned the passport\r\nand delivered it to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan lost no time in useless\r\ncompliments. He thanked the governor, bowed, and departed. Once\r\noutside, he and Planchet set off as fast as they could; and by making a\r\nlong detour avoided the wood and reentered the city by another gate.\r\n\r\nThe vessel was quite ready to sail, and the captain was waiting on the\r\nwharf. \xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, on perceiving D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is my pass countersigned,\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that other gentleman?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will not go today,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut here, I\xe2\x80\x99ll pay you for us\r\ntwo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case let us go,\xe2\x80\x9d said the shipmaster.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nHe leaped with Planchet into the boat, and five minutes after they were\r\non board. It was time; for they had scarcely sailed half a league, when\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan saw a flash and heard a detonation. It was the cannon which\r\nannounced the closing of the port.\r\n\r\nHe had now leisure to look to his wound. Fortunately, as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nthought, it was not dangerous. The point of the sword had touched a\r\nrib, and glanced along the bone. Still further, his shirt had stuck to\r\nthe wound, and he had lost only a few drops of blood.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was worn out with fatigue. A mattress was laid upon the deck\r\nfor him. He threw himself upon it, and fell asleep.\r\n\r\nOn the morrow, at break of day, they were still three or four leagues\r\nfrom the coast of England. The breeze had been so light all night, they\r\nhad made but little progress. At ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock the vessel cast anchor in\r\nthe harbor of Dover, and at half past ten D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan placed his foot on\r\nEnglish land, crying, \xe2\x80\x9cHere I am at last!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut that was not all; they must get to London. In England the post was\r\nwell served. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Planchet took each a post horse, and a\r\npostillion rode before them. In a few hours they were in the capital.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not know London; he did not know a word of English; but\r\nhe wrote the name of Buckingham on a piece of paper, and everyone\r\npointed out to him the way to the duke\xe2\x80\x99s h\xc3\xb4tel.\r\n\r\nThe duke was at Windsor hunting with the king. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan inquired for\r\nthe confidential valet of the duke, who, having accompanied him in all\r\nhis voyages, spoke French perfectly well; he told him that he came from\r\nParis on an affair of life and death, and that he must speak with his\r\nmaster instantly.\r\n\r\nThe confidence with which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan spoke convinced Patrick, which was\r\nthe name of this minister of the minister. He ordered two horses to be\r\nsaddled, and himself went as guide to the young Guardsman. As for\r\nPlanchet, he had been lifted from his horse as stiff as a rush; the\r\npoor lad\xe2\x80\x99s strength was almost exhausted. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan seemed iron.\r\n\r\nOn their arrival at the castle they learned that Buckingham and the\r\nking were hawking in the marshes two or three leagues away. In twenty\r\nminutes they were on the spot named. Patrick soon caught the sound of\r\nhis master\xe2\x80\x99s voice calling his falcon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhom must I announce to my Lord Duke?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Patrick.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe young man who one evening sought a quarrel with him on the Pont\r\nNeuf, opposite the Samaritaine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA singular introduction!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will find that it is as good as another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPatrick galloped off, reached the duke, and announced to him in the\r\nterms directed that a messenger awaited him.\r\n\r\nBuckingham at once remembered the circumstance, and suspecting that\r\nsomething was going on in France of which it was necessary he should be\r\ninformed, he only took the time to inquire where the messenger was, and\r\nrecognizing from afar the uniform of the Guards, he put his horse into\r\na gallop, and rode straight up to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. Patrick discreetly kept\r\nin the background.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo misfortune has happened to the queen?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Buckingham, the\r\ninstant he came up, throwing all his fear and love into the question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe not; nevertheless I believe she runs some great peril from\r\nwhich your Grace alone can extricate her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Buckingham. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it? I should be too happy to be of any\r\nservice to her. Speak, speak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this letter,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis letter! From whom comes this letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom her Majesty, as I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom her Majesty!\xe2\x80\x9d said Buckingham, becoming so pale that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nfeared he would faint as he broke the seal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this rent?\xe2\x80\x9d said he, showing D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan a place where it had\r\nbeen pierced through.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI did not see that; it was the sword of the\r\nComte de Wardes which made that hole, when he gave me a good thrust in\r\nthe breast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wounded?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Buckingham, as he opened the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing but a scratch,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust heaven, what have I read?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the duke. \xe2\x80\x9cPatrick, remain here,\r\nor rather join the king, wherever he may be, and tell his Majesty that\r\nI humbly beg him to excuse me, but an affair of the greatest importance\r\nrecalls me to London. Come, monsieur, come!\xe2\x80\x9d and both set off towards\r\nthe capital at full gallop.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXI.\r\nTHE COUNTESS DE WINTER\r\n\r\n\r\nAs they rode along, the duke endeavored to draw from D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, not\r\nall that had happened, but what D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan himself knew. By adding all\r\nthat he heard from the mouth of the young man to his own remembrances,\r\nhe was enabled to form a pretty exact idea of a position of the\r\nseriousness of which, for the rest, the queen\xe2\x80\x99s letter, short but\r\nexplicit, gave him the clue. But that which astonished him most was\r\nthat the cardinal, so deeply interested in preventing this young man\r\nfrom setting his foot in England, had not succeeded in arresting him on\r\nthe road. It was then, upon the manifestation of this astonishment,\r\nthat D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related to him the precaution taken, and how, thanks to\r\nthe devotion of his three friends, whom he had left scattered and\r\nbleeding on the road, he had succeeded in coming off with a single\r\nsword thrust, which had pierced the queen\xe2\x80\x99s letter and for which he had\r\nrepaid M. de Wardes with such terrible coin. While he was listening to\r\nthis recital, delivered with the greatest simplicity, the duke looked\r\nfrom time to time at the young man with astonishment, as if he could\r\nnot comprehend how so much prudence, courage, and devotedness could be\r\nallied with a countenance which indicated not more than twenty years.\r\n\r\nThe horses went like the wind, and in a few minutes they were at the\r\ngates of London. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan imagined that on arriving in town the duke\r\nwould slacken his pace, but it was not so. He kept on his way at the\r\nsame rate, heedless about upsetting those whom he met on the road. In\r\nfact, in crossing the city two or three accidents of this kind\r\nhappened; but Buckingham did not even turn his head to see what became\r\nof those he had knocked down. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan followed him amid cries which\r\nstrongly resembled curses.\r\n\r\nOn entering the court of his h\xc3\xb4tel, Buckingham sprang from his horse,\r\nand without thinking what became of the animal, threw the bridle on his\r\nneck, and sprang toward the vestibule. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did the same, with a\r\nlittle more concern, however, for the noble creatures, whose merits he\r\nfully appreciated; but he had the satisfaction of seeing three or four\r\ngrooms run from the kitchens and the stables, and busy themselves with\r\nthe steeds.\r\n\r\nThe duke walked so fast that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had some trouble in keeping up\r\nwith him. He passed through several apartments, of an elegance of which\r\neven the greatest nobles of France had not even an idea, and arrived at\r\nlength in a bedchamber which was at once a miracle of taste and of\r\nrichness. In the alcove of this chamber was a door concealed in the\r\ntapestry which the duke opened with a little gold key which he wore\r\nsuspended from his neck by a chain of the same metal. With discretion\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remained behind; but at the moment when Buckingham crossed\r\nthe threshold, he turned round, and seeing the hesitation of the young\r\nman, \xe2\x80\x9cCome in!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cand if you have the good fortune to be\r\nadmitted to her Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s presence, tell her what you have seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEncouraged by this invitation, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan followed the duke, who closed\r\nthe door after them. The two found themselves in a small chapel covered\r\nwith a tapestry of Persian silk worked with gold, and brilliantly\r\nlighted with a vast number of candles. Over a species of altar, and\r\nbeneath a canopy of blue velvet, surmounted by white and red plumes,\r\nwas a full-length portrait of Anne of Austria, so perfect in its\r\nresemblance that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise on beholding it.\r\nOne might believe the queen was about to speak. On the altar, and\r\nbeneath the portrait, was the casket containing the diamond studs.\r\n\r\nThe duke approached the altar, knelt as a priest might have done before\r\na crucifix, and opened the casket. \xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, drawing from the\r\ncasket a large bow of blue ribbon all sparkling with diamonds, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\r\nare the precious studs which I have taken an oath should be buried with\r\nme. The queen gave them to me, the queen requires them again. Her will\r\nbe done, like that of God, in all things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, he began to kiss, one after the other, those dear studs with\r\nwhich he was about to part. All at once he uttered a terrible cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, anxiously; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has\r\nhappened to you, my Lord?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll is lost!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Buckingham, becoming as pale as a corpse; \xe2\x80\x9ctwo of\r\nthe studs are wanting, there are only ten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you have lost them, my Lord, or do you think they have been\r\nstolen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have been stolen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the duke, \xe2\x80\x9cand it is the cardinal who\r\nhas dealt this blow. Hold; see! The ribbons which held them have been\r\ncut with scissors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf my Lord suspects they have been stolen, perhaps the person who\r\nstole them still has them in his hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait, wait!\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke. \xe2\x80\x9cThe only time I have worn these studs was\r\nat a ball given by the king eight days ago at Windsor. The Comtesse de\r\nWinter, with whom I had quarreled, became reconciled to me at that\r\nball. That reconciliation was nothing but the vengeance of a jealous\r\nwoman. I have never seen her from that day. The woman is an agent of\r\nthe cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has agents, then, throughout the world?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Buckingham, grating his teeth with rage. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is a\r\nterrible antagonist. But when is this ball to take place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonday next.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonday next! Still five days before us. That\xe2\x80\x99s more time than we want.\r\nPatrick!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the duke, opening the door of the chapel, \xe2\x80\x9cPatrick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHis confidential valet appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy jeweler and my secretary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe valet went out with a mute promptitude which showed him accustomed\r\nto obey blindly and without reply.\r\n\r\nBut although the jeweler had been mentioned first, it was the secretary\r\nwho first made his appearance. This was simply because he lived in the\r\nh\xc3\xb4tel. He found Buckingham seated at a table in his bedchamber, writing\r\norders with his own hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Jackson,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cgo instantly to the Lord Chancellor, and tell\r\nhim that I charge him with the execution of these orders. I wish them\r\nto be promulgated immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my Lord, if the Lord Chancellor interrogates me upon the motives\r\nwhich may have led your Grace to adopt such an extraordinary measure,\r\nwhat shall I reply?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat such is my pleasure, and that I answer for my will to no man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill that be the answer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the secretary, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich he\r\nmust transmit to his Majesty if, by chance, his Majesty should have the\r\ncuriosity to know why no vessel is to leave any of the ports of Great\r\nBritain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, Mr. Jackson,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Buckingham. \xe2\x80\x9cHe will say, in that\r\ncase, to the king that I am determined on war, and that this measure is\r\nmy first act of hostility against France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe secretary bowed and retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are safe on that side,\xe2\x80\x9d said Buckingham, turning toward D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf the studs are not yet gone to Paris, they will not arrive till\r\nafter you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have just placed an embargo on all vessels at present in his\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s ports, and without particular permission, not one dare lift\r\nan anchor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan looked with stupefaction at a man who thus employed the\r\nunlimited power with which he was clothed by the confidence of a king\r\nin the prosecution of his intrigues. Buckingham saw by the expression\r\nof the young man\xe2\x80\x99s face what was passing in his mind, and he smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, Anne of Austria is my true queen. Upon a word\r\nfrom her, I would betray my country, I would betray my king, I would\r\nbetray my God. She asked me not to send the Protestants of La Rochelle\r\nthe assistance I promised them; I have not done so. I broke my word, it\r\nis true; but what signifies that? I obeyed my love; and have I not been\r\nrichly paid for that obedience? It was to that obedience I owe her\r\nportrait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was amazed to note by what fragile and unknown threads the\r\ndestinies of nations and the lives of men are suspended. He was lost in\r\nthese reflections when the goldsmith entered. He was an Irishman\xe2\x80\x94one of\r\nthe most skillful of his craft, and who himself confessed that he\r\ngained a hundred thousand livres a year by the Duke of Buckingham.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke, leading him into the chapel, \xe2\x80\x9clook at\r\nthese diamond studs, and tell me what they are worth apiece.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe goldsmith cast a glance at the elegant manner in which they were\r\nset, calculated, one with another, what the diamonds were worth, and\r\nwithout hesitation said, \xe2\x80\x9cFifteen hundred pistoles each, my Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many days would it require to make two studs exactly like them?\r\nYou see there are two wanting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEight days, my Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will give you three thousand pistoles apiece if I can have them by\r\nthe day after tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, they shall be yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a jewel of a man, Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly; but that is not all. These\r\nstuds cannot be trusted to anybody; it must be done in the palace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible, my Lord! There is no one but myself can so execute them\r\nthat one cannot tell the new from the old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore, my dear Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly, you are my prisoner. And if you wish\r\never to leave my palace, you cannot; so make the best of it. Name to me\r\nsuch of your workmen as you need, and point out the tools they must\r\nbring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe goldsmith knew the duke. He knew all objection would be useless,\r\nand instantly determined how to act.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I be permitted to inform my wife?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you may even see her if you like, my dear Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly. Your\r\ncaptivity shall be mild, be assured; and as every inconvenience\r\ndeserves its indemnification, here is, in addition to the price of the\r\nstuds, an order for a thousand pistoles, to make you forget the\r\nannoyance I cause you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could not get over the surprise created in him by this\r\nminister, who thus open-handed, sported with men and millions.\r\n\r\nAs to the goldsmith, he wrote to his wife, sending her the order for\r\nthe thousand pistoles, and charging her to send him, in exchange, his\r\nmost skillful apprentice, an assortment of diamonds, of which he gave\r\nthe names and the weight, and the necessary tools.\r\n\r\nBuckingham conducted the goldsmith to the chamber destined for him, and\r\nwhich, at the end of half an hour, was transformed into a workshop.\r\nThen he placed a sentinel at each door, with an order to admit nobody\r\nupon any pretense but his _valet de chambre_, Patrick. We need not add\r\nthat the goldsmith, O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly, and his assistant, were prohibited from\r\ngoing out under any pretext. This point, settled, the duke turned to\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, my young friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cEngland is all our own.\r\nWhat do you wish for? What do you desire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA bed, my Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cAt present, I confess, that is\r\nthe thing I stand most in need of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBuckingham gave D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan a chamber adjoining his own. He wished to\r\nhave the young man at hand\xe2\x80\x94not that he at all mistrusted him, but for\r\nthe sake of having someone to whom he could constantly talk of the\r\nqueen.\r\n\r\nIn one hour after, the ordinance was published in London that no vessel\r\nbound for France should leave port, not even the packet boat with\r\nletters. In the eyes of everybody this was a declaration of war between\r\nthe two kingdoms.\r\n\r\nOn the day after the morrow, by eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the two diamond studs\r\nwere finished, and they were so completely imitated, so perfectly\r\nalike, that Buckingham could not tell the new ones from the old ones,\r\nand experts in such matters would have been deceived as he was. He\r\nimmediately called D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cHere,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to him, \xe2\x80\x9care the diamond\r\nstuds that you came to bring; and be my witness that I have done all\r\nthat human power could do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied, my Lord, I will tell all that I have seen. But does your\r\nGrace mean to give me the studs without the casket?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe casket would encumber you. Besides, the casket is the more\r\nprecious from being all that is left to me. You will say that I keep\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will perform your commission, word for word, my Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Buckingham, looking earnestly at the young man, \xe2\x80\x9chow\r\nshall I ever acquit myself of the debt I owe you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan blushed up to the whites of his eyes. He saw that the duke\r\nwas searching for a means of making him accept something and the idea\r\nthat the blood of his friends and himself was about to be paid for with\r\nEnglish gold was strangely repugnant to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us understand each other, my Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand let\r\nus make things clear beforehand in order that there may be no mistake.\r\nI am in the service of the King and Queen of France, and form part of\r\nthe company of Monsieur Dessessart, who, as well as his brother-in-law,\r\nMonsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, is particularly attached to their Majesties. What\r\nI have done, then, has been for the queen, and not at all for your\r\nGrace. And still further, it is very probable I should not have done\r\nanything of this, if it had not been to make myself agreeable to\r\nsomeone who is my lady, as the queen is yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cand I even believe that I know that\r\nother person; it is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, I have not named her!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the young man, warmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke; \xe2\x80\x9cand it is to this person I am bound to\r\ndischarge my debt of gratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have said, my Lord; for truly, at this moment when there is\r\nquestion of war, I confess to you that I see nothing in your Grace but\r\nan Englishman, and consequently an enemy whom I should have much\r\ngreater pleasure in meeting on the field of battle than in the park at\r\nWindsor or the corridors of the Louvre\xe2\x80\x94all which, however, will not\r\nprevent me from executing to the very point my commission or from\r\nlaying down my life, if there be need of it, to accomplish it; but I\r\nrepeat it to your Grace, without your having personally on that account\r\nmore to thank me for in this second interview than for what I did for\r\nyou in the first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe say, \xe2\x80\x98Proud as a Scotsman,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the Duke of Buckingham.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we say, \xe2\x80\x98Proud as a Gascon,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Gascons are\r\nthe Scots of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan bowed to the duke, and was retiring.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, are you going away in that manner? Where, and how?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFore Gad, these Frenchmen have no consideration!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had forgotten that England was an island, and that you were the king\r\nof it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the riverside, ask for the brig _Sund_, and give this letter to\r\nthe captain; he will convey you to a little port, where certainly you\r\nare not expected, and which is ordinarily only frequented by\r\nfishermen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe name of that port?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. Valery; but listen. When you have arrived there you will go to a\r\nmean tavern, without a name and without a sign\xe2\x80\x94a mere fisherman\xe2\x80\x99s hut.\r\nYou cannot be mistaken; there is but one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfterward?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will ask for the host, and will repeat to him the word \xe2\x80\x98Forward!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn French, _En avant_. It is the password. He will give you a horse\r\nall saddled, and will point out to you the road you ought to take. You\r\nwill find, in the same way, four relays on your route. If you will give\r\nat each of these relays your address in Paris, the four horses will\r\nfollow you thither. You already know two of them, and you appeared to\r\nappreciate them like a judge. They were those we rode on; and you may\r\nrely upon me for the others not being inferior to them. These horses\r\nare equipped for the field. However proud you may be, you will not\r\nrefuse to accept one of them, and to request your three companions to\r\naccept the others\xe2\x80\x94that is, in order to make war against us. Besides,\r\nthe end justified the means, as you Frenchmen say, does it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my Lord, I accept them,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand if it please God,\r\nwe will make a good use of your presents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now, your hand, young man. Perhaps we shall soon meet on the\r\nfield of battle; but in the meantime we shall part good friends, I\r\nhope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my Lord; but with the hope of soon becoming enemies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied; I promise you that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI depend upon your word, my Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan bowed to the duke, and made his way as quickly as possible\r\nto the riverside. Opposite the Tower of London he found the vessel that\r\nhad been named to him, delivered his letter to the captain, who after\r\nhaving it examined by the governor of the port made immediate\r\npreparations to sail.\r\n\r\nFifty vessels were waiting to set out. Passing alongside one of them,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan fancied he perceived on board it the woman of Meung\xe2\x80\x94the same\r\nwhom the unknown gentleman had called Milady, and whom D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nthought so handsome; but thanks to the current of the stream and a fair\r\nwind, his vessel passed so quickly that he had little more than a\r\nglimpse of her.\r\n\r\nThe next day about nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, he landed at St.\r\nValery. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went instantly in search of the inn, and easily\r\ndiscovered it by the riotous noise which resounded from it. War between\r\nEngland and France was talked of as near and certain, and the jolly\r\nsailors were having a carousal.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan made his way through the crowd, advanced toward the host,\r\nand pronounced the word \xe2\x80\x9cForward!\xe2\x80\x9d The host instantly made him a sign\r\nto follow, went out with him by a door which opened into a yard, led\r\nhim to the stable, where a saddled horse awaited him, and asked him if\r\nhe stood in need of anything else.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to know the route I am to follow,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo from hence to Blangy, and from Blangy to Neufch\xc3\xa2tel. At Neufch\xc3\xa2tel,\r\ngo to the tavern of the Golden Harrow, give the password to the\r\nlandlord, and you will find, as you have here, a horse ready saddled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I anything to pay?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything is paid,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the host, \xe2\x80\x9cand liberally. Begone, and may\r\nGod guide you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young man, and set off at full gallop.\r\n\r\nFour hours later he was in Neufch\xc3\xa2tel. He strictly followed the\r\ninstructions he had received. At Neufch\xc3\xa2tel, as at St. Valery, he found\r\na horse quite ready and awaiting him. He was about to remove the\r\npistols from the saddle he had quit to the one he was about to fill,\r\nbut he found the holsters furnished with similar pistols.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour address at Paris?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cH\xc3\xb4tel of the Guards, company of Dessessart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the questioner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich route must I take?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in his turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat of Rouen; but you will leave the city on your right. You must\r\nstop at the little village of Eccuis, in which there is but one\r\ntavern\xe2\x80\x94the Shield of France. Don\xe2\x80\x99t condemn it from appearances; you\r\nwill find a horse in the stables quite as good as this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe same password?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, master!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good journey, gentlemen! Do you want anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan shook his head, and set off at full speed. At Eccuis, the\r\nsame scene was repeated. He found as provident a host and a fresh\r\nhorse. He left his address as he had done before, and set off again at\r\nthe same pace for Pontoise. At Pontoise he changed his horse for the\r\nlast time, and at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock galloped into the yard of Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nh\xc3\xb4tel. He had made nearly sixty leagues in little more than twelve\r\nhours.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville received him as if he had seen him that same morning;\r\nonly, when pressing his hand a little more warmly than usual, he\r\ninformed him that the company of Dessessart was on duty at the Louvre,\r\nand that he might repair at once to his post.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXII.\r\nTHE BALLET OF LA MERLAISON\r\n\r\n\r\nOn the morrow, nothing was talked of in Paris but the ball which the\r\naldermen of the city were to give to the king and queen, and in which\r\ntheir Majesties were to dance the famous La Merlaison\xe2\x80\x94the favorite\r\nballet of the king.\r\n\r\nEight days had been occupied in preparations at the H\xc3\xb4tel de Ville for\r\nthis important evening. The city carpenters had erected scaffolds upon\r\nwhich the invited ladies were to be placed; the city grocer had\r\nornamented the chambers with two hundred _flambeaux_ of white wax, a\r\npiece of luxury unheard of at that period; and twenty violins were\r\nordered, and the price for them fixed at double the usual rate, upon\r\ncondition, said the report, that they should be played all night.\r\n\r\nAt ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning the Sieur de la Coste, ensign in the\r\nking\xe2\x80\x99s Guards, followed by two officers and several archers of that\r\nbody, came to the city registrar, named Clement, and demanded of him\r\nall the keys of the rooms and offices of the h\xc3\xb4tel. These keys were\r\ngiven up to him instantly. Each of them had a ticket attached to it, by\r\nwhich it might be recognized; and from that moment the Sieur de la\r\nCoste was charged with the care of all the doors and all the avenues.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock came in his turn Duhallier, captain of the Guards,\r\nbringing with him fifty archers, who were distributed immediately\r\nthrough the H\xc3\xb4tel de Ville, at the doors assigned them.\r\n\r\nAt three o\xe2\x80\x99clock came two companies of the Guards, one French, the\r\nother Swiss. The company of French guards was composed of half of M.\r\nDuhallier\xe2\x80\x99s men and half of M. Dessessart\xe2\x80\x99s men.\r\n\r\nAt six in the evening the guests began to come. As fast as they\r\nentered, they were placed in the grand saloon, on the platforms\r\nprepared for them.\r\n\r\nAt nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock Madame la Premi\xc3\xa8re Pr\xc3\xa9sidente arrived. As next to the\r\nqueen, she was the most considerable personage of the f\xc3\xaate, she was\r\nreceived by the city officials, and placed in a box opposite to that\r\nwhich the queen was to occupy.\r\n\r\nAt ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the king\xe2\x80\x99s collation, consisting of preserves and other\r\ndelicacies, was prepared in the little room on the side of the church\r\nof St. Jean, in front of the silver buffet of the city, which was\r\nguarded by four archers.\r\n\r\nAt midnight great cries and loud acclamations were heard. It was the\r\nking, who was passing through the streets which led from the Louvre to\r\nthe H\xc3\xb4tel de Ville, and which were all illuminated with colored\r\nlanterns.\r\n\r\nImmediately the aldermen, clothed in their cloth robes and preceded by\r\nsix sergeants, each holding a _flambeau_ in his hand, went to attend\r\nupon the king, whom they met on the steps, where the provost of the\r\nmerchants made him the speech of welcome\xe2\x80\x94a compliment to which his\r\nMajesty replied with an apology for coming so late, laying the blame\r\nupon the cardinal, who had detained him till eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock, talking of\r\naffairs of state.\r\n\r\nHis Majesty, in full dress, was accompanied by his royal Highness, M.\r\nle Comte de Soissons, by the Grand Prior, by the Duc de Longueville, by\r\nthe Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Eub\xc5\x93uf, by the Comte d\xe2\x80\x99Harcourt, by the Comte de la\r\nRoche-Guyon, by M. de Liancourt, by M. de Baradas, by the Comte de\r\nCramail, and by the Chevalier de Souveray. Everybody noticed that the\r\nking looked dull and preoccupied.\r\n\r\nA private room had been prepared for the king and another for Monsieur.\r\nIn each of these closets were placed masquerade dresses. The same had\r\nbeen done for the queen and Madame the President. The nobles and ladies\r\nof their Majesties\xe2\x80\x99 suites were to dress, two by two, in chambers\r\nprepared for the purpose. Before entering his closet the king desired\r\nto be informed the moment the cardinal arrived.\r\n\r\nHalf an hour after the entrance of the king, fresh acclamations were\r\nheard; these announced the arrival of the queen. The aldermen did as\r\nthey had done before, and preceded by their sergeants, advanced to\r\nreceive their illustrious guest. The queen entered the great hall; and\r\nit was remarked that, like the king, she looked dull and even weary.\r\n\r\nAt the moment she entered, the curtain of a small gallery which to that\r\ntime had been closed, was drawn, and the pale face of the cardinal\r\nappeared, he being dressed as a Spanish cavalier. His eyes were fixed\r\nupon those of the queen, and a smile of terrible joy passed over his\r\nlips; the queen did not wear her diamond studs.\r\n\r\nThe queen remained for a short time to receive the compliments of the\r\ncity dignitaries and to reply to the salutations of the ladies. All at\r\nonce the king appeared with the cardinal at one of the doors of the\r\nhall. The cardinal was speaking to him in a low voice, and the king was\r\nvery pale.\r\n\r\nThe king made his way through the crowd without a mask, and the ribbons\r\nof his doublet scarcely tied. He went straight to the queen, and in an\r\naltered voice said, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, madame, have you not thought proper to wear\r\nyour diamond studs, when you know it would give me so much\r\ngratification?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe queen cast a glance around her, and saw the cardinal behind, with a\r\ndiabolical smile on his countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the queen, with a faltering voice, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause, in the\r\nmidst of such a crowd as this, I feared some accident might happen to\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you were wrong, madame. If I made you that present it was that you\r\nmight adorn yourself therewith. I tell you that you were wrong.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe voice of the king was tremulous with anger.
