Everybody looked and\r\nlistened with astonishment, comprehending nothing of what passed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSire,\xe2\x80\x9d said the queen, \xe2\x80\x9cI can send for them to the Louvre, where they\r\nare, and thus your Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s wishes will be complied with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo so, madame, do so, and that at once; for within an hour the ballet\r\nwill commence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe queen bent in token of submission, and followed the ladies who were\r\nto conduct her to her room. On his part the king returned to his\r\napartment.\r\n\r\nThere was a moment of trouble and confusion in the assembly. Everybody\r\nhad remarked that something had passed between the king and queen; but\r\nboth of them had spoken so low that everybody, out of respect, withdrew\r\nseveral steps, so that nobody had heard anything. The violins began to\r\nsound with all their might, but nobody listened to them.\r\n\r\nThe king came out first from his room. He was in a most elegant hunting\r\ncostume; and Monsieur and the other nobles were dressed like him. This\r\nwas the costume that best became the king. So dressed, he really\r\nappeared the first gentleman of his kingdom.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal drew near to the king, and placed in his hand a small\r\ncasket. The king opened it, and found in it two diamond studs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does this mean?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded he of the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter; \xe2\x80\x9conly, if the queen has the studs, which\r\nI very much doubt, count them, sire, and if you only find ten, ask her\r\nMajesty who can have stolen from her the two studs that are here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe king looked at the cardinal as if to interrogate him; but he had\r\nnot time to address any question to him\xe2\x80\x94a cry of admiration burst from\r\nevery mouth. If the king appeared to be the first gentleman of his\r\nkingdom, the queen was without doubt the most beautiful woman in\r\nFrance.\r\n\r\nIt is true that the habit of a huntress became her admirably. She wore\r\na beaver hat with blue feathers, a surtout of gray-pearl velvet,\r\nfastened with diamond clasps, and a petticoat of blue satin,\r\nembroidered with silver. On her left shoulder sparkled the diamond\r\nstuds, on a bow of the same color as the plumes and the petticoat.\r\n\r\nThe king trembled with joy and the cardinal with vexation; although,\r\ndistant as they were from the queen, they could not count the studs.\r\nThe queen had them. The only question was, had she ten or twelve?\r\n\r\nAt that moment the violins sounded the signal for the ballet. The king\r\nadvanced toward Madame the President, with whom he was to dance, and\r\nhis Highness Monsieur with the queen. They took their places, and the\r\nballet began.\r\n\r\nThe king danced facing the queen, and every time he passed by her, he\r\ndevoured with his eyes those studs of which he could not ascertain the\r\nnumber. A cold sweat covered the brow of the cardinal.\r\n\r\nThe ballet lasted an hour, and had sixteen _entr\xc3\xa9es_. The ballet ended\r\namid the applause of the whole assemblage, and everyone reconducted his\r\nlady to her place; but the king took advantage of the privilege he had\r\nof leaving his lady, to advance eagerly toward the queen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cfor the deference you have shown to my\r\nwishes, but I think you want two of the studs, and I bring them back to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words he held out to the queen the two studs the cardinal\r\nhad given him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, sire?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young queen, affecting surprise, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are giving\r\nme, then, two more: I shall have fourteen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact the king counted them, and the twelve studs were all on her\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\nThe king called the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does this mean, Monsieur Cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the king in a severe\r\ntone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis means, sire,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I was desirous of\r\npresenting her Majesty with these two studs, and that not daring to\r\noffer them myself, I adopted this means of inducing her to accept\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am the more grateful to your Eminence,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Anne of Austria,\r\nwith a smile that proved she was not the dupe of this ingenious\r\ngallantry, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom being certain that these two studs alone have cost you\r\nas much as all the others cost his Majesty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen saluting the king and the cardinal, the queen resumed her way to\r\nthe chamber in which she had dressed, and where she was to take off her\r\ncostume.\r\n\r\nThe attention which we have been obliged to give, during the\r\ncommencement of the chapter, to the illustrious personages we have\r\nintroduced into it, has diverted us for an instant from him to whom\r\nAnne of Austria owed the extraordinary triumph she had obtained over\r\nthe cardinal; and who, confounded, unknown, lost in the crowd gathered\r\nat one of the doors, looked on at this scene, comprehensible only to\r\nfour persons\xe2\x80\x94the king, the queen, his Eminence, and himself.\r\n\r\nThe queen had just regained her chamber, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was about to\r\nretire, when he felt his shoulder lightly touched. He turned and saw a\r\nyoung woman, who made him a sign to follow her. The face of this young\r\nwoman was covered with a black velvet mask; but notwithstanding this\r\nprecaution, which was in fact taken rather against others than against\r\nhim, he at once recognized his usual guide, the light and intelligent\r\nMme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\nOn the evening before, they had scarcely seen each other for a moment\r\nat the apartment of the Swiss guard, Germain, whither D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nsent for her. The haste which the young woman was in to convey to the\r\nqueen the excellent news of the happy return of her messenger prevented\r\nthe two lovers from exchanging more than a few words. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\ntherefore followed Mme. Bonacieux moved by a double sentiment\xe2\x80\x94love and\r\ncuriosity. All the way, and in proportion as the corridors became more\r\ndeserted, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan wished to stop the young woman, seize her and gaze\r\nupon her, were it only for a minute; but quick as a bird she glided\r\nbetween his hands, and when he wished to speak to her, her finger\r\nplaced upon her mouth, with a little imperative gesture full of grace,\r\nreminded him that he was under the command of a power which he must\r\nblindly obey, and which forbade him even to make the slightest\r\ncomplaint. At length, after winding about for a minute or two, Mme.\r\nBonacieux opened the door of a closet, which was entirely dark, and led\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan into it. There she made a fresh sign of silence, and opened\r\na second door concealed by tapestry. The opening of this door disclosed\r\na brilliant light, and she disappeared.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remained for a moment motionless, asking himself where he\r\ncould be; but soon a ray of light which penetrated through the chamber,\r\ntogether with the warm and perfumed air which reached him from the same\r\naperture, the conversation of two of three ladies in language at once\r\nrespectful and refined, and the word \xe2\x80\x9cMajesty\xe2\x80\x9d several times repeated,\r\nindicated clearly that he was in a closet attached to the queen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\napartment. The young man waited in comparative darkness and listened.\r\n\r\nThe queen appeared cheerful and happy, which seemed to astonish the\r\npersons who surrounded her and who were accustomed to see her almost\r\nalways sad and full of care. The queen attributed this joyous feeling\r\nto the beauty of the f\xc3\xaate, to the pleasure she had experienced in the\r\nballet; and as it is not permissible to contradict a queen, whether she\r\nsmile or weep, everybody expatiated on the gallantry of the aldermen of\r\nthe city of Paris.\r\n\r\nAlthough D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not at all know the queen, he soon\r\ndistinguished her voice from the others, at first by a slightly foreign\r\naccent, and next by that tone of domination naturally impressed upon\r\nall royal words. He heard her approach and withdraw from the partially\r\nopen door; and twice or three times he even saw the shadow of a person\r\nintercept the light.\r\n\r\nAt length a hand and an arm, surpassingly beautiful in their form and\r\nwhiteness, glided through the tapestry. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at once comprehended\r\nthat this was his recompense. He cast himself on his knees, seized the\r\nhand, and touched it respectfully with his lips. Then the hand was\r\nwithdrawn, leaving in his an object which he perceived to be a ring.\r\nThe door immediately closed, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan found himself again in\r\ncomplete obscurity.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan placed the ring on his finger, and again waited; it was\r\nevident that all was not yet over. After the reward of his devotion,\r\nthat of his love was to come. Besides, although the ballet was danced,\r\nthe evening had scarcely begun. Supper was to be served at three, and\r\nthe clock of St. Jean had struck three quarters past two.\r\n\r\nThe sound of voices diminished by degrees in the adjoining chamber. The\r\ncompany was then heard departing; then the door of the closet in which\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was, was opened, and Mme. Bonacieux entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou at last?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, placing her hand upon his lips;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csilence, and go the same way you came!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where and when shall I see you again?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA note which you will find at home will tell you. Begone, begone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt these words she opened the door of the corridor, and pushed\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan out of the room. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan obeyed like a child, without the\r\nleast resistance or objection, which proved that he was really in love.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXIII.\r\nTHE RENDEZVOUS\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan ran home immediately, and although it was three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in\r\nthe morning and he had some of the worst quarters of Paris to traverse,\r\nhe met with no misadventure. Everyone knows that drunkards and lovers\r\nhave a protecting deity.\r\n\r\nHe found the door of his passage open, sprang up the stairs and knocked\r\nsoftly in a manner agreed upon between him and his lackey. Planchet*,\r\nwhom he had sent home two hours before from the H\xc3\xb4tel de Ville, telling\r\nhim to sit up for him, opened the door for him.\r\n\r\n* The reader may ask, \xe2\x80\x9cHow came Planchet here?\xe2\x80\x9d when he was left \xe2\x80\x9cstiff\r\nas a rush\xe2\x80\x9d in London. In the intervening time Buckingham perhaps sent\r\nhim to Paris, as he did the horses.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas anyone brought a letter for me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one has _brought_ a letter, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Planchet; \xe2\x80\x9cbut one\r\nhas come of itself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean, blockhead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to say that when I came in, although I had the key of your\r\napartment in my pocket, and that key had never quit me, I found a\r\nletter on the green table cover in your bedroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is that letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI left it where I found it, monsieur. It is not natural for letters to\r\nenter people\xe2\x80\x99s houses in this manner. If the window had been open or\r\neven ajar, I should think nothing of it; but, no\xe2\x80\x94all was hermetically\r\nsealed. Beware, monsieur; there is certainly some magic underneath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, the young man had darted in to his chamber, and opened the\r\nletter. It was from Mme. Bonacieux, and was expressed in these terms:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere are many thanks to be offered to you, and to be transmitted to\r\nyou. Be this evening about ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock at St. Cloud, in front of the\r\npavilion which stands at the corner of the house of M. d\xe2\x80\x99Estr\xc3\xa9es.\xe2\x80\x94C.B.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile reading this letter, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan felt his heart dilated and\r\ncompressed by that delicious spasm which tortures and caresses the\r\nhearts of lovers.\r\n\r\nIt was the first billet he had received; it was the first rendezvous\r\nthat had been granted him. His heart, swelled by the intoxication of\r\njoy, felt ready to dissolve away at the very gate of that terrestrial\r\nparadise called Love!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, who had observed his master grow red\r\nand pale successively, \xe2\x80\x9cdid I not guess truly? Is it not some bad\r\naffair?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, Planchet,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand as a proof,\r\nthere is a crown to drink my health.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am much obliged to Monsieur for the crown he has given me, and I\r\npromise him to follow his instructions exactly; but it is not the less\r\ntrue that letters which come in this way into shut-up houses\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFall from heaven, my friend, fall from heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Monsieur is satisfied?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Planchet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Planchet, I am the happiest of men!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I may profit by Monsieur\xe2\x80\x99s happiness, and go to bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay the blessings of heaven fall upon Monsieur! But it is not the less\r\ntrue that that letter\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Planchet retired, shaking his head with an air of doubt, which the\r\nliberality of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had not entirely effaced.\r\n\r\nLeft alone, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan read and reread his billet. Then he kissed and\r\nrekissed twenty times the lines traced by the hand of his beautiful\r\nmistress. At length he went to bed, fell asleep, and had golden dreams.\r\n\r\nAt seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning he arose and called Planchet, who at\r\nthe second summons opened the door, his countenance not yet quite freed\r\nfrom the anxiety of the preceding night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI am going out for all day, perhaps. You\r\nare, therefore, your own master till seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening; but\r\nat seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock you must hold yourself in readiness with two horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet. \xe2\x80\x9cWe are going again, it appears, to have our\r\nhides pierced in all sorts of ways.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will take your musketoon and your pistols.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, now! Didn\xe2\x80\x99t I say so?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Planchet. \xe2\x80\x9cI was sure of it\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ncursed letter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid, you idiot; there is nothing in hand but a party of\r\npleasure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, like the charming journey the other day, when it rained bullets\r\nand produced a crop of steel traps!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you are really afraid, Monsieur Planchet,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI will go without you. I prefer traveling alone to having\r\na companion who entertains the least fear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur does me wrong,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet; \xe2\x80\x9cI thought he had seen me at\r\nwork.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but I thought perhaps you had worn out all your courage the first\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur shall see that upon occasion I have some left; only I beg\r\nMonsieur not to be too prodigal of it if he wishes it to last long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you believe you have still a certain amount of it to expend this\r\nevening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I count on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the appointed hour I shall be ready; only I believed that Monsieur\r\nhad but one horse in the Guard stables.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps there is but one at this moment; but by this evening there\r\nwill be four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears that our journey was a remounting journey, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; and nodding to Planchet, he went out.\r\n\r\nM. Bonacieux was at his door. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s intention was to go out\r\nwithout speaking to the worthy mercer; but the latter made so polite\r\nand friendly a salutation that his tenant felt obliged, not only to\r\nstop, but to enter into conversation with him.\r\n\r\nBesides, how is it possible to avoid a little condescension toward a\r\nhusband whose pretty wife has appointed a meeting with you that same\r\nevening at St. Cloud, opposite D\xe2\x80\x99Estr\xc3\xa9es\xe2\x80\x99s pavilion? D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\napproached him with the most amiable air he could assume.\r\n\r\nThe conversation naturally fell upon the incarceration of the poor man.\r\nM. Bonacieux, who was ignorant that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had overheard his\r\nconversation with the stranger of Meung, related to his young tenant\r\nthe persecutions of that monster, M. de Laffemas, whom he never ceased\r\nto designate, during his account, by the title of the \xe2\x80\x9ccardinal\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nexecutioner,\xe2\x80\x9d and expatiated at great length upon the Bastille, the\r\nbolts, the wickets, the dungeons, the gratings, the instruments of\r\ntorture.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan listened to him with exemplary complaisance, and when he had\r\nfinished said, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Madame Bonacieux, do you know who carried her\r\noff?\xe2\x80\x94For I do not forget that I owe to that unpleasant circumstance the\r\ngood fortune of having made your acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cthey took good care not to tell me that; and my\r\nwife, on her part, has sworn to me by all that\xe2\x80\x99s sacred that she does\r\nnot know. But you,\xe2\x80\x9d continued M. Bonacieux, in a tone of perfect good\r\nfellowship, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has become of you all these days? I have not seen you\r\nnor your friends, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think you could gather all that dust that\r\nI saw Planchet brush off your boots yesterday from the pavement of\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, my friends and I have been\r\non a little journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFar from here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Lord, no! About forty leagues only. We went to take Monsieur Athos\r\nto the waters of Forges, where my friends still remain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have returned, have you not?\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. Bonacieux, giving to\r\nhis countenance a most sly air. \xe2\x80\x9cA handsome young fellow like you does\r\nnot obtain long leaves of absence from his mistress; and we were\r\nimpatiently waited for at Paris, were we not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cI confess it, and so much\r\nmore the readily, my dear Bonacieux, as I see there is no concealing\r\nanything from you. Yes, I was expected, and very impatiently, I\r\nacknowledge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA slight shade passed over the brow of Bonacieux, but so slight that\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not perceive it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd we are going to be recompensed for our diligence?\xe2\x80\x9d continued the\r\nmercer, with a trifling alteration in his voice\xe2\x80\x94so trifling, indeed,\r\nthat D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not perceive it any more than he had the momentary\r\nshade which, an instant before, had darkened the countenance of the\r\nworthy man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, may you be a true prophet!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, laughing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; what I say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cis only that I may know whether I\r\nam delaying you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy that question, my dear host?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you intend to\r\nsit up for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but since my arrest and the robbery that was committed in my\r\nhouse, I am alarmed every time I hear a door open, particularly in the\r\nnight. What the deuce can you expect? I am no swordsman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, don\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed if I return at one, two or three o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the\r\nmorning; indeed, do not be alarmed if I do not come at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time Bonacieux became so pale that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could not help\r\nperceiving it, and asked him what was the matter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cnothing. Since my misfortunes I have\r\nbeen subject to faintnesses, which seize me all at once, and I have\r\njust felt a cold shiver. Pay no attention to it; you have nothing to\r\noccupy yourself with but being happy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I have full occupation, for I am so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet; wait a little! This evening, you said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this evening will come, thank God! And perhaps you look for it\r\nwith as much impatience as I do; perhaps this evening Madame Bonacieux\r\nwill visit the conjugal domicile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Bonacieux is not at liberty this evening,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the husband,\r\nseriously; \xe2\x80\x9cshe is detained at the Louvre this evening by her duties.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the worse for you, my dear host, so much the worse! When I am\r\nhappy, I wish all the world to be so; but it appears that is not\r\npossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man departed, laughing at the joke, which he thought he alone\r\ncould comprehend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmuse yourself well!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bonacieux, in a sepulchral tone.\r\n\r\nBut D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was too far off to hear him; and if he had heard him in\r\nthe disposition of mind he then enjoyed, he certainly would not have\r\nremarked it.\r\n\r\nHe took his way toward the h\xc3\xb4tel of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; his visit of the\r\nday before, it is to be remembered, had been very short and very little\r\nexplicative.\r\n\r\nHe found Tr\xc3\xa9ville in a joyful mood. He had thought the king and queen\r\ncharming at the ball. It is true the cardinal had been particularly\r\nill-tempered. He had retired at one o\xe2\x80\x99clock under the pretense of being\r\nindisposed. As to their Majesties, they did not return to the Louvre\r\ntill six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Tr\xc3\xa9ville, lowering his voice, and looking into every corner\r\nof the apartment to see if they were alone, \xe2\x80\x9cnow let us talk about\r\nyourself, my young friend; for it is evident that your happy return has\r\nsomething to do with the joy of the king, the triumph of the queen, and\r\nthe humiliation of his Eminence. You must look out for yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I to fear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cas long as I shall have the\r\nluck to enjoy the favor of their Majesties?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything, believe me. The cardinal is not the man to forget a\r\nmystification until he has settled account with the mystifier; and the\r\nmystifier appears to me to have the air of being a certain young Gascon\r\nof my acquaintance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you believe that the cardinal is as well posted as yourself, and\r\nknows that I have been to London?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! You have been to London! Was it from London you brought\r\nthat beautiful diamond that glitters on your finger? Beware, my dear\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! A present from an enemy is not a good thing. Are there not\r\nsome Latin verses upon that subject? Stop!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, doubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had never been able to cram\r\nthe first rudiments of that language into his head, and who had by his\r\nignorance driven his master to despair, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, doubtless there is one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere certainly is one,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who had a tincture of\r\nliterature, \xe2\x80\x9cand Monsieur de Benserade was quoting it to me the other\r\nday. Stop a minute\xe2\x80\x94ah, this is it: \xe2\x80\x98Timeo Danaos et dona ferentes,\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwhich means, \xe2\x80\x98Beware of the enemy who makes you presents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis diamond does not come from an enemy, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cit comes from the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom the queen! Oh, oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it is indeed a\r\ntrue royal jewel, which is worth a thousand pistoles if it is worth a\r\ndenier. By whom did the queen send you this jewel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe gave it to me herself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the room adjoining the chamber in which she changed her toilet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGiving me her hand to kiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have kissed the queen\xe2\x80\x99s hand?\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, looking\r\nearnestly at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer Majesty did me the honor to grant me that favor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that in the presence of witnesses! Imprudent, thrice imprudent!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, be satisfied; nobody saw her,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and\r\nhe related to M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville how the affair came to pass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the women, the women!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the old soldier. \xe2\x80\x9cI know them by\r\ntheir romantic imagination. Everything that savors of mystery charms\r\nthem. So you have seen the arm, that was all. You would meet the queen,\r\nand she would not know who you are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but thanks to this diamond,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; \xe2\x80\x9cshall I give you counsel, good counsel,\r\nthe counsel of a friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will do me honor, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, off to the nearest goldsmith\xe2\x80\x99s, and sell that diamond for\r\nthe highest price you can get from him. However much of a Jew he may\r\nbe, he will give you at least eight hundred pistoles. Pistoles have no\r\nname, young man, and that ring has a terrible one, which may betray him\r\nwho wears it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSell this ring, a ring which comes from my sovereign? Never!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, at least turn the gem inside, you silly fellow; for everybody\r\nmust be aware that a cadet from Gascony does not find such stones in\r\nhis mother\xe2\x80\x99s jewel case.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think, then, I have something to dread?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean to say, young man, that he who sleeps over a mine the match of\r\nwhich is already lighted, may consider himself in safety in comparison\r\nwith you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whom the positive tone of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\r\nbegan to disquiet, \xe2\x80\x9cthe devil! What must I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbove all things be always on your guard. The cardinal has a tenacious\r\nmemory and a long arm; you may depend upon it, he will repay you by\r\nsome ill turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut of what sort?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh! How can I tell? Has he not all the tricks of a demon at his\r\ncommand? The least that can be expected is that you will be arrested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Will they dare to arrest a man in his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s service?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_ They did not scruple much in the case of Athos. At all\r\nevents, young man, rely upon one who has been thirty years at court. Do\r\nnot lull yourself in security, or you will be lost; but, on the\r\ncontrary\xe2\x80\x94and it is I who say it\xe2\x80\x94see enemies in all directions. If\r\nanyone seeks a quarrel with you, shun it, were it with a child of ten\r\nyears old. If you are attacked by day or by night, fight, but retreat,\r\nwithout shame; if you cross a bridge, feel every plank of it with your\r\nfoot, lest one should give way beneath you; if you pass before a house\r\nwhich is being built, look up, for fear a stone should fall upon your\r\nhead; if you stay out late, be always followed by your lackey, and let\r\nyour lackey be armed\xe2\x80\x94if, by the by, you can be sure of your lackey.\r\nMistrust everybody, your friend, your brother, your mistress\xe2\x80\x94your\r\nmistress above all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan blushed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mistress above all,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated he, mechanically; \xe2\x80\x9cand why her rather\r\nthan another?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause a mistress is one of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s favorite means; he has not\r\none that is more expeditious. A woman will sell you for ten pistoles,\r\nwitness Delilah. You are acquainted with the Scriptures?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought of the appointment Mme. Bonacieux had made with him\r\nfor that very evening; but we are bound to say, to the credit of our\r\nhero, that the bad opinion entertained by M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville of women in\r\ngeneral, did not inspire him with the least suspicion of his pretty\r\nhostess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, _\xc3\xa0 propos_,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has become of your\r\nthree companions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was about to ask you if you had heard any news of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I left them on my road\xe2\x80\x94Porthos at Chantilly, with a duel on his\r\nhands; Aramis at Cr\xc3\xa8vec\xc5\x93ur, with a ball in his shoulder; and Athos at\r\nAmiens, detained by an accusation of coining.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee there, now!\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville; \xe2\x80\x9cand how the devil did you\r\nescape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy a miracle, monsieur, I must acknowledge, with a sword thrust in my\r\nbreast, and by nailing the Comte de Wardes on the byroad to Calais,\r\nlike a butterfly on a tapestry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere again! De Wardes, one of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s men, a cousin of\r\nRochefort! Stop, my friend, I have an idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn your place, I would do one thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile his Eminence was seeking for me in Paris, I would take, without\r\nsound of drum or trumpet, the road to Picardy, and would go and make\r\nsome inquiries concerning my three companions. What the devil! They\r\nmerit richly that piece of attention on your part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe advice is good, monsieur, and tomorrow I will set out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow! Any why not this evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis evening, monsieur, I am detained in Paris by indispensable\r\nbusiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, young man, young man, some flirtation or other. Take care, I\r\nrepeat to you, take care. It is woman who has ruined us, still ruins\r\nus, and will ruin us, as long as the world stands. Take my advice and\r\nset out this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have given your word, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that\xe2\x80\x99s quite another thing; but promise me, if you should not be\r\nkilled tonight, that you will go tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI promise it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you need money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have still fifty pistoles. That, I think, is as much as I shall\r\nwant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your companions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think they can be in need of any. We left Paris, each with\r\nseventy-five pistoles in his pocket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I see you again before your departure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not, monsieur, unless something new should happen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, a pleasant journey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan left M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, touched more than ever by his paternal\r\nsolicitude for his Musketeers.\r\n\r\nHe called successively at the abodes of Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.\r\nNeither of them had returned. Their lackeys likewise were absent, and\r\nnothing had been heard of either the one or the other. He would have\r\ninquired after them of their mistresses, but he was neither acquainted\r\nwith Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s nor Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s, and as to Athos, he had none.\r\n\r\nAs he passed the H\xc3\xb4tel des Gardes, he took a glance into the stables.\r\nThree of the four horses had already arrived. Planchet, all\r\nastonishment, was busy grooming them, and had already finished two.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, on perceiving D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9chow glad I am\r\nto see you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so, Planchet?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you place confidence in our landlord\xe2\x80\x94Monsieur Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? Not the least in the world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you do quite right, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why this question?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, while you were talking with him, I watched you without\r\nlistening to you; and, monsieur, his countenance changed color two or\r\nthree times!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPreoccupied as Monsieur was with the letter he had received, he did\r\nnot observe that; but I, whom the strange fashion in which that letter\r\ncame into the house had placed on my guard\xe2\x80\x94I did not lose a movement of\r\nhis features.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you found it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTraitorous, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill more; as soon as Monsieur had left and disappeared round the\r\ncorner of the street, Monsieur Bonacieux took his hat, shut his door,\r\nand set off at a quick pace in an opposite direction.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems you are right, Planchet; all this appears to be a little\r\nmysterious; and be assured that we will not pay him our rent until the\r\nmatter shall be categorically explained to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur jests, but Monsieur will see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you have, Planchet? What must come is written.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur does not then renounce his excursion for this evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite the contrary, Planchet; the more ill will I have toward Monsieur\r\nBonacieux, the more punctual I shall be in keeping the appointment made\r\nby that letter which makes you so uneasy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen that is Monsieur\xe2\x80\x99s determination?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndeniably, my friend. At nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock, then, be ready here at the\r\nh\xc3\xb4tel, I will come and take you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPlanchet seeing there was no longer any hope of making his master\r\nrenounce his project, heaved a profound sigh and set to work to groom\r\nthe third horse.\r\n\r\nAs to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, being at bottom a prudent youth, instead of returning\r\nhome, went and dined with the Gascon priest, who, at the time of the\r\ndistress of the four friends, had given them a breakfast of chocolate.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXIV.\r\nTHE PAVILION\r\n\r\n\r\nAt nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was at the H\xc3\xb4tel des Gardes; he found\r\nPlanchet all ready. The fourth horse had arrived.\r\n\r\nPlanchet was armed with his musketoon and a pistol. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had his\r\nsword and placed two pistols in his belt; then both mounted and\r\ndeparted quietly. It was quite dark, and no one saw them go out.\r\nPlanchet took place behind his master, and kept at a distance of ten\r\npaces from him.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan crossed the quays, went out by the gate of La Conf\xc3\xa9rence and\r\nfollowed the road, much more beautiful then than it is now, which leads\r\nto St. Cloud.\r\n\r\nAs long as he was in the city, Planchet kept at the respectful distance\r\nhe had imposed upon himself; but as soon as the road began to be more\r\nlonely and dark, he drew softly nearer, so that when they entered the\r\nBois de Boulogne he found himself riding quite naturally side by side\r\nwith his master. In fact, we must not dissemble that the oscillation of\r\nthe tall trees and the reflection of the moon in the dark underwood\r\ngave him serious uneasiness. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could not help perceiving that\r\nsomething more than usual was passing in the mind of his lackey and\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, Monsieur Planchet, what is the matter with us now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think, monsieur, that woods are like churches?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so, Planchet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause we dare not speak aloud in one or the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why did you not dare to speak aloud, Planchet\xe2\x80\x94because you are\r\nafraid?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfraid of being heard? Yes, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfraid of being heard! Why, there is nothing improper in our\r\nconversation, my dear Planchet, and no one could find fault with it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Planchet, recurring to his besetting idea,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat Monsieur Bonacieux has something vicious in his eyebrows, and\r\nsomething very unpleasant in the play of his lips.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil makes you think of Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, we think of what we can, and not of what we will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you are a coward, Planchet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, we must not confound prudence with cowardice; prudence is a\r\nvirtue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you are very virtuous, are you not, Planchet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, is not that the barrel of a musket which glitters yonder?\r\nHad we not better lower our heads?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, to whom M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nrecommendation recurred, \xe2\x80\x9cthis animal will end by making me afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd he put his horse into a trot.\r\n\r\nPlanchet followed the movements of his master as if he had been his\r\nshadow, and was soon trotting by his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre we going to continue this pace all night?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Planchet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you are at your journey\xe2\x80\x99s end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, monsieur! And you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going a few steps farther.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Monsieur leaves me here alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are afraid, Planchet?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I only beg leave to observe to Monsieur that the night will be\r\nvery cold, that chills bring on rheumatism, and that a lackey who has\r\nthe rheumatism makes but a poor servant, particularly to a master as\r\nactive as Monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you are cold, Planchet, you can go into one of those cabarets\r\nthat you see yonder, and be in waiting for me at the door by six\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I have eaten and drunk respectfully the crown you gave me\r\nthis morning, so that I have not a sou left in case I should be cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s half a pistole. Tomorrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan sprang from his horse, threw the bridle to Planchet, and\r\ndeparted at a quick pace, folding his cloak around him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord, how cold I am!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Planchet, as soon as he had lost\r\nsight of his master; and in such haste was he to warm himself that he\r\nwent straight to a house set out with all the attributes of a suburban\r\ntavern, and knocked at the door.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had plunged into a bypath, continued\r\nhis route and reached St. Cloud; but instead of following the main\r\nstreet he turned behind the ch\xc3\xa2teau, reached a sort of retired lane,\r\nand found himself soon in front of the pavilion named. It was situated\r\nin a very private spot. A high wall, at the angle of which was the\r\npavilion, ran along one side of this lane, and on the other was a\r\nlittle garden connected with a poor cottage which was protected by a\r\nhedge from passers-by.\r\n\r\nHe gained the place appointed, and as no signal had been given him by\r\nwhich to announce his presence, he waited.\r\n\r\nNot the least noise was to be heard; it might be imagined that he was a\r\nhundred miles from the capital. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan leaned against the hedge,\r\nafter having cast a glance behind it. Beyond that hedge, that garden,\r\nand that cottage, a dark mist enveloped with its folds that immensity\r\nwhere Paris slept\xe2\x80\x94a vast void from which glittered a few luminous\r\npoints, the funeral stars of that hell!\r\n\r\nBut for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan all aspects were clothed happily, all ideas wore a\r\nsmile, all shades were diaphanous. The appointed hour was about to\r\nstrike. In fact, at the end of a few minutes the belfry of St. Cloud\r\nlet fall slowly ten strokes from its sonorous jaws. There was something\r\nmelancholy in this brazen voice pouring out its lamentations in the\r\nmiddle of the night; but each of those strokes, which made up the\r\nexpected hour, vibrated harmoniously to the heart of the young man.\r\n\r\nHis eyes were fixed upon the little pavilion situated at the angle of\r\nthe wall, of which all the windows were closed with shutters, except\r\none on the first story. Through this window shone a mild light which\r\nsilvered the foliage of two or three linden trees which formed a group\r\noutside the park. There could be no doubt that behind this little\r\nwindow, which threw forth such friendly beams, the pretty Mme.\r\nBonacieux expected him.\r\n\r\nWrapped in this sweet idea, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan waited half an hour without the\r\nleast impatience, his eyes fixed upon that charming little abode of\r\nwhich he could perceive a part of the ceiling with its gilded moldings,\r\nattesting the elegance of the rest of the apartment.\r\n\r\nThe belfry of St. Cloud sounded half past ten.\r\n\r\nThis time, without knowing why, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan felt a cold shiver run\r\nthrough his veins. Perhaps the cold began to affect him, and he took a\r\nperfectly physical sensation for a moral impression.\r\n\r\nThen the idea seized him that he had read incorrectly, and that the\r\nappointment was for eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock. He drew near to the window, and\r\nplacing himself so that a ray of light should fall upon the letter as\r\nhe held it, he drew it from his pocket and read it again; but he had\r\nnot been mistaken, the appointment was for ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock. He went and\r\nresumed his post, beginning to be rather uneasy at this silence and\r\nthis solitude.\r\n\r\nEleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock sounded.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan began now really to fear that something had happened to Mme.\r\nBonacieux. He clapped his hands three times\xe2\x80\x94the ordinary signal of\r\nlovers; but nobody replied to him, not even an echo.\r\n\r\nHe then thought, with a touch of vexation, that perhaps the young woman\r\nhad fallen asleep while waiting for him. He approached the wall, and\r\ntried to climb it; but the wall had been recently pointed, and\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could get no hold.\r\n\r\nAt that moment he thought of the trees, upon whose leaves the light\r\nstill shone; and as one of them drooped over the road, he thought that\r\nfrom its branches he might get a glimpse of the interior of the\r\npavilion.\r\n\r\nThe tree was easy to climb. Besides, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was but twenty years\r\nold, and consequently had not yet forgotten his schoolboy habits. In an\r\ninstant he was among the branches, and his keen eyes plunged through\r\nthe transparent panes into the interior of the pavilion.\r\n\r\nIt was a strange thing, and one which made D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan tremble from the\r\nsole of his foot to the roots of his hair, to find that this soft\r\nlight, this calm lamp, enlightened a scene of fearful disorder. One of\r\nthe windows was broken, the door of the chamber had been beaten in and\r\nhung, split in two, on its hinges. A table, which had been covered with\r\nan elegant supper, was overturned. The decanters broken in pieces, and\r\nthe fruits crushed, strewed the floor. Everything in the apartment gave\r\nevidence of a violent and desperate struggle. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan even fancied\r\nhe could recognize amid this strange disorder, fragments of garments,\r\nand some bloody spots staining the cloth and the curtains. He hastened\r\nto descend into the street, with a frightful beating at his heart; he\r\nwished to see if he could find other traces of violence.\r\n\r\nThe little soft light shone on in the calmness of the night. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nthen perceived a thing that he had not before remarked\xe2\x80\x94for nothing had\r\nled him to the examination\xe2\x80\x94that the ground, trampled here and\r\nhoofmarked there, presented confused traces of men and horses. Besides,\r\nthe wheels of a carriage, which appeared to have come from Paris, had\r\nmade a deep impression in the soft earth, which did not extend beyond\r\nthe pavilion, but turned again toward Paris.\r\n\r\nAt length D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in pursuing his researches, found near the wall a\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x99s torn glove. This glove, wherever it had not touched the muddy\r\nground, was of irreproachable odor. It was one of those perfumed gloves\r\nthat lovers like to snatch from a pretty hand.\r\n\r\nAs D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan pursued his investigations, a more abundant and more icy\r\nsweat rolled in large drops from his forehead; his heart was oppressed\r\nby a horrible anguish; his respiration was broken and short. And yet he\r\nsaid, to reassure himself, that this pavilion perhaps had nothing in\r\ncommon with Mme. Bonacieux; that the young woman had made an\r\nappointment with him before the pavilion, and not in the pavilion; that\r\nshe might have been detained in Paris by her duties, or perhaps by the\r\njealousy of her husband.\r\n\r\nBut all these reasons were combated, destroyed, overthrown, by that\r\nfeeling of intimate pain which, on certain occasions, takes possession\r\nof our being, and cries to us so as to be understood unmistakably that\r\nsome great misfortune is hanging over us.\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan became almost wild. He ran along the high road, took\r\nthe path he had before taken, and reaching the ferry, interrogated the\r\nboatman.\r\n\r\nAbout seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, the boatman had taken over a young\r\nwoman, wrapped in a black mantle, who appeared to be very anxious not\r\nto be recognized; but entirely on account of her precautions, the\r\nboatman had paid more attention to her and discovered that she was\r\nyoung and pretty.\r\n\r\nThere were then, as now, a crowd of young and pretty women who came to\r\nSt. Cloud, and who had reasons for not being seen, and yet D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\ndid not for an instant doubt that it was Mme. Bonacieux whom the\r\nboatman had noticed.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took advantage of the lamp which burned in the cabin of the\r\nferryman to read the billet of Mme. Bonacieux once again, and satisfy\r\nhimself that he had not been mistaken, that the appointment was at St.\r\nCloud and not elsewhere, before the D\xe2\x80\x99Estr\xc3\xa9es\xe2\x80\x99s pavilion and not in\r\nanother street. Everything conspired to prove to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that his\r\npresentiments had not deceived him, and that a great misfortune had\r\nhappened.\r\n\r\nHe again ran back to the ch\xc3\xa2teau. It appeared to him that something\r\nmight have happened at the pavilion in his absence, and that fresh\r\ninformation awaited him. The lane was still deserted, and the same calm\r\nsoft light shone through the window.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan then thought of that cottage, silent and obscure, which had\r\nno doubt seen all, and could tell its tale. The gate of the enclosure\r\nwas shut; but he leaped over the hedge, and in spite of the barking of\r\na chained-up dog, went up to the cabin.\r\n\r\nNo one answered to his first knocking. A silence of death reigned in\r\nthe cabin as in the pavilion; but as the cabin was his last resource,\r\nhe knocked again.\r\n\r\nIt soon appeared to him that he heard a slight noise within\xe2\x80\x94a timid\r\nnoise which seemed to tremble lest it should be heard.\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan ceased knocking, and prayed with an accent so full of\r\nanxiety and promises, terror and cajolery, that his voice was of a\r\nnature to reassure the most fearful. At length an old, worm-eaten\r\nshutter was opened, or rather pushed ajar, but closed again as soon as\r\nthe light from a miserable lamp which burned in the corner had shone\r\nupon the baldric, sword belt, and pistol pommels of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\nNevertheless, rapid as the movement had been, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had had time\r\nto get a glimpse of the head of an old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of heaven!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9clisten to me; I have been waiting\r\nfor someone who has not come. I am dying with anxiety. Has anything\r\nparticular happened in the neighborhood? Speak!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe window was again opened slowly, and the same face appeared, only it\r\nwas now still more pale than before.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related his story simply, with the omission of names. He\r\ntold how he had a rendezvous with a young woman before that pavilion,\r\nand how, not seeing her come, he had climbed the linden tree, and by\r\nthe light of the lamp had seen the disorder of the chamber.\r\n\r\nThe old man listened attentively, making a sign only that it was all\r\nso; and then, when D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had ended, he shook his head with an air\r\nthat announced nothing good.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of heaven, explain\r\nyourself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! Monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man, \xe2\x80\x9cask me nothing; for if I dared tell\r\nyou what I have seen, certainly no good would befall me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, then, seen something?\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, in\r\nthe name of heaven,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, throwing him a pistole, \xe2\x80\x9ctell me\r\nwhat you have seen, and I will pledge you the word of a gentleman that\r\nnot one of your words shall escape from my heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old man read so much truth and so much grief in the face of the\r\nyoung man that he made him a sign to listen, and repeated in a low\r\nvoice: \xe2\x80\x9cIt was scarcely nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock when I heard a noise in the\r\nstreet, and was wondering what it could be, when on coming to my door,\r\nI found that somebody was endeavoring to open it. As I am very poor and\r\nam not afraid of being robbed, I went and opened the gate and saw three\r\nmen at a few paces from it. In the shadow was a carriage with two\r\nhorses, and some saddlehorses. These horses evidently belonged to the\r\nthree men, who were dressed as cavaliers. \xe2\x80\x98Ah, my worthy gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncried I, \xe2\x80\x98what do you want?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98You must have a ladder?\xe2\x80\x99 said he who\r\nappeared to be the leader of the party. \xe2\x80\x98Yes, monsieur, the one with\r\nwhich I gather my fruit.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Lend it to us, and go into your house again;\r\nthere is a crown for the annoyance we have caused you. Only remember\r\nthis\xe2\x80\x94if you speak a word of what you may see or what you may hear (for\r\nyou will look and you will listen, I am quite sure, however we may\r\nthreaten you), you are lost.\xe2\x80\x99 At these words he threw me a crown, which\r\nI picked up, and he took the ladder. After shutting the gate behind\r\nthem, I pretended to return to the house, but I immediately went out a\r\nback door, and stealing along in the shade of the hedge, I gained\r\nyonder clump of elder, from which I could hear and see everything. The\r\nthree men brought the carriage up quietly, and took out of it a little\r\nman, stout, short, elderly, and commonly dressed in clothes of a dark\r\ncolor, who ascended the ladder very carefully, looked suspiciously in\r\nat the window of the pavilion, came down as quietly as he had gone up,\r\nand whispered, \xe2\x80\x98It is she!\xe2\x80\x99 Immediately, he who had spoken to me\r\napproached the door of the pavilion, opened it with a key he had in his\r\nhand, closed the door and disappeared, while at the same time the other\r\ntwo men ascended the ladder. The little old man remained at the coach\r\ndoor; the coachman took care of his horses, the lackey held the\r\nsaddlehorses. All at once great cries resounded in the pavilion, and a\r\nwoman came to the window, and opened it, as if to throw herself out of\r\nit; but as soon as she perceived the other two men, she fell back and\r\nthey went into the chamber. Then I saw no more; but I heard the noise\r\nof breaking furniture. The woman screamed, and cried for help; but her\r\ncries were soon stifled. Two of the men appeared, bearing the woman in\r\ntheir arms, and carried her to the carriage, into which the little old\r\nman got after her. The leader closed the window, came out an instant\r\nafter by the door, and satisfied himself that the woman was in the\r\ncarriage. His two companions were already on horseback. He sprang into\r\nhis saddle; the lackey took his place by the coachman; the carriage\r\nwent off at a quick pace, escorted by the three horsemen, and all was\r\nover. From that moment I have neither seen nor heard anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, entirely overcome by this terrible story, remained\r\nmotionless and mute, while all the demons of anger and jealousy were\r\nhowling in his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my good gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the old man, upon whom this mute\r\ndespair certainly produced a greater effect than cries and tears would\r\nhave done, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not take on so; they did not kill her, and that\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ncomfort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you guess,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwho was the man who headed this\r\ninfernal expedition?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut as you spoke to him you must have seen him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s a description you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA tall, dark man, with black mustaches, dark eyes, and the air of a\r\ngentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cagain he, forever he! He is my\r\ndemon, apparently. And the other?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe short one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he was not a gentleman, I\xe2\x80\x99ll answer for it; besides, he did not\r\nwear a sword, and the others treated him with small consideration.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome lackey,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor woman, poor woman, what have\r\nthey done with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have promised to be secret, my good monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d said the old man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I renew my promise. Be easy, I am a gentleman. A gentleman has but\r\nhis word, and I have given you mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith a heavy heart, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan again bent his way toward the ferry.\r\nSometimes he hoped it could not be Mme. Bonacieux, and that he should\r\nfind her next day at the Louvre; sometimes he feared she had had an\r\nintrigue with another, who, in a jealous fit, had surprised her and\r\ncarried her off. His mind was torn by doubt, grief, and despair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if I had my three friends here,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9cI should have, at\r\nleast, some hopes of finding her; but who knows what has become of\r\nthem?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was past midnight; the next thing was to find Planchet. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nwent successively into all the cabarets in which there was a light, but\r\ncould not find Planchet in any of them.\r\n\r\nAt the sixth he began to reflect that the search was rather dubious.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had appointed six o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning for his lackey, and\r\nwherever he might be, he was right.\r\n\r\nBesides, it came into the young man\xe2\x80\x99s mind that by remaining in the\r\nenvirons of the spot on which this sad event had passed, he would,\r\nperhaps, have some light thrown upon the mysterious affair. At the\r\nsixth cabaret, then, as we said, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stopped, asked for a bottle\r\nof wine of the best quality, and placing himself in the darkest corner\r\nof the room, determined thus to wait till daylight; but this time again\r\nhis hopes were disappointed, and although he listened with all his\r\nears, he heard nothing, amid the oaths, coarse jokes, and abuse which\r\npassed between the laborers, servants, and carters who comprised the\r\nhonorable society of which he formed a part, which could put him upon\r\nthe least track of her who had been stolen from him. He was compelled,\r\nthen, after having swallowed the contents of his bottle, to pass the\r\ntime as well as to evade suspicion, to fall into the easiest position\r\nin his corner and to sleep, whether well or ill. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, be it\r\nremembered, was only twenty years old, and at that age sleep has its\r\nimprescriptible rights which it imperiously insists upon, even with the\r\nsaddest hearts.\r\n\r\nToward six o\xe2\x80\x99clock D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan awoke with that uncomfortable feeling\r\nwhich generally accompanies the break of day after a bad night. He was\r\nnot long in making his toilet. He examined himself to see if advantage\r\nhad been taken of his sleep, and having found his diamond ring on his\r\nfinger, his purse in his pocket, and his pistols in his belt, he rose,\r\npaid for his bottle, and went out to try if he could have any better\r\nluck in his search after his lackey than he had had the night before.\r\nThe first thing he perceived through the damp gray mist was honest\r\nPlanchet, who, with the two horses in hand, awaited him at the door of\r\na little blind cabaret, before which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had passed without even\r\na suspicion of its existence.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXV.\r\nPORTHOS\r\n\r\n\r\nInstead of returning directly home, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan alighted at the door of\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, and ran quickly up the stairs. This time he had decided\r\nto relate all that had passed. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville would doubtless give him\r\ngood advice as to the whole affair. Besides, as M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville saw the\r\nqueen almost daily, he might be able to draw from her Majesty some\r\nintelligence of the poor young woman, whom they were doubtless making\r\npay very dearly for her devotedness to her mistress.\r\n\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville listened to the young man\xe2\x80\x99s account with a seriousness\r\nwhich proved that he saw something else in this adventure besides a\r\nlove affair. When D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had finished, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cHum! All this\r\nsavors of his Eminence, a league off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, absolutely nothing, at present, but quitting Paris, as I told\r\nyou, as soon as possible. I will see the queen; I will relate to her\r\nthe details of the disappearance of this poor woman, of which she is no\r\ndoubt ignorant. These details will guide her on her part, and on your\r\nreturn, I shall perhaps have some good news to tell you. Rely on me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan knew that, although a Gascon, M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville was not in the\r\nhabit of making promises, and that when by chance he did promise, he\r\nmore than kept his word. He bowed to him, then, full of gratitude for\r\nthe past and for the future; and the worthy captain, who on his side\r\nfelt a lively interest in this young man, so brave and so resolute,\r\npressed his hand kindly, wishing him a pleasant journey.\r\n\r\nDetermined to put the advice of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville in practice instantly,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan directed his course toward the Rue des Fossoyeurs, in order\r\nto superintend the packing of his valise. On approaching the house, he\r\nperceived M. Bonacieux in morning costume, standing at his threshold.\r\nAll that the prudent Planchet had said to him the preceding evening\r\nabout the sinister character of the old man recurred to the mind of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who looked at him with more attention than he had done\r\nbefore. In fact, in addition to that yellow, sickly paleness which\r\nindicates the insinuation of the bile in the blood, and which might,\r\nbesides, be accidental, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remarked something perfidiously\r\nsignificant in the play of the wrinkled features of his countenance. A\r\nrogue does not laugh in the same way that an honest man does; a\r\nhypocrite does not shed the tears of a man of good faith. All falsehood\r\nis a mask; and however well made the mask may be, with a little\r\nattention we may always succeed in distinguishing it from the true\r\nface.\r\n\r\nIt appeared, then, to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that M. Bonacieux wore a mask, and\r\nlikewise that that mask was most disagreeable to look upon. In\r\nconsequence of this feeling of repugnance, he was about to pass without\r\nspeaking to him, but, as he had done the day before, M. Bonacieux\r\naccosted him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe appear to pass rather gay nights! Seven\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning! _Peste!_ You seem to reverse ordinary customs,\r\nand come home at the hour when other people are going out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one can reproach you for anything of the kind, Monsieur Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a model for regular people. It is true\r\nthat when a man possesses a young and pretty wife, he has no need to\r\nseek happiness elsewhere. Happiness comes to meet him, does it not,\r\nMonsieur Bonacieux?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBonacieux became as pale as death, and grinned a ghastly smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are a jocular companion! But where the\r\ndevil were you gladding last night, my young master? It does not appear\r\nto be very clean in the crossroads.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan glanced down at his boots, all covered with mud; but that\r\nsame glance fell upon the shoes and stockings of the mercer, and it\r\nmight have been said they had been dipped in the same mud heap. Both\r\nwere stained with splashes of mud of the same appearance.\r\n\r\nThen a sudden idea crossed the mind of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. That little stout\r\nman, short and elderly, that sort of lackey, dressed in dark clothes,\r\ntreated without ceremony by the men wearing swords who composed the\r\nescort, was Bonacieux himself. The husband had presided at the\r\nabduction of his wife.\r\n\r\nA terrible inclination seized D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to grasp the mercer by the\r\nthroat and strangle him; but, as we have said, he was a very prudent\r\nyouth, and he restrained himself. However, the revolution which\r\nappeared upon his countenance was so visible that Bonacieux was\r\nterrified at it, and he endeavored to draw back a step or two; but as\r\nhe was standing before the half of the door which was shut, the\r\nobstacle compelled him to keep his place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but you are joking, my worthy man!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cIt appears\r\nto me that if my boots need a sponge, your stockings and shoes stand in\r\nequal need of a brush. May you not have been philandering a little\r\nalso, Monsieur Bonacieux? Oh, the devil! That\xe2\x80\x99s unpardonable in a man\r\nof your age, and who besides, has such a pretty wife as yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Lord! no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cbut yesterday I went to St. Mand\xc3\xa9 to\r\nmake some inquiries after a servant, as I cannot possibly do without\r\none; and the roads were so bad that I brought back all this mud, which\r\nI have not yet had time to remove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe place named by Bonacieux as that which had been the object of his\r\njourney was a fresh proof in support of the suspicions D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nconceived. Bonacieux had named Mand\xc3\xa9 because Mand\xc3\xa9 was in an exactly\r\nopposite direction from St. Cloud. This probability afforded him his\r\nfirst consolation. If Bonacieux knew where his wife was, one might, by\r\nextreme means, force the mercer to open his teeth and let his secret\r\nescape. The question, then, was how to change this probability into a\r\ncertainty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon, my dear Monsieur Bonacieux, if I don\xe2\x80\x99t stand upon ceremony,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cbut nothing makes one so thirsty as want of sleep. I\r\nam parched with thirst. Allow me to take a glass of water in your\r\napartment; you know that is never refused among neighbors.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWithout waiting for the permission of his host, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went quickly\r\ninto the house, and cast a rapid glance at the bed. It had not been\r\nused. Bonacieux had not been abed. He had only been back an hour or\r\ntwo; he had accompanied his wife to the place of her confinement, or\r\nelse at least to the first relay.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, Monsieur Bonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, emptying his glass,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthat is all I wanted of you. I will now go up into my apartment. I\r\nwill make Planchet brush my boots; and when he has done, I will, if you\r\nlike, send him to you to brush your shoes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left the mercer quite astonished at his singular farewell, and\r\nasking himself if he had not been a little inconsiderate.\r\n\r\nAt the top of the stairs he found Planchet in a great fright.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Planchet, as soon as he perceived his master,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chere is more trouble. I thought you would never come in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter now, Planchet?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I give you a hundred, I give you a thousand times to guess,\r\nmonsieur, the visit I received in your absence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbout half an hour ago, while you were at Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho has been here? Come, speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Cavois.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Cavois?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe captain of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guards?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he come to arrest me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have no doubt that he did, monsieur, for all his wheedling manner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas he so sweet, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, he was all honey, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe came, he said, on the part of his Eminence, who wished you well,\r\nand to beg you to follow him to the Palais-Royal*.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n* It was called the Palais-Cardinal before Richelieu gave it to the\r\nKing.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you answer him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat the thing was impossible, seeing that you were not at home, as he\r\ncould see.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what did he say then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat you must not fail to call upon him in the course of the day; and\r\nthen he added in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x98Tell your master that his Eminence is\r\nvery well disposed toward him, and that his fortune perhaps depends\r\nupon this interview.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe snare is rather _maladroit_ for the cardinal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young\r\nman, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I saw the snare, and I answered you would be quite in despair on\r\nyour return.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Where has he gone?\xe2\x80\x99 asked Monsieur de Cavois.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98To Troyes, in Champagne,\xe2\x80\x99 I answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98And when did he set out?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Yesterday evening.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are really a\r\nprecious fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will understand, monsieur, I thought there would be still time, if\r\nyou wish, to see Monsieur de Cavois to contradict me by saying you were\r\nnot yet gone. The falsehood would then lie at my door, and as I am not\r\na gentleman, I may be allowed to lie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe of good heart, Planchet, you shall preserve your reputation as a\r\nveracious man. In a quarter of an hour we set off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the advice I was about to give Monsieur; and where are we\r\ngoing, may I ask, without being too curious?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_\xe2\x80\x9cPardieu!_ In the opposite direction to that which you said I was\r\ngone. Besides, are you not as anxious to learn news of Grimaud,\r\nMousqueton, and Bazin as I am to know what has become of Athos,\r\nPorthos, and Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cand I will go as soon as you please.\r\nIndeed, I think provincial air will suit us much better just now than\r\nthe air of Paris. So then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo then, pack up our luggage, Planchet, and let us be off. On my part,\r\nI will go out with my hands in my pockets, that nothing may be\r\nsuspected. You may join me at the H\xc3\xb4tel des Gardes. By the way,\r\nPlanchet, I think you are right with respect to our host, and that he\r\nis decidedly a frightfully low wretch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur, you may take my word when I tell you anything. I am a\r\nphysiognomist, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went out first, as had been agreed upon. Then, in order that\r\nhe might have nothing to reproach himself with, he directed his steps,\r\nfor the last time, toward the residences of his three friends. No news\r\nhad been received of them; only a letter, all perfumed and of an\r\nelegant writing in small characters, had come for Aramis. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\ntook charge of it. Ten minutes afterward Planchet joined him at the\r\nstables of the H\xc3\xb4tel des Gardes. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in order that there might\r\nbe no time lost, had saddled his horse himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to Planchet, when the latter added the\r\nportmanteau to the equipment. \xe2\x80\x9cNow saddle the other three horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think, then, monsieur, that we shall travel faster with two\r\nhorses apiece?\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, with his shrewd air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Monsieur Jester,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut with our four horses we\r\nmay bring back our three friends, if we should have the good fortune to\r\nfind them living.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich is a great chance,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we must not despair\r\nof the mercy of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, getting into his saddle.\r\n\r\nAs they went from the H\xc3\xb4tel des Gardes, they separated, leaving the\r\nstreet at opposite ends, one having to quit Paris by the Barri\xc3\xa8re de la\r\nVillette and the other by the Barri\xc3\xa8re Montmartre, to meet again beyond\r\nSt. Denis\xe2\x80\x94a strategic maneuver which, having been executed with equal\r\npunctuality, was crowned with the most fortunate results. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nand Planchet entered Pierrefitte together.\r\n\r\nPlanchet was more courageous, it must be admitted, by day than by\r\nnight. His natural prudence, however, never forsook him for a single\r\ninstant. He had forgotten not one of the incidents of the first\r\njourney, and he looked upon everybody he met on the road as an enemy.\r\nIt followed that his hat was forever in his hand, which procured him\r\nsome severe reprimands from D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who feared that his excess of\r\npoliteness would lead people to think he was the lackey of a man of no\r\nconsequence.\r\n\r\nNevertheless, whether the passengers were really touched by the\r\nurbanity of Planchet or whether this time nobody was posted on the\r\nyoung man\xe2\x80\x99s road, our two travelers arrived at Chantilly without any\r\naccident, and alighted at the tavern of Great St. Martin, the same at\r\nwhich they had stopped on their first journey.\r\n\r\nThe host, on seeing a young man followed by a lackey with two extra\r\nhorses, advanced respectfully to the door. Now, as they had already\r\ntraveled eleven leagues, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought it time to stop, whether\r\nPorthos were or were not in the inn. Perhaps it would not be prudent to\r\nask at once what had become of the Musketeer. The result of these\r\nreflections was that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, without asking information of any\r\nkind, alighted, commended the horses to the care of his lackey, entered\r\na small room destined to receive those who wished to be alone, and\r\ndesired the host to bring him a bottle of his best wine and as good a\r\nbreakfast as possible\xe2\x80\x94a desire which further corroborated the high\r\nopinion the innkeeper had formed of the traveler at first sight.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was therefore served with miraculous celerity. The regiment\r\nof the Guards was recruited among the first gentlemen of the kingdom;\r\nand D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, followed by a lackey, and traveling with four\r\nmagnificent horses, despite the simplicity of his uniform, could not\r\nfail to make a sensation. The host desired himself to serve him; which\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan perceiving, ordered two glasses to be brought, and commenced\r\nthe following conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, my good host,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, filling the two glasses, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nasked for a bottle of your best wine, and if you have deceived me, you\r\nwill be punished in what you have sinned; for seeing that I hate\r\ndrinking by myself, you shall drink with me. Take your glass, then, and\r\nlet us drink. But what shall we drink to, so as to avoid wounding any\r\nsusceptibility? Let us drink to the prosperity of your establishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Lordship does me much honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host, \xe2\x80\x9cand I thank you\r\nsincerely for your kind wish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t mistake,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is more selfishness in my\r\ntoast than perhaps you may think\xe2\x80\x94for it is only in prosperous\r\nestablishments that one is well received. In h\xc3\xb4tels that do not\r\nflourish, everything is in confusion, and the traveler is a victim to\r\nthe embarrassments of his host. Now, I travel a great deal,\r\nparticularly on this road, and I wish to see all innkeepers making a\r\nfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this is not the first time I\r\nhave had the honor of seeing Monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah, I have passed perhaps ten times through Chantilly, and out of the\r\nten times I have stopped three or four times at your house at least.\r\nWhy I was here only ten or twelve days ago. I was conducting some\r\nfriends, Musketeers, one of whom, by the by, had a dispute with a\r\nstranger\xe2\x80\x94a man who sought a quarrel with him, for I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host; \xe2\x80\x9cI remember it perfectly. It is not\r\nMonsieur Porthos that your Lordship means?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is my companion\xe2\x80\x99s name. My God, my dear host, tell me if\r\nanything has happened to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Lordship must have observed that he could not continue his\r\njourney.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, to be sure, he promised to rejoin us, and we have seen nothing of\r\nhim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe has done us the honor to remain here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, he had done you the honor to remain here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, in this house; and we are even a little uneasy\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn what account?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf certain expenses he has contracted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but whatever expenses he may have incurred, I am sure he is in a\r\ncondition to pay them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur, you infuse genuine balm into my blood. We have made\r\nconsiderable advances; and this very morning the surgeon declared that\r\nif Monsieur Porthos did not pay him, he should look to me, as it was I\r\nwho had sent for him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPorthos is wounded, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell you, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! You cannot tell me?
