Surely you ought to be able to tell me\r\nbetter than any other person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but in our situation we must not say all we know\xe2\x80\x94particularly as\r\nwe have been warned that our ears should answer for our tongues.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, can I see Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, monsieur. Take the stairs on your right; go up the first\r\nflight and knock at Number One. Only warn him that it is you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy should I do that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, monsieur, some mischief might happen to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf what kind, in the name of wonder?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos may imagine you belong to the house, and in a fit of\r\npassion might run his sword through you or blow out your brains.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done to him, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have asked him for money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! Ah, I can understand that. It is a demand that Porthos\r\ntakes very ill when he is not in funds; but I know he must be so at\r\npresent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe thought so, too, monsieur. As our house is carried on very\r\nregularly, and we make out our bills every week, at the end of eight\r\ndays we presented our account; but it appeared we had chosen an unlucky\r\nmoment, for at the first word on the subject, he sent us to all the\r\ndevils. It is true he had been playing the day before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlaying the day before! And with whom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord, who can say, monsieur? With some gentleman who was traveling\r\nthis way, to whom he proposed a game of _lansquenet_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it, then, and the foolish fellow lost all he had?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven to his horse, monsieur; for when the gentleman was about to set\r\nout, we perceived that his lackey was saddling Monsieur Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhorse, as well as his master\xe2\x80\x99s. When we observed this to him, he told\r\nus all to trouble ourselves about our own business, as this horse\r\nbelonged to him. We also informed Monsieur Porthos of what was going\r\non; but he told us we were scoundrels to doubt a gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s word, and\r\nthat as he had said the horse was his, it must be so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s Porthos all over,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the host, \xe2\x80\x9cI replied that as from the moment we\r\nseemed not likely to come to a good understanding with respect to\r\npayment, I hoped that he would have at least the kindness to grant the\r\nfavor of his custom to my brother host of the Golden Eagle; but\r\nMonsieur Porthos replied that, my house being the best, he should\r\nremain where he was. This reply was too flattering to allow me to\r\ninsist on his departure. I confined myself then to begging him to give\r\nup his chamber, which is the handsomest in the h\xc3\xb4tel, and to be\r\nsatisfied with a pretty little room on the third floor; but to this\r\nMonsieur Porthos replied that as he every moment expected his mistress,\r\nwho was one of the greatest ladies in the court, I might easily\r\ncomprehend that the chamber he did me the honor to occupy in my house\r\nwas itself very mean for the visit of such a personage. Nevertheless,\r\nwhile acknowledging the truth of what he said, I thought proper to\r\ninsist; but without even giving himself the trouble to enter into any\r\ndiscussion with me, he took one of his pistols, laid it on his table,\r\nday and night, and said that at the first word that should be spoken to\r\nhim about removing, either within the house or out of it, he would blow\r\nout the brains of the person who should be so imprudent as to meddle\r\nwith a matter which only concerned himself. Since that time, monsieur,\r\nnobody entered his chamber but his servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Mousqueton is here, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, monsieur. Five days after your departure, he came back, and\r\nin a very bad condition, too. It appears that he had met with\r\ndisagreeableness, likewise, on his journey. Unfortunately, he is more\r\nnimble than his master; so that for the sake of his master, he puts us\r\nall under his feet, and as he thinks we might refuse what he asked for,\r\nhe takes all he wants without asking at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI have always observed a great degree\r\nof intelligence and devotedness in Mousqueton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is possible, monsieur; but suppose I should happen to be brought\r\nin contact, even four times a year, with such intelligence and\r\ndevotedness\xe2\x80\x94why, I should be a ruined man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, for Porthos will pay you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHum!\xe2\x80\x9d said the host, in a doubtful tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe favorite of a great lady will not be allowed to be inconvenienced\r\nfor such a paltry sum as he owes you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I durst say what I believe on that head\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you believe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ought rather to say, what I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd even what I am sure of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd of what are you so sure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would say that I know this great lady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how do you know her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur, if I could believe I might trust in your discretion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak! By the word of a gentleman, you shall have no cause to repent\r\nof your confidence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur, you understand that uneasiness makes us do many\r\nthings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, nothing which was not right in the character of a creditor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos gave us a note for his duchess, ordering us to put it\r\nin the post. This was before his servant came. As he could not leave\r\nhis chamber, it was necessary to charge us with this commission.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstead of putting the letter in the post, which is never safe, I took\r\nadvantage of the journey of one of my lads to Paris, and ordered him to\r\nconvey the letter to this duchess himself. This was fulfilling the\r\nintentions of Monsieur Porthos, who had desired us to be so careful of\r\nthis letter, was it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNearly so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur, do you know who this great lady is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I have heard Porthos speak of her, that\xe2\x80\x99s all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know who this pretended duchess is?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI repeat to you, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, she is the old wife of a procurator* of the Ch\xc3\xa2telet, monsieur,\r\nnamed Madame Coquenard, who, although she is at least fifty, still\r\ngives herself jealous airs. It struck me as very odd that a princess\r\nshould live in the Rue aux Ours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n* Attorney\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how do you know all this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause she flew into a great passion on receiving the letter, saying\r\nthat Monsieur Porthos was a weathercock, and that she was sure it was\r\nfor some woman he had received this wound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he been wounded, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, good Lord! What have I said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said that Porthos had received a sword cut.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but he has forbidden me so strictly to say so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cZounds, monsieur! Because he had boasted that he would perforate the\r\nstranger with whom you left him in dispute; whereas the stranger, on\r\nthe contrary, in spite of all his rodomontades quickly threw him on his\r\nback. As Monsieur Porthos is a very boastful man, he insists that\r\nnobody shall know he has received this wound except the duchess, whom\r\nhe endeavored to interest by an account of his adventure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a wound that confines him to his bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, and a master stroke, too, I assure you. Your friend\xe2\x80\x99s soul must\r\nstick tight to his body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere you there, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I followed them from curiosity, so that I saw the combat\r\nwithout the combatants seeing me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what took place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! The affair was not long, I assure you. They placed themselves on\r\nguard; the stranger made a feint and a lunge, and that so rapidly that\r\nwhen Monsieur Porthos came to the _parade_, he had already three inches\r\nof steel in his breast. He immediately fell backward. The stranger\r\nplaced the point of his sword at his throat; and Monsieur Porthos,\r\nfinding himself at the mercy of his adversary, acknowledged himself\r\nconquered. Upon which the stranger asked his name, and learning that it\r\nwas Porthos, and not D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he assisted him to rise, brought him\r\nback to the h\xc3\xb4tel, mounted his horse, and disappeared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it was with Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan this stranger meant to quarrel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you know what has become of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I never saw him until that moment, and have not seen him since.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; I know all that I wish to know. Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s chamber is, you\r\nsay, on the first story, Number One?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, the handsomest in the inn\xe2\x80\x94a chamber that I could have\r\nlet ten times over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah! Be satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cPorthos will pay you\r\nwith the money of the Duchess Coquenard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur, procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife or duchess, if she will but loosen her\r\npursestrings, it will be all the same; but she positively answered that\r\nshe was tired of the exigencies and infidelities of Monsieur Porthos,\r\nand that she would not send him a denier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did you convey this answer to your guest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe took good care not to do that; he would have found in what fashion\r\nwe had executed his commission.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that he still expects his money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Lord, yes, monsieur! Yesterday he wrote again; but it was his\r\nservant who this time put the letter in the post.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you say the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife is old and ugly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty at least, monsieur, and not at all handsome, according to\r\nPathaud\xe2\x80\x99s account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case, you may be quite at ease; she will soon be softened.\r\nBesides, Porthos cannot owe you much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, not much! Twenty good pistoles, already, without reckoning the\r\ndoctor. He denies himself nothing; it may easily be seen he has been\r\naccustomed to live well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind; if his mistress abandons him, he will find friends, I will\r\nanswer for it. So, my dear host, be not uneasy, and continue to take\r\nall the care of him that his situation requires.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur has promised me not to open his mouth about the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife, and not to say a word of the wound?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s agreed; you have my word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, he would kill me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid; he is not so much of a devil as he appears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaying these words, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went upstairs, leaving his host a little\r\nbetter satisfied with respect to two things in which he appeared to be\r\nvery much interested\xe2\x80\x94his debt and his life.\r\n\r\nAt the top of the stairs, upon the most conspicuous door of the\r\ncorridor, was traced in black ink a gigantic number \xe2\x80\x9c1.\xe2\x80\x9d D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nknocked, and upon the bidding to come in which came from inside, he\r\nentered the chamber.\r\n\r\nPorthos was in bed, and was playing a game at _lansquenet_ with\r\nMousqueton, to keep his hand in; while a spit loaded with partridges\r\nwas turning before the fire, and on each side of a large chimneypiece,\r\nover two chafing dishes, were boiling two stewpans, from which exhaled\r\na double odor of rabbit and fish stews, rejoicing to the smell. In\r\naddition to this he perceived that the top of a wardrobe and the marble\r\nof a commode were covered with empty bottles.\r\n\r\nAt the sight of his friend, Porthos uttered a loud cry of joy; and\r\nMousqueton, rising respectfully, yielded his place to him, and went to\r\ngive an eye to the two stewpans, of which he appeared to have the\r\nparticular inspection.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _pardieu!_ Is that you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are\r\nright welcome. Excuse my not coming to meet you; but,\xe2\x80\x9d added he,\r\nlooking at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with a certain degree of uneasiness, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know\r\nwhat has happened to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas the host told you nothing, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI asked after you, and came up as soon as I could.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos seemed to breathe more freely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what has happened to you, my dear Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, on making a thrust at my adversary, whom I had already hit three\r\ntimes, and whom I meant to finish with the fourth, I put my foot on a\r\nstone, slipped, and strained my knee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHonor! Luckily for the rascal, for I should have left him dead on the\r\nspot, I assure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what has became of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know; he had enough, and set off without waiting for the\r\nrest. But you, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, what has happened to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that this strain of the knee,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear\r\nPorthos, keeps you in bed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. I shall be about again in a few days.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you not have yourself conveyed to Paris? You must be cruelly\r\nbored here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was my intention; but, my dear friend, I have one thing to\r\nconfess to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is that as I was cruelly bored, as you say, and as I had the\r\nseventy-five pistoles in my pocket which you had distributed to me, in\r\norder to amuse myself I invited a gentleman who was traveling this way\r\nto walk up, and proposed a cast of dice. He accepted my challenge, and,\r\nmy faith, my seventy-five pistoles passed from my pocket to his,\r\nwithout reckoning my horse, which he won into the bargain. But you, my\r\ndear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can you expect, my dear Porthos; a man is not privileged in all\r\nways,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cYou know the proverb \xe2\x80\x98Unlucky at play, lucky\r\nin love.\xe2\x80\x99 You are too fortunate in your love for play not to take its\r\nrevenge. What consequence can the reverses of fortune be to you? Have\r\nyou not, happy rogue that you are\xe2\x80\x94have you not your duchess, who cannot\r\nfail to come to your aid?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with what ill luck I play,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nPorthos, with the most careless air in the world. \xe2\x80\x9cI wrote to her to\r\nsend me fifty louis or so, of which I stood absolutely in need on\r\naccount of my accident.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, she must be at her country seat, for she has not answered me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; so I yesterday addressed another epistle to her, still more\r\npressing than the first. But you are here, my dear fellow, let us speak\r\nof you. I confess I began to be very uneasy on your account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut your host behaves very well toward you, as it appears, my dear\r\nPorthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, directing the sick man\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the\r\nfull stewpans and the empty bottles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo, so,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cOnly three or four days ago the impertinent\r\njackanapes gave me his bill, and I was forced to turn both him and his\r\nbill out of the door; so that I am here something in the fashion of a\r\nconqueror, holding my position, as it were, my conquest. So you see,\r\nbeing in constant fear of being forced from that position, I am armed\r\nto the teeth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears to me that from time\r\nto time you must make _sorties_.\xe2\x80\x9d And he again pointed to the bottles\r\nand the stewpans.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I, unfortunately!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cThis miserable strain confines\r\nme to my bed; but Mousqueton forages, and brings in provisions. Friend\r\nMousqueton, you see that we have a reinforcement, and we must have an\r\nincrease of supplies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMousqueton,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must render me a service.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must give your recipe to Planchet. I may be besieged in my turn,\r\nand I shall not be sorry for him to be able to let me enjoy the same\r\nadvantages with which you gratify your master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord, monsieur! There is nothing more easy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mousqueton, with a\r\nmodest air. \xe2\x80\x9cOne only needs to be sharp, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. I was brought up\r\nin the country, and my father in his leisure time was something of a\r\npoacher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did he do the rest of his time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, he carried on a trade which I have always thought\r\nsatisfactory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs it was a time of war between the Catholics and the Huguenots, and\r\nas he saw the Catholics exterminate the Huguenots and the Huguenots\r\nexterminate the Catholics\xe2\x80\x94all in the name of religion\xe2\x80\x94he adopted a\r\nmixed belief which permitted him to be sometimes Catholic, sometimes a\r\nHuguenot. Now, he was accustomed to walk with his fowling piece on his\r\nshoulder, behind the hedges which border the roads, and when he saw a\r\nCatholic coming alone, the Protestant religion immediately prevailed in\r\nhis mind. He lowered his gun in the direction of the traveler; then,\r\nwhen he was within ten paces of him, he commenced a conversation which\r\nalmost always ended by the traveler\xe2\x80\x99s abandoning his purse to save his\r\nlife. It goes without saying that when he saw a Huguenot coming, he\r\nfelt himself filled with such ardent Catholic zeal that he could not\r\nunderstand how, a quarter of an hour before, he had been able to have\r\nany doubts upon the superiority of our holy religion. For my part,\r\nmonsieur, I am Catholic\xe2\x80\x94my father, faithful to his principles, having\r\nmade my elder brother a Huguenot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what was the end of this worthy man?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, of the most unfortunate kind, monsieur. One day he was surprised\r\nin a lonely road between a Huguenot and a Catholic, with both of whom\r\nhe had before had business, and who both knew him again; so they united\r\nagainst him and hanged him on a tree. Then they came and boasted of\r\ntheir fine exploit in the cabaret of the next village, where my brother\r\nand I were drinking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did you do?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe let them tell their story out,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mousqueton. \xe2\x80\x9cThen, as in\r\nleaving the cabaret they took different directions, my brother went and\r\nhid himself on the road of the Catholic, and I on that of the Huguenot.\r\nTwo hours after, all was over; we had done the business of both,\r\nadmiring the foresight of our poor father, who had taken the precaution\r\nto bring each of us up in a different religion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I must allow, as you say, your father was a very intelligent\r\nfellow. And you say in his leisure moments the worthy man was a\r\npoacher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, and it was he who taught me to lay a snare and ground a\r\nline. The consequence is that when I saw our laborers, which did not at\r\nall suit two such delicate stomachs as ours, I had recourse to a little\r\nof my old trade. While walking near the wood of Monsieur le Prince, I\r\nlaid a few snares in the runs; and while reclining on the banks of his\r\nHighness\xe2\x80\x99s pieces of water, I slipped a few lines into his fish ponds.\r\nSo that now, thanks be to God, we do not want, as Monsieur can testify,\r\nfor partridges, rabbits, carp or eels\xe2\x80\x94all light, wholesome food,\r\nsuitable for the sick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the wine,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwho furnishes the wine? Your host?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, yes and no.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow yes and no?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe furnishes it, it is true, but he does not know that he has that\r\nhonor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain yourself, Mousqueton; your conversation is full of instructive\r\nthings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is it, monsieur. It has so chanced that I met with a Spaniard in\r\nmy peregrinations who had seen many countries, and among them the New\r\nWorld.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat connection can the New World have with the bottles which are on\r\nthe commode and the wardrobe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatience, monsieur, everything will come in its turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis Spaniard had in his service a lackey who had accompanied him in\r\nhis voyage to Mexico. This lackey was my compatriot; and we became the\r\nmore intimate from there being many resemblances of character between\r\nus. We loved sporting of all kinds better than anything; so that he\r\nrelated to me how in the plains of the Pampas the natives hunt the\r\ntiger and the wild bull with simple running nooses which they throw to\r\na distance of twenty or thirty paces the end of a cord with such\r\nnicety; but in face of the proof I was obliged to acknowledge the truth\r\nof the recital. My friend placed a bottle at the distance of thirty\r\npaces, and at each cast he caught the neck of the bottle in his running\r\nnoose. I practiced this exercise, and as nature has endowed me with\r\nsome faculties, at this day I can throw the lasso with any man in the\r\nworld. Well, do you understand, monsieur? Our host has a well-furnished\r\ncellar the key of which never leaves him; only this cellar has a\r\nventilating hole. Now through this ventilating hole I throw my lasso,\r\nand as I now know in which part of the cellar is the best wine, that\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nmy point for sport. You see, monsieur, what the New World has to do\r\nwith the bottles which are on the commode and the wardrobe. Now, will\r\nyou taste our wine, and without prejudice say what you think of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my friend, thank you; unfortunately, I have just\r\nbreakfasted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9carrange the table, Mousqueton, and while we\r\nbreakfast, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan will relate to us what has happened to him during\r\nthe ten days since he left us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nWhile Porthos and Mousqueton were breakfasting, with the appetites of\r\nconvalescents and with that brotherly cordiality which unites men in\r\nmisfortune, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related how Aramis, being wounded, was obliged\r\nto stop at Cr\xc3\xa8vec\xc5\x93ur, how he had left Athos fighting at Amiens with\r\nfour men who accused him of being a coiner, and how he, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, had\r\nbeen forced to run the Comtes de Wardes through the body in order to\r\nreach England.\r\n\r\nBut there the confidence of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stopped. He only added that on\r\nhis return from Great Britain he had brought back four magnificent\r\nhorses\xe2\x80\x94one for himself, and one for each of his companions; then he\r\ninformed Porthos that the one intended for him was already installed in\r\nthe stable of the tavern.\r\n\r\nAt this moment Planchet entered, to inform his master that the horses\r\nwere sufficiently refreshed and that it would be possible to sleep at\r\nClermont.\r\n\r\nAs D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was tolerably reassured with regard to Porthos, and as he\r\nwas anxious to obtain news of his two other friends, he held out his\r\nhand to the wounded man, and told him he was about to resume his route\r\nin order to continue his researches. For the rest, as he reckoned upon\r\nreturning by the same route in seven or eight days, if Porthos were\r\nstill at the Great St. Martin, he would call for him on his way.\r\n\r\nPorthos replied that in all probability his sprain would not permit him\r\nto depart yet awhile. Besides, it was necessary he should stay at\r\nChantilly to wait for the answer from his duchess.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan wished that answer might be prompt and favorable; and having\r\nagain recommended Porthos to the care of Mousqueton, and paid his bill\r\nto the host, he resumed his route with Planchet, already relieved of\r\none of his led horses.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXVI.\r\nARAMIS AND HIS THESIS\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had said nothing to Porthos of his wound or of his\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife. Our B\xc3\xa9arnais was a prudent lad, however young he\r\nmight be. Consequently he had appeared to believe all that the\r\nvainglorious Musketeer had told him, convinced that no friendship will\r\nhold out against a surprised secret. Besides, we feel always a sort of\r\nmental superiority over those whose lives we know better than they\r\nsuppose. In his projects of intrigue for the future, and determined as\r\nhe was to make his three friends the instruments of his fortune,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not sorry at getting into his grasp beforehand the\r\ninvisible strings by which he reckoned upon moving them.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, as he journeyed along, a profound sadness weighed upon his\r\nheart. He thought of that young and pretty Mme. Bonacieux who was to\r\nhave paid him the price of his devotedness; but let us hasten to say\r\nthat this sadness possessed the young man less from the regret of the\r\nhappiness he had missed, than from the fear he entertained that some\r\nserious misfortune had befallen the poor woman. For himself, he had no\r\ndoubt she was a victim of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s vengeance; and, as was well\r\nknown, the vengeance of his Eminence was terrible. How he had found\r\ngrace in the eyes of the minister, he did not know; but without doubt\r\nM. de Cavois would have revealed this to him if the captain of the\r\nGuards had found him at home.\r\n\r\nNothing makes time pass more quickly or more shortens a journey than a\r\nthought which absorbs in itself all the faculties of the organization\r\nof him who thinks. External existence then resembles a sleep of which\r\nthis thought is the dream. By its influence, time has no longer\r\nmeasure, space has no longer distance. We depart from one place, and\r\narrive at another, that is all. Of the interval passed, nothing remains\r\nin the memory but a vague mist in which a thousand confused images of\r\ntrees, mountains, and landscapes are lost. It was as a prey to this\r\nhallucination that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan traveled, at whatever pace his horse\r\npleased, the six or eight leagues that separated Chantilly from\r\nCr\xc3\xa8vec\xc5\x93ur, without his being able to remember on his arrival in the\r\nvillage any of the things he had passed or met with on the road.\r\n\r\nThere only his memory returned to him. He shook his head, perceived the\r\ncabaret at which he had left Aramis, and putting his horse to the trot,\r\nhe shortly pulled up at the door.\r\n\r\nThis time it was not a host but a hostess who received him. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nwas a physiognomist. His eye took in at a glance the plump, cheerful\r\ncountenance of the mistress of the place, and he at once perceived\r\nthere was no occasion for dissembling with her, or of fearing anything\r\nfrom one blessed with such a joyous physiognomy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy good dame,\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ccan you tell me what has become of\r\none of my friends, whom we were obliged to leave here about a dozen\r\ndays ago?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA handsome young man, three- or four-and-twenty years old, mild,\r\namiable, and well made?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is he\xe2\x80\x94wounded in the shoulder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust so. Well, monsieur, he is still here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _pardieu!_ My dear dame,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, springing from his\r\nhorse, and throwing the bridle to Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cyou restore me to life;\r\nwhere is this dear Aramis? Let me embrace him, I am in a hurry to see\r\nhim again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon, monsieur, but I doubt whether he can see you at this moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so? Has he a lady with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJesus! What do you mean by that? Poor lad! No, monsieur, he has not a\r\nlady with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith whom is he, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the curate of Montdidier and the superior of the Jesuits of\r\nAmiens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heavens!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cis the poor fellow worse, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, quite the contrary; but after his illness grace touched\r\nhim, and he determined to take orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI had forgotten that he was only a\r\nMusketeer for a time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur still insists upon seeing him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMore than ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur has only to take the right-hand staircase in the\r\ncourtyard, and knock at Number Five on the second floor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan walked quickly in the direction indicated, and found one of\r\nthose exterior staircases that are still to be seen in the yards of our\r\nold-fashioned taverns. But there was no getting at the place of sojourn\r\nof the future abb\xc3\xa9; the defiles of the chamber of Aramis were as well\r\nguarded as the gardens of Armida. Bazin was stationed in the corridor,\r\nand barred his passage with the more intrepidity that, after many years\r\nof trial, Bazin found himself near a result of which he had ever been\r\nambitious.\r\n\r\nIn fact, the dream of poor Bazin had always been to serve a churchman;\r\nand he awaited with impatience the moment, always in the future, when\r\nAramis would throw aside the uniform and assume the cassock. The\r\ndaily-renewed promise of the young man that the moment would not long\r\nbe delayed, had alone kept him in the service of a Musketeer\xe2\x80\x94a service\r\nin which, he said, his soul was in constant jeopardy.\r\n\r\nBazin was then at the height of joy. In all probability, this time his\r\nmaster would not retract. The union of physical pain with moral\r\nuneasiness had produced the effect so long desired. Aramis, suffering\r\nat once in body and mind, had at length fixed his eyes and his thoughts\r\nupon religion, and he had considered as a warning from heaven the\r\ndouble accident which had happened to him; that is to say, the sudden\r\ndisappearance of his mistress and the wound in his shoulder.\r\n\r\nIt may be easily understood that in the present disposition of his\r\nmaster nothing could be more disagreeable to Bazin than the arrival of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, which might cast his master back again into that vortex of\r\nmundane affairs which had so long carried him away. He resolved, then,\r\nto defend the door bravely; and as, betrayed by the mistress of the\r\ninn, he could not say that Aramis was absent, he endeavored to prove to\r\nthe newcomer that it would be the height of indiscretion to disturb his\r\nmaster in his pious conference, which had commenced with the morning\r\nand would not, as Bazin said, terminate before night.\r\n\r\nBut D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took very little heed of the eloquent discourse of M.\r\nBazin; and as he had no desire to support a polemic discussion with his\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s valet, he simply moved him out of the way with one hand, and\r\nwith the other turned the handle of the door of Number Five. The door\r\nopened, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went into the chamber.\r\n\r\nAramis, in a black gown, his head enveloped in a sort of round flat\r\ncap, not much unlike a _calotte_, was seated before an oblong table,\r\ncovered with rolls of paper and enormous volumes in folio. At his right\r\nhand was placed the superior of the Jesuits, and on his left the curate\r\nof Montdidier. The curtains were half drawn, and only admitted the\r\nmysterious light calculated for beatific reveries. All the mundane\r\nobjects that generally strike the eye on entering the room of a young\r\nman, particularly when that young man is a Musketeer, had disappeared\r\nas if by enchantment; and for fear, no doubt, that the sight of them\r\nmight bring his master back to ideas of this world, Bazin had laid his\r\nhands upon sword, pistols, plumed hat, and embroideries and laces of\r\nall kinds and sorts. In their stead D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought he perceived in\r\nan obscure corner a discipline cord suspended from a nail in the wall.\r\n\r\nAt the noise made by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan in entering, Aramis lifted up his head,\r\nand beheld his friend; but to the great astonishment of the young man,\r\nthe sight of him did not produce much effect upon the Musketeer, so\r\ncompletely was his mind detached from the things of this world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood day, dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cbelieve me, I am glad to see\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo am I delighted to see you,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9calthough I am not yet\r\nsure that it is Aramis I am speaking to.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo himself, my friend, to himself! But what makes you doubt it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid I had made a mistake in the chamber, and that I had found\r\nmy way into the apartment of some churchman. Then another error seized\r\nme on seeing you in company with these gentlemen\xe2\x80\x94I was afraid you were\r\ndangerously ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two men in black, who guessed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s meaning, darted at him a\r\nglance which might have been thought threatening; but D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took\r\nno heed of it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI disturb you, perhaps, my dear Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cfor by\r\nwhat I see, I am led to believe that you are confessing to these\r\ngentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis colored imperceptibly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou disturb me? Oh, quite the contrary,\r\ndear friend, I swear; and as a proof of what I say, permit me to\r\ndeclare I am rejoiced to see you safe and sound.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, he\xe2\x80\x99ll come round,\xe2\x80\x9d thought D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s not bad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis gentleman, who is my friend, has just escaped from a serious\r\ndanger,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, with unction, pointing to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with\r\nhis hand, and addressing the two ecclesiastics.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPraise God, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied they, bowing together.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not failed to do so, your Reverences,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man,\r\nreturning their salutation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou arrive in good time, dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cand by taking\r\npart in our discussion may assist us with your intelligence. Monsieur\r\nthe Principal of Amiens, Monsieur the Curate of Montdidier, and I are\r\narguing certain theological questions in which we have been much\r\ninterested; I shall be delighted to have your opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe opinion of a swordsman can have very little weight,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who began to be uneasy at the turn things were taking, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nyou had better be satisfied, believe me, with the knowledge of these\r\ngentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two men in black bowed in their turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cyour opinion will be very valuable.\r\nThe question is this: Monsieur the Principal thinks that my thesis\r\nought to be dogmatic and didactic.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour thesis! Are you then making a thesis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jesuit. \xe2\x80\x9cIn the examination which precedes\r\nordination, a thesis is always a requisite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOrdination!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who could not believe what the hostess\r\nand Bazin had successively told him; and he gazed, half stupefied, upon\r\nthe three persons before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, taking the same graceful position in his easy\r\nchair that he would have assumed in bed, and complacently examining his\r\nhand, which was as white and plump as that of a woman, and which he\r\nheld in the air to cause the blood to descend, \xe2\x80\x9cnow, as you have heard,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, Monsieur the Principal is desirous that my thesis should be\r\ndogmatic, while I, for my part, would rather it should be ideal. This\r\nis the reason why Monsieur the Principal has proposed to me the\r\nfollowing subject, which has not yet been treated upon, and in which I\r\nperceive there is matter for magnificent elaboration\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98_Utraque manus in\r\nbenedicendo clericis inferioribus necessaria est_.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose erudition we are well acquainted with, evinced no\r\nmore interest on hearing this quotation than he had at that of M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville in allusion to the gifts he pretended that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nreceived from the Duke of Buckingham.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Aramis, that he might perfectly understand,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98The two hands are indispensable for priests of the inferior orders,\r\nwhen they bestow the benediction.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn admirable subject!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jesuit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdmirable and dogmatic!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the curate, who, about as strong as\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with respect to Latin, carefully watched the Jesuit in order\r\nto keep step with him, and repeated his words like an echo.\r\n\r\nAs to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he remained perfectly insensible to the enthusiasm of\r\nthe two men in black.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, admirable! _prorsus admirabile!_\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cbut which\r\nrequires a profound study of both the Scriptures and the Fathers. Now,\r\nI have confessed to these learned ecclesiastics, and that in all\r\nhumility, that the duties of mounting guard and the service of the king\r\nhave caused me to neglect study a little. I should find myself,\r\ntherefore, more at my ease, _facilius natans_, in a subject of my own\r\nchoice, which would be to these hard theological questions what morals\r\nare to metaphysics in philosophy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan began to be tired, and so did the curate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee what an exordium!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jesuit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExordium,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the curate, for the sake of saying something.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Quemadmodum inter c\xc5\x93lorum immensitatem_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis cast a glance upon D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to see what effect all this\r\nproduced, and found his friend gaping enough to split his jaws.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us speak French, my father,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the Jesuit; \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan will enjoy our conversation better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI am fatigued with reading, and all this\r\nLatin confuses me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Jesuit, a little put out, while the curate,\r\ngreatly delighted, turned upon D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan a look full of gratitude.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, let us see what is to be derived from this gloss. Moses, the\r\nservant of God\xe2\x80\x94he was but a servant, please to understand\xe2\x80\x94Moses blessed\r\nwith the hands; he held out both his arms while the Hebrews beat their\r\nenemies, and then he blessed them with his two hands. Besides, what\r\ndoes the Gospel say? _Imponite manus_, and not _manum_\xe2\x80\x94place the\r\n_hands_, not the _hand_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlace the _hands_,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the curate, with a gesture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. Peter, on the contrary, of whom the Popes are the successors,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued the Jesuit; \xe2\x80\x9c_porrige digitos_\xe2\x80\x94present the fingers. Are you\r\nthere, now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Certes_,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, in a pleased tone, \xe2\x80\x9cbut the thing is\r\nsubtle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _fingers_,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the Jesuit, \xe2\x80\x9cSt. Peter blessed with the\r\n_fingers_. The Pope, therefore blesses with the fingers. And with how\r\nmany fingers does he bless? With _three_ fingers, to be sure\xe2\x80\x94one for\r\nthe Father, one for the Son, and one for the Holy Ghost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll crossed themselves. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought it was proper to follow this\r\nexample.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Pope is the successor of St. Peter, and represents the three\r\ndivine powers; the rest\xe2\x80\x94_ordines inferiores_\xe2\x80\x94of the ecclesiastical\r\nhierarchy bless in the name of the holy archangels and angels. The most\r\nhumble clerks such as our deacons and sacristans, bless with holy water\r\nsprinklers, which resemble an infinite number of blessing fingers.\r\nThere is the subject simplified. _Argumentum omni denudatum ornamento_.\r\nI could make of that subject two volumes the size of this,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nthe Jesuit; and in his enthusiasm he struck a St. Chrysostom in folio,\r\nwhich made the table bend beneath its weight.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan trembled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Certes_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI do justice to the beauties of this thesis;\r\nbut at the same time I perceive it would be overwhelming for me. I had\r\nchosen this text\xe2\x80\x94tell me, dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, if it is not to your\r\ntaste\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98_Non inutile est desiderium in oblatione_\xe2\x80\x99; that is, \xe2\x80\x98A little\r\nregret is not unsuitable in an offering to the Lord.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop there!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jesuit, \xe2\x80\x9cfor that thesis touches closely upon\r\nheresy. There is a proposition almost like it in the _Augustinus_ of\r\nthe heresiarch Jansenius, whose book will sooner or later be burned by\r\nthe hands of the executioner. Take care, my young friend. You are\r\ninclining toward false doctrines, my young friend; you will be lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will be lost,\xe2\x80\x9d said the curate, shaking his head sorrowfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou approach that famous point of free will which is a mortal rock.\r\nYou face the insinuations of the Pelagians and the semi-Pelagians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, my Reverend\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, a little amazed by the shower of\r\narguments that poured upon his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow will you prove,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the Jesuit, without allowing him time\r\nto speak, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we ought to regret the world when we offer ourselves to\r\nGod? Listen to this dilemma: God is God, and the world is the devil. To\r\nregret the world is to regret the devil; that is my conclusion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is mine also,\xe2\x80\x9d said the curate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, for heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Desideras diabolum_, unhappy man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jesuit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe regrets the devil! Ah, my young friend,\xe2\x80\x9d added the curate,\r\ngroaning, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not regret the devil, I implore you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan felt himself bewildered. It seemed to him as though he were\r\nin a madhouse, and was becoming as mad as those he saw. He was,\r\nhowever, forced to hold his tongue from not comprehending half the\r\nlanguage they employed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut listen to me, then,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Aramis with politeness mingled with a\r\nlittle impatience. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not say I regret; no, I will never pronounce\r\nthat sentence, which would not be orthodox.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Jesuit raised his hands toward heaven, and the curate did the same.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but pray grant me that it is acting with an ill grace to offer to\r\nthe Lord only that with which we are perfectly disgusted! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you\r\nthink so, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he.\r\n\r\nThe Jesuit and the curate quite started from their chairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the point of departure; it is a syllogism. The world is not\r\nwanting in attractions. I quit the world; then I make a sacrifice. Now,\r\nthe Scripture says positively, \xe2\x80\x98Make a sacrifice unto the Lord.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true,\xe2\x80\x9d said his antagonists.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, pinching his ear to make it red, as he rubbed\r\nhis hands to make them white, \xe2\x80\x9cand then I made a certain _rondeau_ upon\r\nit last year, which I showed to Monsieur Voiture, and that great man\r\npaid me a thousand compliments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA _rondeau!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jesuit, disdainfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA _rondeau!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the curate, mechanically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRepeat it! Repeat it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cit will make a little\r\nchange.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so, for it is religious,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cit is theology in\r\nverse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, with a little look of diffidence, which,\r\nhowever, was not exempt from a shade of hypocrisy:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVous qui pleurez un pass\xc3\xa9 plein de charmes,\r\n    Et qui trainez des jours infortun\xc3\xa9s,\r\n    Tous vos malheurs se verront termin\xc3\xa9s,\r\nQuand \xc3\xa0 Dieu seul vous offrirez vos larmes,\r\n        Vous qui pleurez!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou who weep for pleasures fled,\r\n    While dragging on a life of care,\r\n    All your woes will melt in air,\r\nIf to God your tears are shed,\r\n        You who weep!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and the curate appeared pleased. The Jesuit persisted in his\r\nopinion. \xe2\x80\x9cBeware of a profane taste in your theological style. What\r\nsays Augustine on this subject: \xe2\x80\x98_Severus sit clericorum verbo_.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, let the sermon be clear,\xe2\x80\x9d said the curate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d hastily interrupted the Jesuit, on seeing that his acolyte was\r\ngoing astray, \xe2\x80\x9cnow your thesis would please the ladies; it would have\r\nthe success of one of Monsieur Patru\xe2\x80\x99s pleadings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis, transported.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere it is,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Jesuit; \xe2\x80\x9cthe world still speaks within you in\r\na loud voice, _altisim\xc3\xa2 voce_. You follow the world, my young friend,\r\nand I tremble lest grace prove not efficacious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied, my reverend father, I can answer for myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMundane presumption!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know myself, Father; my resolution is irrevocable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you persist in continuing that thesis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel myself called upon to treat that, and no other. I will see\r\nabout the continuation of it, and tomorrow I hope you will be satisfied\r\nwith the corrections I shall have made in consequence of your advice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWork slowly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the curate; \xe2\x80\x9cwe leave you in an excellent tone of\r\nmind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the ground is all sown,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jesuit, \xe2\x80\x9cand we have not to\r\nfear that one portion of the seed may have fallen upon stone, another\r\nupon the highway, or that the birds of heaven have eaten the rest,\r\n_aves c\xc5\x93li comederunt illam_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlague stifle you and your Latin!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who began to feel\r\nall his patience exhausted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, my son,\xe2\x80\x9d said the curate, \xe2\x80\x9ctill tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill tomorrow, rash youth,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Jesuit. \xe2\x80\x9cYou promise to become\r\none of the lights of the Church. Heaven grant that this light prove not\r\na devouring fire!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who for an hour past had been gnawing his nails with\r\nimpatience, was beginning to attack the quick.\r\n\r\nThe two men in black rose, bowed to Aramis and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and advanced\r\ntoward the door. Bazin, who had been standing listening to all this\r\ncontroversy with a pious jubilation, sprang toward them, took the\r\nbreviary of the curate and the missal of the Jesuit, and walked\r\nrespectfully before them to clear their way.\r\n\r\nAramis conducted them to the foot of the stairs, and then immediately\r\ncame up again to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose senses were still in a state of\r\nconfusion.\r\n\r\nWhen left alone, the two friends at first kept an embarrassed silence.\r\nIt however became necessary for one of them to break it first, and as\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan appeared determined to leave that honor to his companion,\r\nAramis said, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see that I am returned to my fundamental ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, efficacious grace has touched you, as that gentleman said just\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, these plans of retreat have been formed for a long time. You have\r\noften heard me speak of them, have you not, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but I confess I always thought you jested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith such things! Oh, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! Why, people jest with death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd people are wrong, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; for death is the door which leads to\r\nperdition or to salvation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGranted; but if you please, let us not theologize, Aramis. You must\r\nhave had enough for today. As for me, I have almost forgotten the\r\nlittle Latin I have ever known. Then I confess to you that I have eaten\r\nnothing since ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock this morning, and I am devilish hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will dine directly, my friend; only you must please to remember\r\nthat this is Friday. Now, on such a day I can neither eat flesh nor see\r\nit eaten. If you can be satisfied with my dinner\xe2\x80\x94it consists of cooked\r\ntetragones and fruits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean by tetragones?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, uneasily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean spinach,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cbut on your account I will add some\r\neggs, and that is a serious infraction of the rule\xe2\x80\x94for eggs are meat,\r\nsince they engender chickens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis feast is not very succulent; but never mind, I will put up with\r\nit for the sake of remaining with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am grateful to you for the sacrifice,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if your\r\nbody be not greatly benefited by it, be assured your soul will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, Aramis, you are decidedly going into the Church? What will our\r\ntwo friends say? What will Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville say? They will treat\r\nyou as a deserter, I warn you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not enter the Church; I re-enter it. I deserted the Church for\r\nthe world, for you know that I forced myself when I became a\r\nMusketeer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? I know nothing about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know I quit the seminary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is my story, then. Besides, the Scriptures say, \xe2\x80\x98Confess\r\nyourselves to one another,\xe2\x80\x99 and I confess to you, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I give you absolution beforehand. You see I am a good sort of a\r\nman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not jest about holy things, my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, then, I listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had been at the seminary from nine years old; in three days I should\r\nhave been twenty. I was about to become an abb\xc3\xa9, and all was arranged.\r\nOne evening I went, according to custom, to a house which I frequented\r\nwith much pleasure: when one is young, what can be expected?\xe2\x80\x94one is\r\nweak. An officer who saw me, with a jealous eye, reading the _Lives of\r\nthe Saints_ to the mistress of the house, entered suddenly and without\r\nbeing announced. That evening I had translated an episode of Judith,\r\nand had just communicated my verses to the lady, who gave me all sorts\r\nof compliments, and leaning on my shoulder, was reading them a second\r\ntime with me. Her pose, which I must admit was rather free, wounded\r\nthis officer. He said nothing; but when I went out he followed, and\r\nquickly came up with me. \xe2\x80\x98Monsieur the Abb\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98do you like\r\nblows with a cane?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I cannot say, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x99 answered I; \xe2\x80\x98no one has\r\never dared to give me any.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Well, listen to me, then, Monsieur the\r\nAbb\xc3\xa9! If you venture again into the house in which I have met you this\r\nevening, I will dare it myself.\xe2\x80\x99 I really think I must have been\r\nfrightened. I became very pale; I felt my legs fail me; I sought for a\r\nreply, but could find none\xe2\x80\x94I was silent. The officer waited for his\r\nreply, and seeing it so long coming, he burst into a laugh, turned upon\r\nhis heel, and re-entered the house. I returned to the seminary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a gentleman born, and my blood is warm, as you may have remarked,\r\nmy dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. The insult was terrible, and although unknown to\r\nthe rest of the world, I felt it live and fester at the bottom of my\r\nheart. I informed my superiors that I did not feel myself sufficiently\r\nprepared for ordination, and at my request the ceremony was postponed\r\nfor a year. I sought out the best fencing master in Paris, I made an\r\nagreement with him to take a lesson every day, and every day for a year\r\nI took that lesson. Then, on the anniversary of the day on which I had\r\nbeen insulted, I hung my cassock on a peg, assumed the costume of a\r\ncavalier, and went to a ball given by a lady friend of mine and to\r\nwhich I knew my man was invited. It was in the Rue des\r\nFrance-Bourgeois, close to La Force. As I expected, my officer was\r\nthere. I went up to him as he was singing a love ditty and looking\r\ntenderly at a lady, and interrupted him exactly in the middle of the\r\nsecond couplet. \xe2\x80\x98Monsieur,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98does it still displease you that I\r\nshould frequent a certain house of La Rue Payenne? And would you still\r\ncane me if I took it into my head to disobey you? The officer looked at\r\nme with astonishment, and then said, \xe2\x80\x98What is your business with me,\r\nmonsieur? I do not know you.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I am,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98the little abb\xc3\xa9 who\r\nreads _Lives of the Saints_, and translates Judith into verse.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Ah,\r\nah! I recollect now,\xe2\x80\x99 said the officer, in a jeering tone; \xe2\x80\x98well, what\r\ndo you want with me?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I want you to spare time to take a walk with\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Tomorrow morning, if you like, with the greatest pleasure.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98No,\r\nnot tomorrow morning, if you please, but immediately.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98If you\r\nabsolutely insist.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98I do insist upon it.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Come, then. Ladies,\xe2\x80\x99 said\r\nthe officer, \xe2\x80\x98do not disturb yourselves; allow me time just to kill\r\nthis gentleman, and I will return and finish the last couplet.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe went out. I took him to the Rue Payenne, to exactly the same spot\r\nwhere, a year before, at the very same hour, he had paid me the\r\ncompliment I have related to you. It was a superb moonlight night. We\r\nimmediately drew, and at the first pass I laid him stark dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cas the ladies did not see the singer come\r\nback, and as he was found in the Rue Payenne with a great sword wound\r\nthrough his body, it was supposed that I had accommodated him thus; and\r\nthe matter created some scandal which obliged me to renounce the\r\ncassock for a time. Athos, whose acquaintance I made about that period,\r\nand Porthos, who had in addition to my lessons taught me some effective\r\ntricks of fence, prevailed upon me to solicit the uniform of a\r\nMusketeer. The king entertained great regard for my father, who had\r\nfallen at the siege of Arras, and the uniform was granted. You may\r\nunderstand that the moment has come for me to re-enter the bosom of the\r\nChurch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why today, rather than yesterday or tomorrow? What has happened to\r\nyou today, to raise all these melancholy ideas?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis wound, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, has been a warning to me from heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis wound? Bah, it is now nearly healed, and I am sure it is not that\r\nwhich gives you the most pain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, then?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have one at heart, Aramis, one deeper and more painful\xe2\x80\x94a wound\r\nmade by a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe eye of Aramis kindled in spite of himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, dissembling his emotion under a feigned carelessness,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo not talk of such things, and suffer love pains? _Vanitas\r\nvanitatum!_ According to your idea, then, my brain is turned. And for\r\nwhom\xe2\x80\x94for some _grisette_, some chambermaid with whom I have trifled in\r\nsome garrison? Fie!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon, my dear Aramis, but I thought you carried your eyes higher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHigher? And who am I, to nourish such ambition? A poor Musketeer, a\r\nbeggar, an unknown\xe2\x80\x94who hates slavery, and finds himself ill-placed in\r\nthe world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAramis, Aramis!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, looking at his friend with an air\r\nof doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDust I am, and to dust I return. Life is full of humiliations and\r\nsorrows,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, becoming still more melancholy; \xe2\x80\x9call the ties\r\nwhich attach him to life break in the hand of man, particularly the\r\ngolden ties. Oh, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Aramis, giving to his\r\nvoice a slight tone of bitterness, \xe2\x80\x9ctrust me! Conceal your wounds when\r\nyou have any; silence is the last joy of the unhappy. Beware of giving\r\nanyone the clue to your griefs; the curious suck our tears as flies\r\nsuck the blood of a wounded hart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, my dear Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in his turn heaving a profound\r\nsigh, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is my story you are relating!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; a woman whom I love, whom I adore, has just been torn from me by\r\nforce. I do not know where she is or whither they have conducted her.\r\nShe is perhaps a prisoner; she is perhaps dead!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, but you have at least this consolation, that you can say to\r\nyourself she has not quit you voluntarily, that if you learn no news of\r\nher, it is because all communication with you is interdicted; while I\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cnothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you renounce the world, then, forever; that is a settled thing\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nresolution registered!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForever! You are my friend today; tomorrow you will be no more to me\r\nthan a shadow, or rather, even, you will no longer exist. As for the\r\nworld, it is a sepulcher and nothing else.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! All this is very sad which you tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will you? My vocation commands me; it carries me away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan smiled, but made no answer.\r\n\r\nAramis continued, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet, while I do belong to the earth, I wish to\r\nspeak of you\xe2\x80\x94of our friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd on my part,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI wished to speak of you, but I\r\nfind you so completely detached from everything! To love you cry, \xe2\x80\x98Fie!\r\nFriends are shadows! The world is a sepulcher!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, you will find it so yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, with a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, let us say no more about it,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand let us\r\nburn this letter, which, no doubt, announces to you some fresh\r\ninfidelity of your _grisette_ or your chambermaid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat letter?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis, eagerly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA letter which was sent to your abode in your absence, and which was\r\ngiven to me for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut from whom is that letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, from some heartbroken waiting woman, some desponding _grisette;_\r\nfrom Madame de Chevreuse\xe2\x80\x99s chambermaid, perhaps, who was obliged to\r\nreturn to Tours with her mistress, and who, in order to appear smart\r\nand attractive, stole some perfumed paper, and sealed her letter with a\r\nduchess\xe2\x80\x99s coronet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold! I must have lost it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man maliciously, pretending\r\nto search for it. \xe2\x80\x9cBut fortunately the world is a sepulcher; the men,\r\nand consequently the women, are but shadows, and love is a sentiment to\r\nwhich you cry, \xe2\x80\x98Fie! Fie!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are killing me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here it is at last!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, as he drew the letter from\r\nhis pocket.\r\n\r\nAramis made a bound, seized the letter, read it, or rather devoured it,\r\nhis countenance radiant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis same waiting maid seems to have an agreeable style,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nmessenger, carelessly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, thanks!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis, almost in a state of\r\ndelirium. \xe2\x80\x9cShe was forced to return to Tours; she is not faithless; she\r\nstill loves me! Come, my friend, come, let me embrace you. Happiness\r\nalmost stifles me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two friends began to dance around the venerable St. Chrysostom,\r\nkicking about famously the sheets of the thesis, which had fallen on\r\nthe floor.\r\n\r\nAt that moment Bazin entered with the spinach and the omelet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe off, you wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis, throwing his skullcap in his face.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReturn whence you came; take back those horrible vegetables, and that\r\npoor kickshaw! Order a larded hare, a fat capon, mutton leg dressed\r\nwith garlic, and four bottles of old Burgundy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBazin, who looked at his master, without comprehending the cause of\r\nthis change, in a melancholy manner, allowed the omelet to slip into\r\nthe spinach, and the spinach onto the floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow this is the moment to consecrate your existence to the King of\r\nkings,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cif you persist in offering him a civility.\r\n_Non inutile desiderium oblatione_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the devil with your Latin. Let us drink, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\n_morbleu!_ Let us drink while the wine is fresh! Let us drink heartily,\r\nand while we do so, tell me a little of what is going on in the world\r\nyonder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXVII.\r\nTHE WIFE OF ATHOS\r\n\r\n\r\nWe have now to search for Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to the vivacious\r\nAramis, when he had informed him of all that had passed since their\r\ndeparture from the capital, and an excellent dinner had made one of\r\nthem forget his thesis and the other his fatigue.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think, then, that any harm can have happened to him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked\r\nAramis. \xe2\x80\x9cAthos is so cool, so brave, and handles his sword so\r\nskillfully.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt. Nobody has a higher opinion of the courage and skill of\r\nAthos than I have; but I like better to hear my sword clang against\r\nlances than against staves. I fear lest Athos should have been beaten\r\ndown by serving men. Those fellows strike hard, and don\xe2\x80\x99t leave off in\r\na hurry. This is why I wish to set out again as soon as possible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will try to accompany you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cthough I scarcely feel in\r\na condition to mount on horseback. Yesterday I undertook to employ that\r\ncord which you see hanging against the wall, but pain prevented my\r\ncontinuing the pious exercise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the first time I ever heard of anybody trying to cure gunshot\r\nwounds with cat-o\xe2\x80\x99-nine-tails; but you were ill, and illness renders\r\nthe head weak, therefore you may be excused.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen do you mean to set out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow at daybreak. Sleep as soundly as you can tonight, and\r\ntomorrow, if you can, we will take our departure together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill tomorrow, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cfor iron-nerved as you are, you\r\nmust need repose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe next morning, when D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan entered Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s chamber, he found\r\nhim at the window.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you looking at?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith! I am admiring three magnificent horses which the stable boys\r\nare leading about. It would be a pleasure worthy of a prince to travel\r\nupon such horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear Aramis, you may enjoy that pleasure, for one of those\r\nthree horses is yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, bah! Which?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhichever of the three you like, I have no preference.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the rich caparison, is that mine, too?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou laugh, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have left off laughing, now that you speak French.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, those rich holsters, that velvet housing, that saddle studded\r\nwith silver\xe2\x80\x94are they all for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor you and nobody else, as the horse which paws the ground is mine,\r\nand the other horse, which is caracoling, belongs to Athos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Peste!_ They are three superb animals!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad they please you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it must have been the king who made you such a present.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly it was not the cardinal; but don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble yourself whence\r\nthey come, think only that one of the three is your property.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI choose that which the red-headed boy is leading.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is yours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood heaven! That is enough to drive away all my pains; I could mount\r\nhim with thirty balls in my body. On my soul, handsome stirrups!\r\n_Hol\xc3\xa0_, Bazin, come here this minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBazin appeared on the threshold, dull and spiritless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat last order is useless,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cthere are loaded\r\npistols in your holsters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBazin sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Monsieur Bazin, make yourself easy,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cpeople of\r\nall conditions gain the kingdom of heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur was already such a good theologian,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bazin, almost\r\nweeping; \xe2\x80\x9che might have become a bishop, and perhaps a cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but my poor Bazin, reflect a little. Of what use is it to be a\r\nchurchman, pray? You do not avoid going to war by that means; you see,\r\nthe cardinal is about to make the next campaign, helm on head and\r\npartisan in hand. And Monsieur de Nogaret de la Valette, what do you\r\nsay of him? He is a cardinal likewise. Ask his lackey how often he has\r\nhad to prepare lint of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d sighed Bazin. \xe2\x80\x9cI know it, monsieur; everything is turned\r\ntopsy-turvy in the world nowadays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile this dialogue was going on, the two young men and the poor lackey\r\ndescended.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold my stirrup, Bazin,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis; and Aramis sprang into the\r\nsaddle with his usual grace and agility, but after a few vaults and\r\ncurvets of the noble animal his rider felt his pains come on so\r\ninsupportably that he turned pale and became unsteady in his seat.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, foreseeing such an event, had kept his eye on him,\r\nsprang toward him, caught him in his arms, and assisted him to his\r\nchamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all right, my dear Aramis, take care of yourself,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwill go alone in search of Athos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a man of brass,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I have good luck, that is all. But how do you mean to pass your\r\ntime till I come back? No more theses, no more glosses upon the fingers\r\nor upon benedictions, hey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cI will make verses,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I dare say; verses perfumed with the odor of the billet from the\r\nattendant of Madame de Chevreuse. Teach Bazin prosody; that will\r\nconsole him. As to the horse, ride him a little every day, and that\r\nwill accustom you to his maneuvers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, make yourself easy on that head,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will find\r\nme ready to follow you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey took leave of each other, and in ten minutes, after having\r\ncommended his friend to the cares of the hostess and Bazin, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nwas trotting along in the direction of Amiens.\r\n\r\nHow was he going to find Athos? Should he find him at all? The position\r\nin which he had left him was critical. He probably had succumbed. This\r\nidea, while darkening his brow, drew several sighs from him, and caused\r\nhim to formulate to himself a few vows of vengeance. Of all his\r\nfriends, Athos was the eldest, and the least resembling him in\r\nappearance, in his tastes and sympathies.\r\n\r\nYet he entertained a marked preference for this gentleman. The noble\r\nand distinguished air of Athos, those flashes of greatness which from\r\ntime to time broke out from the shade in which he voluntarily kept\r\nhimself, that unalterable equality of temper which made him the most\r\npleasant companion in the world, that forced and cynical gaiety, that\r\nbravery which might have been termed blind if it had not been the\r\nresult of the rarest coolness\xe2\x80\x94such qualities attracted more than the\r\nesteem, more than the friendship of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; they attracted his\r\nadmiration.\r\n\r\nIndeed, when placed beside M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, the elegant and noble\r\ncourtier, Athos in his most cheerful days might advantageously sustain\r\na comparison. He was of middle height; but his person was so admirably\r\nshaped and so well proportioned that more than once in his struggles\r\nwith Porthos he had overcome the giant whose physical strength was\r\nproverbial among the Musketeers. His head, with piercing eyes, a\r\nstraight nose, a chin cut like that of Brutus, had altogether an\r\nindefinable character of grandeur and grace. His hands, of which he\r\ntook little care, were the despair of Aramis, who cultivated his with\r\nalmond paste and perfumed oil. The sound of his voice was at once\r\npenetrating and melodious; and then, that which was inconceivable in\r\nAthos, who was always retiring, was that delicate knowledge of the\r\nworld and of the usages of the most brilliant society\xe2\x80\x94those manners of\r\na high degree which appeared, as if unconsciously to himself, in his\r\nleast actions.\r\n\r\nIf a repast were on foot, Athos presided over it better than any other,\r\nplacing every guest exactly in the rank which his ancestors had earned\r\nfor him or that he had made for himself. If a question in heraldry were\r\nstarted, Athos knew all the noble families of the kingdom, their\r\ngenealogy, their alliances, their coats of arms, and the origin of\r\nthem. Etiquette had no minuti\xc3\xa6 unknown to him. He knew what were the\r\nrights of the great land owners. He was profoundly versed in hunting\r\nand falconry, and had one day when conversing on this great art\r\nastonished even Louis XIII. himself, who took a pride in being\r\nconsidered a past master therein.\r\n\r\nLike all the great nobles of that period, Athos rode and fenced to\r\nperfection. But still further, his education had been so little\r\nneglected, even with respect to scholastic studies, so rare at this\r\ntime among gentlemen, that he smiled at the scraps of Latin which\r\nAramis sported and which Porthos pretended to understand. Two or three\r\ntimes, even, to the great astonishment of his friends, he had, when\r\nAramis allowed some rudimental error to escape him, replaced a verb in\r\nits right tense and a noun in its case. Besides, his probity was\r\nirreproachable, in an age in which soldiers compromised so easily with\r\ntheir religion and their consciences, lovers with the rigorous delicacy\r\nof our era, and the poor with God\xe2\x80\x99s Seventh Commandment. This Athos,\r\nthen, was a very extraordinary man.\r\n\r\nAnd yet this nature so distinguished, this creature so beautiful, this\r\nessence so fine, was seen to turn insensibly toward material life, as\r\nold men turn toward physical and moral imbecility. Athos, in his hours\r\nof gloom\xe2\x80\x94and these hours were frequent\xe2\x80\x94was extinguished as to the whole\r\nof the luminous portion of him, and his brilliant side disappeared as\r\ninto profound darkness.\r\n\r\nThen the demigod vanished; he remained scarcely a man. His head hanging\r\ndown, his eye dull, his speech slow and painful, Athos would look for\r\nhours together at his bottle, his glass, or at Grimaud, who, accustomed\r\nto obey him by signs, read in the faint glance of his master his least\r\ndesire, and satisfied it immediately. If the four friends were\r\nassembled at one of these moments, a word, thrown forth occasionally\r\nwith a violent effort, was the share Athos furnished to the\r\nconversation. In exchange for his silence Athos drank enough for four,\r\nand without appearing to be otherwise affected by wine than by a more\r\nmarked constriction of the brow and by a deeper sadness.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose inquiring disposition we are acquainted with, had\r\nnot\xe2\x80\x94whatever interest he had in satisfying his curiosity on this\r\nsubject\xe2\x80\x94been able to assign any cause for these fits, or for the\r\nperiods of their recurrence. Athos never received any letters; Athos\r\nnever had concerns which all his friends did not know.\r\n\r\nIt could not be said that it was wine which produced this sadness; for\r\nin truth he only drank to combat this sadness, which wine however, as\r\nwe have said, rendered still darker. This excess of bilious humor could\r\nnot be attributed to play; for unlike Porthos, who accompanied the\r\nvariations of chance with songs or oaths, Athos when he won remained as\r\nunmoved as when he lost.
