He had been known, in the circle of the\r\nMusketeers, to win in one night three thousand pistoles; to lose them\r\neven to the gold-embroidered belt for gala days, win all this again\r\nwith the addition of a hundred louis, without his beautiful eyebrow\r\nbeing heightened or lowered half a line, without his hands losing their\r\npearly hue, without his conversation, which was cheerful that evening,\r\nceasing to be calm and agreeable.\r\n\r\nNeither was it, as with our neighbors, the English, an atmospheric\r\ninfluence which darkened his countenance; for the sadness generally\r\nbecame more intense toward the fine season of the year. June and July\r\nwere the terrible months with Athos.\r\n\r\nFor the present he had no anxiety. He shrugged his shoulders when\r\npeople spoke of the future. His secret, then, was in the past, as had\r\noften been vaguely said to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nThis mysterious shade, spread over his whole person, rendered still\r\nmore interesting the man whose eyes or mouth, even in the most complete\r\nintoxication, had never revealed anything, however skillfully questions\r\nhad been put to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d thought D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cpoor Athos is perhaps at this moment dead,\r\nand dead by my fault\xe2\x80\x94for it was I who dragged him into this affair, of\r\nwhich he did not know the origin, of which he is ignorant of the\r\nresult, and from which he can derive no advantage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout reckoning, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d added Planchet to his master\xe2\x80\x99s audibly\r\nexpressed reflections, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we perhaps owe our lives to him. Do you\r\nremember how he cried, \xe2\x80\x98On, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, on, I am taken\xe2\x80\x99? And when he\r\nhad discharged his two pistols, what a terrible noise he made with his\r\nsword! One might have said that twenty men, or rather twenty mad\r\ndevils, were fighting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words redoubled the eagerness of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who urged his horse,\r\nthough he stood in need of no incitement, and they proceeded at a rapid\r\npace. About eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning they perceived Amiens, and at\r\nhalf past eleven they were at the door of the cursed inn.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had often meditated against the perfidious host one of those\r\nhearty vengeances which offer consolation while they are hoped for. He\r\nentered the hostelry with his hat pulled over his eyes, his left hand\r\non the pommel of the sword, and cracking his whip with his right hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you remember me?\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the host, who advanced to greet him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not that honor, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter, his eyes\r\ndazzled by the brilliant style in which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan traveled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you don\xe2\x80\x99t know me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, two words will refresh your memory. What have you done with that\r\ngentleman against whom you had the audacity, about twelve days ago, to\r\nmake an accusation of passing false money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe host became as pale as death; for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had assumed a\r\nthreatening attitude, and Planchet modeled himself after his master.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monseigneur, do not mention it!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the host, in the most\r\npitiable voice imaginable. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, monseigneur, how dearly have I paid for\r\nthat fault, unhappy wretch as I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat gentleman, I say, what has become of him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeign to listen to me, monseigneur, and be merciful! Sit down, in\r\nmercy!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, mute with anger and anxiety, took a seat in the threatening\r\nattitude of a judge. Planchet glared fiercely over the back of his\r\narmchair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is the story, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the trembling host; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I\r\nnow recollect you. It was you who rode off at the moment I had that\r\nunfortunate difference with the gentleman you speak of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it was I; so you may plainly perceive that you have no mercy to\r\nexpect if you do not tell me the whole truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCondescend to listen to me, and you shall know all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had been warned by the authorities that a celebrated coiner of bad\r\nmoney would arrive at my inn, with several of his companions, all\r\ndisguised as Guards or Musketeers. Monseigneur, I was furnished with a\r\ndescription of your horses, your lackeys, your countenances\xe2\x80\x94nothing was\r\nomitted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, go on!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who quickly understood whence such an\r\nexact description had come.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI took then, in conformity with the orders of the authorities, who\r\nsent me a reinforcement of six men, such measures as I thought\r\nnecessary to get possession of the persons of the pretended coiners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgain!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose ears chafed terribly under the\r\nrepetition of this word _coiners_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, monseigneur, for saying such things, but they form my\r\nexcuse. The authorities had terrified me, and you know that an\r\ninnkeeper must keep on good terms with the authorities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut once again, that gentleman\xe2\x80\x94where is he? What has become of him? Is\r\nhe dead? Is he living?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPatience, monseigneur, we are coming to it. There happened then that\r\nwhich you know, and of which your precipitate departure,\xe2\x80\x9d added the\r\nhost, with an acuteness that did not escape D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cappeared to\r\nauthorize the issue. That gentleman, your friend, defended himself\r\ndesperately. His lackey, who, by an unforeseen piece of ill luck, had\r\nquarreled with the officers, disguised as stable lads\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiserable scoundrel!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou were all in the plot,\r\nthen! And I really don\xe2\x80\x99t know what prevents me from exterminating you\r\nall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, monseigneur, we were not in the plot, as you will soon see.\r\nMonsieur your friend (pardon for not calling him by the honorable name\r\nwhich no doubt he bears, but we do not know that name), Monsieur your\r\nfriend, having disabled two men with his pistols, retreated fighting\r\nwith his sword, with which he disabled one of my men, and stunned me\r\nwith a blow of the flat side of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou villain, will you finish?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cAthos\xe2\x80\x94what has\r\nbecome of Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile fighting and retreating, as I have told Monseigneur, he found\r\nthe door of the cellar stairs behind him, and as the door was open, he\r\ntook out the key, and barricaded himself inside. As we were sure of\r\nfinding him there, we left him alone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou did not really wish to kill; you only\r\nwished to imprison him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God! To imprison him, monseigneur? Why, he imprisoned himself, I\r\nswear to you he did. In the first place he had made rough work of it;\r\none man was killed on the spot, and two others were severely wounded.\r\nThe dead man and the two wounded were carried off by their comrades,\r\nand I have heard nothing of either of them since. As for myself, as\r\nsoon as I recovered my senses I went to Monsieur the Governor, to whom\r\nI related all that had passed, and asked, what I should do with my\r\nprisoner. Monsieur the Governor was all astonishment. He told me he\r\nknew nothing about the matter, that the orders I had received did not\r\ncome from him, and that if I had the audacity to mention his name as\r\nbeing concerned in this disturbance he would have me hanged. It appears\r\nthat I had made a mistake, monsieur, that I had arrested the wrong\r\nperson, and that he whom I ought to have arrested had escaped.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose impatience was increased by the\r\ndisregard of the authorities, \xe2\x80\x9cAthos, where is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I was anxious to repair the wrongs I had done the prisoner,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nresumed the innkeeper, \xe2\x80\x9cI took my way straight to the cellar in order\r\nto set him at liberty. Ah, monsieur, he was no longer a man, he was a\r\ndevil! To my offer of liberty, he replied that it was nothing but a\r\nsnare, and that before he came out he intended to impose his own\r\nconditions. I told him very humbly\xe2\x80\x94for I could not conceal from myself\r\nthe scrape I had got into by laying hands on one of his Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMusketeers\xe2\x80\x94I told him I was quite ready to submit to his conditions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98In the first place,\xe2\x80\x99 said he, \xe2\x80\x98I wish my lackey placed with me, fully\r\narmed.\xe2\x80\x99 We hastened to obey this order; for you will please to\r\nunderstand, monsieur, we were disposed to do everything your friend\r\ncould desire. Monsieur Grimaud (he told us his name, although he does\r\nnot talk much)\xe2\x80\x94Monsieur Grimaud, then, went down to the cellar, wounded\r\nas he was; then his master, having admitted him, barricaded the door\r\nafresh, and ordered us to remain quietly in our own bar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where is Athos now?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the cellar, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you scoundrel! Have you kept him in the cellar all this time?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerciful heaven! No, monsieur! We keep him in the cellar! You do not\r\nknow what he is about in the cellar. Ah! If you could but persuade him\r\nto come out, monsieur, I should owe you the gratitude of my whole life;\r\nI should adore you as my patron saint!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen he is there? I shall find him there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt you will, monsieur; he persists in remaining there. We\r\nevery day pass through the air hole some bread at the end of a fork,\r\nand some meat when he asks for it; but alas! It is not of bread and\r\nmeat of which he makes the greatest consumption. I once endeavored to\r\ngo down with two of my servants; but he flew into terrible rage. I\r\nheard the noise he made in loading his pistols, and his servant in\r\nloading his musketoon. Then, when we asked them what were their\r\nintentions, the master replied that he had forty charges to fire, and\r\nthat he and his lackey would fire to the last one before he would allow\r\na single soul of us to set foot in the cellar. Upon this I went and\r\ncomplained to the governor, who replied that I only had what I\r\ndeserved, and that it would teach me to insult honorable gentlemen who\r\ntook up their abode in my house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo that since that time\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, totally unable to\r\nrefrain from laughing at the pitiable face of the host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo from that time, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have led the\r\nmost miserable life imaginable; for you must know, monsieur, that all\r\nour provisions are in the cellar. There is our wine in bottles, and our\r\nwine in casks; the beer, the oil, and the spices, the bacon, and\r\nsausages. And as we are prevented from going down there, we are forced\r\nto refuse food and drink to the travelers who come to the house; so\r\nthat our hostelry is daily going to ruin. If your friend remains\r\nanother week in my cellar I shall be a ruined man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd not more than justice, either, you ass! Could you not perceive by\r\nour appearance that we were people of quality, and not coiners\xe2\x80\x94say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, you are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host. \xe2\x80\x9cBut, hark, hark! There\r\nhe is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomebody has disturbed him, without doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he must be disturbed,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the host; \xe2\x80\x9cHere are two English\r\ngentlemen just arrived.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, the English like good wine, as you may know, monsieur; these\r\nhave asked for the best. My wife has perhaps requested permission of\r\nMonsieur Athos to go into the cellar to satisfy these gentlemen; and\r\nhe, as usual, has refused. Ah, good heaven! There is the hullabaloo\r\nlouder than ever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in fact, heard a great noise on the side next the cellar.\r\nHe rose, and preceded by the host wringing his hands, and followed by\r\nPlanchet with his musketoon ready for use, he approached the scene of\r\naction.\r\n\r\nThe two gentlemen were exasperated; they had had a long ride, and were\r\ndying with hunger and thirst.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this is tyranny!\xe2\x80\x9d cried one of them, in very good French, though\r\nwith a foreign accent, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this madman will not allow these good\r\npeople access to their own wine! Nonsense, let us break open the door,\r\nand if he is too far gone in his madness, well, we will kill him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoftly, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, drawing his pistols from his\r\nbelt, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will kill nobody, if you please!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood, good!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the calm voice of Athos, from the other side of the\r\ndoor, \xe2\x80\x9clet them just come in, these devourers of little children, and\r\nwe shall see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBrave as they appeared to be, the two English gentlemen looked at each\r\nother hesitatingly. One might have thought there was in that cellar one\r\nof those famished ogres\xe2\x80\x94the gigantic heroes of popular legends, into\r\nwhose cavern nobody could force their way with impunity.\r\n\r\nThere was a moment of silence; but at length the two Englishmen felt\r\nashamed to draw back, and the angrier one descended the five or six\r\nsteps which led to the cellar, and gave a kick against the door enough\r\nto split a wall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, cocking his pistols, \xe2\x80\x9cI will take charge\r\nof the one at the top; you look to the one below. Ah, gentlemen, you\r\nwant battle; and you shall have it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the hollow voice of Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI can hear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, I\r\nthink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, raising his voice in turn, \xe2\x80\x9cI am here, my\r\nfriend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, good, then,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cwe will teach them, these door\r\nbreakers!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe gentlemen had drawn their swords, but they found themselves taken\r\nbetween two fires. They still hesitated an instant; but, as before,\r\npride prevailed, and a second kick split the door from bottom to top.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStand on one side, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, stand on one side,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\ngoing to fire!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whom reflection never abandoned,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgentlemen, think of what you are about. Patience, Athos! You are\r\nrunning your heads into a very silly affair; you will be riddled. My\r\nlackey and I will have three shots at you, and you will get as many\r\nfrom the cellar. You will then have our swords, with which, I can\r\nassure you, my friend and I can play tolerably well. Let me conduct\r\nyour business and my own. You shall soon have something to drink; I\r\ngive you my word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf there is any left,\xe2\x80\x9d grumbled the jeering voice of Athos.\r\n\r\nThe host felt a cold sweat creep down his back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow! \xe2\x80\x98If there is any left!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d murmured he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil! There must be plenty left,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cBe\r\nsatisfied of that; these two cannot have drunk all the cellar.\r\nGentlemen, return your swords to their scabbards.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, provided you replace your pistols in your belt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWillingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan set the example. Then, turning toward Planchet, he made\r\nhim a sign to uncock his musketoon.\r\n\r\nThe Englishmen, convinced of these peaceful proceedings, sheathed their\r\nswords grumblingly. The history of Athos\xe2\x80\x99s imprisonment was then\r\nrelated to them; and as they were really gentlemen, they pronounced the\r\nhost in the wrong.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cgo up to your room again; and in\r\nten minutes, I will answer for it, you shall have all you desire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Englishmen bowed and went upstairs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I am alone, my dear Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9copen the door, I beg\r\nof you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstantly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\nThen was heard a great noise of fagots being removed and of the\r\ngroaning of posts; these were the counterscarps and bastions of Athos,\r\nwhich the besieged himself demolished.\r\n\r\nAn instant after, the broken door was removed, and the pale face of\r\nAthos appeared, who with a rapid glance took a survey of the\r\nsurroundings.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan threw himself on his neck and embraced him tenderly. He then\r\ntried to draw him from his moist abode, but to his surprise he\r\nperceived that Athos staggered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are wounded,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI! Not at all. I am dead drunk, that\xe2\x80\x99s all, and never did a man more\r\nstrongly set about getting so. By the Lord, my good host! I must at\r\nleast have drunk for my part a hundred and fifty bottles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMercy!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the host, \xe2\x80\x9cif the lackey has drunk only half as much as\r\nthe master, I am a ruined man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud is a well-bred lackey. He would never think of faring in the\r\nsame manner as his master; he only drank from the cask. Hark! I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthink he put the faucet in again. Do you hear it? It is running now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan burst into a laugh which changed the shiver of the host into\r\na burning fever.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime, Grimaud appeared in his turn behind his master, with\r\nthe musketoon on his shoulder, and his head shaking. Like one of those\r\ndrunken satyrs in the pictures of Rubens. He was moistened before and\r\nbehind with a greasy liquid which the host recognized as his best olive\r\noil.\r\n\r\nThe four crossed the public room and proceeded to take possession of\r\nthe best apartment in the house, which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan occupied with\r\nauthority.\r\n\r\nIn the meantime the host and his wife hurried down with lamps into the\r\ncellar, which had so long been interdicted to them and where a\r\nfrightful spectacle awaited them.\r\n\r\nBeyond the fortifications through which Athos had made a breach in\r\norder to get out, and which were composed of fagots, planks, and empty\r\ncasks, heaped up according to all the rules of the strategic art, they\r\nfound, swimming in puddles of oil and wine, the bones and fragments of\r\nall the hams they had eaten; while a heap of broken bottles filled the\r\nwhole left-hand corner of the cellar, and a tun, the cock of which was\r\nleft running, was yielding, by this means, the last drop of its blood.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe image of devastation and death,\xe2\x80\x9d as the ancient poet says,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9creigned as over a field of battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOf fifty large sausages, suspended from the joists, scarcely ten\r\nremained.\r\n\r\nThen the lamentations of the host and hostess pierced the vault of the\r\ncellar. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan himself was moved by them. Athos did not even turn\r\nhis head.\r\n\r\nTo grief succeeded rage. The host armed himself with a spit, and rushed\r\ninto the chamber occupied by the two friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome wine!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, on perceiving the host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome wine!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the stupefied host, \xe2\x80\x9csome wine? Why you have drunk\r\nmore than a hundred pistoles\xe2\x80\x99 worth! I am a ruined man, lost,\r\ndestroyed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cwe were always dry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you had been contented with drinking, well and good; but you have\r\nbroken all the bottles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou pushed me upon a heap which rolled down. That was your fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll my oil is lost!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOil is a sovereign balm for wounds; and my poor Grimaud here was\r\nobliged to dress those you had inflicted on him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll my sausages are gnawed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is an enormous quantity of rats in that cellar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall pay me for all this,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the exasperated host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTriple ass!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, rising; but he sank down again immediately.\r\nHe had tried his strength to the utmost. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan came to his relief\r\nwith his whip in his hand.\r\n\r\nThe host drew back and burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis will teach you,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cto treat the guests God sends\r\nyou in a more courteous fashion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod? Say the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cif you annoy us in this manner we\r\nwill all four go and shut ourselves up in your cellar, and we will see\r\nif the mischief is as great as you say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host, \xe2\x80\x9cI have been wrong. I confess it, but\r\npardon to every sin! You are gentlemen, and I am a poor innkeeper. You\r\nwill have pity on me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, if you speak in that way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will break my heart,\r\nand the tears will flow from my eyes as the wine flowed from the cask.\r\nWe are not such devils as we appear to be. Come hither, and let us\r\ntalk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe host approached with hesitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome hither, I say, and don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cAt the\r\nvery moment when I was about to pay you, I had placed my purse on the\r\ntable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat purse contained sixty pistoles; where is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeposited with the justice; they said it was bad money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; get me my purse back and keep the sixty pistoles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Monseigneur knows very well that justice never lets go that which\r\nit once lays hold of. If it were bad money, there might be some hopes;\r\nbut unfortunately, those were all good pieces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cManage the matter as well as you can, my good man; it does not concern\r\nme, the more so as I have not a livre left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9clet us inquire further. Athos\xe2\x80\x99s horse, where\r\nis that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the stable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much is it worth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty pistoles at most.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s worth eighty. Take it, and there ends the matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, \xe2\x80\x9care you selling my horse\xe2\x80\x94my Bajazet? And pray\r\nupon what shall I make my campaign; upon Grimaud?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have brought you another,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a magnificent one!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, since there is another finer and younger, why, you may take the\r\nold one; and let us drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the host, quite cheerful again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome of that at the bottom, near the laths. There are twenty-five\r\nbottles of it left; all the rest were broken by my fall. Bring six of\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this man is a cask!\xe2\x80\x9d said the host, aside. \xe2\x80\x9cIf he only remains\r\nhere a fortnight, and pays for what he drinks, I shall soon\r\nre-establish my business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd don\xe2\x80\x99t forget,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cto bring up four bottles of the\r\nsame sort for the two English gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile they bring the wine, tell me, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nwhat has become of the others, come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related how he had found Porthos in bed with a strained\r\nknee, and Aramis at a table between two theologians. As he finished,\r\nthe host entered with the wine ordered and a ham which, fortunately for\r\nhim, had been left out of the cellar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, filling his glass and that of his friend;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s to Porthos and Aramis! But you, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, what is the matter\r\nwith you, and what has happened to you personally? You have a sad air.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cit is because I am the most unfortunate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPresently,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPresently! And why presently? Because you think I am drunk?\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, remember this! My ideas are never so clear as when I have\r\nhad plenty of wine. Speak, then, I am all ears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related his adventure with Mme. Bonacieux. Athos listened to\r\nhim without a frown; and when he had finished, said, \xe2\x80\x9cTrifles, only\r\ntrifles!\xe2\x80\x9d That was his favorite word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou always say _trifles_, my dear Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand that\r\ncomes very ill from you, who have never loved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe drink-deadened eye of Athos flashed out, but only for a moment; it\r\nbecame as dull and vacant as before.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, quietly, \xe2\x80\x9cfor my part I have never loved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAcknowledge, then, you stony heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you are\r\nwrong to be so hard upon us tender hearts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTender hearts! Pierced hearts!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say that love is a lottery in which he who wins, wins death! You are\r\nvery fortunate to have lost, believe me, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. And if I\r\nhave any counsel to give, it is, always lose!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe seemed to love me so!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe _seemed_, did she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, she _did_ love me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou child, why, there is not a man who has not believed, as you do,\r\nthat his mistress loved him, and there lives not a man who has not been\r\ndeceived by his mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcept you, Athos, who never had one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, after a moment\xe2\x80\x99s silence, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s true! I\r\nnever had one! Let us drink!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut then, philosopher that you are,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cinstruct me,\r\nsupport me. I stand in need of being taught and consoled.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsoled for what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my misfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour misfortune is laughable,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, shrugging his shoulders; \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshould like to know what you would say if I were to relate to you a\r\nreal tale of love!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich has happened to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr one of my friends, what matters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell it, Athos, tell it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter if I drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink and relate, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a bad idea!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, emptying and refilling his glass. \xe2\x80\x9cThe\r\ntwo things agree marvelously well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all attention,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nAthos collected himself, and in proportion as he did so, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan saw\r\nthat he became pale. He was at that period of intoxication in which\r\nvulgar drinkers fall on the floor and go to sleep. He kept himself\r\nupright and dreamed, without sleeping. This somnambulism of drunkenness\r\nhad something frightful in it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou particularly wish it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI pray for it,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe it then as you desire. One of my friends\xe2\x80\x94one of my friends, please\r\nto observe, not myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, interrupting himself with a\r\nmelancholy smile, \xe2\x80\x9cone of the counts of my province\xe2\x80\x94that is to say, of\r\nBerry\xe2\x80\x94noble as a Dandolo or a Montmorency, at twenty-five years of age\r\nfell in love with a girl of sixteen, beautiful as fancy can paint.\r\nThrough the ingenuousness of her age beamed an ardent mind, not of the\r\nwoman, but of the poet. She did not please; she intoxicated. She lived\r\nin a small town with her brother, who was a curate. Both had recently\r\ncome into the country. They came nobody knew whence; but when seeing\r\nher so lovely and her brother so pious, nobody thought of asking whence\r\nthey came. They were said, however, to be of good extraction. My\r\nfriend, who was seigneur of the country, might have seduced her, or\r\ntaken her by force, at his will\xe2\x80\x94for he was master. Who would have come\r\nto the assistance of two strangers, two unknown persons? Unfortunately\r\nhe was an honorable man; he married her. The fool! The ass! The idiot!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so, if he loved her?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cHe took her to his ch\xc3\xa2teau, and made her the first\r\nlady in the province; and in justice it must be allowed that she\r\nsupported her rank becomingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, one day when she was hunting with her husband,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos,\r\nin a low voice, and speaking very quickly, \xe2\x80\x9cshe fell from her horse and\r\nfainted. The count flew to her to help, and as she appeared to be\r\noppressed by her clothes, he ripped them open with his poniard, and in\r\nso doing laid bare her shoulder. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, with a\r\nmaniacal burst of laughter, \xe2\x80\x9cguess what she had on her shoulder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I tell?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA _fleur-de-lis_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cShe was branded.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos emptied at a single draught the glass he held in his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHorror!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you tell me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruth, my friend. The angel was a demon; the poor young girl had\r\nstolen the sacred vessels from a church.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did the count do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe count was of the highest nobility. He had on his estates the\r\nrights of high and low tribunals. He tore the dress of the countess to\r\npieces; he tied her hands behind her, and hanged her on a tree.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeavens, Athos, a murder?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo less,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, as pale as a corpse. \xe2\x80\x9cBut methinks I need wine!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand he seized by the neck the last bottle that was left, put it to his\r\nmouth, and emptied it at a single draught, as he would have emptied an\r\nordinary glass.\r\n\r\nThen he let his head sink upon his two hands, while D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stood\r\nbefore him, stupefied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat has cured me of beautiful, poetical, and loving women,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos, after a considerable pause, raising his head, and forgetting to\r\ncontinue the fiction of the count. \xe2\x80\x9cGod grant you as much! Let us\r\ndrink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen she is dead?\xe2\x80\x9d stammered D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cBut hold out your glass. Some ham, my boy, or\r\nwe can\xe2\x80\x99t drink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd her brother?\xe2\x80\x9d added D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, timidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer brother?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the priest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I inquired after him for the purpose of hanging him likewise; but\r\nhe was beforehand with me, he had quit the curacy the night before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it ever known who this miserable fellow was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was doubtless the first lover and accomplice of the fair lady. A\r\nworthy man, who had pretended to be a curate for the purpose of getting\r\nhis mistress married, and securing her a position. He has been hanged\r\nand quartered, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, quite stunned by the relation of\r\nthis horrible adventure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTaste some of this ham, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; it is exquisite,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos,\r\ncutting a slice, which he placed on the young man\xe2\x80\x99s plate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pity it is there were only four like this in the cellar. I\r\ncould have drunk fifty bottles more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could no longer endure this conversation, which had made him\r\nbewildered. Allowing his head to sink upon his two hands, he pretended\r\nto sleep.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese young fellows can none of them drink,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, looking at\r\nhim with pity, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet this is one of the best!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXVIII.\r\nTHE RETURN\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was astounded by the terrible confidence of Athos; yet many\r\nthings appeared very obscure to him in this half revelation. In the\r\nfirst place it had been made by a man quite drunk to one who was half\r\ndrunk; and yet, in spite of the incertainty which the vapor of three or\r\nfour bottles of Burgundy carries with it to the brain, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, when\r\nawaking on the following morning, had all the words of Athos as present\r\nto his memory as if they then fell from his mouth\xe2\x80\x94they had been so\r\nimpressed upon his mind. All this doubt only gave rise to a more lively\r\ndesire of arriving at a certainty, and he went into his friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchamber with a fixed determination of renewing the conversation of the\r\npreceding evening; but he found Athos quite himself again\xe2\x80\x94that is to\r\nsay, the most shrewd and impenetrable of men. Besides which, the\r\nMusketeer, after having exchanged a hearty shake of the hand with him,\r\nbroached the matter first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was pretty drunk yesterday, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI can tell that\r\nby my tongue, which was swollen and hot this morning, and by my pulse,\r\nwhich was very tremulous. I wager that I uttered a thousand\r\nextravagances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile saying this he looked at his friend with an earnestness that\r\nembarrassed him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cif I recollect well what you said, it was\r\nnothing out of the common way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you surprise me. I thought I had told you a most lamentable\r\nstory.\xe2\x80\x9d And he looked at the young man as if he would read the bottom\r\nof his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears that I was more drunk than\r\nyou, since I remember nothing of the kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos did not trust this reply, and he resumed; \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot have failed\r\nto remark, my dear friend, that everyone has his particular kind of\r\ndrunkenness, sad or gay. My drunkenness is always sad, and when I am\r\nthoroughly drunk my mania is to relate all the lugubrious stories which\r\nmy foolish nurse inculcated into my brain. That is my failing\xe2\x80\x94a capital\r\nfailing, I admit; but with that exception, I am a good drinker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos spoke this in so natural a manner that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was shaken in\r\nhis conviction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is that, then,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, anxious to find out the\r\ntruth, \xe2\x80\x9cit is that, then, I remember as we remember a dream. We were\r\nspeaking of hanging.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you see how it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, becoming still paler, but yet\r\nattempting to laugh; \xe2\x80\x9cI was sure it was so\xe2\x80\x94the hanging of people is my\r\nnightmare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI remember now; yes, it was about\xe2\x80\x94stop\r\na minute\xe2\x80\x94yes, it was about a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, becoming almost livid; \xe2\x80\x9cthat is my grand\r\nstory of the fair lady, and when I relate that, I must be very drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that was it,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthe story of a tall, fair lady,\r\nwith blue eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, who was hanged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy her husband, who was a nobleman of your acquaintance,\xe2\x80\x9d continued\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, looking intently at Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you see how a man may compromise himself when he does not know\r\nwhat he says,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, shrugging his shoulders as if he thought\r\nhimself an object of pity. \xe2\x80\x9cI certainly never will get drunk again,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; it is too bad a habit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remained silent; and then changing the conversation all at\r\nonce, Athos said:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the by, I thank you for the horse you have brought me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it to your mind?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but it is not a horse for hard work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken; I rode him nearly ten leagues in less than an hour\r\nand a half, and he appeared no more distressed than if he had only made\r\nthe tour of the Place St. Sulpice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you begin to awaken my regret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRegret?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; This morning I awoke at six o\xe2\x80\x99clock. You\r\nwere still fast asleep, and I did not know what to do with myself; I\r\nwas still stupid from our yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s debauch. As I came into the\r\npublic room, I saw one of our Englishman bargaining with a dealer for a\r\nhorse, his own having died yesterday from bleeding. I drew near, and\r\nfound he was bidding a hundred pistoles for a chestnut nag.\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_Pardieu_,\xe2\x80\x99 said I, \xe2\x80\x98my good gentleman, I have a horse to sell, too.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\xe2\x80\x98Ay, and a very fine one! I saw him yesterday; your friend\xe2\x80\x99s lackey was\r\nleading him.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Do you think he is worth a hundred pistoles?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Yes! Will\r\nyou sell him to me for that sum?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98No; but I will play for him.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\xe2\x80\x98What?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98At dice.\xe2\x80\x99 No sooner said than done, and I lost the horse. It was a pledge, a\r\nremembrance. If it is only to be recognized, why the saddle will\r\nsuffice for that; it is quite remarkable enough. As to the horse, we\r\ncan easily find some excuse for its disappearance. Why the devil! A\r\nhorse is mortal; suppose mine had had the glanders or the farcy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt vexes me greatly,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you attach so much\r\nimportance to these animals, for I am not yet at the end of my story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat else have you done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfter having lost my own horse, nine against ten\xe2\x80\x94see how near\xe2\x80\x94I formed\r\nan idea of staking yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but you stopped at the idea, I hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; for I put it in execution that very minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the consequence?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in great anxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI threw, and I lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, my horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour horse, seven against eight; a point short\xe2\x80\x94you know the proverb.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos, you are not in your right senses, I swear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear lad, that was yesterday, when I was telling you silly stories,\r\nit was proper to tell me that, and not this morning. Well, I was not hot-headed then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but what else could you play for? I\r\nstaked Grimaud, the silent Grimaud, divided into ten portions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what next?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, laughing in spite of himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud himself, understand; and with the ten parts of Grimaud, which\r\nare not worth a ducatoon, I regained the diamond. The opportunity was good. He\r\nproposed the conditions\xe2\x80\x94the two harnesses, either against one horse or\r\na hundred pistoles. The Englishman calculated fast; the two harnesses\r\nwere worth three hundred pistoles. He consented.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan threw the dice with a trembling hand, and turned up the\r\nnumber three; his paleness terrified Athos, who, however, consented\r\nhimself with saying, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a sad throw, comrade; you will have the\r\nhorses fully equipped, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Englishman, quite triumphant, did not even give himself the trouble\r\nto shake the dice. I have not seen such a one four times in my\r\nlife. Two aces!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Englishman looked, and was seized with astonishment. We\r\nwant money for our return to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am much attached to that horse, Athos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there again you are wrong. There is a horse, while on\r\nthe contrary, the hundred pistoles feed their master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how shall we get back?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon our lackey\xe2\x80\x99s horses, _pardieu_. With the hundred pistoles we\r\ncan live well to the end of the month. Take the\r\nhundred pistoles, my friend; take the hundred pistoles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan only required one reason to be satisfied. This last reason\r\nappeared convincing. He acquiesced, therefore,\r\nand chose the hundred pistoles, which the Englishman paid down on the\r\nspot.\r\n\r\nThey then determined to depart. Peace with the landlord, in addition to\r\nAthos\xe2\x80\x99s old horse, cost six pistoles. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Athos took the\r\nnags of Planchet and Grimaud, and the two lackeys started on foot,\r\ncarrying the saddles on their heads.\r\n\r\nHowever ill our two friends were mounted, they were soon far in advance\r\nof their servants, and arrived at Cr\xc3\xa8vec\xc5\x93ur. From a distance they\r\nperceived Aramis, seated in a melancholy manner at his window, looking\r\nout, like Sister Anne, at the dust in the horizon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Hol\xc3\xa0_, Aramis! What the devil are you doing there?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the two\r\nfriends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, is that you, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and you, Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwas reflecting upon the rapidity with which the blessings of this world\r\nleave us. My English horse, which has just disappeared amid a cloud of\r\ndust, has furnished me with a living image of the fragility of the\r\nthings of the earth. Life itself may be resolved into three words:\r\n_Erat, est, fuit_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who began to suspect the truth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means that I have just been duped\xe2\x80\x94sixty louis for a horse which\r\nby the manner of his gait can do at least five leagues an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Athos laughed aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t be too angry with me, I beg.\r\nNecessity has no law; besides, I am the person punished, as that\r\nrascally horsedealer has robbed me of fifty louis, at least. Ah, you\r\nfellows are good managers! You ride on our lackey\xe2\x80\x99s horses, and have\r\nyour own gallant steeds led along carefully by hand, at short stages.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the same instant a market cart, which some minutes before had\r\nappeared upon the Amiens road, pulled up at the inn, and Planchet and\r\nGrimaud came out of it with the saddles on their heads. The cart was\r\nreturning empty to Paris, and the two lackeys had agreed, for their\r\ntransport, to slake the wagoner\xe2\x80\x99s thirst along the route.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, on seeing them arrive. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing but\r\nsaddles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow do you understand?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friends, that\xe2\x80\x99s exactly like me! I retained my harness by instinct.\r\n_Hol\xc3\xa0_, Bazin! Bring my new saddle and carry it along with those of\r\nthese gentlemen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what have you done with your ecclesiastics?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, I invited them to a dinner the next day,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nAramis. \xe2\x80\x9cThey have some capital wine here\xe2\x80\x94please to observe that in\r\npassing. I did my best to make them drunk. Then the curate forbade me\r\nto quit my uniform, and the Jesuit entreated me to get him made a\r\nMusketeer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout a thesis?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwithout a thesis? I demand the\r\nsuppression of the thesis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSince then,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI have lived very agreeably. I have\r\nbegun a poem in verses of one syllable. That is rather difficult, but\r\nthe merit in all things consists in the difficulty. The matter is\r\ngallant. I will read you the first canto. It has four hundred lines,\r\nand lasts a minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, my dear Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who detested verses almost\r\nas much as he did Latin, \xe2\x80\x9cadd to the merit of the difficulty that of\r\nthe brevity, and you are sure that your poem will at least have two\r\nmerits.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will see,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cthat it breathes irreproachable\r\npassion. And so, my friends, we return to Paris? Bravo! I am ready. We\r\nare going to rejoin that good fellow, Porthos. So much the better. You\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t think how I have missed him, the great simpleton. To see him so\r\nself-satisfied reconciles me with myself. He would not sell his horse;\r\nnot for a kingdom! I think I can see him now, mounted upon his superb\r\nanimal and seated in his handsome saddle. I am sure he will look like\r\nthe Great Mogul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey made a halt for an hour to refresh their horses. Aramis discharged\r\nhis bill, placed Bazin in the cart with his comrades, and they set\r\nforward to join Porthos.\r\n\r\nThey found him up, less pale than when D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan left him after his\r\nfirst visit, and seated at a table on which, though he was alone, was\r\nspread enough for four persons. This dinner consisted of meats nicely\r\ndressed, choice wines, and superb fruit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said he, rising, \xe2\x80\x9cyou come in the nick of time,\r\ngentlemen. I was just beginning the soup, and you will dine with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cMousqueton has not caught these bottles\r\nwith his lasso. Besides, here is a piquant _fricandeau_ and a fillet of\r\nbeef.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am recruiting myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cI am recruiting myself.\r\nNothing weakens a man more than these devilish strains. Did you ever\r\nsuffer from a strain, Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever! Though I remember, in our affair of the Rue F\xc3\xa9rou, I received a\r\nsword wound which at the end of fifteen or eighteen days produced the\r\nsame effect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this dinner was not intended for you alone, Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cI expected some gentlemen of the neighborhood, who\r\nhave just sent me word they could not come. You will take their places\r\nand I shall not lose by the exchange. _Hol\xc3\xa0_, Mousqueton, seats, and\r\norder double the bottles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know what we are eating here?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, at the end of ten\r\nminutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cfor my part, I am eating veal\r\ngarnished with shrimps and vegetables.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I some lamb chops,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I a plain chicken,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are all mistaken, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Athos, gravely; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are\r\neating horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEating what?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHorse!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, with a grimace of disgust.\r\n\r\nPorthos alone made no reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, horse. Are we not eating a horse, Porthos? And perhaps his\r\nsaddle, therewith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, gentlemen, I have kept the harness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are all alike. One would think we had\r\ntipped the wink.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat could I do?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cThis horse made my visitors ashamed\r\nof theirs, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to humiliate people.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen your duchess is still at the waters?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd, my faith, the governor of the\r\nprovince\xe2\x80\x94one of the gentlemen I expected today\xe2\x80\x94seemed to have such a\r\nwish for him, that I gave him to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGave him?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, yes, _gave_, that is the word,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cfor the animal\r\nwas worth at least a hundred and fifty louis, and the stingy fellow\r\nwould only give me eighty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout the saddle?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, without the saddle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will observe, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat Porthos has made the\r\nbest bargain of any of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then commenced a roar of laughter in which they all joined, to the\r\nastonishment of poor Porthos; but when he was informed of the cause of\r\ntheir hilarity, he shared it vociferously according to his custom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is one comfort, we are all in cash,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, for my part,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI found Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s Spanish wine so good\r\nthat I sent on a hamper of sixty bottles of it in the wagon with the\r\nlackeys. That has weakened my purse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cimagined that I had given almost my last sou to\r\nthe church of Montdidier and the Jesuits of Amiens, with whom I had\r\nmade engagements which I ought to have kept. I have ordered Masses for\r\nmyself, and for you, gentlemen, which will be said, gentlemen, for\r\nwhich I have not the least doubt you will be marvelously benefited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you think my strain cost me nothing?\xe2\x80\x94without\r\nreckoning Mousqueton\xe2\x80\x99s wound, for which I had to have the surgeon twice\r\na day, and who charged me double on account of that foolish Mousqueton\r\nhaving allowed himself a ball in a part which people generally only\r\nshow to an apothecary; so I advised him to try never to get wounded\r\nthere any more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, exchanging a smile with D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Aramis,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cit is very clear you acted nobly with regard to the poor lad; that is\r\nlike a good master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn short,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen all my expenses are paid, I shall have,\r\nat most, thirty crowns left.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I about ten pistoles,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then it appears that we are the Cr\xc5\x93suses of the society. How\r\nmuch have you left of your hundred pistoles, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf my hundred pistoles? Why, in the first place I gave you fifty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that is true. I recollect.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I paid the host six.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a brute of a host! Why did you give him six pistoles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou told me to give them to him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is true; I am too good-natured. In brief, how much remains?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-five pistoles,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, taking some small change from his pocket, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou? Nothing!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith! So little that it is not worth reckoning with the general\r\nstock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then, let us calculate how much we posses in all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPorthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirty crowns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTen pistoles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty-five.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat makes in all?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour hundred and seventy-five livres,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who reckoned\r\nlike Archimedes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn our arrival in Paris, we shall still have four hundred, besides the\r\nharnesses,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut our troop horses?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, of the four horses of our lackeys we will make two for the\r\nmasters, for which we will draw lots. With the four hundred livres we\r\nwill make the half of one for one of the unmounted, and then we will\r\ngive the turnings out of our pockets to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who has a steady\r\nhand, and will go and play in the first gaming house we come to.\r\nThere!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us dine, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cit is getting cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe friends, at ease with regard to the future, did honor to the\r\nrepast, the remains of which were abandoned to Mousqueton, Bazin,\r\nPlanchet, and Grimaud.\r\n\r\nOn arriving in Paris, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan found a letter from M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\r\nwhich informed him that, at his request, the king had promised that he\r\nshould enter the company of the Musketeers.\r\n\r\nAs this was the height of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s worldly ambition\xe2\x80\x94apart, be it\r\nwell understood, from his desire of finding Mme. Bonacieux\xe2\x80\x94he ran, full\r\nof joy, to seek his comrades, whom he had left only half an hour\r\nbefore, but whom he found very sad and deeply preoccupied. They were\r\nassembled in council at the residence of Athos, which always indicated\r\nan event of some gravity. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville had intimated to them his\r\nMajesty\xe2\x80\x99s fixed intention to open the campaign on the first of May, and\r\nthey must immediately prepare their outfits.\r\n\r\nThe four philosophers looked at one another in a state of bewilderment.\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville never jested in matters relating to discipline.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you reckon your outfit will cost?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, we can scarcely say. We have made our calculations with Spartan\r\neconomy, and we each require fifteen hundred livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour times fifteen makes sixty\xe2\x80\x94six thousand livres,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwith a thousand livres each\xe2\x80\x94I do\r\nnot speak as a Spartan, but as a procurator\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis word _procurator_ roused Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cStop,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI have an\r\nidea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, that\xe2\x80\x99s something, for I have not the shadow of one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos\r\ncoolly; \xe2\x80\x9cbut as to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, gentlemen, the idea of belonging to\r\n_ours_ has driven him out of his senses. A thousand livres! For my\r\npart, I declare I want two thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFour times two makes eight,\xe2\x80\x9d then said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cit is eight thousand\r\nthat we want to complete our outfits, toward which, it is true, we have\r\nalready the saddles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, waiting till D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who went to thank\r\nMonsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, had shut the door, \xe2\x80\x9cbesides, there is that\r\nbeautiful ring which beams from the finger of our friend. What the\r\ndevil! D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is too good a comrade to leave his brothers in\r\nembarrassment while he wears the ransom of a king on his finger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXIX.\r\nHUNTING FOR THE EQUIPMENTS\r\n\r\n\r\nThe most preoccupied of the four friends was certainly D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nalthough he, in his quality of Guardsman, would be much more easily\r\nequipped than Messieurs the Musketeers, who were all of high rank; but\r\nour Gascon cadet was, as may have been observed, of a provident and\r\nalmost avaricious character, and with that (explain the contradiction)\r\nso vain as almost to rival Porthos. To this preoccupation of his\r\nvanity, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at this moment joined an uneasiness much less\r\nselfish. Notwithstanding all his inquiries respecting Mme. Bonacieux,\r\nhe could obtain no intelligence of her. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville had spoken of\r\nher to the queen. The queen was ignorant where the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s young wife\r\nwas, but had promised to have her sought for; but this promise was very\r\nvague and did not at all reassure D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nAthos did not leave his chamber; he made up his mind not to take a\r\nsingle step to equip himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have still fifteen days before us,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to his friends, \xe2\x80\x9cwell,\r\nif at the end of a fortnight I have found nothing, or rather if nothing\r\nhas come to find me, as I, too good a Catholic to kill myself with a\r\npistol bullet, I will seek a good quarrel with four of his Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGuards or with eight Englishmen, and I will fight until one of them has\r\nkilled me, which, considering the number, cannot fail to happen. It\r\nwill then be said of me that I died for the king; so that I shall have\r\nperformed my duty without the expense of an outfit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos continued to walk about with his hands behind him, tossing his\r\nhead and repeating, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall follow up on my idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis, anxious and negligently dressed, said nothing.\r\n\r\nIt may be seen by these disastrous details that desolation reigned in\r\nthe community.\r\n\r\nThe lackeys on their part, like the coursers of Hippolytus, shared the\r\nsadness of their masters. Mousqueton collected a store of crusts;\r\nBazin, who had always been inclined to devotion, never quit the\r\nchurches; Planchet watched the flight of flies; and Grimaud, whom the\r\ngeneral distress could not induce to break the silence imposed by his\r\nmaster, heaved sighs enough to soften the stones.\r\n\r\nThe three friends\xe2\x80\x94for, as we have said, Athos had sworn not to stir a\r\nfoot to equip himself\xe2\x80\x94went out early in the morning, and returned late\r\nat night. They wandered about the streets, looking at the pavement as\r\nif to see whether the passengers had not left a purse behind them. They\r\nmight have been supposed to be following tracks, so observant were they\r\nwherever they went. When they met they looked desolately at one\r\nanother, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x9cHave you found anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHowever, as Porthos had first found an idea, and had thought of it\r\nearnestly afterward, he was the first to act. He was a man of\r\nexecution, this worthy Porthos. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan perceived him one day\r\nwalking toward the church of St. Leu, and followed him instinctively.\r\nHe entered, after having twisted his mustache and elongated his\r\nimperial, which always announced on his part the most triumphant\r\nresolutions. As D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took some precautions to conceal himself,\r\nPorthos believed he had not been seen. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan entered behind him.\r\nPorthos went and leaned against the side of a pillar. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, still\r\nunperceived, supported himself against the other side.\r\n\r\nThere happened to be a sermon, which made the church very full of\r\npeople. Porthos took advantage of this circumstance to ogle the women.\r\nThanks to the cares of Mousqueton, the exterior was far from announcing\r\nthe distress of the interior. His hat was a little napless, his feather\r\nwas a little faded, his gold lace was a little tarnished, his laces\r\nwere a trifle frayed; but in the obscurity of the church these things\r\nwere not seen, and Porthos was still the handsome Porthos.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan observed, on the bench nearest to the pillar against which\r\nPorthos leaned, a sort of ripe beauty, rather yellow and rather dry,\r\nbut erect and haughty under her black hood. The eyes of Porthos were\r\nfurtively cast upon this lady, and then roved about at large over the\r\nnave.\r\n\r\nOn her side the lady, who from time to time blushed, darted with the\r\nrapidity of lightning a glance toward the inconstant Porthos; and then\r\nimmediately the eyes of Porthos wandered anxiously. It was plain that\r\nthis mode of proceeding piqued the lady in the black hood, for she bit\r\nher lips till they bled, scratched the end of her nose, and could not\r\nsit still in her seat.\r\n\r\nPorthos, seeing this, retwisted his mustache, elongated his imperial a\r\nsecond time, and began to make signals to a beautiful lady who was near\r\nthe choir, and who not only was a beautiful lady, but still further, no\r\ndoubt, a great lady\xe2\x80\x94for she had behind her a Negro boy who had brought\r\nthe cushion on which she knelt, and a female servant who held the\r\nemblazoned bag in which was placed the book from which she read the\r\nMass.\r\n\r\nThe lady with the black hood followed through all their wanderings the\r\nlooks of Porthos, and perceived that they rested upon the lady with the\r\nvelvet cushion, the little Negro, and the maid-servant.\r\n\r\nDuring this time Porthos played close. It was almost imperceptible\r\nmotions of his eyes, fingers placed upon the lips, little assassinating\r\nsmiles, which really did assassinate the disdained beauty.\r\n\r\nThen she cried, \xe2\x80\x9cAhem!\xe2\x80\x9d under cover of the _mea culpa_, striking her\r\nbreast so vigorously that everybody, even the lady with the red\r\ncushion, turned round toward her. Porthos paid no attention.\r\nNevertheless, he understood it all, but was deaf.\r\n\r\nThe lady with the red cushion produced a great effect\xe2\x80\x94for she was very\r\nhandsome\xe2\x80\x94upon the lady with the black hood, who saw in her a rival\r\nreally to be dreaded; a great effect upon Porthos, who thought her much\r\nprettier than the lady with the black hood; a great effect upon\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who recognized in her the lady of Meung, of Calais, and of\r\nDover, whom his persecutor, the man with the scar, had saluted by the\r\nname of Milady.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, without losing sight of the lady of the red cushion,\r\ncontinued to watch the proceedings of Porthos, which amused him\r\ngreatly. He guessed that the lady of the black hood was the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife of the Rue aux Ours, which was the more probable from\r\nthe church of St. Leu being not far from that locality.\r\n\r\nHe guessed, likewise, by induction, that Porthos was taking his revenge\r\nfor the defeat of Chantilly, when the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife had proved so\r\nrefractory with respect to her purse.\r\n\r\nAmid all this, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remarked also that not one countenance\r\nresponded to the gallantries of Porthos. There were only chimeras and\r\nillusions; but for real love, for true jealousy, is there any reality\r\nexcept illusions and chimeras?\r\n\r\nThe sermon over, the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife advanced toward the holy font.\r\nPorthos went before her, and instead of a finger, dipped his whole hand\r\nin. The procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife smiled, thinking that it was for her Porthos\r\nhad put himself to this trouble; but she was cruelly and promptly\r\nundeceived. When she was only about three steps from him, he turned his\r\nhead round, fixing his eyes steadfastly upon the lady with the red\r\ncushion, who had risen and was approaching, followed by her black boy\r\nand her woman.\r\n\r\nWhen the lady of the red cushion came close to Porthos, Porthos drew\r\nhis dripping hand from the font. The fair worshipper touched the great\r\nhand of Porthos with her delicate fingers, smiled, made the sign of the\r\ncross, and left the church.\r\n\r\nThis was too much for the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife; she doubted not there was\r\nan intrigue between this lady and Porthos. If she had been a great lady\r\nshe would have fainted; but as she was only a procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, she\r\ncontented herself saying to the Musketeer with concentrated fury, \xe2\x80\x9cEh,\r\nMonsieur Porthos, you don\xe2\x80\x99t offer me any holy water?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos, at the sound of that voice, started like a man awakened from a\r\nsleep of a hundred years.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMa-madame!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; \xe2\x80\x9cis that you? How is your husband, our dear\r\nMonsieur Coquenard? Is he still as stingy as ever? Where can my eyes\r\nhave been not to have seen you during the two hours of the sermon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was within two paces of you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife; \xe2\x80\x9cbut you did not perceive me because you had no eyes but for the\r\npretty lady to whom you just now gave the holy water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos pretended to be confused. \xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have remarked\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must have been blind not to have seen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is a duchess of my acquaintance whom I have\r\ngreat trouble to meet on account of the jealousy of her husband, and\r\nwho sent me word that she should come today to this poor church, buried\r\nin this vile quarter, solely for the sake of seeing me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you have the\r\nkindness to offer me your arm for five minutes? I have something to say\r\nto you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, winking to himself, as a gambler\r\ndoes who laughs at the dupe he is about to pluck.\r\n\r\nAt that moment D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan passed in pursuit of Milady; he cast a\r\npassing glance at Porthos, and beheld this triumphant look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, reasoning to himself according to the strangely easy\r\nmorality of that gallant period, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is one who will be equipped in\r\ngood time!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos, yielding to the pressure of the arm of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife,\r\nas a bark yields to the rudder, arrived at the cloister St. Magloire\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nlittle-frequented passage, enclosed with a turnstile at each end. In\r\nthe daytime nobody was seen there but mendicants devouring their\r\ncrusts, and children at play.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Monsieur Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, when she was\r\nassured that no one who was a stranger to the population of the\r\nlocality could either see or hear her, \xe2\x80\x9cah, Monsieur Porthos, you are a\r\ngreat conqueror, as it appears!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, drawing himself up proudly; \xe2\x80\x9chow so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe signs just now, and the holy water! But that must be a princess,\r\nat least\xe2\x80\x94that lady with her Negro boy and her maid!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God! Madame, you are deceived,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cshe is simply a\r\nduchess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that running footman who waited at the door, and that carriage\r\nwith a coachman in grand livery who sat waiting on his seat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos had seen neither the footman nor the carriage, but with the eye\r\nof a jealous woman, Mme. Coquenard had seen everything.\r\n\r\nPorthos regretted that he had not at once made the lady of the red\r\ncushion a princess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you are quite the pet of the ladies, Monsieur Porthos!\xe2\x80\x9d resumed\r\nthe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, with a sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may imagine, with the physique with\r\nwhich nature has endowed me, I am not in want of good luck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord, how quickly men forget!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife,\r\nraising her eyes toward heaven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLess quickly than the women, it seems to me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I,\r\nmadame, I may say I was your victim, when wounded, dying, I was\r\nabandoned by the surgeons. I, the offspring of a noble family, who\r\nplaced reliance upon your friendship\xe2\x80\x94I was near dying of my wounds at\r\nfirst, and of hunger afterward, in a beggarly inn at Chantilly, without\r\nyou ever deigning once to reply to the burning letters I addressed to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Monsieur Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, who began to\r\nfeel that, to judge by the conduct of the great ladies of the time, she\r\nwas wrong.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, who had sacrificed for you the Baronne de\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Comtesse de\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos, be generous!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, madame, and I will not finish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was my husband who would not hear of lending.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Coquenard,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cremember the first letter you wrote\r\nme, and which I preserve engraved in my memory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife uttered a groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthe sum you required me to borrow was rather\r\nlarge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Coquenard, I gave you the preference. I had but to write to the\r\nDuchesse\xe2\x80\x94but I won\xe2\x80\x99t repeat her name, for I am incapable of\r\ncompromising a woman; but this I know, that I had but to write to her\r\nand she would have sent me fifteen hundred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife shed a tear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI can assure you that you have severely\r\npunished me; and if in the time to come you should find yourself in a\r\nsimilar situation, you have but to apply to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFie, madame, fie!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, as if disgusted. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us not talk\r\nabout money, if you please; it is humiliating.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you no longer love me!\xe2\x80\x9d said the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, slowly and\r\nsadly.\r\n\r\nPorthos maintained a majestic silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is the only reply you make? Alas, I understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink of the offense you have committed toward me, madame! It remains\r\n_here!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, placing his hand on his heart, and pressing it\r\nstrongly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will repair it, indeed I will, my dear Porthos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, what did I ask of you?\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Porthos, with a movement of\r\nthe shoulders full of good fellowship. \xe2\x80\x9cA loan, nothing more! After\r\nall, I am not an unreasonable man. I know you are not rich, Madame\r\nCoquenard, and that your husband is obliged to bleed his poor clients\r\nto squeeze a few paltry crowns from them. Oh! If you were a duchess, a\r\nmarchioness, or a countess, it would be quite a different thing; it\r\nwould be unpardonable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife was piqued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlease to know, Monsieur Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my strongbox, the\r\nstrongbox of a procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife though it may be, is better filled\r\nthan those of your affected minxes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat doubles the offense,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, disengaging his arm from that\r\nof the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife; \xe2\x80\x9cfor if you are rich, Madame Coquenard, then\r\nthere is no excuse for your refusal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen I said rich,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, who saw that she had\r\ngone too far, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must not take the word literally. I am not precisely\r\nrich, though I am pretty well off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9clet us say no more upon the subject, I\r\nbeg of you. You have misunderstood me, all sympathy is extinct between\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIngrate that you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! I advise you to complain!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBegone, then, to your beautiful duchess; I will detain you no longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she is not to be despised, in my opinion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Monsieur Porthos, once more, and this is the last! Do you love me\r\nstill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, in the most melancholy tone he could\r\nassume, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen we are about to enter upon a campaign\xe2\x80\x94a campaign, in\r\nwhich my presentiments tell me I shall be killed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t talk of such things!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, bursting\r\ninto tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething whispers me so,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Porthos, becoming more and more\r\nmelancholy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather say that you have a new love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so; I speak frankly to you. No object affects me; and I even feel\r\nhere, at the bottom of my heart, something which speaks for you. But in\r\nfifteen days, as you know, or as you do not know, this fatal campaign\r\nis to open. I shall be fearfully preoccupied with my outfit. Then I\r\nmust make a journey to see my family, in the lower part of Brittany, to\r\nobtain the sum necessary for my departure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos observed a last struggle between love and avarice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe duchess whom you saw at the church has\r\nestates near to those of my family, we mean to make the journey\r\ntogether. Journeys, you know, appear much shorter when we travel two in\r\ncompany.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you no friends in Paris, then, Monsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I had,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, resuming his melancholy air; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\r\nhave been taught my mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have some!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, in a transport that\r\nsurprised even herself. \xe2\x80\x9cCome to our house tomorrow. You are the son of\r\nmy aunt, consequently my cousin; you come from Noyon, in Picardy; you\r\nhave several lawsuits and no attorney. Can you recollect all that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome at dinnertime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd be upon your guard before my husband, who is rather shrewd,\r\nnotwithstanding his seventy-six years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeventy-six years! _Peste!_ That\xe2\x80\x99s a fine age!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great age, you mean, Monsieur Porthos.
