Yes, the poor man may be\r\nexpected to leave me a widow, any hour,\xe2\x80\x9d continued she, throwing a\r\nsignificant glance at Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cFortunately, by our marriage contract,\r\nthe survivor takes everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a woman of precaution, I see, my dear Madame Coquenard,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nPorthos, squeezing the hand of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are then reconciled, dear Monsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, simpering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor life,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos, in the same manner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill we meet again, then, dear traitor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTill we meet again, my forgetful charmer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, my angel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow, flame of my life!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXX.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99ARTAGNAN AND THE ENGLISHMAN\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan followed Milady without being perceived by her. He saw her\r\nget into her carriage, and heard her order the coachman to drive to St.\r\nGermain.\r\n\r\nIt was useless to try to keep pace on foot with a carriage drawn by two\r\npowerful horses. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan therefore returned to the Rue F\xc3\xa9rou.\r\n\r\nIn the Rue de Seine he met Planchet, who had stopped before the house\r\nof a pastry cook, and was contemplating with ecstasy a cake of the most\r\nappetizing appearance.\r\n\r\nHe ordered him to go and saddle two horses in M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nstables\xe2\x80\x94one for himself, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and one for Planchet\xe2\x80\x94and bring\r\nthem to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s place. Once for all, Tr\xc3\xa9ville had placed his stable at\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s service.\r\n\r\nPlanchet proceeded toward the Rue du Colombier, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan toward\r\nthe Rue F\xc3\xa9rou. Athos was at home, emptying sadly a bottle of the famous\r\nSpanish wine he had brought back with him from his journey into\r\nPicardy. He made a sign for Grimaud to bring a glass for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nand Grimaud obeyed as usual.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan related to Athos all that had passed at the church between\r\nPorthos and the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, and how their comrade was probably\r\nby that time in a fair way to be equipped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs for me,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos to this recital, \xe2\x80\x9cI am quite at my ease; it\r\nwill not be women that will defray the expense of my outfit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHandsome, well-bred, noble lord as you are, my dear Athos, neither\r\nprincesses nor queens would be secure from your amorous solicitations.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow young this D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, shrugging his shoulders;\r\nand he made a sign to Grimaud to bring another bottle.\r\n\r\nAt that moment Planchet put his head modestly in at the half-open door,\r\nand told his master that the horses were ready.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat horses?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo horses that Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville lends me at my pleasure, and with\r\nwhich I am now going to take a ride to St. Germain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and what are you going to do at St. Germain?\xe2\x80\x9d then demanded\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan described the meeting which he had at the church, and\r\nhow he had found that lady who, with the seigneur in the black cloak\r\nand with the scar near his temple, filled his mind constantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, you are in love with this lady as you were with Madame\r\nBonacieux,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, shrugging his shoulders contemptuously, as if\r\nhe pitied human weakness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? not at all!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI am only curious to unravel the\r\nmystery to which she is attached. I do not know why, but I imagine that\r\nthis woman, wholly unknown to me as she is, and wholly unknown to her\r\nas I am, has an influence over my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps you are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not know a woman that\r\nis worth the trouble of being sought for when she is once lost. Madame\r\nBonacieux is lost; so much the worse for her if she is found.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Athos, no, you are mistaken,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI love my poor\r\nConstance more than ever, and if I knew the place in which she is, were\r\nit at the end of the world, I would go to free her from the hands of\r\nher enemies; but I am ignorant. All my researches have been useless.\r\nWhat is to be said? I must divert my attention!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmuse yourself with Milady, my dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; I wish you may with\r\nall my heart, if that will amuse you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear me, Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cInstead of shutting yourself up\r\nhere as if you were under arrest, get on horseback and come and take a\r\nride with me to St. Germain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI ride horses when I have any; when I\r\nhave none, I go afoot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, smiling at the misanthropy of Athos, which\r\nfrom any other person would have offended him, \xe2\x80\x9cI ride what I can get;\r\nI am not so proud as you. So _au revoir_, dear Athos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Au revoir_,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeer, making a sign to Grimaud to uncork\r\nthe bottle he had just brought.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Planchet mounted, and took the road to St. Germain.\r\n\r\nAll along the road, what Athos had said respecting Mme. Bonacieux\r\nrecurred to the mind of the young man. Although D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was not of a\r\nvery sentimental character, the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s pretty wife had made a real\r\nimpression upon his heart. As he said, he was ready to go to the end of\r\nthe world to seek her; but the world, being round, has many ends, so\r\nthat he did not know which way to turn. Meantime, he was going to try\r\nto find out Milady. Milady had spoken to the man in the black cloak;\r\ntherefore she knew him. Now, in the opinion of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, it was\r\ncertainly the man in the black cloak who had carried off Mme. Bonacieux\r\nthe second time, as he had carried her off the first. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan then\r\nonly half-lied, which is lying but little, when he said that by going\r\nin search of Milady he at the same time went in search of Constance.\r\n\r\nThinking of all this, and from time to time giving a touch of the spur\r\nto his horse, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan completed his short journey, and arrived at\r\nSt. Germain. He had just passed by the pavilion in which ten years\r\nlater Louis XIV. was born. He rode up a very quiet street, looking to\r\nthe right and the left to see if he could catch any vestige of his\r\nbeautiful Englishwoman, when from the ground floor of a pretty house,\r\nwhich, according to the fashion of the time, had no window toward the\r\nstreet, he saw a face peep out with which he thought he was acquainted.\r\nThis person walked along the terrace, which was ornamented with\r\nflowers. Planchet recognized him first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, addressing D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you remember\r\nthat face which is blinking yonder?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet I am certain it is not the first time I\r\nhave seen that visage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu_, I believe it is not,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, it is poor\r\nLubin, the lackey of the Comte de Wardes\xe2\x80\x94he whom you took such good\r\ncare of a month ago at Calais, on the road to the governor\xe2\x80\x99s country\r\nhouse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo it is!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI know him now. Do you think he would\r\nrecollect you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, monsieur, he was in such trouble that I doubt if he can have\r\nretained a very clear recollection of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go and talk with the boy,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand make out if you\r\ncan from his conversation whether his master is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPlanchet dismounted and went straight up to Lubin, who did not at all\r\nremember him, and the two lackeys began to chat with the best\r\nunderstanding possible; while D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan turned the two horses into a\r\nlane, went round the house, and came back to watch the conference from\r\nbehind a hedge of filberts.\r\n\r\nAt the end of an instant\xe2\x80\x99s observation he heard the noise of a vehicle,\r\nand saw Milady\xe2\x80\x99s carriage stop opposite to him. He could not be\r\nmistaken; Milady was in it. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan leaned upon the neck of his\r\nhorse, in order that he might see without being seen.\r\n\r\nMilady put her charming blond head out at the window, and gave her\r\norders to her maid.\r\n\r\nThe latter\xe2\x80\x94a pretty girl of about twenty or twenty-two years, active\r\nand lively, the true _soubrette_ of a great lady\xe2\x80\x94jumped from the step\r\nupon which, according to the custom of the time, she was seated, and\r\ntook her way toward the terrace upon which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had perceived\r\nLubin.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan followed the _soubrette_ with his eyes, and saw her go\r\ntoward the terrace; but it happened that someone in the house called\r\nLubin, so that Planchet remained alone, looking in all directions for\r\nthe road where D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had disappeared.\r\n\r\nThe maid approached Planchet, whom she took for Lubin, and holding out\r\na little billet to him said, \xe2\x80\x9cFor your master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my master?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Planchet, astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and important. Take it quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThereupon she ran toward the carriage, which had turned round toward\r\nthe way it came, jumped upon the step, and the carriage drove off.\r\n\r\nPlanchet turned and returned the billet. Then, accustomed to passive\r\nobedience, he jumped down from the terrace, ran toward the lane, and at\r\nthe end of twenty paces met D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, having seen all, was\r\ncoming to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor you, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, presenting the billet to the young\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor me?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9care you sure of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu_, monsieur, I can\xe2\x80\x99t be more sure. The _soubrette_ said, \xe2\x80\x98For\r\nyour master.\xe2\x80\x99 I have no other master but you; so\xe2\x80\x94a pretty little lass,\r\nmy faith, is that _soubrette!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan opened the letter, and read these words:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA person who takes more interest in you than she is willing to confess\r\nwishes to know on what day it will suit you to walk in the forest?\r\nTomorrow, at the H\xc3\xb4tel Field of the Cloth of Gold, a lackey in black\r\nand red will wait for your reply.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is rather warm; it appears that Milady and\r\nI are anxious about the health of the same person. Well, Planchet, how\r\nis the good Monsieur de Wardes? He is not dead, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, monsieur, he is as well as a man can be with four sword wounds in\r\nhis body; for you, without question, inflicted four upon the dear\r\ngentleman, and he is still very weak, having lost almost all his blood.\r\nAs I said, monsieur, Lubin did not know me, and told me our adventure\r\nfrom one end to the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell done, Planchet! you are the king of lackeys. Now jump onto your\r\nhorse, and let us overtake the carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis did not take long. At the end of five minutes they perceived the\r\ncarriage drawn up by the roadside; a cavalier, richly dressed, was\r\nclose to the door.\r\n\r\nThe conversation between Milady and the cavalier was so animated that\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stopped on the other side of the carriage without anyone but\r\nthe pretty _soubrette_ perceiving his presence.\r\n\r\nThe conversation took place in English\xe2\x80\x94a language which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\ncould not understand; but by the accent the young man plainly saw that\r\nthe beautiful Englishwoman was in a great rage. She terminated it by an\r\naction which left no doubt as to the nature of this conversation; this\r\nwas a blow with her fan, applied with such force that the little\r\nfeminine weapon flew into a thousand pieces.\r\n\r\nThe cavalier laughed aloud, which appeared to exasperate Milady still\r\nmore.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan thought this was the moment to interfere. He approached the\r\nother door, and taking off his hat respectfully, said, \xe2\x80\x9cMadame, will\r\nyou permit me to offer you my services? It appears to me that this\r\ncavalier has made you very angry. Speak one word, madame, and I take\r\nupon myself to punish him for his want of courtesy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the first word Milady turned, looking at the young man with\r\nastonishment; and when he had finished, she said in very good French,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I should with great confidence place myself under your\r\nprotection if the person with whom I quarrel were not my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, excuse me, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cYou must be aware that I was\r\nignorant of that, madame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that stupid fellow troubling himself about?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the\r\ncavalier whom Milady had designated as her brother, stooping down to\r\nthe height of the coach window. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy does not he go about his\r\nbusiness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStupid fellow yourself!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, stooping in his turn on the\r\nneck of his horse, and answering on his side through the carriage\r\nwindow. \xe2\x80\x9cI do not go on because it pleases me to stop here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cavalier addressed some words in English to his sister.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI speak to you in French,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbe kind enough, then, to\r\nreply to me in the same language. You are Madame\xe2\x80\x99s brother, I learn\xe2\x80\x94be\r\nit so; but fortunately you are not mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt might be thought that Milady, timid as women are in general, would\r\nhave interposed in this commencement of mutual provocations in order to\r\nprevent the quarrel from going too far; but on the contrary, she threw\r\nherself back in her carriage, and called out coolly to the coachman,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on\xe2\x80\x94home!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe pretty _soubrette_ cast an anxious glance at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose good\r\nlooks seemed to have made an impression on her.\r\n\r\nThe carriage went on, and left the two men facing each other; no\r\nmaterial obstacle separated them.\r\n\r\nThe cavalier made a movement as if to follow the carriage; but\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose anger, already excited, was much increased by\r\nrecognizing in him the Englishman of Amiens who had won his horse and\r\nhad been very near winning his diamond of Athos, caught at his bridle\r\nand stopped him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou appear to be more stupid than I am, for\r\nyou forget there is a little quarrel to arrange between us two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, \xe2\x80\x9cis it you, my master? It seems you must\r\nalways be playing some game or other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and that reminds me that I have a revenge to take. We will see,\r\nmy dear monsieur, if you can handle a sword as skillfully as you can a\r\ndice box.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see plainly that I have no sword,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nwish to play the braggart with an unarmed man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope you have a sword at home; but at all events, I have two, and if\r\nyou like, I will throw with you for one of them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeedless,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman; \xe2\x80\x9cI am well furnished with such\r\nplaythings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well, my worthy gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cpick out the\r\nlongest, and come and show it to me this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere, if you please?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBehind the Luxembourg; that\xe2\x80\x99s a charming spot for such amusements as\r\nthe one I propose to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do; I will be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSix o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_A propos_, you have probably one or two friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have three, who would be honored by joining in the sport with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree? Marvelous! That falls out oddly! Three is just my number!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, then, who are you?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, a Gascon gentleman, serving in the king\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMusketeers. And you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Lord de Winter, Baron Sheffield.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, I am your servant, Monsieur Baron,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthough you have names rather difficult to recollect.\xe2\x80\x9d And touching his\r\nhorse with the spur, he cantered back to Paris. As he was accustomed to\r\ndo in all cases of any consequence, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went straight to the\r\nresidence of Athos.\r\n\r\nHe found Athos reclining upon a large sofa, where he was waiting, as he\r\nsaid, for his outfit to come and find him. He related to Athos all that\r\nhad passed, except the letter to M. de Wardes.\r\n\r\nAthos was delighted to find he was going to fight an Englishman. We\r\nmight say that was his dream.\r\n\r\nThey immediately sent their lackeys for Porthos and Aramis, and on\r\ntheir arrival made them acquainted with the situation.\r\n\r\nPorthos drew his sword from the scabbard, and made passes at the wall,\r\nspringing back from time to time, and making contortions like a dancer.\r\n\r\nAramis, who was constantly at work at his poem, shut himself up in\r\nAthos\xe2\x80\x99s closet, and begged not to be disturbed before the moment of\r\ndrawing swords.\r\n\r\nAthos, by signs, desired Grimaud to bring another bottle of wine.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan employed himself in arranging a little plan, of which we\r\nshall hereafter see the execution, and which promised him some\r\nagreeable adventure, as might be seen by the smiles which from time to\r\ntime passed over his countenance, whose thoughtfulness they animated.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXI.\r\nENGLISH AND FRENCH\r\n\r\n\r\nThe hour having come, they went with their four lackeys to a spot\r\nbehind the Luxembourg given up to the feeding of goats. Athos threw a\r\npiece of money to the goatkeeper to withdraw. The lackeys were ordered\r\nto act as sentinels.\r\n\r\nA silent party soon drew near to the same enclosure, entered, and\r\njoined the Musketeers. Then, according to foreign custom, the\r\npresentations took place.\r\n\r\nThe Englishmen were all men of rank; consequently the odd names of\r\ntheir adversaries were for them not only a matter of surprise, but of\r\nannoyance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut after all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord de Winter, when the three friends had been\r\nnamed, \xe2\x80\x9cwe do not know who you are. We cannot fight with such names;\r\nthey are names of shepherds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore your lordship may suppose they are only assumed names,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich only gives us a greater desire to know the real ones,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nthe Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou played very willingly with us without knowing our names,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos, \xe2\x80\x9cby the same token that you won our horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is true, but we then only risked our pistoles; this time we risk\r\nour blood. One plays with anybody; but one fights only with equals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is but just,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, and he took aside the one of the\r\nfour Englishmen with whom he was to fight, and communicated his name in\r\na low voice.\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis did the same.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes that satisfy you?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos to his adversary. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you find me\r\nof sufficient rank to do me the honor of crossing swords with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman, bowing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! now shall I tell you something?\xe2\x80\x9d added Athos, coolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that is that you would have acted much more wisely if you had not\r\nrequired me to make myself known.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I am believed to be dead, and have reasons for wishing nobody\r\nto know I am living; so that I shall be obliged to kill you to prevent\r\nmy secret from roaming over the fields.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Englishman looked at Athos, believing that he jested, but Athos did\r\nnot jest the least in the world.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, addressing at the same time his companions and\r\ntheir adversaries, \xe2\x80\x9care we ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes!\xe2\x80\x9d answered the Englishmen and the Frenchmen, as with one voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn guard, then!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos.\r\n\r\nImmediately eight swords glittered in the rays of the setting sun, and\r\nthe combat began with an animosity very natural between men twice\r\nenemies.\r\n\r\nAthos fenced with as much calmness and method as if he had been\r\npracticing in a fencing school.\r\n\r\nPorthos, abated, no doubt, of his too-great confidence by his adventure\r\nof Chantilly, played with skill and prudence. Aramis, who had the third\r\ncanto of his poem to finish, behaved like a man in haste.\r\n\r\nAthos killed his adversary first. He hit him but once, but as he had\r\nforetold, that hit was a mortal one; the sword pierced his heart.\r\n\r\nSecond, Porthos stretched his upon the grass with a wound through his\r\nthigh, As the Englishman, without making any further resistance, then\r\nsurrendered his sword, Porthos took him up in his arms and bore him to\r\nhis carriage.\r\n\r\nAramis pushed his so vigorously that after going back fifty paces, the\r\nman ended by fairly taking to his heels, and disappeared amid the\r\nhooting of the lackeys.\r\n\r\nAs to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he fought purely and simply on the defensive; and\r\nwhen he saw his adversary pretty well fatigued, with a vigorous side\r\nthrust sent his sword flying. The baron, finding himself disarmed, took\r\ntwo or three steps back, but in this movement his foot slipped and he\r\nfell backward.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was over him at a bound, and said to the Englishman,\r\npointing his sword to his throat, \xe2\x80\x9cI could kill you, my Lord, you are\r\ncompletely in my hands; but I spare your life for the sake of your\r\nsister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was at the height of joy; he had realized the plan he had\r\nimagined beforehand, whose picturing had produced the smiles we noted\r\nupon his face.\r\n\r\nThe Englishman, delighted at having to do with a gentleman of such a\r\nkind disposition, pressed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan in his arms, and paid a thousand\r\ncompliments to the three Musketeers, and as Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s adversary was\r\nalready installed in the carriage, and as Aramis\xe2\x80\x99s had taken to his\r\nheels, they had nothing to think about but the dead.\r\n\r\nAs Porthos and Aramis were undressing him, in the hope of finding his\r\nwound not mortal, a large purse dropped from his clothes. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\npicked it up and offered it to Lord de Winter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil would you have me do with that?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Englishman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can restore it to his family,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis family will care much about such a trifle as that! His family will\r\ninherit fifteen thousand louis a year from him. Keep the purse for your\r\nlackeys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan put the purse into his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, my young friend, for you will permit me, I hope, to give you\r\nthat name,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord de Winter, \xe2\x80\x9con this very evening, if agreeable to\r\nyou, I will present you to my sister, Milady Clarik, for I am desirous\r\nthat she should take you into her good graces; and as she is not in bad\r\nodor at court, she may perhaps on some future day speak a word that\r\nwill not prove useless to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan blushed with pleasure, and bowed a sign of assent.\r\n\r\nAt this time Athos came up to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean to do with that purse?\xe2\x80\x9d whispered he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I meant to pass it over to you, my dear Athos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMe! why to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you killed him! They are the spoils of victory.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, the heir of an enemy!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cfor whom, then, do you take\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the custom in war,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy should it not be the\r\ncustom in a duel?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEven on the field of battle, I have never done that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos shrugged his shoulders; Aramis by a movement of his lips\r\nendorsed Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9clet us give the money to the lackeys, as Lord\r\nde Winter desired us to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9clet us give the money to the lackeys\xe2\x80\x94not to our\r\nlackeys, but to the lackeys of the Englishmen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos took the purse, and threw it into the hand of the coachman. \xe2\x80\x9cFor\r\nyou and your comrades.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis greatness of spirit in a man who was quite destitute struck even\r\nPorthos; and this French generosity, repeated by Lord de Winter and his\r\nfriend, was highly applauded, except by MM. Grimaud, Bazin, Mousqueton\r\nand Planchet.\r\n\r\nLord de Winter, on quitting D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, gave him his sister\xe2\x80\x99s address.\r\nShe lived in the Place Royale\xe2\x80\x94then the fashionable quarter\xe2\x80\x94at Number 6,\r\nand he undertook to call and take D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with him in order to\r\nintroduce him. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan appointed eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock at Athos\xe2\x80\x99s residence.\r\n\r\nThis introduction to Milady Clarik occupied the head of our Gascon\r\ngreatly. He remembered in what a strange manner this woman had hitherto\r\nbeen mixed up in his destiny. According to his conviction, she was some\r\ncreature of the cardinal, and yet he felt himself invincibly drawn\r\ntoward her by one of those sentiments for which we cannot account. His\r\nonly fear was that Milady would recognize in him the man of Meung and\r\nof Dover. Then she knew that he was one of the friends of M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville, and consequently, that he belonged body and soul to the king;\r\nwhich would make him lose a part of his advantage, since when known to\r\nMilady as he knew her, he played only an equal game with her. As to the\r\ncommencement of an intrigue between her and M. de Wardes, our\r\npresumptuous hero gave but little heed to that, although the marquis\r\nwas young, handsome, rich, and high in the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s favor. It is not\r\nfor nothing we are but twenty years old, above all if we were born at\r\nTarbes.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan began by making his most splendid toilet, then returned to\r\nAthos\xe2\x80\x99s, and according to custom, related everything to him. Athos\r\nlistened to his projects, then shook his head, and recommended prudence\r\nto him with a shade of bitterness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have just lost one woman, whom you call good,\r\ncharming, perfect; and here you are, running headlong after another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan felt the truth of this reproach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI loved Madame Bonacieux with my heart, while I only love Milady with\r\nmy head,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cIn getting introduced to her, my principal object\r\nis to ascertain what part she plays at court.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe part she plays, _pardieu!_ It is not difficult to divine that,\r\nafter all you have told me. She is some emissary of the cardinal; a\r\nwoman who will draw you into a snare in which you will leave your\r\nhead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! my dear Athos, you view things on the dark side, methinks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear fellow, I mistrust women. Can it be otherwise? I bought my\r\nexperience dearly\xe2\x80\x94particularly fair women. Milady is fair, you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has the most beautiful light hair imaginable!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my poor D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me! I want to be enlightened on a subject; then, when I\r\nshall have learned what I desire to know, I will withdraw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe enlightened!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, phlegmatically.\r\n\r\nLord de Winter arrived at the appointed time; but Athos, being warned\r\nof his coming, went into the other chamber. He therefore found\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan alone, and as it was nearly eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock he took the young\r\nman with him.\r\n\r\nAn elegant carriage waited below, and as it was drawn by two excellent\r\nhorses, they were soon at the Place Royale.\r\n\r\nMilady Clarik received D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan ceremoniously. Her h\xc3\xb4tel was\r\nremarkably sumptuous, and while the most part of the English had quit,\r\nor were about to quit, France on account of the war, Milady had just\r\nbeen laying out much money upon her residence; which proved that the\r\ngeneral measure which drove the English from France did not affect her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord de Winter, presenting D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to his sister, \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nyoung gentleman who has held my life in his hands, and who has not\r\nabused his advantage, although we have been twice enemies, although it\r\nwas I who insulted him, and although I am an Englishman. Thank him,\r\nthen, madame, if you have any affection for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady frowned slightly; a scarcely visible cloud passed over her brow,\r\nand so peculiar a smile appeared upon her lips that the young man, who\r\nsaw and observed this triple shade, almost shuddered at it.\r\n\r\nThe brother did not perceive this; he had turned round to play with\r\nMilady\xe2\x80\x99s favorite monkey, which had pulled him by the doublet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are welcome, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in a voice whose singular\r\nsweetness contrasted with the symptoms of ill-humor which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nhad just remarked; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have today acquired eternal rights to my\r\ngratitude.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe Englishman then turned round and described the combat without\r\nomitting a single detail. Milady listened with the greatest attention,\r\nand yet it was easily to be perceived, whatever effort she made to\r\nconceal her impressions, that this recital was not agreeable to her.\r\nThe blood rose to her head, and her little foot worked with impatience\r\nbeneath her robe.\r\n\r\nLord de Winter perceived nothing of this. When he had finished, he went\r\nto a table upon which was a salver with Spanish wine and glasses. He\r\nfilled two glasses, and by a sign invited D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to drink.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan knew it was considered disobliging by an Englishman to\r\nrefuse to pledge him. He therefore drew near to the table and took the\r\nsecond glass. He did not, however, lose sight of Milady, and in a\r\nmirror he perceived the change that came over her face. Now that she\r\nbelieved herself to be no longer observed, a sentiment resembling\r\nferocity animated her countenance. She bit her handkerchief with her\r\nbeautiful teeth.\r\n\r\nThat pretty little _soubrette_ whom D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had already observed\r\nthen came in. She spoke some words to Lord de Winter in English, who\r\nthereupon requested D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s permission to retire, excusing himself\r\non account of the urgency of the business that had called him away, and\r\ncharging his sister to obtain his pardon.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan exchanged a shake of the hand with Lord de Winter, and then\r\nreturned to Milady. Her countenance, with surprising mobility, had\r\nrecovered its gracious expression; but some little red spots on her\r\nhandkerchief indicated that she had bitten her lips till the blood\r\ncame. Those lips were magnificent; they might be said to be of coral.\r\n\r\nThe conversation took a cheerful turn. Milady appeared to have entirely\r\nrecovered. She told D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that Lord de Winter was her\r\nbrother-in-law, and not her brother. She had married a younger brother\r\nof the family, who had left her a widow with one child. This child was\r\nthe only heir to Lord de Winter, if Lord de Winter did not marry. All\r\nthis showed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that there was a veil which concealed something;\r\nbut he could not yet see under this veil.\r\n\r\nIn addition to this, after a half hour\xe2\x80\x99s conversation D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was\r\nconvinced that Milady was his compatriot; she spoke French with an\r\nelegance and a purity that left no doubt on that head.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was profuse in gallant speeches and protestations of\r\ndevotion. To all the simple things which escaped our Gascon, Milady\r\nreplied with a smile of kindness. The hour came for him to retire.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took leave of Milady, and left the saloon the happiest of\r\nmen.\r\n\r\nOn the staircase he met the pretty _soubrette_, who brushed gently\r\nagainst him as she passed, and then, blushing to the eyes, asked his\r\npardon for having touched him in a voice so sweet that the pardon was\r\ngranted instantly.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan came again on the morrow, and was still better received than\r\non the evening before. Lord de Winter was not at home; and it was\r\nMilady who this time did all the honors of the evening. She appeared to\r\ntake a great interest in him, asked him whence he came, who were his\r\nfriends, and whether he had not sometimes thought of attaching himself\r\nto the cardinal.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, as we have said, was exceedingly prudent for a young\r\nman of twenty, then remembered his suspicions regarding Milady. He\r\nlaunched into a eulogy of his Eminence, and said that he should not\r\nhave failed to enter into the Guards of the cardinal instead of the\r\nking\xe2\x80\x99s Guards if he had happened to know M. de Cavois instead of M. de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville.\r\n\r\nMilady changed the conversation without any appearance of affectation,\r\nand asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan in the most careless manner possible if he had\r\never been in England.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan replied that he had been sent thither by M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville to\r\ntreat for a supply of horses, and that he had brought back four as\r\nspecimens.\r\n\r\nMilady in the course of the conversation twice or thrice bit her lips;\r\nshe had to deal with a Gascon who played close.\r\n\r\nAt the same hour as on the preceding evening, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan retired. In\r\nthe corridor he again met the pretty Kitty; that was the name of the\r\n_soubrette_. She looked at him with an expression of kindness which it\r\nwas impossible to mistake; but D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was so preoccupied by the\r\nmistress that he noticed absolutely nothing but her.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan came again on the morrow and the day after that, and each\r\nday Milady gave him a more gracious reception.\r\n\r\nEvery evening, either in the antechamber, the corridor, or on the\r\nstairs, he met the pretty _soubrette_. But, as we have said, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\npaid no attention to this persistence of poor Kitty.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXII.\r\nA PROCURATOR\xe2\x80\x99S DINNER\r\n\r\n\r\nHowever brilliant had been the part played by Porthos in the duel, it\r\nhad not made him forget the dinner of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\nOn the morrow he received the last touches of Mousqueton\xe2\x80\x99s brush for an\r\nhour, and took his way toward the Rue aux Ours with the steps of a man\r\nwho was doubly in favor with fortune.\r\n\r\nHis heart beat, but not like D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s with a young and impatient\r\nlove. No; a more material interest stirred his blood. He was about at\r\nlast to pass that mysterious threshold, to climb those unknown stairs\r\nby which, one by one, the old crowns of M. Coquenard had ascended. He\r\nwas about to see in reality a certain coffer of which he had twenty\r\ntimes beheld the image in his dreams\xe2\x80\x94a coffer long and deep, locked,\r\nbolted, fastened in the wall; a coffer of which he had so often heard,\r\nand which the hands\xe2\x80\x94a little wrinkled, it is true, but still not\r\nwithout elegance\xe2\x80\x94of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife were about to open to his\r\nadmiring looks.\r\n\r\nAnd then he\xe2\x80\x94a wanderer on the earth, a man without fortune, a man\r\nwithout family, a soldier accustomed to inns, cabarets, taverns, and\r\nrestaurants, a lover of wine forced to depend upon chance treats\xe2\x80\x94was\r\nabout to partake of family meals, to enjoy the pleasures of a\r\ncomfortable establishment, and to give himself up to those little\r\nattentions which \xe2\x80\x9cthe harder one is, the more they please,\xe2\x80\x9d as old\r\nsoldiers say.\r\n\r\nTo come in the capacity of a cousin, and seat himself every day at a\r\ngood table; to smooth the yellow, wrinkled brow of the old procurator;\r\nto pluck the clerks a little by teaching them _bassette_, _passe-dix_,\r\nand _lansquenet_, in their utmost nicety, and winning from them, by way\r\nof fee for the lesson he would give them in an hour, their savings of a\r\nmonth\xe2\x80\x94all this was enormously delightful to Porthos.\r\n\r\nThe Musketeer could not forget the evil reports which then prevailed,\r\nand which indeed have survived them, of the procurators of the\r\nperiod\xe2\x80\x94meanness, stinginess, fasts; but as, after all, excepting some\r\nfew acts of economy which Porthos had always found very unseasonable,\r\nthe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife had been tolerably liberal\xe2\x80\x94that is, be it\r\nunderstood, for a procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife\xe2\x80\x94he hoped to see a household of a\r\nhighly comfortable kind.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, at the very door the Musketeer began to entertain some doubts.\r\nThe approach was not such as to prepossess people\xe2\x80\x94an ill-smelling, dark\r\npassage, a staircase half-lighted by bars through which stole a glimmer\r\nfrom a neighboring yard; on the first floor a low door studded with\r\nenormous nails, like the principal gate of the Grand Ch\xc3\xa2telet.\r\n\r\nPorthos knocked with his hand. A tall, pale clerk, his face shaded by a\r\nforest of virgin hair, opened the door, and bowed with the air of a man\r\nforced at once to respect in another lofty stature, which indicated\r\nstrength, the military dress, which indicated rank, and a ruddy\r\ncountenance, which indicated familiarity with good living.\r\n\r\nA shorter clerk came behind the first, a taller clerk behind the\r\nsecond, a stripling of a dozen years rising behind the third. In all,\r\nthree clerks and a half, which, for the time, argued a very extensive\r\nclientage.\r\n\r\nAlthough the Musketeer was not expected before one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife had been on the watch ever since midday, reckoning\r\nthat the heart, or perhaps the stomach, of her lover would bring him\r\nbefore his time.\r\n\r\nMme. Coquenard therefore entered the office from the house at the same\r\nmoment her guest entered from the stairs, and the appearance of the\r\nworthy lady relieved him from an awkward embarrassment. The clerks\r\nsurveyed him with great curiosity, and he, not knowing well what to say\r\nto this ascending and descending scale, remained tongue-tied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is my cousin!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife. \xe2\x80\x9cCome in, come in,\r\nMonsieur Porthos!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe name of Porthos produced its effect upon the clerks, who began to\r\nlaugh; but Porthos turned sharply round, and every countenance quickly\r\nrecovered its gravity.\r\n\r\nThey reached the office of the procurator after having passed through\r\nthe antechamber in which the clerks were, and the study in which they\r\nought to have been. This last apartment was a sort of dark room,\r\nlittered with papers. On quitting the study they left the kitchen on\r\nthe right, and entered the reception room.\r\n\r\nAll these rooms, which communicated with one another, did not inspire\r\nPorthos favorably. Words might be heard at a distance through all these\r\nopen doors. Then, while passing, he had cast a rapid, investigating\r\nglance into the kitchen; and he was obliged to confess to himself, to\r\nthe shame of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife and his own regret, that he did not\r\nsee that fire, that animation, that bustle, which when a good repast is\r\non foot prevails generally in that sanctuary of good living.\r\n\r\nThe procurator had without doubt been warned of his visit, as he\r\nexpressed no surprise at the sight of Porthos, who advanced toward him\r\nwith a sufficiently easy air, and saluted him courteously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are cousins, it appears, Monsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d said the procurator,\r\nrising, yet supporting his weight upon the arms of his cane chair.\r\n\r\nThe old man, wrapped in a large black doublet, in which the whole of\r\nhis slender body was concealed, was brisk and dry. His little gray eyes\r\nshone like carbuncles, and appeared, with his grinning mouth, to be the\r\nonly part of his face in which life survived. Unfortunately the legs\r\nbegan to refuse their service to this bony machine. During the last\r\nfive or six months that this weakness had been felt, the worthy\r\nprocurator had nearly become the slave of his wife.\r\n\r\nThe cousin was received with resignation, that was all. M. Coquenard,\r\nfirm upon his legs, would have declined all relationship with M.\r\nPorthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur, we are cousins,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, without being\r\ndisconcerted, as he had never reckoned upon being received\r\nenthusiastically by the husband.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the female side, I believe?\xe2\x80\x9d said the procurator, maliciously.\r\n\r\nPorthos did not feel the ridicule of this, and took it for a piece of\r\nsimplicity, at which he laughed in his large mustache. Mme. Coquenard,\r\nwho knew that a simple-minded procurator was a very rare variety in the\r\nspecies, smiled a little, and colored a great deal.\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard had, since the arrival of Porthos, frequently cast his\r\neyes with great uneasiness upon a large chest placed in front of his\r\noak desk. Porthos comprehended that this chest, although it did not\r\ncorrespond in shape with that which he had seen in his dreams, must be\r\nthe blessed coffer, and he congratulated himself that the reality was\r\nseveral feet higher than the dream.\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard did not carry his genealogical investigations any further;\r\nbut withdrawing his anxious look from the chest and fixing it upon\r\nPorthos, he contented himself with saying, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur our cousin will do\r\nus the favor of dining with us once before his departure for the\r\ncampaign, will he not, Madame Coquenard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis time Porthos received the blow right in his stomach, and felt it.\r\nIt appeared likewise that Mme. Coquenard was not less affected by it on\r\nher part, for she added, \xe2\x80\x9cMy cousin will not return if he finds that we\r\ndo not treat him kindly; but otherwise he has so little time to pass in\r\nParis, and consequently to spare to us, that we must entreat him to\r\ngive us every instant he can call his own previous to his departure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my legs, my poor legs! where are you?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Coquenard, and he\r\ntried to smile.\r\n\r\nThis succor, which came to Porthos at the moment in which he was\r\nattacked in his gastronomic hopes, inspired much gratitude in the\r\nMusketeer toward the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\nThe hour of dinner soon arrived. They passed into the eating room\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nlarge dark room situated opposite the kitchen.\r\n\r\nThe clerks, who, as it appeared, had smelled unusual perfumes in the\r\nhouse, were of military punctuality, and held their stools in hand\r\nquite ready to sit down. Their jaws moved preliminarily with fearful\r\nthreatenings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Porthos, casting a glance at the three hungry\r\nclerks\xe2\x80\x94for the errand boy, as might be expected, was not admitted to\r\nthe honors of the magisterial table, \xe2\x80\x9cin my cousin\xe2\x80\x99s place, I would not\r\nkeep such gourmands! They look like shipwrecked sailors who have not\r\neaten for six weeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard entered, pushed along upon his armchair with casters by\r\nMme. Coquenard, whom Porthos assisted in rolling her husband up to the\r\ntable. He had scarcely entered when he began to agitate his nose and\r\nhis jaws after the example of his clerks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9chere is a soup which is rather inviting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil can they smell so extraordinary in this soup?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nPorthos, at the sight of a pale liquid, abundant but entirely free from\r\nmeat, on the surface of which a few crusts swam about as rare as the\r\nislands of an archipelago.\r\n\r\nMme. Coquenard smiled, and upon a sign from her everyone eagerly took\r\nhis seat.\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard was served first, then Porthos. Afterward Mme. Coquenard\r\nfilled her own plate, and distributed the crusts without soup to the\r\nimpatient clerks. At this moment the door of the dining room unclosed\r\nwith a creak, and Porthos perceived through the half-open flap the\r\nlittle clerk who, not being allowed to take part in the feast, ate his\r\ndry bread in the passage with the double odor of the dining room and\r\nkitchen.\r\n\r\nAfter the soup the maid brought a boiled fowl\xe2\x80\x94a piece of magnificence\r\nwhich caused the eyes of the diners to dilate in such a manner that\r\nthey seemed ready to burst.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne may see that you love your family, Madame Coquenard,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nprocurator, with a smile that was almost tragic. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are certainly\r\ntreating your cousin very handsomely!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor fowl was thin, and covered with one of those thick, bristly\r\nskins through which the teeth cannot penetrate with all their efforts.\r\nThe fowl must have been sought for a long time on the perch, to which\r\nit had retired to die of old age.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthis is poor work. I respect old age,\r\nbut I don\xe2\x80\x99t much like it boiled or roasted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he looked round to see if anybody partook of his opinion; but on\r\nthe contrary, he saw nothing but eager eyes which were devouring, in\r\nanticipation, that sublime fowl which was the object of his contempt.\r\n\r\nMme. Coquenard drew the dish toward her, skillfully detached the two\r\ngreat black feet, which she placed upon her husband\xe2\x80\x99s plate, cut off\r\nthe neck, which with the head she put on one side for herself, raised\r\nthe wing for Porthos, and then returned the bird otherwise intact to\r\nthe servant who had brought it in, who disappeared with it before the\r\nMusketeer had time to examine the variations which disappointment\r\nproduces upon faces, according to the characters and temperaments of\r\nthose who experience it.\r\n\r\nIn the place of the fowl a dish of haricot beans made its appearance\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nenormous dish in which some bones of mutton that at first sight one\r\nmight have believed to have some meat on them pretended to show\r\nthemselves.\r\n\r\nBut the clerks were not the dupes of this deceit, and their lugubrious\r\nlooks settled down into resigned countenances.\r\n\r\nMme. Coquenard distributed this dish to the young men with the\r\nmoderation of a good housewife.\r\n\r\nThe time for wine came. M. Coquenard poured from a very small stone\r\nbottle the third of a glass for each of the young men, served himself\r\nin about the same proportion, and passed the bottle to Porthos and Mme.\r\nCoquenard.\r\n\r\nThe young men filled up their third of a glass with water; then, when\r\nthey had drunk half the glass, they filled it up again, and continued\r\nto do so. This brought them, by the end of the repast, to swallowing a\r\ndrink which from the color of the ruby had passed to that of a pale\r\ntopaz.\r\n\r\nPorthos ate his wing of the fowl timidly, and shuddered when he felt\r\nthe knee of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife under the table, as it came in search\r\nof his. He also drank half a glass of this sparingly served wine, and\r\nfound it to be nothing but that horrible Montreuil\xe2\x80\x94the terror of all\r\nexpert palates.\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard saw him swallowing this wine undiluted, and sighed deeply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you eat any of these beans, Cousin Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Coquenard,\r\nin that tone which says, \xe2\x80\x9cTake my advice, don\xe2\x80\x99t touch them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDevil take me if I taste one of them!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Porthos to himself,\r\nand then said aloud, \xe2\x80\x9cThank you, my cousin, I am no longer hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was silence. Porthos could hardly keep his countenance.\r\n\r\nThe procurator repeated several times, \xe2\x80\x9cAh, Madame Coquenard! Accept my\r\ncompliments; your dinner has been a real feast. Lord, how I have\r\neaten!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard had eaten his soup, the black feet of the fowl, and the\r\nonly mutton bone on which there was the least appearance of meat.\r\n\r\nPorthos fancied they were mystifying him, and began to curl his\r\nmustache and knit his eyebrows; but the knee of Mme. Coquenard gently\r\nadvised him to be patient.\r\n\r\nThis silence and this interruption in serving, which were\r\nunintelligible to Porthos, had, on the contrary, a terrible meaning for\r\nthe clerks. Upon a look from the procurator, accompanied by a smile\r\nfrom Mme. Coquenard, they arose slowly from the table, folded their\r\nnapkins more slowly still, bowed, and retired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo, young men! go and promote digestion by working,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nprocurator, gravely.\r\n\r\nThe clerks gone, Mme. Coquenard rose and took from a buffet a piece of\r\ncheese, some preserved quinces, and a cake which she had herself made\r\nof almonds and honey.\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard knit his eyebrows because there were too many good things.\r\nPorthos bit his lips because he saw not the wherewithal to dine. He\r\nlooked to see if the dish of beans was still there; the dish of beans\r\nhad disappeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA positive feast!\xe2\x80\x9d cried M. Coquenard, turning about in his chair, \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nreal feast, _epul\xc5\x93 epulorum_. Lucullus dines with Lucullus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos looked at the bottle, which was near him, and hoped that with\r\nwine, bread, and cheese, he might make a dinner; but wine was wanting,\r\nthe bottle was empty. M. and Mme. Coquenard did not seem to observe it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is fine!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos to himself; \xe2\x80\x9cI am prettily caught!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe passed his tongue over a spoonful of preserves, and stuck his teeth\r\ninto the sticky pastry of Mme. Coquenard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthe sacrifice is consummated! Ah! if I had not the\r\nhope of peeping with Madame Coquenard into her husband\xe2\x80\x99s chest!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nM. Coquenard, after the luxuries of such a repast, which he called an\r\nexcess, felt the want of a siesta. Porthos began to hope that the thing\r\nwould take place at the present sitting, and in that same locality; but\r\nthe procurator would listen to nothing, he would be taken to his room,\r\nand was not satisfied till he was close to his chest, upon the edge of\r\nwhich, for still greater precaution, he placed his feet.\r\n\r\nThe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife took Porthos into an adjoining room, and they\r\nbegan to lay the basis of a reconciliation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou can come and dine three times a week,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Coquenard.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to abuse your\r\nkindness; besides, I must think of my outfit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, groaning, \xe2\x80\x9cthat unfortunate\r\noutfit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cit is so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut of what, then, does the equipment of your company consist,\r\nMonsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, of many things!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Musketeers are, as you know,\r\npicked soldiers, and they require many things useless to the Guardsmen\r\nor the Swiss.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut yet, detail them to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, they may amount to\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c, said Porthos, who preferred discussing the\r\ntotal to taking them one by one.\r\n\r\nThe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife waited tremblingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo how much?\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope it does not exceed\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d She stopped;\r\nspeech failed her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cit does not exceed two thousand five hundred\r\nlivres! I even think that with economy I could manage it with two\r\nthousand livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, \xe2\x80\x9ctwo thousand livres! Why, that is a fortune!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos made a most significant grimace; Mme. Coquenard understood it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wished to know the detail,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause, having many\r\nrelatives in business, I was almost sure of obtaining things at a\r\nhundred per cent less than you would pay yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is what you meant to say!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, dear Monsieur Porthos. Thus, for instance, don\xe2\x80\x99t you in the first\r\nplace want a horse?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a horse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then! I can just suit you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, brightening, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s well as regards my horse; but\r\nI must have the appointments complete, as they include objects which a\r\nMusketeer alone can purchase, and which will not amount, besides, to\r\nmore than three hundred livres.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThree hundred livres? Then put down three hundred livres,\xe2\x80\x9d said the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, with a sigh.\r\n\r\nPorthos smiled. It may be remembered that he had the saddle which came\r\nfrom Buckingham. These three hundred livres he reckoned upon putting\r\nsnugly into his pocket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a horse for my lackey, and my valise.\r\nAs to my arms, it is useless to trouble you about them; I have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA horse for your lackey?\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, hesitatingly;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut that is doing things in lordly style, my friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, haughtily; \xe2\x80\x9cdo you take me for a beggar?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I only thought that a pretty mule makes sometimes as good an\r\nappearance as a horse, and it seemed to me that by getting a pretty\r\nmule for Mousqueton\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, agreed for a pretty mule,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are right, I have\r\nseen very great Spanish nobles whose whole suite were mounted on mules.\r\nBut then you understand, Madame Coquenard, a mule with feathers and\r\nbells.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied,\xe2\x80\x9d said the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere remains the valise,\xe2\x80\x9d added Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t let that disturb you,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Coquenard. \xe2\x80\x9cMy husband has\r\nfive or six valises; you shall choose the best. There is one in\r\nparticular which he prefers in his journeys, large enough to hold all\r\nthe world.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour valise is then empty?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos, with simplicity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly it is empty,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, in real\r\ninnocence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, but the valise I want,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cis a well-filled one, my\r\ndear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMadame uttered fresh sighs. Moli\xc3\xa8re had not written his scene in\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cL\xe2\x80\x99Avare\xe2\x80\x9d then. Mme. Coquenard was in the dilemma of Harpagan.\r\n\r\nFinally, the rest of the equipment was successively debated in the same\r\nmanner; and the result of the sitting was that the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife\r\nshould give eight hundred livres in money, and should furnish the horse\r\nand the mule which should have the honor of carrying Porthos and\r\nMousqueton to glory.\r\n\r\nThese conditions being agreed to, Porthos took leave of Mme. Coquenard.\r\nThe latter wished to detain him by darting certain tender glances; but\r\nPorthos urged the commands of duty, and the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife was\r\nobliged to give place to the king.\r\n\r\nThe Musketeer returned home hungry and in bad humor.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXIII.\r\nSOUBRETTE AND MISTRESS\r\n\r\n\r\nMeantime, as we have said, despite the cries of his conscience and the\r\nwise counsels of Athos, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan became hourly more in love with\r\nMilady. Thus he never failed to pay his diurnal court to her; and the\r\nself-satisfied Gascon was convinced that sooner or later she could not\r\nfail to respond.\r\n\r\nOne day, when he arrived with his head in the air, and as light at\r\nheart as a man who awaits a shower of gold, he found the _soubrette_\r\nunder the gateway of the h\xc3\xb4tel; but this time the pretty Kitty was not\r\ncontented with touching him as he passed, she took him gently by the\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d thought D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cShe is charged with some message for me\r\nfrom her mistress; she is about to appoint some rendezvous of which she\r\nhad not courage to speak.\xe2\x80\x9d And he looked down at the pretty girl with\r\nthe most triumphant air imaginable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to say three words to you, Monsieur Chevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered the\r\n_soubrette_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, my child, speak,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere? Impossible! That which I have to say is too long, and above all,\r\ntoo secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf Monsieur Chevalier would follow me?\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, timidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere you please, my dear child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Kitty, who had not let go the hand of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, led him up a\r\nlittle dark, winding staircase, and after ascending about fifteen\r\nsteps, opened a door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome in here, Monsieur Chevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9chere we shall be alone,\r\nand can talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd whose room is this, my dear child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is mine, Monsieur Chevalier; it communicates with my mistress\xe2\x80\x99s by\r\nthat door. But you need not fear. She will not hear what we say; she\r\nnever goes to bed before midnight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan cast a glance around him. The little apartment was charming\r\nfor its taste and neatness; but in spite of himself, his eyes were\r\ndirected to that door which Kitty said led to Milady\xe2\x80\x99s chamber.\r\n\r\nKitty guessed what was passing in the mind of the young man, and heaved\r\na deep sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou love my mistress, then, very dearly, Monsieur Chevalier?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nshe.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, more than I can say, Kitty! I am mad for her!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKitty breathed a second sigh.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthat is too bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil do you see so bad in it?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cmy mistress loves you not at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Hein!_\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ccan she have charged you to tell me so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no, monsieur; but out of the regard I have for you, I have taken\r\nthe resolution to tell you so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch obliged, my dear Kitty; but for the intention only\xe2\x80\x94for the\r\ninformation, you must agree, is not likely to be at all agreeable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe what I have told you; is it not so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have always some difficulty in believing such things, my pretty\r\ndear, were it only from self-love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you don\xe2\x80\x99t believe me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI confess that unless you deign to give me some proof of what you\r\nadvance\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you think of this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKitty drew a little note from her bosom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor me?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, seizing the letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; for another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor another?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis name; his name!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead the address.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur El Comte de Wardes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe remembrance of the scene at St. Germain presented itself to the\r\nmind of the presumptuous Gascon. As quick as thought, he tore open the\r\nletter, in spite of the cry which Kitty uttered on seeing what he was\r\ngoing to do, or rather, what he was doing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, good Lord, Monsieur Chevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat are you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cnothing,\xe2\x80\x9d and he read,\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have not answered my first note. Are you indisposed, or have you\r\nforgotten the glances you favored me with at the ball of Mme. de Guise?\r\nYou have an opportunity now, Count; do not allow it to escape.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan became very pale; he was wounded in his _self_-love: he\r\nthought that it was in his _love_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor dear Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, in a voice full of\r\ncompassion, and pressing anew the young man\xe2\x80\x99s hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou pity me, little one?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, and with all my heart; for I know what it is to be in love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know what it is to be in love?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, looking at her\r\nfor the first time with much attention.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, instead of pitying me, you would do much better to assist\r\nme in avenging myself on your mistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what sort of revenge would you take?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would triumph over her, and supplant my rival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will never help you in that, Monsieur Chevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty,\r\nwarmly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why not?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor two reasons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat ones?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe first is that my mistress will never love you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have cut her to the heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI? In what can I have offended her\xe2\x80\x94I who ever since I have known her\r\nhave lived at her feet like a slave? Speak, I beg you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will never confess that but to the man\xe2\x80\x94who should read to the bottom\r\nof my soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan looked at Kitty for the second time. The young girl had\r\nfreshness and beauty which many duchesses would have purchased with\r\ntheir coronets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKitty,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cI will read to the bottom of your soul whenever you\r\nlike; don\xe2\x80\x99t let that disturb you.\xe2\x80\x9d And he gave her a kiss at which the\r\npoor girl became as red as a cherry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not me you love! It is my mistress you\r\nlove; you told me so just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd does that hinder you from letting me know the second reason?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe second reason, Monsieur the Chevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Kitty, emboldened\r\nby the kiss in the first place, and still further by the expression of\r\nthe eyes of the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cis that in love, everyone for herself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen only D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan remembered the languishing glances of Kitty, her\r\nconstantly meeting him in the antechamber, the corridor, or on the\r\nstairs, those touches of the hand every time she met him, and her deep\r\nsighs; but absorbed by his desire to please the great lady, he had\r\ndisdained the _soubrette_. He whose game is the eagle takes no heed of\r\nthe sparrow.\r\n\r\nBut this time our Gascon saw at a glance all the advantage to be\r\nderived from the love which Kitty had just confessed so innocently, or\r\nso boldly: the interception of letters addressed to the Comte de\r\nWardes, news on the spot, entrance at all hours into Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s chamber,\r\nwhich was contiguous to her mistress\xe2\x80\x99s. The perfidious deceiver was, as\r\nmay plainly be perceived, already sacrificing, in intention, the poor\r\ngirl in order to obtain Milady, willy-nilly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to the young girl, \xe2\x80\x9care you willing, my dear Kitty,\r\nthat I should give you a proof of that love which you doubt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat love?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young girl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf that which I am ready to feel toward you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that proof?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you willing that I should this evening pass with you the time I\r\ngenerally spend with your mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, clapping her hands, \xe2\x80\x9cvery willing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, come here, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, establishing himself\r\nin an easy chair; \xe2\x80\x9ccome, and let me tell you that you are the prettiest\r\n_soubrette_ I ever saw!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he did tell her so much, and so well, that the poor girl, who asked\r\nnothing better than to believe him, did believe him. Nevertheless, to\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s great astonishment, the pretty Kitty defended herself\r\nresolutely.\r\n\r\nTime passes quickly when it is passed in attacks and defenses. Midnight\r\nsounded, and almost at the same time the bell was rung in Milady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is my mistress calling me! Go; go\r\ndirectly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rose, took his hat, as if it had been his intention to obey,\r\nthen, opening quickly the door of a large closet instead of that\r\nleading to the staircase, he buried himself amid the robes and dressing\r\ngowns of Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kitty.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had secured the key, shut himself up in the closet\r\nwithout reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, in a sharp voice. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you asleep, that you don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nanswer when I ring?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan heard the door of communication opened violently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere am I, Milady, here am I!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kitty, springing forward to meet\r\nher mistress.\r\n\r\nBoth went into the bedroom, and as the door of communication remained\r\nopen, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could hear Milady for some time scolding her maid. She\r\nwas at length appeased, and the conversation turned upon him while\r\nKitty was assisting her mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cI have not seen our Gascon this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Milady! has he not come?\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty. \xe2\x80\x9cCan he be inconstant\r\nbefore being happy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; he must have been prevented by Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville or\r\nMonsieur Dessessart. I understand my game, Kitty; I have this one\r\nsafe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will you do with him, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat will I do with him? Be easy, Kitty, there is something between\r\nthat man and me that he is quite ignorant of: he nearly made me lose my\r\ncredit with his Eminence. Oh, I will be revenged!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believed that Madame loved him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love him? I detest him! An idiot, who held the life of Lord de\r\nWinter in his hands and did not kill him, by which I missed three\r\nhundred thousand livres\xe2\x80\x99 income.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty; \xe2\x80\x9cyour son was the only heir of his uncle,\r\nand until his majority you would have had the enjoyment of his\r\nfortune.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan shuddered to the marrow at hearing this suave creature\r\nreproach him, with that sharp voice which she took such pains to\r\nconceal in conversation, for not having killed a man whom he had seen\r\nload her with kindnesses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor all this,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cI should long ago have revenged\r\nmyself on him if, and I don\xe2\x80\x99t know why, the cardinal had not requested\r\nme to conciliate him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes; but Madame has not conciliated that little woman he was so\r\nfond of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, the mercer\xe2\x80\x99s wife of the Rue des Fossoyeurs? Has he not already\r\nforgotten she ever existed? Fine vengeance that, on my faith!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA cold sweat broke from D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s brow. Why, this woman was a\r\nmonster! He resumed his listening, but unfortunately the toilet was\r\nfinished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cgo into your own room, and tomorrow\r\nendeavor again to get me an answer to the letter I gave you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor Monsieur de Wardes?\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure; for Monsieur de Wardes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, there is one,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cwho appears to me quite a different\r\nsort of a man from that poor Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to bed, mademoiselle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like comments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan heard the door close; then the noise of two bolts by which\r\nMilady fastened herself in. On her side, but as softly as possible,\r\nKitty turned the key of the lock, and then D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan opened the closet\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, good Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is the matter with\r\nyou? How pale you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe abominable creature,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, silence, begone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is nothing but a\r\nwainscot between my chamber and Milady\xe2\x80\x99s; every word that is uttered in\r\none can be heard in the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s exactly the reason I won\xe2\x80\x99t go,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, blushing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr, at least, I will go\xe2\x80\x94later.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew Kitty to him. She had the less motive to resist, resistance\r\nwould make so much noise. Therefore Kitty surrendered.\r\n\r\nIt was a movement of vengeance upon Milady. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan believed it\r\nright to say that vengeance is the pleasure of the gods. With a little\r\nmore heart, he might have been contented with this new conquest; but\r\nthe principal features of his character were ambition and pride. It\r\nmust, however, be confessed in his justification that the first use he\r\nmade of his influence over Kitty was to try and find out what had\r\nbecome of Mme. Bonacieux; but the poor girl swore upon the crucifix to\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that she was entirely ignorant on that head, her mistress\r\nnever admitting her into half her secrets\xe2\x80\x94only she believed she could\r\nsay she was not dead.\r\n\r\nAs to the cause which was near making Milady lose her credit with the\r\ncardinal, Kitty knew nothing about it; but this time D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was\r\nbetter informed than she was. As he had seen Milady on board a vessel\r\nat the moment he was leaving England, he suspected that it was, almost\r\nwithout a doubt, on account of the diamond studs.\r\n\r\nBut what was clearest in all this was that the true hatred, the\r\nprofound hatred, the inveterate hatred of Milady, was increased by his\r\nnot having killed her brother-in-law.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan came the next day to Milady\xe2\x80\x99s, and finding her in a very\r\nill-humor, had no doubt that it was lack of an answer from M. de Wardes\r\nthat provoked her thus. Kitty came in, but Milady was very cross with\r\nher. The poor girl ventured a glance at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan which said, \xe2\x80\x9cSee how\r\nI suffer on your account!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nToward the end of the evening, however, the beautiful lioness became\r\nmilder; she smilingly listened to the soft speeches of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and\r\neven gave him her hand to kiss.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan departed, scarcely knowing what to think, but as he was a\r\nyouth who did not easily lose his head, while continuing to pay his\r\ncourt to Milady, he had framed a little plan in his mind.\r\n\r\nHe found Kitty at the gate, and, as on the preceding evening, went up\r\nto her chamber. Kitty had been accused of negligence and severely\r\nscolded. Milady could not at all comprehend the silence of the Comte de\r\nWardes, and she ordered Kitty to come at nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning to\r\ntake a third letter.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan made Kitty promise to bring him that letter on the following\r\nmorning. The poor girl promised all her lover desired; she was mad.\r\n\r\nThings passed as on the night before. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan concealed himself in\r\nhis closet; Milady called, undressed, sent away Kitty, and shut the\r\ndoor. As the night before, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan did not return home till five\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning.\r\n\r\nAt eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock Kitty came to him. She held in her hand a fresh\r\nbillet from Milady. This time the poor girl did not even argue with\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; she gave it to him at once. She belonged body and soul to\r\nher handsome soldier.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan opened the letter and read as follows:\r\n\r\nThis is the third time I have written to you to tell you that I love\r\nyou. Beware that I do not write to you a fourth time to tell you that I\r\ndetest you.\r\n    If you repent of the manner in which you have acted toward me, the\r\n    young girl who brings you this will tell you how a man of spirit\r\n    may obtain his pardon.\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan colored and grew pale several times in reading this billet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you love her still,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, who had not taken her eyes off\r\nthe young man\xe2\x80\x99s countenance for an instant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Kitty, you are mistaken. I do not love her, but I will avenge\r\nmyself for her contempt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, I know what sort of vengeance! You told me that!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat matters it to you, Kitty? You know it is you alone whom I love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the scorn I will throw upon her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took a pen and wrote:\r\n\r\nMADAME, Until the present moment I could not believe that it was to me\r\nyour first two letters were addressed, so unworthy did I feel myself of\r\nsuch an honor; besides, I was so seriously indisposed that I could not\r\nin any case have replied to them.\r\n    But now I am forced to believe in the excess of your kindness,\r\n    since not only your letter but your servant assures me that I have\r\n    the good fortune to be beloved by you.\r\n    She has no occasion to teach me the way in which a man of spirit\r\n    may obtain his pardon. I will come and ask mine at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock\r\n    this evening.\r\n    To delay it a single day would be in my eyes now to commit a fresh\r\n    offense.\r\n    From him whom you have rendered the happiest of men,\r\n\r\n\r\nCOMTE DE WARDES\r\n\r\n\r\nThis note was in the first place a forgery; it was likewise an\r\nindelicacy. It was even, according to our present manners, something\r\nlike an infamous action; but at that period people did not manage\r\naffairs as they do today.
