Besides, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan from her own admission\r\nknew Milady culpable of treachery in matters more important, and could\r\nentertain no respect for her. And yet, notwithstanding this want of\r\nrespect, he felt an uncontrollable passion for this woman boiling in\r\nhis veins\xe2\x80\x94passion drunk with contempt; but passion or thirst, as the\r\nreader pleases.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s plan was very simple. By Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s chamber he could gain\r\nthat of her mistress. He would take advantage of the first moment of\r\nsurprise, shame, and terror, to triumph over her. He might fail, but\r\nsomething must be left to chance. In eight days the campaign would\r\nopen, and he would be compelled to leave Paris; D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had no time\r\nfor a prolonged love siege.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, handing Kitty the letter sealed; \xe2\x80\x9cgive\r\nthat to Milady. It is the count\xe2\x80\x99s reply.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Kitty became as pale as death; she suspected what the letter\r\ncontained.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, my dear girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cyou cannot but perceive that\r\nall this must end, some way or other. Milady may discover that you gave\r\nthe first billet to my lackey instead of to the count\xe2\x80\x99s; that it is I\r\nwho have opened the others which ought to have been opened by de\r\nWardes. Milady will then turn you out of doors, and you know she is not\r\nthe woman to limit her vengeance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cfor whom have I exposed myself to all that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor me, I well know, my sweet girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I am\r\ngrateful, I swear to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what does this note contain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMilady will tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you do not love me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am very wretched.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo this reproach there is always one response which deludes women.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan replied in such a manner that Kitty remained in her great\r\ndelusion. Although she cried freely before deciding to transmit the\r\nletter to her mistress, she did at last so decide, which was all\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan wished. Finally he promised that he would leave her\r\nmistress\xe2\x80\x99s presence at an early hour that evening, and that when he\r\nleft the mistress he would ascend with the maid. This promise completed\r\npoor Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s consolation.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXIV.\r\nIN WHICH THE EQUIPMENT OF ARAMIS AND PORTHOS IS TREATED OF\r\n\r\n\r\nSince the four friends had been each in search of his equipments, there\r\nhad been no fixed meeting between them. They dined apart from one\r\nanother, wherever they might happen to be, or rather where they could.\r\nDuty likewise on its part took a portion of that precious time which\r\nwas gliding away so rapidly\xe2\x80\x94only they had agreed to meet once a week,\r\nabout one o\xe2\x80\x99clock, at the residence of Athos, seeing that he, in\r\nagreement with the vow he had formed, did not pass over the threshold\r\nof his door.\r\n\r\nThis day of reunion was the same day as that on which Kitty came to\r\nfind D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. Soon as Kitty left him, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan directed his steps\r\ntoward the Rue F\xc3\xa9rou.\r\n\r\nHe found Athos and Aramis philosophizing. Aramis had some slight\r\ninclination to resume the cassock. Athos, according to his system,\r\nneither encouraged nor dissuaded him. Athos believed that everyone\r\nshould be left to his own free will. He never gave advice but when it\r\nwas asked, and even then he required to be asked twice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPeople, in general,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9conly ask advice not to follow it; or if\r\nthey do follow it, it is for the sake of having someone to blame for\r\nhaving given it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos arrived a minute after D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. The four friends were\r\nreunited.\r\n\r\nThe four countenances expressed four different feelings: that of\r\nPorthos, tranquillity; that of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, hope; that of Aramis,\r\nuneasiness; that of Athos, carelessness.\r\n\r\nAt the end of a moment\xe2\x80\x99s conversation, in which Porthos hinted that a\r\nlady of elevated rank had condescended to relieve him from his\r\nembarrassment, Mousqueton entered. He came to request his master to\r\nreturn to his lodgings, where his presence was urgent, as he piteously\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it my equipment?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes and no,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mousqueton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but can\xe2\x80\x99t you speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, monsieur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos rose, saluted his friends, and followed Mousqueton. An instant\r\nafter, Bazin made his appearance at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want with me, my friend?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, with that mildness\r\nof language which was observable in him every time that his ideas were\r\ndirected toward the Church.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man wishes to see Monsieur at home,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Bazin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man! What man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mendicant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive him alms, Bazin, and bid him pray for a poor sinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis mendicant insists upon speaking to you, and pretends that you\r\nwill be very glad to see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas he sent no particular message for me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes. If Monsieur Aramis hesitates to come,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9ctell him I am\r\nfrom Tours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom Tours!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cA thousand pardons, gentlemen; but no\r\ndoubt this man brings me the news I expected.\xe2\x80\x9d And rising also, he went\r\noff at a quick pace. There remained Athos and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe these fellows have managed their business. What do you\r\nthink, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know that Porthos was in a fair way,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cand as to\r\nAramis to tell you the truth, I have never been seriously uneasy on his\r\naccount. But you, my dear Athos\xe2\x80\x94you, who so generously distributed the\r\nEnglishman\xe2\x80\x99s pistoles, which were our legitimate property\xe2\x80\x94what do you\r\nmean to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am satisfied with having killed that fellow, my boy, seeing that it\r\nis blessed bread to kill an Englishman; but if I had pocketed his\r\npistoles, they would have weighed me down like a remorse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to, my dear Athos; you have truly inconceivable ideas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it pass. What do you think of Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville telling me,\r\nwhen he did me the honor to call upon me yesterday, that you associated\r\nwith the suspected English, whom the cardinal protects?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, I visit an Englishwoman\xe2\x80\x94the one I named.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, ay! the fair woman on whose account I gave you advice, which\r\nnaturally you took care not to adopt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI gave you my reasons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you look there for your outfit, I think you said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all. I have acquired certain knowledge that that woman was\r\nconcerned in the abduction of Madame Bonacieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I understand now: to find one woman, you court another. It is the\r\nlongest road, but certainly the most amusing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was on the point of telling Athos all; but one consideration\r\nrestrained him. Athos was a gentleman, punctilious in points of honor;\r\nand there were in the plan which our lover had devised for Milady, he\r\nwas sure, certain things that would not obtain the assent of this\r\nPuritan. He was therefore silent; and as Athos was the least\r\ninquisitive of any man on earth, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s confidence stopped there.\r\nWe will therefore leave the two friends, who had nothing important to\r\nsay to each other, and follow Aramis.\r\n\r\nUpon being informed that the person who wanted to speak to him came\r\nfrom Tours, we have seen with what rapidity the young man followed, or\r\nrather went before, Bazin; he ran without stopping from the Rue F\xc3\xa9rou\r\nto the Rue de Vaugirard. On entering he found a man of short stature\r\nand intelligent eyes, but covered with rags.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have asked for me?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to speak with Monsieur Aramis. Is that your name, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy very own. You have brought me something?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, if you show me a certain embroidered handkerchief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, taking a small key from his breast and\r\nopening a little ebony box inlaid with mother of pearl, \xe2\x80\x9chere it is.\r\nLook.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is right,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the mendicant; \xe2\x80\x9cdismiss your lackey.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, Bazin, curious to know what the mendicant could want with his\r\nmaster, kept pace with him as well as he could, and arrived almost at\r\nthe same time he did; but his quickness was not of much use to him. At\r\nthe hint from the mendicant his master made him a sign to retire, and\r\nhe was obliged to obey.\r\n\r\nBazin gone, the mendicant cast a rapid glance around him in order to be\r\nsure that nobody could either see or hear him, and opening his ragged\r\nvest, badly held together by a leather strap, he began to rip the upper\r\npart of his doublet, from which he drew a letter.\r\n\r\nAramis uttered a cry of joy at the sight of the seal, kissed the\r\nsuperscription with an almost religious respect, and opened the\r\nepistle, which contained what follows:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Friend, it is the will of fate that we should be still for some\r\ntime separated; but the delightful days of youth are not lost beyond\r\nreturn. Perform your duty in camp; I will do mine elsewhere. Accept\r\nthat which the bearer brings you; make the campaign like a handsome\r\ntrue gentleman, and think of me, who kisses tenderly your black eyes.\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAdieu; or rather, _au revoir_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe mendicant continued to rip his garments; and drew from amid his\r\nrags a hundred and fifty Spanish double pistoles, which he laid down on\r\nthe table; then he opened the door, bowed, and went out before the\r\nyoung man, stupefied by his letter, had ventured to address a word to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nAramis then reperused the letter, and perceived a postscript:\r\n\r\nPS. You may behave politely to the bearer, who is a count and a grandee\r\nof Spain!\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGolden dreams!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, beautiful life! Yes, we are young;\r\nyes, we shall yet have happy days! My love, my blood, my life! all,\r\nall, all, are thine, my adored mistress!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he kissed the letter with passion, without even vouchsafing a look\r\nat the gold which sparkled on the table.\r\n\r\nBazin scratched at the door, and as Aramis had no longer any reason to\r\nexclude him, he bade him come in.\r\n\r\nBazin was stupefied at the sight of the gold, and forgot that he came\r\nto announce D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, curious to know who the mendicant could\r\nbe, came to Aramis on leaving Athos.\r\n\r\nNow, as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan used no ceremony with Aramis, seeing that Bazin\r\nforgot to announce him, he announced himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! my dear Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cif these are the prunes\r\nthat are sent to you from Tours, I beg you will make my compliments to\r\nthe gardener who gathers them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken, friend D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, always on his\r\nguard; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is from my publisher, who has just sent me the price of\r\nthat poem in one-syllable verse which I began yonder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, your publisher is very generous,\r\nmy dear Aramis, that\xe2\x80\x99s all I can say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Bazin, \xe2\x80\x9ca poem sell so dear as that! It is\r\nincredible! Oh, monsieur, you can write as much as you like; you may\r\nbecome equal to Monsieur de Voiture and Monsieur de Benserade. I like\r\nthat. A poet is as good as an abb\xc3\xa9. Ah! Monsieur Aramis, become a poet,\r\nI beg of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBazin, my friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe you meddle with my\r\nconversation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBazin perceived he was wrong; he bowed and went out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cyou sell your productions at their\r\nweight in gold. You are very fortunate, my friend; but take care or you\r\nwill lose that letter which is peeping from your doublet, and which\r\nalso comes, no doubt, from your publisher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis blushed to the eyes, crammed in the letter, and re-buttoned his\r\ndoublet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cif you please, we will join our\r\nfriends; as I am rich, we will today begin to dine together again,\r\nexpecting that you will be rich in your turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with great pleasure. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is long since we\r\nhave had a good dinner; and I, for my part, have a somewhat hazardous\r\nexpedition for this evening, and shall not be sorry, I confess, to\r\nfortify myself with a few glasses of good old Burgundy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAgreed, as to the old Burgundy; I have no objection to that,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAramis, from whom the letter and the gold had removed, as by magic, his\r\nideas of conversion.\r\n\r\nAnd having put three or four double pistoles into his pocket to answer\r\nthe needs of the moment, he placed the others in the ebony box, inlaid\r\nwith mother of pearl, in which was the famous handkerchief which served\r\nhim as a talisman.\r\n\r\nThe two friends repaired to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s, and he, faithful to his vow of not\r\ngoing out, took upon him to order dinner to be brought to them. As he\r\nwas perfectly acquainted with the details of gastronomy, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and\r\nAramis made no objection to abandoning this important care to him.\r\n\r\nThey went to find Porthos, and at the corner of the Rue Bac met\r\nMousqueton, who, with a most pitiable air, was driving before him a\r\nmule and a horse.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan uttered a cry of surprise, which was not quite free from\r\njoy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my yellow horse,\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cAramis, look at that horse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the frightful brute!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cupon that very horse I came to\r\nParis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, does Monsieur know this horse?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mousqueton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is of an original color,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cI never saw one with such a\r\nhide in my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can well believe it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand that was why I got\r\nthree crowns for him. It must have been for his hide, for, _certes_,\r\nthe carcass is not worth eighteen livres. But how did this horse come\r\ninto your hands, Mousqueton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray,\xe2\x80\x9d said the lackey, \xe2\x80\x9csay nothing about it, monsieur; it is a\r\nfrightful trick of the husband of our duchess!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that, Mousqueton?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, we are looked upon with a rather favorable eye by a lady of\r\nquality, the Duchesse de\xe2\x80\x94but, your pardon; my master has commanded me\r\nto be discreet. She had forced us to accept a little souvenir, a\r\nmagnificent Spanish _genet_ and an Andalusian mule, which were\r\nbeautiful to look upon. The husband heard of the affair; on their way\r\nhe confiscated the two magnificent beasts which were being sent to us,\r\nand substituted these horrible animals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich you are taking back to him?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Mousqueton. \xe2\x80\x9cYou may well believe that we will not\r\naccept such steeds as these in exchange for those which had been\r\npromised to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, _pardieu;_ though I should like to have seen Porthos on my yellow\r\nhorse. That would give me an idea of how I looked when I arrived in\r\nParis. But don\xe2\x80\x99t let us hinder you, Mousqueton; go and perform your\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s orders. Is he at home?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mousqueton, \xe2\x80\x9cbut in a very ill humor. Get up!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe continued his way toward the Quai des Grands Augustins, while the\r\ntwo friends went to ring at the bell of the unfortunate Porthos. He,\r\nhaving seen them crossing the yard, took care not to answer, and they\r\nrang in vain.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile Mousqueton continued on his way, and crossing the Pont Neuf,\r\nstill driving the two sorry animals before him, he reached the Rue aux\r\nOurs. Arrived there, he fastened, according to the orders of his\r\nmaster, both horse and mule to the knocker of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s door;\r\nthen, without taking any thought for their future, he returned to\r\nPorthos, and told him that his commission was completed.\r\n\r\nIn a short time the two unfortunate beasts, who had not eaten anything\r\nsince the morning, made such a noise in raising and letting fall the\r\nknocker that the procurator ordered his errand boy to go and inquire in\r\nthe neighborhood to whom this horse and mule belonged.\r\n\r\nMme. Coquenard recognized her present, and could not at first\r\ncomprehend this restitution; but the visit of Porthos soon enlightened\r\nher. The anger which fired the eyes of the Musketeer, in spite of his\r\nefforts to suppress it, terrified his sensitive inamorata. In fact,\r\nMousqueton had not concealed from his master that he had met D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nand Aramis, and that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan in the yellow horse had recognized the\r\nB\xc3\xa9arnese pony upon which he had come to Paris, and which he had sold\r\nfor three crowns.\r\n\r\nPorthos went away after having appointed a meeting with the\r\nprocurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife in the cloister of St. Magloire. The procurator,\r\nseeing he was going, invited him to dinner\xe2\x80\x94an invitation which the\r\nMusketeer refused with a majestic air.\r\n\r\nMme. Coquenard repaired trembling to the cloister of St. Magloire, for\r\nshe guessed the reproaches that awaited her there; but she was\r\nfascinated by the lofty airs of Porthos.\r\n\r\nAll that which a man wounded in his self-love could let fall in the\r\nshape of imprecations and reproaches upon the head of a woman Porthos\r\nlet fall upon the bowed head of the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI did all for the best! One of our clients is a\r\nhorsedealer; he owes money to the office, and is backward in his pay. I\r\ntook the mule and the horse for what he owed us; he assured me that\r\nthey were two noble steeds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cif he owed you more than five crowns,\r\nyour horsedealer is a thief.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no harm in trying to buy things cheap, Monsieur Porthos,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife, seeking to excuse herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame; but they who so assiduously try to buy things cheap ought\r\nto permit others to seek more generous friends.\xe2\x80\x9d And Porthos, turning\r\non his heel, made a step to retire.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos! Monsieur Porthos!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nhave been wrong; I see it. I ought not to have driven a bargain when it\r\nwas to equip a cavalier like you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos, without reply, retreated a second step. The procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife\r\nfancied she saw him in a brilliant cloud, all surrounded by duchesses\r\nand marchionesses, who cast bags of money at his feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop, in the name of heaven, Monsieur Porthos!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she. \xe2\x80\x9cStop, and\r\nlet us talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTalking with you brings me misfortune,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, tell me, what do you ask?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing; for that amounts to the same thing as if I asked you for\r\nsomething.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe procurator\xe2\x80\x99s wife hung upon the arm of Porthos, and in the violence\r\nof her grief she cried out, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Porthos, I am ignorant of all\r\nsuch matters! How should I know what a horse is? How should I know what\r\nhorse furniture is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should have left it to me, then, madame, who know what they are;\r\nbut you wished to be frugal, and consequently to lend at usury.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was wrong, Monsieur Porthos; but I will repair that wrong, upon my\r\nword of honor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow so?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the Musketeer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen. This evening M. Coquenard is going to the house of the Duc de\r\nChaulnes, who has sent for him. It is for a consultation, which will\r\nlast three hours at least. Come! We shall be alone, and can make up our\r\naccounts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn good time. Now you talk, my dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou pardon me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, majestically; and the two separated\r\nsaying, \xe2\x80\x9cTill this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d thought Porthos, as he walked away, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears I am\r\ngetting nearer to Monsieur Coquenard\xe2\x80\x99s strongbox at last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXV.\r\nA GASCON A MATCH FOR CUPID\r\n\r\n\r\nThe evening so impatiently waited for by Porthos and by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at\r\nlast arrived.\r\n\r\nAs was his custom, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan presented himself at Milady\xe2\x80\x99s at about\r\nnine o\xe2\x80\x99clock. He found her in a charming humor. Never had he been so\r\nwell received. Our Gascon knew, by the first glance of his eye, that\r\nhis billet had been delivered, and that this billet had had its effect.\r\n\r\nKitty entered to bring some sherbet. Her mistress put on a charming\r\nface, and smiled on her graciously; but alas! the poor girl was so sad\r\nthat she did not even notice Milady\xe2\x80\x99s condescension.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan looked at the two women, one after the other, and was forced\r\nto acknowledge that in his opinion Dame Nature had made a mistake in\r\ntheir formation. To the great lady she had given a heart vile and\r\nvenal; to the _soubrette_ she had given the heart of a duchess.\r\n\r\nAt ten o\xe2\x80\x99clock Milady began to appear restless. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan knew what\r\nshe wanted. She looked at the clock, rose, reseated herself, smiled at\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan with an air which said, \xe2\x80\x9cYou are very amiable, no doubt, but\r\nyou would be _charming_ if you would only depart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rose and took his hat; Milady gave him her hand to kiss. The\r\nyoung man felt her press his hand, and comprehended that this was a\r\nsentiment, not of coquetry, but of gratitude because of his departure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe loves him devilishly,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. Then he went out.\r\n\r\nThis time Kitty was nowhere waiting for him; neither in the\r\nantechamber, nor in the corridor, nor beneath the great door. It was\r\nnecessary that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan should find alone the staircase and the\r\nlittle chamber. She heard him enter, but she did not raise her head.\r\nThe young man went to her and took her hands; then she sobbed aloud.\r\n\r\nAs D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had presumed, on receiving his letter, Milady in a\r\ndelirium of joy had told her servant everything; and by way of\r\nrecompense for the manner in which she had this time executed the\r\ncommission, she had given Kitty a purse.\r\n\r\nReturning to her own room, Kitty had thrown the purse into a corner,\r\nwhere it lay open, disgorging three or four gold pieces on the carpet.\r\nThe poor girl, under the caresses of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, lifted her head.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan himself was frightened by the change in her countenance. She\r\njoined her hands with a suppliant air, but without venturing to speak a\r\nword. As little sensitive as was the heart of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he was\r\ntouched by this mute sorrow; but he held too tenaciously to his\r\nprojects, above all to this one, to change the program which he had\r\nlaid out in advance. He did not therefore allow her any hope that he\r\nwould flinch; only he represented his action as one of simple\r\nvengeance.\r\n\r\nFor the rest this vengeance was very easy; for Milady, doubtless to\r\nconceal her blushes from her lover, had ordered Kitty to extinguish all\r\nthe lights in the apartment, and even in the little chamber itself.\r\nBefore daybreak M. de Wardes must take his departure, still in\r\nobscurity.\r\n\r\nPresently they heard Milady retire to her room. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan slipped into\r\nthe wardrobe. Hardly was he concealed when the little bell sounded.\r\nKitty went to her mistress, and did not leave the door open; but the\r\npartition was so thin that one could hear nearly all that passed\r\nbetween the two women.\r\n\r\nMilady seemed overcome with joy, and made Kitty repeat the smallest\r\ndetails of the pretended interview of the _soubrette_ with De Wardes\r\nwhen he received the letter; how he had responded; what was the\r\nexpression of his face; if he seemed very amorous. And to all these\r\nquestions poor Kitty, forced to put on a pleasant face, responded in a\r\nstifled voice whose dolorous accent her mistress did not however\r\nremark, solely because happiness is egotistical.\r\n\r\nFinally, as the hour for her interview with the count approached,\r\nMilady had everything about her darkened, and ordered Kitty to return\r\nto her own chamber, and introduce De Wardes whenever he presented\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nKitty\xe2\x80\x99s detention was not long. Hardly had D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan seen, through a\r\ncrevice in his closet, that the whole apartment was in obscurity, than\r\nhe slipped out of his concealment, at the very moment when Kitty\r\nreclosed the door of communication.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that noise?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is I,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan in a subdued voice, \xe2\x80\x9cI, the Comte de\r\nWardes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9che has not even waited for the\r\nhour he himself named!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in a trembling voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy do you not enter?\r\nCount, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d added she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know that I wait for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this appeal D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan drew Kitty quietly away, and slipped into the\r\nchamber.\r\n\r\nIf rage or sorrow ever torture the heart, it is when a lover receives\r\nunder a name which is not his own protestations of love addressed to\r\nhis happy rival. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was in a dolorous situation which he had\r\nnot foreseen. Jealousy gnawed his heart; and he suffered almost as much\r\nas poor Kitty, who at that very moment was crying in the next chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Count,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in her softest voice, and pressing his hand\r\nin her own, \xe2\x80\x9cI am happy in the love which your looks and your words\r\nhave expressed to me every time we have met. I also\xe2\x80\x94I love you. Oh,\r\ntomorrow, tomorrow, I must have some pledge from you which will prove\r\nthat you think of me; and that you may not forget me, take this!\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nshe slipped a ring from her finger onto D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nremembered having seen this ring on the finger of Milady; it was a\r\nmagnificent sapphire, encircled with brilliants.\r\n\r\nThe first movement of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was to return it, but Milady added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no! Keep that ring for love of me. Besides, in accepting it,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nadded, in a voice full of emotion, \xe2\x80\x9cyou render me a much greater\r\nservice than you imagine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis woman is full of mysteries,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself. At\r\nthat instant he felt himself ready to reveal all. He even opened his\r\nmouth to tell Milady who he was, and with what a revengeful purpose he\r\nhad come; but she added, \xe2\x80\x9cPoor angel, whom that monster of a Gascon\r\nbarely failed to kill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe monster was himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cdo your wounds still make you suffer?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, much,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who did not well know how to answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe tranquil,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cI will avenge you\xe2\x80\x94and cruelly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Peste!_\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cthe moment for confidences has\r\nnot yet come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt took some time for D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to resume this little dialogue; but\r\nthen all the ideas of vengeance which he had brought with him had\r\ncompletely vanished. This woman exercised over him an unaccountable\r\npower; he hated and adored her at the same time. He would not have\r\nbelieved that two sentiments so opposite could dwell in the same heart,\r\nand by their union constitute a passion so strange, and as it were,\r\ndiabolical.\r\n\r\nPresently it sounded one o\xe2\x80\x99clock. It was necessary to separate.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at the moment of quitting Milady felt only the liveliest\r\nregret at the parting; and as they addressed each other in a\r\nreciprocally passionate adieu, another interview was arranged for the\r\nfollowing week.\r\n\r\nPoor Kitty hoped to speak a few words to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan when he passed\r\nthrough her chamber; but Milady herself reconducted him through the\r\ndarkness, and only quit him at the staircase.\r\n\r\nThe next morning D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan ran to find Athos. He was engaged in an\r\nadventure so singular that he wished for counsel. He therefore told him\r\nall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Milady,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cappears to be an infamous creature, but not\r\nthe less you have done wrong to deceive her. In one fashion or another\r\nyou have a terrible enemy on your hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile thus speaking Athos regarded with attention the sapphire set with\r\ndiamonds which had taken, on D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s finger, the place of the\r\nqueen\xe2\x80\x99s ring, carefully kept in a casket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou notice my ring?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Gascon, proud to display so rich a gift\r\nin the eyes of his friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cit reminds me of a family jewel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is beautiful, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cmagnificent. I did not think two sapphires of such\r\na fine water existed. Have you traded it for your diamond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. It is a gift from my beautiful Englishwoman, or rather\r\nFrenchwoman\xe2\x80\x94for I am convinced she was born in France, though I have\r\nnot questioned her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat ring comes from Milady?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, with a voice in which it\r\nwas easy to detect strong emotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer very self; she gave it me last night. Here it is,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, taking it from his finger.\r\n\r\nAthos examined it and became very pale. He tried it on his left hand;\r\nit fit his finger as if made for it.\r\n\r\nA shade of anger and vengeance passed across the usually calm brow of\r\nthis gentleman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible it can be she,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cHow could this ring come\r\ninto the hands of Milady Clarik? And yet it is difficult to suppose\r\nsuch a resemblance should exist between two jewels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know this ring?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I did,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cbut no doubt I was mistaken.\xe2\x80\x9d And he\r\nreturned D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan the ring without, however, ceasing to look at it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPray, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, after a minute, \xe2\x80\x9ceither take off that\r\nring or turn the mounting inside; it recalls such cruel recollections\r\nthat I shall have no head to converse with you. Don\xe2\x80\x99t ask me for\r\ncounsel; don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me you are perplexed what to do. But stop! let me\r\nlook at that sapphire again; the one I mentioned to you had one of its\r\nfaces scratched by accident.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took off the ring, giving it again to Athos.\r\n\r\nAthos started. \xe2\x80\x9cLook,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis it not strange?\xe2\x80\x9d and he pointed out\r\nto D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan the scratch he had remembered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut from whom did this ring come to you, Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom my mother, who inherited it from her mother. As I told you, it is\r\nan old family jewel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you\xe2\x80\x94sold it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, hesitatingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, with a singular smile. \xe2\x80\x9cI gave it away in a night\r\nof love, as it has been given to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan became pensive in his turn; it appeared as if there were\r\nabysses in Milady\xe2\x80\x99s soul whose depths were dark and unknown. He took\r\nback the ring, but put it in his pocket and not on his finger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, taking his hand, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know I love you; if I\r\nhad a son I could not love him better. Take my advice, renounce this\r\nwoman. I do not know her, but a sort of intuition tells me she is a\r\nlost creature, and that there is something fatal about her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI will have done with her. I own\r\nthat this woman terrifies me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall you have the courage?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cand instantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth, my young friend, you will act rightly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the gentleman,\r\npressing the Gascon\xe2\x80\x99s hand with an affection almost paternal; \xe2\x80\x9cand God\r\ngrant that this woman, who has scarcely entered into your life, may not\r\nleave a terrible trace in it!\xe2\x80\x9d And Athos bowed to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan like a man\r\nwho wishes it understood that he would not be sorry to be left alone\r\nwith his thoughts.\r\n\r\nOn reaching home D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan found Kitty waiting for him. A month of\r\nfever could not have changed her more than this one night of\r\nsleeplessness and sorrow.\r\n\r\nShe was sent by her mistress to the false De Wardes. Her mistress was\r\nmad with love, intoxicated with joy. She wished to know when her lover\r\nwould meet her a second night; and poor Kitty, pale and trembling,\r\nawaited D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s reply. The counsels of his friend, joined to the\r\ncries of his own heart, made him determine, now his pride was saved and\r\nhis vengeance satisfied, not to see Milady again. As a reply, he wrote\r\nthe following letter:\r\n\r\nDo not depend upon me, madame, for the next meeting. Since my\r\nconvalescence I have so many affairs of this kind on my hands that I am\r\nforced to regulate them a little. When your turn comes, I shall have\r\nthe honor to inform you of it. I kiss your hands.\r\n\r\n\r\nCOMTE DE WARDES\r\n\r\n\r\nNot a word about the sapphire. Was the Gascon determined to keep it as\r\na weapon against Milady, or else, let us be frank, did he not reserve\r\nthe sapphire as a last resource for his outfit? It would be wrong to\r\njudge the actions of one period from the point of view of another. That\r\nwhich would now be considered as disgraceful to a gentleman was at that\r\ntime quite a simple and natural affair, and the younger sons of the\r\nbest families were frequently supported by their mistresses. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\ngave the open letter to Kitty, who at first was unable to comprehend\r\nit, but who became almost wild with joy on reading it a second time.\r\nShe could scarcely believe in her happiness; and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was forced\r\nto renew with the living voice the assurances which he had written. And\r\nwhatever might be\xe2\x80\x94considering the violent character of Milady\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ndanger which the poor girl incurred in giving this billet to her\r\nmistress, she ran back to the Place Royale as fast as her legs could\r\ncarry her.\r\n\r\nThe heart of the best woman is pitiless toward the sorrows of a rival.\r\n\r\nMilady opened the letter with eagerness equal to Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s in bringing\r\nit; but at the first words she read she became livid. She crushed the\r\npaper in her hand, and turning with flashing eyes upon Kitty, she\r\ncried, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is this letter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe answer to Madame\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Kitty, all in a tremble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is impossible a gentleman could have\r\nwritten such a letter to a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d Then all at once, starting, she\r\ncried, \xe2\x80\x9cMy God! can he have\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d and she stopped. She ground her teeth;\r\nshe was of the color of ashes. She tried to go toward the window for\r\nair, but she could only stretch forth her arms; her legs failed her,\r\nand she sank into an armchair. Kitty, fearing she was ill, hastened\r\ntoward her and was beginning to open her dress; but Milady started up,\r\npushing her away. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want with me?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand why do you\r\nplace your hand on me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought that Madame was ill, and I wished to bring her help,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nresponded the maid, frightened at the terrible expression which had\r\ncome over her mistress\xe2\x80\x99s face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI faint? I? I? Do you take me for half a woman? When I am insulted I\r\ndo not faint; I avenge myself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she made a sign for Kitty to leave the room.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXVI.\r\nDREAM OF VENGEANCE\r\n\r\n\r\nThat evening Milady gave orders that when M. d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan came as usual,\r\nhe should be immediately admitted; but he did not come.\r\n\r\nThe next day Kitty went to see the young man again, and related to him\r\nall that had passed on the preceding evening. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan smiled; this\r\njealous anger of Milady was his revenge.\r\n\r\nThat evening Milady was still more impatient than on the preceding\r\nevening. She renewed the order relative to the Gascon; but as before\r\nshe expected him in vain.\r\n\r\nThe next morning, when Kitty presented herself at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s, she was\r\nno longer joyous and alert as on the two preceding days; but on the\r\ncontrary sad as death.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan asked the poor girl what was the matter with her; but she,\r\nas her only reply, drew a letter from her pocket and gave it to him.\r\n\r\nThis letter was in Milady\xe2\x80\x99s handwriting; only this time it was\r\naddressed to M. d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and not to M. de Wardes.\r\n\r\nHe opened it and read as follows:\r\n\r\nDEAR M. D\xe2\x80\x99ARTAGNAN, It is wrong thus to neglect your friends,\r\nparticularly at the moment you are about to leave them for so long a\r\ntime. My brother-in-law and myself expected you yesterday and the day\r\nbefore, but in vain. Will it be the same this evening?\r\n\r\n\r\nYour very grateful,\r\nMILADY CLARIK\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all very simple,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cI expected this letter. My\r\ncredit rises by the fall of that of the Comte de Wardes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd will you go?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Kitty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen to me, my dear girl,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Gascon, who sought for an excuse\r\nin his own eyes for breaking the promise he had made Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must\r\nunderstand it would be impolitic not to accept such a positive\r\ninvitation. Milady, not seeing me come again, would not be able to\r\nunderstand what could cause the interruption of my visits, and might\r\nsuspect something; who could say how far the vengeance of such a woman\r\nwould go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know how to represent things in such a\r\nway that you are always in the right. You are going now to pay your\r\ncourt to her again, and if this time you succeed in pleasing her in\r\nyour own name and with your own face, it will be much worse than\r\nbefore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nInstinct made poor Kitty guess a part of what was to happen. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nreassured her as well as he could, and promised to remain insensible to\r\nthe seductions of Milady.\r\n\r\nHe desired Kitty to tell her mistress that he could not be more\r\ngrateful for her kindnesses than he was, and that he would be obedient\r\nto her orders. He did not dare to write for fear of not being able\xe2\x80\x94to\r\nsuch experienced eyes as those of Milady\xe2\x80\x94to disguise his writing\r\nsufficiently.\r\n\r\nAs nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock sounded, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was at the Place Royale. It was\r\nevident that the servants who waited in the antechamber were warned,\r\nfor as soon as D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan appeared, before even he had asked if Milady\r\nwere visible, one of them ran to announce him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow him in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in a quick tone, but so piercing that\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan heard her in the antechamber.\r\n\r\nHe was introduced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am at home to nobody,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cobserve, to _nobody_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe servant went out.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan cast an inquiring glance at Milady. She was pale, and looked\r\nfatigued, either from tears or want of sleep. The number of lights had\r\nbeen intentionally diminished, but the young woman could not conceal\r\nthe traces of the fever which had devoured her for two days.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan approached her with his usual gallantry. She then made an\r\nextraordinary effort to receive him, but never did a more distressed\r\ncountenance give the lie to a more amiable smile.\r\n\r\nTo the questions which D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan put concerning her health, she\r\nreplied, \xe2\x80\x9cBad, very bad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cmy visit is ill-timed; you, no doubt, stand in\r\nneed of repose, and I will withdraw.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady. \xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary, stay, Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan;\r\nyour agreeable company will divert me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, oh!\xe2\x80\x9d thought D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cShe has never been so kind before. On\r\nguard!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady assumed the most agreeable air possible, and conversed with more\r\nthan her usual brilliancy. At the same time the fever, which for an\r\ninstant abandoned her, returned to give luster to her eyes, color to\r\nher cheeks, and vermillion to her lips. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was again in the\r\npresence of the Circe who had before surrounded him with her\r\nenchantments. His love, which he believed to be extinct but which was\r\nonly asleep, awoke again in his heart. Milady smiled, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nfelt that he could damn himself for that smile. There was a moment at\r\nwhich he felt something like remorse.\r\n\r\nBy degrees, Milady became more communicative. She asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan if\r\nhe had a mistress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with the most sentimental air he could assume,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccan you be cruel enough to put such a question to me\xe2\x80\x94to me, who, from\r\nthe moment I saw you, have only breathed and sighed through you and for\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady smiled with a strange smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you love me?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I any need to tell you so? Have you not perceived it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt may be; but you know the more hearts are worth the capture, the\r\nmore difficult they are to be won.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, difficulties do not affright me,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI shrink\r\nbefore nothing but impossibilities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing is impossible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cto true love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d thought D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cThe note is changed. Is she going to\r\nfall in love with me, by chance, this fair inconstant; and will she be\r\ndisposed to give me myself another sapphire like that which she gave me\r\nfor De Wardes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rapidly drew his seat nearer to Milady\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9clet us see what you would do to prove this love\r\nof which you speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll that could be required of me. Order; I am ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor everything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor everything,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who knew beforehand that he had not\r\nmuch to risk in engaging himself thus.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now let us talk a little seriously,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in her turn\r\ndrawing her armchair nearer to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all attention, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nMilady remained thoughtful and undecided for a moment; then, as if\r\nappearing to have formed a resolution, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have an enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, affecting surprise; \xe2\x80\x9cis that possible,\r\nmy God?\xe2\x80\x94good and beautiful as you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mortal enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn enemy who has insulted me so cruelly that between him and me it is\r\nwar to the death. May I reckon on you as an auxiliary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at once perceived the ground which the vindictive creature\r\nwished to reach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, with emphasis. \xe2\x80\x9cMy arm and my life belong\r\nto you, like my love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9csince you are as generous as you are loving\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe stopped.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, after a moment of silence, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom the present\r\ntime, cease to talk of impossibilities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not overwhelm me with happiness,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, throwing\r\nhimself on his knees, and covering with kisses the hands abandoned to\r\nhim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAvenge me of that infamous De Wardes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, between her teeth,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand I shall soon know how to get rid of you\xe2\x80\x94you double idiot, you\r\nanimated sword blade!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFall voluntarily into my arms, hypocritical and dangerous woman,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, likewise to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cafter having abused me with such\r\neffrontery, and afterward I will laugh at you with him whom you wish me\r\nto kill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan lifted up his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ready,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have understood me, then, dear Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could interpret one of your looks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you would employ for me your arm which has already acquired so\r\nmuch renown?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstantly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut on my part,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9chow should I repay such a service? I\r\nknow these lovers. They are men who do nothing for nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know the only reply that I desire,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthe only one\r\nworthy of you and of me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he drew nearer to her.\r\n\r\nShe scarcely resisted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInterested man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, smiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, really carried away by the passion this woman\r\nhad the power to kindle in his heart, \xe2\x80\x9cah, that is because my happiness\r\nappears so impossible to me; and I have such fear that it should fly\r\naway from me like a dream that I pant to make a reality of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, merit this pretended happiness, then!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am at your orders,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite certain?\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, with a last doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly name to me the base man that has brought tears into your\r\nbeautiful eyes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you that I had been weeping?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appeared to me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSuch women as I never weep,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much the better! Come, tell me his name!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember that his name is all my secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet I must know his name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you must; see what confidence I have in you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou overwhelm me with joy. What is his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is surely not one of my friends?\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, affecting\r\nhesitation in order to make her believe him ignorant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were one of your friends you would hesitate, then?\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nMilady; and a threatening glance darted from her eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot if it were my own brother!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, as if carried away\r\nby his enthusiasm.\r\n\r\nOur Gascon promised this without risk, for he knew all that was meant.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love your devotedness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, do you love nothing else in me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love you also, _you!_\xe2\x80\x9d said she, taking his hand.\r\n\r\nThe warm pressure made D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan tremble, as if by the touch that\r\nfever which consumed Milady attacked himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou love me, you!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, if that were so, I should lose my\r\nreason!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he folded her in his arms. She made no effort to remove her lips\r\nfrom his kisses; only she did not respond to them. Her lips were cold;\r\nit appeared to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that he had embraced a statue.\r\n\r\nHe was not the less intoxicated with joy, electrified by love. He\r\nalmost believed in the tenderness of Milady; he almost believed in the\r\ncrime of De Wardes. If De Wardes had at that moment been under his\r\nhand, he would have killed him.\r\n\r\nMilady seized the occasion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis name is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d said she, in her turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDe Wardes; I know it,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how do you know it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady, seizing both his hands, and\r\nendeavoring to read with her eyes to the bottom of his heart.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan felt he had allowed himself to be carried away, and that he\r\nhad committed an error.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me, tell me, tell me, I say,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Milady, \xe2\x80\x9chow do you know\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do I know it?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it because yesterday Monsieur de Wardes, in a saloon where I\r\nwas, showed a ring which he said he had received from you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWretch!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady.\r\n\r\nThe epithet, as may be easily understood, resounded to the very bottom\r\nof D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d continued she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will avenge you of this wretch,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, giving\r\nhimself the airs of Don Japhet of Armenia.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my brave friend!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cand when shall I be avenged?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow\xe2\x80\x94immediately\xe2\x80\x94when you please!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady was about to cry out, \xe2\x80\x9cImmediately,\xe2\x80\x9d but she reflected that such\r\nprecipitation would not be very gracious toward D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nBesides, she had a thousand precautions to take, a thousand counsels to\r\ngive to her defender, in order that he might avoid explanations with\r\nthe count before witnesses. All this was answered by an expression of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cTomorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will be avenged, or I shall be\r\ndead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will avenge me; but you will not be dead. He is a\r\ncoward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith women, perhaps; but not with men. I know something of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it seems you had not much reason to complain of your fortune in\r\nyour contest with him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortune is a courtesan; favorable yesterday, she may turn her back\r\ntomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich means that you now hesitate?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I do not hesitate; God forbid! But would it be just to allow me to\r\ngo to a possible death without having given me at least something more\r\nthan hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady answered by a glance which said, \xe2\x80\x9cIs that all?\xe2\x80\x94speak, then.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nthen accompanying the glance with explanatory words, \xe2\x80\x9cThat is but too\r\njust,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are an angel!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen all is agreed?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcept that which I ask of you, dear love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when I assure you that you may rely on my tenderness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot wait till tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence! I hear my brother. It will be useless for him to find you\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe rang the bell and Kitty appeared.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo out this way,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, opening a small private door, \xe2\x80\x9cand come\r\nback at eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock; we will then terminate this conversation. Kitty\r\nwill conduct you to my chamber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor girl almost fainted at hearing these words.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, mademoiselle, what are you thinking about, standing there like a\r\nstatue? Do as I bid you: show the chevalier out; and this evening at\r\neleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock\xe2\x80\x94you have heard what I said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears that these appointments are all made for eleven o\xe2\x80\x99clock,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthought D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a settled custom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady held out her hand to him, which he kissed tenderly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he retired as quickly as possible from the\r\nreproaches of Kitty, \xe2\x80\x9cI must not play the fool. This woman is certainly\r\na great liar. I must take care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXVII.\r\nMILADY\xe2\x80\x99S SECRET\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan left the h\xc3\xb4tel instead of going up at once to Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchamber, as she endeavored to persuade him to do\xe2\x80\x94and that for two\r\nreasons: the first, because by this means he should escape reproaches,\r\nrecriminations, and prayers; the second, because he was not sorry to\r\nhave an opportunity of reading his own thoughts and endeavoring, if\r\npossible, to fathom those of this woman.\r\n\r\nWhat was most clear in the matter was that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan loved Milady like\r\na madman, and that she did not love him at all. In an instant\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan perceived that the best way in which he could act would be\r\nto go home and write Milady a long letter, in which he would confess to\r\nher that he and De Wardes were, up to the present moment absolutely the\r\nsame, and that consequently he could not undertake, without committing\r\nsuicide, to kill the Comte de Wardes. But he also was spurred on by a\r\nferocious desire of vengeance. He wished to subdue this woman in his\r\nown name; and as this vengeance appeared to him to have a certain\r\nsweetness in it, he could not make up his mind to renounce it.\r\n\r\nHe walked six or seven times round the Place Royale, turning at every\r\nten steps to look at the light in Milady\xe2\x80\x99s apartment, which was to be\r\nseen through the blinds. It was evident that this time the young woman\r\nwas not in such haste to retire to her apartment as she had been the\r\nfirst.\r\n\r\nAt length the light disappeared. With this light was extinguished the\r\nlast irresolution in the heart of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. He recalled to his mind\r\nthe details of the first night, and with a beating heart and a brain on\r\nfire he re-entered the h\xc3\xb4tel and flew toward Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s chamber.\r\n\r\nThe poor girl, pale as death and trembling in all her limbs, wished to\r\ndelay her lover; but Milady, with her ear on the watch, had heard the\r\nnoise D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had made, and opening the door, said, \xe2\x80\x9cCome in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll this was of such incredible immodesty, of such monstrous\r\neffrontery, that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan could scarcely believe what he saw or what\r\nhe heard. He imagined himself to be drawn into one of those fantastic\r\nintrigues one meets in dreams. He, however, darted not the less quickly\r\ntoward Milady, yielding to that magnetic attraction which the loadstone\r\nexercises over iron.\r\n\r\nAs the door closed after them Kitty rushed toward it. Jealousy, fury,\r\noffended pride, all the passions in short that dispute the heart of an\r\noutraged woman in love, urged her to make a revelation; but she\r\nreflected that she would be totally lost if she confessed having\r\nassisted in such a machination, and above all, that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan would\r\nalso be lost to her forever. This last thought of love counseled her to\r\nmake this last sacrifice.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, on his part, had gained the summit of all his wishes. It\r\nwas no longer a rival who was beloved; it was himself who was\r\napparently beloved. A secret voice whispered to him, at the bottom of\r\nhis heart, that he was but an instrument of vengeance, that he was only\r\ncaressed till he had given death; but pride, but self-love, but madness\r\nsilenced this voice and stifled its murmurs. And then our Gascon, with\r\nthat large quantity of conceit which we know he possessed, compared\r\nhimself with De Wardes, and asked himself why, after all, he should not\r\nbe beloved for himself?\r\n\r\nHe was absorbed entirely by the sensations of the moment. Milady was no\r\nlonger for him that woman of fatal intentions who had for a moment\r\nterrified him; she was an ardent, passionate mistress, abandoning\r\nherself to love which she also seemed to feel. Two hours thus glided\r\naway. When the transports of the two lovers were calmer, Milady, who\r\nhad not the same motives for forgetfulness that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had, was the\r\nfirst to return to reality, and asked the young man if the means which\r\nwere on the morrow to bring on the encounter between him and De Wardes\r\nwere already arranged in his mind.\r\n\r\nBut D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, whose ideas had taken quite another course, forgot\r\nhimself like a fool, and answered gallantly that it was too late to\r\nthink about duels and sword thrusts.\r\n\r\nThis coldness toward the only interests that occupied her mind\r\nterrified Milady, whose questions became more pressing.\r\n\r\nThen D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had never seriously thought of this impossible\r\nduel, endeavored to turn the conversation; but he could not succeed.\r\nMilady kept him within the limits she had traced beforehand with her\r\nirresistible spirit and her iron will.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan fancied himself very cunning when advising Milady to\r\nrenounce, by pardoning De Wardes, the furious projects she had formed.\r\n\r\nBut at the first word the young woman started, and exclaimed in a\r\nsharp, bantering tone, which sounded strangely in the darkness, \xe2\x80\x9cAre\r\nyou afraid, dear Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot think so, dear love!\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut now, suppose\r\nthis poor Comte de Wardes were less guilty than you think him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt all events,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, seriously, \xe2\x80\x9che has deceived me, and from\r\nthe moment he deceived me, he merited death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall die, then, since you condemn him!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in so\r\nfirm a tone that it appeared to Milady an undoubted proof of devotion.\r\nThis reassured her.\r\n\r\nWe cannot say how long the night seemed to Milady, but D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nbelieved it to be hardly two hours before the daylight peeped through\r\nthe window blinds, and invaded the chamber with its paleness. Seeing\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan about to leave her, Milady recalled his promise to avenge\r\nher on the Comte de Wardes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am quite ready,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut in the first place I should\r\nlike to be certain of one thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is, whether you really love me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have given you proof of that, it seems to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am yours, body and soul!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThanks, my brave lover; but as you are satisfied of my love, you must,\r\nin your turn, satisfy me of yours. Is it not so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; but if you love me as much as you say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo you not entertain a little fear on my account?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have I to fear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, that I may be dangerously wounded\xe2\x80\x94killed even.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are such a valiant man, and such an\r\nexpert swordsman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would not, then, prefer a method,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwhich\r\nwould equally avenge you while rendering the combat useless?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady looked at her lover in silence. The pale light of the first rays\r\nof day gave to her clear eyes a strangely frightful expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe you now begin to hesitate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I do not hesitate; but I really pity this poor Comte de Wardes,\r\nsince you have ceased to love him. I think that a man must be so\r\nseverely punished by the loss of your love that he stands in need of no\r\nother chastisement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you that I loved him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady, sharply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least, I am now at liberty to believe, without too much fatuity,\r\nthat you love another,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man, in a caressing tone, \xe2\x80\x9cand I\r\nrepeat that I am really interested for the count.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why _you?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I alone know\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat he is far from being, or rather having been, so guilty toward you\r\nas he appears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in an anxious tone; \xe2\x80\x9cexplain yourself, for I\r\nreally cannot tell what you mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she looked at D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who embraced her tenderly, with eyes\r\nwhich seemed to burn themselves away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I am a man of honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, determined to come to an\r\nend, \xe2\x80\x9cand since your love is mine, and I am satisfied I possess it\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nI do possess it, do I not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEntirely; go on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I feel as if transformed\xe2\x80\x94a confession weighs on my mind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA confession!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had the least doubt of your love I would not make it, but you\r\nlove me, my beautiful mistress, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen if through excess of love I have rendered myself culpable toward\r\nyou, you will pardon me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan tried with his sweetest smile to touch his lips to Milady\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nbut she evaded him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis confession,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, growing paler, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is this confession?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou gave De Wardes a meeting on Thursday last in this very room, did\r\nyou not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no! It is not true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in a tone of voice so firm, and\r\nwith a countenance so unchanged, that if D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had not been in\r\nsuch perfect possession of the fact, he would have doubted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not lie, my angel,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, smiling; \xe2\x80\x9cthat would be\r\nuseless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean? Speak! you kill me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied; you are not guilty toward me, and I have already\r\npardoned you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat next? what next?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDe Wardes cannot boast of anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is that? You told me yourself that that ring\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat ring I have! The Comte de Wardes of Thursday and the D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nof today are the same person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe imprudent young man expected a surprise, mixed with shame\xe2\x80\x94a slight\r\nstorm which would resolve itself into tears; but he was strangely\r\ndeceived, and his error was not of long duration.\r\n\r\nPale and trembling, Milady repulsed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s attempted embrace by a\r\nviolent blow on the chest, as she sprang out of bed.\r\n\r\nIt was almost broad daylight.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan detained her by her night dress of fine India linen, to\r\nimplore her pardon; but she, with a strong movement, tried to escape.\r\nThen the cambric was torn from her beautiful shoulders; and on one of\r\nthose lovely shoulders, round and white, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan recognized, with\r\ninexpressible astonishment, the _fleur-de-lis_\xe2\x80\x94that indelible mark\r\nwhich the hand of the infamous executioner had imprinted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, loosing his hold of her dress, and\r\nremaining mute, motionless, and frozen.\r\n\r\nBut Milady felt herself denounced even by his terror. He had doubtless\r\nseen all. The young man now knew her secret, her terrible secret\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nsecret she concealed even from her maid with such care, the secret of\r\nwhich all the world was ignorant, except himself.\r\n\r\nShe turned upon him, no longer like a furious woman, but like a wounded\r\npanther.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, wretch!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have basely betrayed me, and still more,\r\nyou have my secret! You shall die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she flew to a little inlaid casket which stood upon the dressing\r\ntable, opened it with a feverish and trembling hand, drew from it a\r\nsmall poniard, with a golden haft and a sharp thin blade, and then\r\nthrew herself with a bound upon D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nAlthough the young man was brave, as we know, he was terrified at that\r\nwild countenance, those terribly dilated pupils, those pale cheeks, and\r\nthose bleeding lips. He recoiled to the other side of the room as he\r\nwould have done from a serpent which was crawling toward him, and his\r\nsword coming in contact with his nervous hand, he drew it almost\r\nunconsciously from the scabbard. But without taking any heed of the\r\nsword, Milady endeavored to get near enough to him to stab him, and did\r\nnot stop till she felt the sharp point at her throat.\r\n\r\nShe then tried to seize the sword with her hands; but D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan kept\r\nit free from her grasp, and presenting the point, sometimes at her\r\neyes, sometimes at her breast, compelled her to glide behind the\r\nbedstead, while he aimed at making his retreat by the door which led to\r\nKitty\xe2\x80\x99s apartment.\r\n\r\nMilady during this time continued to strike at him with horrible fury,\r\nscreaming in a formidable way.\r\n\r\nAs all this, however, bore some resemblance to a duel, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan began\r\nto recover himself little by little.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, beautiful lady, very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut, _pardieu_, if you\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t calm yourself, I will design a second _fleur-de-lis_ upon one of\r\nthose pretty cheeks!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cScoundrel, infamous scoundrel!\xe2\x80\x9d howled Milady.\r\n\r\nBut D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, still keeping on the defensive, drew near to Kitty\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndoor. At the noise they made, she in overturning the furniture in her\r\nefforts to get at him, he in screening himself behind the furniture to\r\nkeep out of her reach, Kitty opened the door. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had\r\nunceasingly maneuvered to gain this point, was not at more than three\r\npaces from it. With one spring he flew from the chamber of Milady into\r\nthat of the maid, and quick as lightning, he slammed to the door, and\r\nplaced all his weight against it, while Kitty pushed the bolts.\r\n\r\nThen Milady attempted to tear down the doorcase, with a strength\r\napparently above that of a woman; but finding she could not accomplish\r\nthis, she in her fury stabbed at the door with her poniard, the point\r\nof which repeatedly glittered through the wood. Every blow was\r\naccompanied with terrible imprecations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuick, Kitty, quick!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in a low voice, as soon as the\r\nbolts were fast, \xe2\x80\x9clet me get out of the h\xc3\xb4tel; for if we leave her time\r\nto turn round, she will have me killed by the servants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you can\xe2\x80\x99t go out so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Kitty; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are naked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, then first thinking of the costume he\r\nfound himself in, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s true. But dress me as well as you are able,\r\nonly make haste; think, my dear girl, it\xe2\x80\x99s life and death!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nKitty was but too well aware of that. In a turn of the hand she muffled\r\nhim up in a flowered robe, a large hood, and a cloak. She gave him some\r\nslippers, in which he placed his naked feet, and then conducted him\r\ndown the stairs. It was time. Milady had already rung her bell, and\r\nroused the whole h\xc3\xb4tel. The porter was drawing the cord at the moment\r\nMilady cried from her window, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t open!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young man fled while she was still threatening him with an impotent\r\ngesture. The moment she lost sight of him, Milady tumbled fainting into\r\nher chamber.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XXXVIII.\r\nHOW, WITHOUT INCOMMDING HIMSELF, ATHOS PROCURES HIS EQUIPMENT\r\n\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was so completely bewildered that without taking any heed of\r\nwhat might become of Kitty he ran at full speed across half Paris, and\r\ndid not stop till he came to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s door. The confusion of his mind,\r\nthe terror which spurred him on, the cries of some of the patrol who\r\nstarted in pursuit of him, and the hooting of the people who,\r\nnotwithstanding the early hour, were going to their work, only made him\r\nprecipitate his course.\r\n\r\nHe crossed the court, ran up the two flights to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s apartment, and\r\nknocked at the door enough to break it down.\r\n\r\nGrimaud came, rubbing his half-open eyes, to answer this noisy summons,\r\nand D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan sprang with such violence into the room as nearly to\r\noverturn the astonished lackey.\r\n\r\nIn spite of his habitual silence, the poor lad this time found his\r\nspeech.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHolloa, there!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you want, you strumpet? What\xe2\x80\x99s your\r\nbusiness here, you hussy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan threw off his hood, and disengaged his hands from the folds\r\nof the cloak. At sight of the mustaches and the naked sword, the poor\r\ndevil perceived he had to deal with a man. He then concluded it must be\r\nan assassin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp! murder! help!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold your tongue, you stupid fellow!\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man; \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; don\xe2\x80\x99t you know me? Where is your master?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Grimaud, \xe2\x80\x9cimpossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, coming out of his apartment in a dressing gown,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud, I thought I heard you permitting yourself to speak?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur, it is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrimaud contented himself with pointing D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan out to his master\r\nwith his finger.\r\n\r\nAthos recognized his comrade, and phlegmatic as he was, he burst into a\r\nlaugh which was quite excused by the strange masquerade before his\r\neyes\xe2\x80\x94petticoats falling over his shoes, sleeves tucked up, and\r\nmustaches stiff with agitation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t laugh, my friend!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cfor heaven\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nlaugh, for upon my soul, it\xe2\x80\x99s no laughing matter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he pronounced these words with such a solemn air and with such a\r\nreal appearance of terror, that Athos eagerly seized his hand, crying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you wounded, my friend? How pale you are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, but I have just met with a terrible adventure! Are you alone,\r\nAthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Parbleu!_ whom do you expect to find with me at this hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well!\xe2\x80\x9d and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rushed into Athos\xe2\x80\x99s chamber.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, speak!\xe2\x80\x9d said the latter, closing the door and bolting it, that\r\nthey might not be disturbed. \xe2\x80\x9cIs the king dead? Have you killed the\r\ncardinal? You are quite upset! Come, come, tell me; I am dying with\r\ncuriosity and uneasiness!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, getting rid of his female garments, and\r\nappearing in his shirt, \xe2\x80\x9cprepare yourself to hear an incredible, an\r\nunheard-of story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but put on this dressing gown first,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeer to his\r\nfriend.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan donned the robe as quickly as he could, mistaking one sleeve\r\nfor the other, so greatly was he still agitated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, bending his mouth to Athos\xe2\x80\x99s ear, and\r\nlowering his voice, \xe2\x80\x9cMilady is marked with a _fleur-de-lis_ upon her\r\nshoulder!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Musketeer, as if he had received a ball in his heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cAre you _sure_ that the _other_ is\r\ndead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_The other?_\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, in so stifled a voice that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nscarcely heard him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she of whom you told me one day at Amiens.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos uttered a groan, and let his head sink on his hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is a woman of twenty-six or twenty-eight years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFair,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cis she not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBlue and clear eyes, of a strange brilliancy, with black eyelids and\r\neyebrows?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTall, well-made? Lord de Winter is only\r\nher brother-in-law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will see her, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware, Athos, beware.
