D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, not less forward than they, did likewise, and\r\nall ran out, in order to repair to their posts.\r\n\r\nBut scarcely were they out of the room before they were made aware of\r\nthe cause of this noise. Cries of \xe2\x80\x9cLive the king! Live the cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nresounded on every side, and the drums were beaten in all directions.\r\n\r\nIn short, the king, impatient, as has been said, had come by forced\r\nmarches, and had that moment arrived with all his household and a\r\nreinforcement of ten thousand troops. His Musketeers proceeded and\r\nfollowed him. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, placed in line with his company, saluted with\r\nan expressive gesture his three friends, whose eyes soon discovered\r\nhim, and M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who detected him at once.\r\n\r\nThe ceremony of reception over, the four friends were soon in one\r\nanother\xe2\x80\x99s arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou could not have arrived in better\r\ntime; the dinner cannot have had time to get cold! Can it, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nadded the young man, turning to the two Guards, whom he introduced to\r\nhis friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears we are feasting!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cthere are no women at your dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there any drinkable wine in your tavern?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, _pardieu!_ there is yours, my dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur wine!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, astonished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that you sent me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe sent you wine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know very well\xe2\x80\x94the wine from the hills of Anjou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know what brand you are talking about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe wine you prefer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, in the absence of champagne and chambertin, you must content\r\nyourselves with that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so, connoisseurs in wine as we are, we have sent you some Anjou\r\nwine?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot exactly, it is the wine that was sent by your order.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn our account?\xe2\x80\x9d said the three Musketeers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you send this wine, Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; and you, Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; and you, Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it was not you, it was your purveyor,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur purveyor!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your purveyor, Godeau\xe2\x80\x94the purveyor of the Musketeers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith! never mind where it comes from,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9clet us taste\r\nit, and if it is good, let us drink it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t let us drink wine which comes from an unknown\r\nsource.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right, Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cDid none of you charge your\r\npurveyor, Godeau, to send me some wine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! And yet you say he has sent you some as from us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere is his letter,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and he presented the note to his\r\ncomrades.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is not his writing!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI am acquainted with it; before\r\nwe left Villeroy I settled the accounts of the regiment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA false letter altogether,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have not been\r\ndisciplined.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, in a reproachful tone, \xe2\x80\x9chow could you\r\nbelieve that we had made a disturbance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan grew pale, and a convulsive trembling shook all his limbs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThou alarmest me!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, who never used _thee_ and _thou_ but\r\nupon very particular occasions, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook you, my friends!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ca horrible suspicion crosses\r\nmy mind! Can this be another vengeance of that woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was now Athos who turned pale.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan rushed toward the refreshment room, the three Musketeers and\r\nthe two Guards following him.\r\n\r\nThe first object that met the eyes of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan on entering the room\r\nwas Brisemont, stretched upon the ground and rolling in horrible\r\nconvulsions.\r\n\r\nPlanchet and Fourreau, as pale as death, were trying to give him\r\nsuccor; but it was plain that all assistance was useless\xe2\x80\x94all the\r\nfeatures of the dying man were distorted with agony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, on perceiving D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cah! this is frightful! You\r\npretend to pardon me, and you poison me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI, wretch? What do you say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say that it was you who gave me the wine; I say that it was you who\r\ndesired me to drink it. I say you wished to avenge yourself on me, and\r\nI say that it is horrible!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not think so, Brisemont,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cdo not think so. I\r\nswear to you, I protest\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, but God is above! God will punish you! My God, grant that he may\r\none day suffer what I suffer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon the Gospel,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, throwing himself down by the dying\r\nman, \xe2\x80\x9cI swear to you that the wine was poisoned and that I was going to\r\ndrink of it as you did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not believe you,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the soldier, and he expired amid horrible\r\ntortures.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrightful! frightful!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Athos, while Porthos broke the bottles\r\nand Aramis gave orders, a little too late, that a confessor should be\r\nsent for.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou come once more to save my life,\r\nnot only mine but that of these gentlemen. Gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he,\r\naddressing the Guardsmen, \xe2\x80\x9cI request you will be silent with regard to\r\nthis adventure. Great personages may have had a hand in what you have\r\nseen, and if talked about, the evil would only recoil upon us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Planchet, more dead than alive, \xe2\x80\x9cah,\r\nmonsieur, what an escape I have had!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, sirrah! you were going to drink my wine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the health of the king, monsieur; I was going to drink a small\r\nglass of it if Fourreau had not told me I was called.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Fourreau, whose teeth chattered with terror, \xe2\x80\x9cI wanted to\r\nget him out of the way that I might drink myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, addressing the Guardsmen, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may easily\r\ncomprehend that such a feast can only be very dull after what has taken\r\nplace; so accept my excuses, and put off the party till another day, I\r\nbeg of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe two Guardsmen courteously accepted D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s excuses, and\r\nperceiving that the four friends desired to be alone, retired.\r\n\r\nWhen the young Guardsman and the three Musketeers were without\r\nwitnesses, they looked at one another with an air which plainly\r\nexpressed that each of them perceived the gravity of their situation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9clet us leave this chamber; the dead\r\nare not agreeable company, particularly when they have died a violent\r\ndeath.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI commit the corpse of this poor devil to\r\nyour care. Let him be interred in holy ground. He committed a crime, it\r\nis true; but he repented of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the four friends quit the room, leaving to Planchet and Fourreau\r\nthe duty of paying mortuary honors to Brisemont.\r\n\r\nThe host gave them another chamber, and served them with fresh eggs and\r\nsome water, which Athos went himself to draw at the fountain. In a few\r\nwords, Porthos and Aramis were posted as to the situation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou see, my dear friend, that this\r\nis war to the death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied he, \xe2\x80\x9cI perceive that plainly; but do you really\r\nbelieve it is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNevertheless, I confess I still doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the _fleur-de-lis_ on her shoulder?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is some Englishwoman who has committed a crime in France, and has\r\nbeen branded in consequence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos, she is your wife, I tell you,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9conly\r\nreflect how much the two descriptions resemble each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but I should think the other must be dead, I hanged her so\r\neffectually.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan who now shook his head in his turn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in either case, what is to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d said the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fact is, one cannot remain thus, with a sword hanging eternally\r\nover his head,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cWe must extricate ourselves from this\r\nposition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut how?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen! You must try to see her, and have an explanation with her. Say\r\nto her: \xe2\x80\x98Peace or war! My word as a gentleman never to say anything of\r\nyou, never to do anything against you; on your side, a solemn oath to\r\nremain neutral with respect to me. If not, I will apply to the\r\nchancellor, I will apply to the king, I will apply to the hangman, I\r\nwill move the courts against you, I will denounce you as branded, I\r\nwill bring you to trial; and if you are acquitted, well, by the faith\r\nof a gentleman, I will kill you at the corner of some wall, as I would\r\na mad dog.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like the means well enough,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cbut where and how to\r\nmeet with her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTime, dear friend, time brings round opportunity; opportunity is the\r\nmartingale of man. The more we have ventured the more we gain, when we\r\nknow how to wait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but to wait surrounded by assassins and poisoners.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cGod has preserved us hitherto, God will preserve us\r\nstill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, we. Besides, we are men; and everything considered, it is our lot\r\nto risk our lives; but _she_,\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, in an undertone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat she?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConstance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame Bonacieux! Ah, that\xe2\x80\x99s true!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cMy poor friend, I had\r\nforgotten you were in love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9chave you not learned by the letter you found\r\non the wretched corpse that she is in a convent? One may be very\r\ncomfortable in a convent; and as soon as the siege of La Rochelle is\r\nterminated, I promise you on my part\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cgood! Yes, my dear Aramis, we all know that your\r\nviews have a religious tendency.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am only temporarily a Musketeer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, humbly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is some time since we heard from his mistress,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, in a\r\nlow voice. \xe2\x80\x9cBut take no notice; we know all about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cit appears to me that the means are very\r\nsimple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say she is in a convent?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well. As soon as the siege is over, we\xe2\x80\x99ll carry her off from that\r\nconvent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we must first learn what convent she is in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I think I have it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you say, dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nthat it is the queen who has made choice of the convent for her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case Porthos will assist us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how so, if you please?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, by your marchioness, your duchess, your princess. She must have a\r\nlong arm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, placing a finger on his lips. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe her to\r\nbe a cardinalist; she must know nothing of the matter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI take upon myself to obtain intelligence of\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d cried the three friends. \xe2\x80\x9cYou! And how?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy the queen\xe2\x80\x99s almoner, to whom I am very intimately allied,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAramis, coloring.\r\n\r\nAnd on this assurance, the four friends, who had finished their modest\r\nrepast, separated, with the promise of meeting again that evening.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan returned to less important affairs, and the three Musketeers\r\nrepaired to the king\xe2\x80\x99s quarters, where they had to prepare their\r\nlodging.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLIII.\r\nTHE SIGN OF THE RED DOVECOT\r\n\r\n\r\nMeanwhile the king, who, with more reason than the cardinal, showed his\r\nhatred for Buckingham, although scarcely arrived was in such a haste to\r\nmeet the enemy that he commanded every disposition to be made to drive\r\nthe English from the Isle of R\xc3\xa9, and afterward to press the siege of La\r\nRochelle; but notwithstanding his earnest wish, he was delayed by the\r\ndissensions which broke out between MM. Bassompierre and Schomberg,\r\nagainst the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Angoul\xc3\xaame.\r\n\r\nMM. Bassompierre and Schomberg were marshals of France, and claimed\r\ntheir right of commanding the army under the orders of the king; but\r\nthe cardinal, who feared that Bassompierre, a Huguenot at heart, might\r\npress but feebly the English and Rochellais, his brothers in religion,\r\nsupported the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Angoul\xc3\xaame, whom the king, at his instigation, had\r\nnamed lieutenant general. The result was that to prevent MM.\r\nBassompierre and Schomberg from deserting the army, a separate command\r\nhad to be given to each. Bassompierre took up his quarters on the north\r\nof the city, between Leu and Dompierre; the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Angoul\xc3\xaame on the\r\neast, from Dompierre to Perigny; and M. de Schomberg on the south, from\r\nPerigny to Angoutin.\r\n\r\nThe quarters of Monsieur were at Dompierre; the quarters of the king\r\nwere sometimes at Estr\xc3\xa9e, sometimes at Jarrie; the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s quarters\r\nwere upon the downs, at the bridge of La Pierre, in a simple house\r\nwithout any entrenchment. So that Monsieur watched Bassompierre; the\r\nking, the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Angoul\xc3\xaame; and the cardinal, M. de Schomberg.\r\n\r\nAs soon as this organization was established, they set about driving\r\nthe English from the Isle.\r\n\r\nThe juncture was favorable. The English, who require, above everything,\r\ngood living in order to be good soldiers, only eating salt meat and bad\r\nbiscuit, had many invalids in their camp. Still further, the sea, very\r\nrough at this period of the year all along the sea coast, destroyed\r\nevery day some little vessel; and the shore, from the point of\r\nl\xe2\x80\x99Aiguillon to the trenches, was at every tide literally covered with\r\nthe wrecks of pinnacles, _roberges_, and feluccas. The result was that\r\neven if the king\xe2\x80\x99s troops remained quietly in their camp, it was\r\nevident that some day or other, Buckingham, who only continued in the\r\nIsle from obstinacy, would be obliged to raise the siege.\r\n\r\nBut as M. de Toiras gave information that everything was preparing in\r\nthe enemy\xe2\x80\x99s camp for a fresh assault, the king judged that it would be\r\nbest to put an end to the affair, and gave the necessary orders for a\r\ndecisive action.\r\n\r\nAs it is not our intention to give a journal of the siege, but on the\r\ncontrary only to describe such of the events of it as are connected\r\nwith the story we are relating, we will content ourselves with saying\r\nin two words that the expedition succeeded, to the great astonishment\r\nof the king and the great glory of the cardinal. The English, repulsed\r\nfoot by foot, beaten in all encounters, and defeated in the passage of\r\nthe Isle of Loie, were obliged to re-embark, leaving on the field of\r\nbattle two thousand men, among whom were five colonels, three\r\nlieutenant colonels, two hundred and fifty captains, twenty gentlemen\r\nof rank, four pieces of cannon, and sixty flags, which were taken to\r\nParis by Claude de St. Simon, and suspended with great pomp in the\r\narches of Notre Dame.\r\n\r\nTe Deums were chanted in camp, and afterward throughout France.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal was left free to carry on the siege, without having, at\r\nleast at the present, anything to fear on the part of the English.\r\n\r\nBut it must be acknowledged, this response was but momentary. An envoy\r\nof the Duke of Buckingham, named Montague, was taken, and proof was\r\nobtained of a league between the German Empire, Spain, England, and\r\nLorraine. This league was directed against France.\r\n\r\nStill further, in Buckingham\xe2\x80\x99s lodging, which he had been forced to\r\nabandon more precipitately than he expected, papers were found which\r\nconfirmed this alliance and which, as the cardinal asserts in his\r\nmemoirs, strongly compromised Mme. de Chevreuse and consequently the\r\nqueen.\r\n\r\nIt was upon the cardinal that all the responsibility fell, for one is\r\nnot a despotic minister without responsibility. All, therefore, of the\r\nvast resources of his genius were at work night and day, engaged in\r\nlistening to the least report heard in any of the great kingdoms of\r\nEurope.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal was acquainted with the activity, and more particularly\r\nthe hatred, of Buckingham. If the league which threatened France\r\ntriumphed, all his influence would be lost. Spanish policy and Austrian\r\npolicy would have their representatives in the cabinet of the Louvre,\r\nwhere they had as yet but partisans; and he, Richelieu\xe2\x80\x94the French\r\nminister, the national minister\xe2\x80\x94would be ruined. The king, even while\r\nobeying him like a child, hated him as a child hates his master, and\r\nwould abandon him to the personal vengeance of Monsieur and the queen.\r\nHe would then be lost, and France, perhaps, with him. All this must be\r\nprepared against.\r\n\r\nCourtiers, becoming every instant more numerous, succeeded one another,\r\nday and night, in the little house of the bridge of La Pierre, in which\r\nthe cardinal had established his residence.\r\n\r\nThere were monks who wore the frock with such an ill grace that it was\r\neasy to perceive they belonged to the church militant; women a little\r\ninconvenienced by their costume as pages and whose large trousers could\r\nnot entirely conceal their rounded forms; and peasants with blackened\r\nhands but with fine limbs, savoring of the man of quality a league off.\r\n\r\nThere were also less agreeable visits\xe2\x80\x94for two or three times reports\r\nwere spread that the cardinal had nearly been assassinated.\r\n\r\nIt is true that the enemies of the cardinal said that it was he himself\r\nwho set these bungling assassins to work, in order to have, if wanted,\r\nthe right of using reprisals; but we must not believe everything\r\nministers say, nor everything their enemies say.\r\n\r\nThese attempts did not prevent the cardinal, to whom his most\r\ninveterate detractors have never denied personal bravery, from making\r\nnocturnal excursions, sometimes to communicate to the Duc d\xe2\x80\x99Angoul\xc3\xaame\r\nimportant orders, sometimes to confer with the king, and sometimes to\r\nhave an interview with a messenger whom he did not wish to see at home.\r\n\r\nOn their part the Musketeers, who had not much to do with the siege,\r\nwere not under very strict orders and led a joyous life. This was the\r\nmore easy for our three companions in particular; for being friends of\r\nM. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, they obtained from him special permission to be absent\r\nafter the closing of the camp.\r\n\r\nNow, one evening when D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was in the trenches, was not able\r\nto accompany them, Athos, Porthos, and Aramis, mounted on their battle\r\nsteeds, enveloped in their war cloaks, with their hands upon their\r\npistol butts, were returning from a drinking place called the Red\r\nDovecot, which Athos had discovered two days before upon the route to\r\nJarrie, following the road which led to the camp and quite on their\r\nguard, as we have stated, for fear of an ambuscade, when, about a\r\nquarter of a league from the village of Boisnau, they fancied they\r\nheard the sound of horses approaching them. They immediately all three\r\nhalted, closed in, and waited, occupying the middle of the road. In an\r\ninstant, and as the moon broke from behind a cloud, they saw at a\r\nturning of the road two horsemen who, on perceiving them, stopped in\r\ntheir turn, appearing to deliberate whether they should continue their\r\nroute or go back. The hesitation created some suspicion in the three\r\nfriends, and Athos, advancing a few paces in front of the others, cried\r\nin a firm voice, \xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there, yourselves?\xe2\x80\x9d replied one of the horsemen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is not an answer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there? Answer, or we\r\ncharge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBeware of what you are about, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d said a clear voice which\r\nseemed accustomed to command.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is some superior officer making his night rounds,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you wish, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d said the same voice, in the same commanding tone.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnswer in your turn, or you may repent of your disobedience.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKing\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, more and more convinced that he who\r\ninterrogated them had the right to do so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat company?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCompany of Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdvance, and give an account of what you are doing here at this hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three companions advanced rather humbly\xe2\x80\x94for all were now convinced\r\nthat they had to do with someone more powerful than themselves\xe2\x80\x94leaving\r\nAthos the post of speaker.\r\n\r\nOne of the two riders, he who had spoken second, was ten paces in front\r\nof his companion. Athos made a sign to Porthos and Aramis also to\r\nremain in the rear, and advanced alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour pardon, my officer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we were ignorant with whom\r\nwe had to do, and you may see that we were keeping good guard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour name?\xe2\x80\x9d said the officer, who covered a part of his face with his\r\ncloak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut yourself, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, who began to be annoyed by this\r\ninquisition, \xe2\x80\x9cgive me, I beg you, the proof that you have the right to\r\nquestion me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour name?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated the cavalier a second time, letting his cloak\r\nfall, and leaving his face uncovered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur the Cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the stupefied Musketeer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour name?\xe2\x80\x9d cried his Eminence, for the third time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAthos,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeer.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal made a sign to his attendant, who drew near. \xe2\x80\x9cThese three\r\nMusketeers shall follow us,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in an undertone. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not\r\nwilling it should be known I have left the camp; and if they follow us\r\nwe shall be certain they will tell nobody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are gentlemen, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9crequire our parole, and\r\ngive yourself no uneasiness. Thank God, we can keep a secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal fixed his piercing eyes on this courageous speaker.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a quick ear, Monsieur Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cbut now\r\nlisten to this. It is not from mistrust that I request you to follow\r\nme, but for my security. Your companions are no doubt Messieurs Porthos\r\nand Aramis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, your Eminence,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, while the two Musketeers who had\r\nremained behind advanced hat in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know you, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cI know you. I know you are\r\nnot quite my friends, and I am sorry you are not so; but I know you are\r\nbrave and loyal gentlemen, and that confidence may be placed in you.\r\nMonsieur Athos, do me, then, the honor to accompany me; you and your\r\ntwo friends, and then I shall have an escort to excite envy in his\r\nMajesty, if we should meet him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three Musketeers bowed to the necks of their horses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, upon my honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyour Eminence is right in taking us\r\nwith you; we have seen several ill-looking faces on the road, and we\r\nhave even had a quarrel at the Red Dovecot with four of those faces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA quarrel, and what for, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cyou know I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t like quarrelers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that is the reason why I have the honor to inform your Eminence of\r\nwhat has happened; for you might learn it from others, and upon a false\r\naccount believe us to be in fault.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have been the results of your quarrel?\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal,\r\nknitting his brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy friend, Aramis, here, has received a slight sword wound in the arm,\r\nbut not enough to prevent him, as your Eminence may see, from mounting\r\nto the assault tomorrow, if your Eminence orders an escalade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are not the men to allow sword wounds to be inflicted upon you\r\nthus,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, be frank, gentlemen, you have settled\r\naccounts with somebody! Confess; you know I have the right of giving\r\nabsolution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, monseigneur?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI did not even draw my sword, but I took\r\nhim who offended me round the body, and threw him out of the window. It\r\nappears that in falling,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos, with some hesitation, \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nbroke his thigh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cand you, Monsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, monseigneur, knowing that dueling is prohibited\xe2\x80\x94I seized a bench,\r\nand gave one of those brigands such a blow that I believe his shoulder\r\nis broken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cand you, Monsieur Aramis?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonseigneur, being of a very mild disposition, and being, likewise, of\r\nwhich Monseigneur perhaps is not aware, about to enter into orders, I\r\nendeavored to appease my comrades, when one of these wretches gave me a\r\nwound with a sword, treacherously, across my left arm. Then I admit my\r\npatience failed me; I drew my sword in my turn, and as he came back to\r\nthe charge, I fancied I felt that in throwing himself upon me, he let\r\nit pass through his body. I only know for a certainty that he fell; and\r\nit seemed to me that he was borne away with his two companions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil, gentlemen!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthree men placed _hors de\r\ncombat_ in a cabaret squabble! You don\xe2\x80\x99t do your work by halves. And\r\npray what was this quarrel about?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese fellows were drunk,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cand knowing there was a lady\r\nwho had arrived at the cabaret this evening, they wanted to force her\r\ndoor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForce her door!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cand for what purpose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo do her violence, without doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI have had the honor\r\nof informing your Eminence that these men were drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd was this lady young and handsome?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the cardinal, with a\r\ncertain degree of anxiety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe did not see her, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did not see her? Ah, very well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal, quickly.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did well to defend the honor of a woman; and as I am going to the\r\nRed Dovecot myself, I shall know if you have told me the truth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, haughtily, \xe2\x80\x9cwe are gentlemen, and to save\r\nour heads we would not be guilty of a falsehood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTherefore I do not doubt what you say, Monsieur Athos, I do not doubt\r\nit for a single instant; but,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, \xe2\x80\x9cto change the conversation,\r\nwas this lady alone?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe lady had a cavalier shut up with her,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cbut as\r\nnotwithstanding the noise, this cavalier did not show himself, it is to\r\nbe presumed that he is a coward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Judge not rashly\xe2\x80\x99, says the Gospel,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal.\r\n\r\nAthos bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, gentlemen, that\xe2\x80\x99s well,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cI know what\r\nI wish to know; follow me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three Musketeers passed behind his Eminence, who again enveloped\r\nhis face in his cloak, and put his horse in motion, keeping from eight\r\nto ten paces in advance of his four companions.\r\n\r\nThey soon arrived at the silent, solitary inn. No doubt the host knew\r\nwhat illustrious visitor was expected, and had consequently sent\r\nintruders out of the way.\r\n\r\nTen paces from the door the cardinal made a sign to his esquire and the\r\nthree Musketeers to halt. A saddled horse was fastened to the window\r\nshutter. The cardinal knocked three times, and in a peculiar manner.\r\n\r\nA man, enveloped in a cloak, came out immediately, and exchanged some\r\nrapid words with the cardinal; after which he mounted his horse, and\r\nset off in the direction of Surg\xc3\xa8res, which was likewise the way to\r\nParis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdvance, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have told me the truth, my gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, addressing the\r\nMusketeers, \xe2\x80\x9cand it will not be my fault if our encounter this evening\r\nbe not advantageous to you. In the meantime, follow me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe cardinal alighted; the three Musketeers did likewise. The cardinal\r\nthrew the bridle of his horse to his esquire; the three Musketeers\r\nfastened the horses to the shutters.\r\n\r\nThe host stood at the door. For him, the cardinal was only an officer\r\ncoming to visit a lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any chamber on the ground floor where these gentlemen can\r\nwait near a good fire?\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\nThe host opened the door of a large room, in which an old stove had\r\njust been replaced by a large and excellent chimney.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have this,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cEnter, gentlemen, and be kind\r\nenough to wait for me; I shall not be more than half an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd while the three Musketeers entered the ground floor room, the\r\ncardinal, without asking further information, ascended the staircase\r\nlike a man who has no need of having his road pointed out to him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLIV.\r\nTHE UTILITY OF STOVEPIPES\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was evident that without suspecting it, and actuated solely by their\r\nchivalrous and adventurous character, our three friends had just\r\nrendered a service to someone the cardinal honored with his special\r\nprotection.\r\n\r\nNow, who was that someone? That was the question the three Musketeers\r\nput to one another. Then, seeing that none of their replies could throw\r\nany light on the subject, Porthos called the host and asked for dice.\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis placed themselves at the table and began to play.\r\nAthos walked about in a contemplative mood.\r\n\r\nWhile thinking and walking, Athos passed and repassed before the pipe\r\nof the stove, broken in halves, the other extremity passing into the\r\nchamber above; and every time he passed and repassed he heard a murmur\r\nof words, which at length fixed his attention. Athos went close to it,\r\nand distinguished some words that appeared to merit so great an\r\ninterest that he made a sign to his friends to be silent, remaining\r\nhimself bent with his ear directed to the opening of the lower orifice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Milady,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthe affair is important. Sit\r\ndown, and let us talk it over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMilady!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI listen to your Eminence with greatest attention,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a female\r\nvoice which made the Musketeer start.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA small vessel with an English crew, whose captain is on my side,\r\nawaits you at the mouth of Charente, at Fort La Pointe*. He will set\r\nsail tomorrow morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n* Fort La Pointe, or Fort Vasou, was not built until 1672, nearly 50\r\nyears later.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must go thither tonight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInstantly! That is to say, when you have received my instructions. Two\r\nmen, whom you will find at the door on going out, will serve you as\r\nescort. You will allow me to leave first; then, after half an hour, you\r\ncan go away in your turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur. Now let us return to the mission with which you wish\r\nto charge me; and as I desire to continue to merit the confidence of\r\nyour Eminence, deign to unfold it to me in terms clear and precise,\r\nthat I may not commit an error.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was an instant of profound silence between the two interlocutors.\r\nIt was evident that the cardinal was weighing beforehand the terms in\r\nwhich he was about to speak, and that Milady was collecting all her\r\nintellectual faculties to comprehend the things he was about to say,\r\nand to engrave them in her memory when they should be spoken.\r\n\r\nAthos took advantage of this moment to tell his two companions to\r\nfasten the door inside, and to make them a sign to come and listen with\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nThe two Musketeers, who loved their ease, brought a chair for each of\r\nthemselves and one for Athos. All three then sat down with their heads\r\ntogether and their ears on the alert.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will go to London,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cArrived in London,\r\nyou will seek Buckingham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must beg your Eminence to observe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cthat since the\r\naffair of the diamond studs, about which the duke always suspected me,\r\nhis Grace distrusts me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this time,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not necessary to steal his\r\nconfidence, but to present yourself frankly and loyally as a\r\nnegotiator.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrankly and loyally,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Milady, with an unspeakable expression\r\nof duplicity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, frankly and loyally,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal, in the same tone.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this negotiation must be carried on openly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will follow your Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s instructions to the letter. I only wait\r\ntill you give them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will go to Buckingham in my behalf, and you will tell him I am\r\nacquainted with all the preparations he has made; but that they give me\r\nno uneasiness, since at the first step he takes I will ruin the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill he believe that your Eminence is in a position to accomplish the\r\nthreat thus made?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; for I have the proofs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must be able to present these proofs for his appreciation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout doubt. And you will tell him I will publish the report of\r\nBois-Robert and the Marquis de Beautru, upon the interview which the\r\nduke had at the residence of Madame the Constable with the queen on the\r\nevening Madame the Constable gave a masquerade. You will tell him, in\r\norder that he may not doubt, that he came there in the costume of the\r\nGreat Mogul, which the Chevalier de Guise was to have worn, and that he\r\npurchased this exchange for the sum of three thousand pistoles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monseigneur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll the details of his coming into and going out of the palace\xe2\x80\x94on the\r\nnight when he introduced himself in the character of an Italian fortune\r\nteller\xe2\x80\x94you will tell him, that he may not doubt the correctness of my\r\ninformation; that he had under his cloak a large white robe dotted with\r\nblack tears, death\xe2\x80\x99s heads, and crossbones\xe2\x80\x94for in case of a surprise,\r\nhe was to pass for the phantom of the White Lady who, as all the world\r\nknows, appears at the Louvre every time any great event is impending.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that all, monseigneur?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him also that I am acquainted with all the details of the\r\nadventure at Amiens; that I will have a little romance made of it,\r\nwittily turned, with a plan of the garden and portraits of the\r\nprincipal actors in that nocturnal romance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell him that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him further that I hold Montague in my power; that Montague is in\r\nthe Bastille; that no letters were found upon him, it is true, but that\r\ntorture may make him tell much of what he knows, and even what he does\r\nnot know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen add that his Grace has, in the precipitation with which he quit\r\nthe Isle of R\xc3\xa9, forgotten and left behind him in his lodging a certain\r\nletter from Madame de Chevreuse which singularly compromises the queen,\r\ninasmuch as it proves not only that her Majesty can love the enemies of\r\nthe king but that she can conspire with the enemies of France. You\r\nrecollect perfectly all I have told you, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Eminence will judge: the ball of Madame the Constable; the night\r\nat the Louvre; the evening at Amiens; the arrest of Montague; the\r\nletter of Madame de Chevreuse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s it. You have an excellent\r\nmemory, Milady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed she to whom the cardinal addressed this flattering\r\ncompliment, \xe2\x80\x9cif, in spite of all these reasons, the duke does not give\r\nway and continues to menace France?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe duke is in love to madness, or rather to folly,\xe2\x80\x9d replied\r\nRichelieu, with great bitterness. \xe2\x80\x9cLike the ancient paladins, he has\r\nonly undertaken this war to obtain a look from his lady love. If he\r\nbecomes certain that this war will cost the honor, and perhaps the\r\nliberty, of the lady of his thoughts, as he says, I will answer for it\r\nhe will look twice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, with a persistence that proved she wished to\r\nsee clearly to the end of the mission with which she was about to be\r\ncharged, \xe2\x80\x9cif he persists?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he persists?\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is not probable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is possible,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf he persists\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d His Eminence made a pause, and resumed: \xe2\x80\x9cIf he\r\npersists\xe2\x80\x94well, then I shall hope for one of those events which change\r\nthe destinies of states.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf your Eminence would quote to me some one of these events in\r\nhistory,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cperhaps I should partake of your confidence as\r\nto the future.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, here, for example,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richelieu: \xe2\x80\x9cwhen, in 1610, for a cause\r\nsimilar to that which moves the duke, King Henry IV., of glorious\r\nmemory, was about, at the same time, to invade Flanders and Italy, in\r\norder to attack Austria on both sides. Well, did there not happen an\r\nevent which saved Austria? Why should not the king of France have the\r\nsame chance as the emperor?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Eminence means, I presume, the knife stab in the Rue de la\r\nFeronnerie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes not your Eminence fear that the punishment inflicted upon\r\nRavaillac may deter anyone who might entertain the idea of imitating\r\nhim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere will be, in all times and in all countries, particularly if\r\nreligious divisions exist in those countries, fanatics who ask nothing\r\nbetter than to become martyrs. Ay, and observe\xe2\x80\x94it just occurs to me\r\nthat the Puritans are furious against Buckingham, and their preachers\r\ndesignate him as the Antichrist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the cardinal, in an indifferent tone, \xe2\x80\x9cthe only thing\r\nto be sought for at this moment is some woman, handsome, young, and\r\nclever, who has cause of quarrel with the duke. The duke has had many\r\naffairs of gallantry; and if he has fostered his amours by promises of\r\neternal constancy, he must likewise have sown the seeds of hatred by\r\nhis eternal infidelities.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, coolly, \xe2\x80\x9csuch a woman may be found.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, such a woman, who would place the knife of Jacques Cl\xc3\xa9ment or of\r\nRavaillac in the hands of a fanatic, would save France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but she would then be the accomplice of an assassination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere the accomplices of Ravaillac or of Jacques Cl\xc3\xa9ment ever known?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; for perhaps they were too high-placed for anyone to dare look for\r\nthem where they were. The Palace of Justice would not be burned down\r\nfor everybody, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think, then, that the fire at the Palace of Justice was not caused\r\nby chance?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Richelieu, in the tone with which he would have put a\r\nquestion of no importance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI, monseigneur?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady. \xe2\x80\x9cI think nothing; I quote a fact,\r\nthat is all. Only I say that if I were named Madame de Montpensier, or\r\nthe Queen Marie de M\xc3\xa9dicis, I should use less precautions than I take,\r\nbeing simply called Milady Clarik.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is just,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richelieu. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you require, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI require an order which would ratify beforehand all that I should\r\nthink proper to do for the greatest good of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut in the first place, this woman I have described must be found who\r\nis desirous of avenging herself upon the duke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is found,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen the miserable fanatic must be found who will serve as an\r\ninstrument of God\xe2\x80\x99s justice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will be found.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cthen it will be time to claim the order\r\nwhich you just now required.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour Eminence is right,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cand I have been wrong in\r\nseeing in the mission with which you honor me anything but that which\r\nit really is\xe2\x80\x94that is, to announce to his Grace, on the part of your\r\nEminence, that you are acquainted with the different disguises by means\r\nof which he succeeded in approaching the queen during the f\xc3\xaate given by\r\nMadame the Constable; that you have proofs of the interview granted at\r\nthe Louvre by the queen to a certain Italian astrologer who was no\r\nother than the Duke of Buckingham; that you have ordered a little\r\nromance of a satirical nature to be written upon the adventures of\r\nAmiens, with a plan of the gardens in which those adventures took\r\nplace, and portraits of the actors who figured in them; that Montague\r\nis in the Bastille, and that the torture may make him say things he\r\nremembers, and even things he has forgotten; that you possess a certain\r\nletter from Madame de Chevreuse, found in his Grace\xe2\x80\x99s lodging, which\r\nsingularly compromises not only her who wrote it, but her in whose name\r\nit was written. Then, if he persists, notwithstanding all this\xe2\x80\x94as that\r\nis, as I have said, the limit of my mission\xe2\x80\x94I shall have nothing to do\r\nbut to pray God to work a miracle for the salvation of France. That is\r\nit, is it not, monseigneur, and I shall have nothing else to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal, dryly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, without appearing to remark the change of the\r\nduke\xe2\x80\x99s tone toward her\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cnow that I have received the instructions of\r\nyour Eminence as concerns your enemies, Monseigneur will permit me to\r\nsay a few words to him of mine?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you enemies, then?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Richelieu.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur, enemies against whom you owe me all your support,\r\nfor I made them by serving your Eminence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are they?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the duke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place, there is a little _intrigante_ named Bonacieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is in the prison of Nantes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say, she was there,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cbut the queen has\r\nobtained an order from the king by means of which she has been conveyed\r\nto a convent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo a convent?\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to a convent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to which?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know; the secret has been well kept.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut _I_ will know!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your Eminence will tell me in what convent that woman is?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can see nothing inconvenient in that,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now I have an enemy much more to be dreaded by me than this\r\nlittle Madame Bonacieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer lover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is his name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, your Eminence knows him well,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, carried away by her\r\nanger. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is the evil genius of both of us. It is he who in an\r\nencounter with your Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s Guards decided the victory in favor of\r\nthe king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers; it is he who gave three desperate wounds to De\r\nWardes, your emissary, and who caused the affair of the diamond studs\r\nto fail; it is he who, knowing it was I who had Madame Bonacieux\r\ncarried off, has sworn my death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal, \xe2\x80\x9cI know of whom you speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean that miserable D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a bold fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is exactly because he is a bold fellow that he is the more to\r\nbe feared.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must have,\xe2\x80\x9d said the duke, \xe2\x80\x9ca proof of his connection with\r\nBuckingham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA proof?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cI will have ten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, it becomes the simplest thing in the world; get me that\r\nproof, and I will send him to the Bastille.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo far good, monseigneur; but afterwards?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen once in the Bastille, there is no afterward!\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal,\r\nin a low voice. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, _pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9cif it were as easy for\r\nme to get rid of my enemy as it is easy to get rid of yours, and if it\r\nwere against such people you require impunity\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, \xe2\x80\x9ca fair exchange. Life for life, man for\r\nman; give me one, I will give you the other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know what you mean, nor do I even desire to know what you\r\nmean,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I wish to please you, and see nothing\r\nout of the way in giving you what you demand with respect to so\r\ninfamous a creature\xe2\x80\x94the more so as you tell me this D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is a\r\nlibertine, a duelist, and a traitor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn infamous scoundrel, monseigneur, a scoundrel!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me paper, a quill, and some ink, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere they are, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a moment of silence, which proved that the cardinal was\r\nemployed in seeking the terms in which he should write the note, or\r\nelse in writing it. Athos, who had not lost a word of the conversation,\r\ntook his two companions by the hand, and led them to the other end of\r\nthe room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat do you want, and why do you not let us\r\nlisten to the end of the conversation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, speaking in a low voice. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have heard all it was\r\nnecessary we should hear; besides, I don\xe2\x80\x99t prevent you from listening,\r\nbut I must be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be gone!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cand if the cardinal asks for you,\r\nwhat answer can we make?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will not wait till he asks; you will speak first, and tell him\r\nthat I am gone on the lookout, because certain expressions of our host\r\nhave given me reason to think the road is not safe. I will say two\r\nwords about it to the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s esquire likewise. The rest concerns\r\nmyself; don\xe2\x80\x99t be uneasy about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe prudent, Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe easy on that head,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cyou know I am cool enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis resumed their places by the stovepipe.\r\n\r\nAs to Athos, he went out without any mystery, took his horse, which was\r\ntied with those of his friends to the fastenings of the shutters, in\r\nfour words convinced the attendant of the necessity of a vanguard for\r\ntheir return, carefully examined the priming of his pistols, drew his\r\nsword, and took, like a forlorn hope, the road to the camp.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLV.\r\nA CONJUGAL SCENE\r\n\r\n\r\nAs Athos had foreseen, it was not long before the cardinal came down.\r\nHe opened the door of the room in which the Musketeers were, and found\r\nPorthos playing an earnest game of dice with Aramis. He cast a rapid\r\nglance around the room, and perceived that one of his men was missing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has become of Monseigneur Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9che has gone as a scout, on account of\r\nsome words of our host, which made him believe the road was not safe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you, what have you done, Monsieur Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have won five pistoles of Aramis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell; now will you return with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are at your Eminence\xe2\x80\x99s orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo horse, then, gentlemen; for it is getting late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe attendant was at the door, holding the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s horse by the\r\nbridle. At a short distance a group of two men and three horses\r\nappeared in the shade. These were the two men who were to conduct\r\nMilady to Fort La Pointe, and superintend her embarkation.\r\n\r\nThe attendant confirmed to the cardinal what the two Musketeers had\r\nalready said with respect to Athos. The cardinal made an approving\r\ngesture, and retraced his route with the same precautions he had used\r\nin coming.\r\n\r\nLet us leave him to follow the road to the camp protected by his\r\nesquire and the two Musketeers, and return to Athos.\r\n\r\nFor a hundred paces he maintained the speed at which he started; but\r\nwhen out of sight he turned his horse to the right, made a circuit, and\r\ncame back within twenty paces of a high hedge to watch the passage of\r\nthe little troop. Having recognized the laced hats of his companions\r\nand the golden fringe of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s cloak, he waited till the\r\nhorsemen had turned the angle of the road, and having lost sight of\r\nthem, he returned at a gallop to the inn, which was opened to him\r\nwithout hesitation.\r\n\r\nThe host recognized him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy officer,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9chas forgotten to give a piece of very\r\nimportant information to the lady, and has sent me back to repair his\r\nforgetfulness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo up,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host; \xe2\x80\x9cshe is still in her chamber.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos availed himself of the permission, ascended the stairs with his\r\nlightest step, gained the landing, and through the open door perceived\r\nMilady putting on her hat.\r\n\r\nHe entered the chamber and closed the door behind him. At the noise he\r\nmade in pushing the bolt, Milady turned round.\r\n\r\nAthos was standing before the door, enveloped in his cloak, with his\r\nhat pulled down over his eyes. On seeing this figure, mute and\r\nimmovable as a statue, Milady was frightened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you, and what do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d cried she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cit is certainly she!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd letting fall his cloak and raising his hat, he advanced toward\r\nMilady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know me, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nMilady made one step forward, and then drew back as if she had seen a\r\nserpent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo far, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI perceive you know me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe Comte de la F\xc3\xa8re!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Milady, becoming exceedingly pale, and\r\ndrawing back till the wall prevented her from going any farther.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Milady,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cthe Comte de la F\xc3\xa8re in person, who\r\ncomes expressly from the other world to have the pleasure of paying you\r\na visit. Sit down, madame, and let us talk, as the cardinal said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady, under the influence of inexpressible terror, sat down without\r\nuttering a word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou certainly are a demon sent upon the earth!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cYour\r\npower is great, I know; but you also know that with the help of God men\r\nhave often conquered the most terrible demons. You have once before\r\nthrown yourself in my path. I thought I had crushed you, madame; but\r\neither I was deceived or hell has resuscitated you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady at these words, which recalled frightful remembrances, hung down\r\nher head with a suppressed groan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, hell has resuscitated you,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cHell has made you\r\nrich, hell has given you another name, hell has almost made you another\r\nface; but it has neither effaced the stains from your soul nor the\r\nbrand from your body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady arose as if moved by a powerful spring, and her eyes flashed\r\nlightning. Athos remained sitting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou believed me to be dead, did you not, as I believed you to be? And\r\nthe name of Athos as well concealed the Comte de la F\xc3\xa8re, as the name\r\nMilady Clarik concealed Anne de Breuil. Was it not so you were called\r\nwhen your honored brother married us? Our position is truly a strange\r\none,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos, laughing. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have only lived up to the present\r\ntime because we believed each other dead, and because a remembrance is\r\nless oppressive than a living creature, though a remembrance is\r\nsometimes devouring.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in a hollow, faint voice, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat brings you back to\r\nme, and what do you want with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish to tell you that though remaining invisible to your eyes, I\r\nhave not lost sight of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know what I have done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can relate to you, day by day, your actions from your entrance to\r\nthe service of the cardinal to this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA smile of incredulity passed over the pale lips of Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen! It was you who cut off the two diamond studs from the shoulder\r\nof the Duke of Buckingham; it was you who had Madame Bonacieux carried\r\noff; it was you who, in love with De Wardes and thinking to pass the\r\nnight with him, opened the door to Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; it was you who,\r\nbelieving that De Wardes had deceived you, wished to have him killed by\r\nhis rival; it was you who, when this rival had discovered your infamous\r\nsecret, wished to have him killed in his turn by two assassins, whom\r\nyou sent in pursuit of him; it was you who, finding the balls had\r\nmissed their mark, sent poisoned wine with a forged letter, to make\r\nyour victim believe that the wine came from his friends. In short, it\r\nwas you who have but now in this chamber, seated in this chair I now\r\nfill, made an engagement with Cardinal Richelieu to cause the Duke of\r\nBuckingham to be assassinated, in exchange for the promise he has made\r\nyou to allow you to assassinate D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady was livid.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must be Satan!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cBut at all events listen well to this.\r\nAssassinate the Duke of Buckingham, or cause him to be assassinated\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ncare very little about that! I don\xe2\x80\x99t know him. Besides, he is an\r\nEnglishman. But do not touch with the tip of your finger a single hair\r\nof D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who is a faithful friend whom I love and defend, or I\r\nswear to you by the head of my father the crime which you shall have\r\nendeavored to commit, or shall have committed, shall be the last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan has cruelly insulted me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, in a hollow\r\ntone; \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan shall die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! Is it possible to insult you, madame?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, laughing;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9che has insulted you, and he shall die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe shall die!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cshe first, and he afterward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos was seized with a kind of vertigo. The sight of this creature,\r\nwho had nothing of the woman about her, recalled awful remembrances. He\r\nthought how one day, in a less dangerous situation than the one in\r\nwhich he was now placed, he had already endeavored to sacrifice her to\r\nhis honor. His desire for blood returned, burning his brain and\r\npervading his frame like a raging fever; he arose in his turn, reached\r\nhis hand to his belt, drew forth a pistol, and cocked it.\r\n\r\nMilady, pale as a corpse, endeavored to cry out; but her swollen tongue\r\ncould utter no more than a hoarse sound which had nothing human in it\r\nand resembled the rattle of a wild beast. Motionless against the dark\r\ntapestry, with her hair in disorder, she appeared like a horrid image\r\nof terror.\r\n\r\nAthos slowly raised his pistol, stretched out his arm so that the\r\nweapon almost touched Milady\xe2\x80\x99s forehead, and then, in a voice the more\r\nterrible from having the supreme calmness of a fixed resolution,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will this instant deliver to me the paper the\r\ncardinal signed; or upon my soul, I will blow your brains out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith another man, Milady might have preserved some doubt; but she knew\r\nAthos. Nevertheless, she remained motionless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have one second to decide,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nMilady saw by the contraction of his countenance that the trigger was\r\nabout to be pulled; she reached her hand quickly to her bosom, drew out\r\na paper, and held it toward Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand be accursed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos took the paper, returned the pistol to his belt, approached the\r\nlamp to be assured that it was the paper, unfolded it, and read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDec. 3, 1627\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of\r\nthis has done what he has done.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRICHELIEU\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, resuming his cloak and putting on his hat, \xe2\x80\x9cnow\r\nthat I have drawn your teeth, viper, bite if you can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd he left the chamber without once looking behind him.\r\n\r\nAt the door he found the two men and the spare horse which they held.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cMonseigneur\xe2\x80\x99s order is, you know, to conduct\r\nthat woman, without losing time, to Fort La Pointe, and never to leave\r\nher till she is on board.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs these words agreed wholly with the order they had received, they\r\nbowed their heads in sign of assent.\r\n\r\nWith regard to Athos, he leaped lightly into the saddle and set out at\r\nfull gallop; only instead of following the road, he went across the\r\nfields, urging his horse to the utmost and stopping occasionally to\r\nlisten.\r\n\r\nIn one of those halts he heard the steps of several horses on the road.\r\nHe had no doubt it was the cardinal and his escort. He immediately made\r\na new point in advance, rubbed his horse down with some heath and\r\nleaves of trees, and placed himself across the road, about two hundred\r\npaces from the camp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho goes there?\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, as soon as he perceived the horsemen.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is our brave Musketeer, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cit is he.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said Richelieu, \xe2\x80\x9creceive my thanks for the good guard\r\nyou have kept. Gentlemen, we are arrived; take the gate on the left.\r\nThe watchword is, \xe2\x80\x98King and R\xc3\xa9.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSaying these words, the cardinal saluted the three friends with an\r\ninclination of his head, and took the right hand, followed by his\r\nattendant\xe2\x80\x94for that night he himself slept in the camp.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos and Aramis together, as soon as the cardinal was\r\nout of hearing, \xe2\x80\x9cwell, he signed the paper she required!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, coolly, \xe2\x80\x9csince here it is.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the three friends did not exchange another word till they reached\r\ntheir quarters, except to give the watchword to the sentinels. Only\r\nthey sent Mousqueton to tell Planchet that his master was requested,\r\nthe instant that he left the trenches, to come to the quarters of the\r\nMusketeers.\r\n\r\nMilady, as Athos had foreseen, on finding the two men that awaited her,\r\nmade no difficulty in following them. She had had for an instant an\r\ninclination to be reconducted to the cardinal, and relate everything to\r\nhim; but a revelation on her part would bring about a revelation on the\r\npart of Athos. She might say that Athos had hanged her; but then Athos\r\nwould tell that she was branded. She thought it was best to preserve\r\nsilence, to discreetly set off to accomplish her difficult mission with\r\nher usual skill; and then, all things being accomplished to the\r\nsatisfaction of the cardinal, to come to him and claim her vengeance.\r\n\r\nIn consequence, after having traveled all night, at seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock she\r\nwas at the fort of the Point; at eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock she had embarked; and at\r\nnine, the vessel, which with letters of marque from the cardinal was\r\nsupposed to be sailing for Bayonne, raised anchor, and steered its\r\ncourse toward England.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLVI.\r\nTHE BASTION SAINT-GERVAIS\r\n\r\n\r\nOn arriving at the lodgings of his three friends, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan found them\r\nassembled in the same chamber. Athos was meditating; Porthos was\r\ntwisting his mustache; Aramis was saying his prayers in a charming\r\nlittle Book of Hours, bound in blue velvet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu_, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope what you have to tell me is\r\nworth the trouble, or else, I warn you, I will not pardon you for\r\nmaking me come here instead of getting a little rest after a night\r\nspent in taking and dismantling a bastion. Ah, why were you not there,\r\ngentlemen? It was warm work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe were in a place where it was not very cold,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Porthos,\r\ngiving his mustache a twist which was peculiar to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, oh!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, comprehending the slight frown of the\r\nMusketeer. \xe2\x80\x9cIt appears there is something fresh aboard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou went to breakfast the day before yesterday\r\nat the inn of the Parpaillot, I believe?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow did you fare?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor my part, I ate but little. The day before yesterday was a fish\r\nday, and they had nothing but meat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cno fish at a seaport?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey say,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, resuming his pious reading, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the dyke\r\nwhich the cardinal is making drives them all out into the open sea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that is not quite what I mean to ask you, Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want to know if you were left alone, and nobody interrupted you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I think there were not many intruders. Yes, Athos, I know what\r\nyou mean: we shall do very well at the Parpaillot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us go to the Parpaillot, then, for here the walls are like sheets\r\nof paper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was accustomed to his friend\xe2\x80\x99s manner of acting, and\r\nwho perceived immediately, by a word, a gesture, or a sign from him,\r\nthat the circumstances were serious, took Athos\xe2\x80\x99s arm, and went out\r\nwithout saying anything. Porthos followed, chatting with Aramis.\r\n\r\nOn their way they met Grimaud. Athos made him a sign to come with them.\r\nGrimaud, according to custom, obeyed in silence; the poor lad had\r\nnearly come to the pass of forgetting how to speak.\r\n\r\nThey arrived at the drinking room of the Parpaillot. It was seven\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, and daylight began to appear. The three friends\r\nordered breakfast, and went into a room in which the host said they\r\nwould not be disturbed.\r\n\r\nUnfortunately, the hour was badly chosen for a private conference. The\r\nmorning drum had just been beaten; everyone shook off the drowsiness of\r\nnight, and to dispel the humid morning air, came to take a drop at the\r\ninn. Dragoons, Swiss, Guardsmen, Musketeers, light-horsemen, succeeded\r\none another with a rapidity which might answer the purpose of the host\r\nvery well, but agreed badly with the views of the four friends. Thus\r\nthey applied very curtly to the salutations, healths, and jokes of\r\ntheir companions.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see how it will be,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos: \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall get into some pretty\r\nquarrel or other, and we have no need of one just now. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, tell\r\nus what sort of a night you have had, and we will describe ours\r\nafterward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said a light-horseman, with a glass of brandy in his hand,\r\nwhich he sipped slowly. \xe2\x80\x9cI hear you gentlemen of the Guards have been\r\nin the trenches tonight, and that you did not get much the best of the\r\nRochellais.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan looked at Athos to know if he ought to reply to this\r\nintruder who thus mixed unasked in their conversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you hear Monsieur de Busigny, who does you\r\nthe honor to ask you a question? Relate what has passed during the\r\nnight, since these gentlemen desire to know it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you not taken a bastion?\xe2\x80\x9d said a Swiss, who was drinking rum out\r\nof a beer glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, bowing, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have had that honor. We\r\neven have, as you may have heard, introduced a barrel of powder under\r\none of the angles, which in blowing up made a very pretty breach.\r\nWithout reckoning that as the bastion was not built yesterday all the\r\nrest of the building was badly shaken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what bastion is it?\xe2\x80\x9d asked a dragoon, with his saber run through a\r\ngoose which he was taking to be cooked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bastion St. Gervais,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom behind which the\r\nRochellais annoyed our workmen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas that affair hot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, moderately so. We lost five men, and the Rochellais eight or\r\nten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Balzempleu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss, who, notwithstanding the admirable\r\ncollection of oaths possessed by the German language, had acquired a\r\nhabit of swearing in French.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is probable,\xe2\x80\x9d said the light-horseman, \xe2\x80\x9cthat they will send\r\npioneers this morning to repair the bastion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s probable,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9ca wager!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, _wooi_, a vager!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the Swiss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the light-horseman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop a bit,\xe2\x80\x9d said the dragoon, placing his saber like a spit upon the\r\ntwo large iron dogs which held the firebrands in the chimney, \xe2\x80\x9cstop a\r\nbit, I am in it. You cursed host! a dripping pan immediately, that I\r\nmay not lose a drop of the fat of this estimable bird.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou was right,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss; \xe2\x80\x9cgoose grease is kood with basdry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere!\xe2\x80\x9d said the dragoon. \xe2\x80\x9cNow for the wager! We listen, Monsieur\r\nAthos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the wager!\xe2\x80\x9d said the light-horseman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Monsieur de Busigny, I will bet you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat my three\r\ncompanions, Messieurs Porthos, Aramis, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and myself, will\r\ngo and breakfast in the bastion St. Gervais, and we will remain there\r\nan hour, by the watch, whatever the enemy may do to dislodge us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis looked at each other; they began to comprehend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in the ear of Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are going to get us\r\nall killed without mercy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are much more likely to be killed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cif we do not go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, turning round upon his chair and\r\ntwisting his mustache, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a fair bet, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI take it,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Busigny; \xe2\x80\x9cso let us fix the stake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are four gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cand we are four; an unlimited\r\ndinner for eight. Will that do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapitally,\xe2\x80\x9d replied M. de Busigny.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerfectly,\xe2\x80\x9d said the dragoon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat shoots me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss.\r\n\r\nThe fourth auditor, who during all this conversation had played a mute\r\npart, made a sign of the head in proof that he acquiesced in the\r\nproposition.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe breakfast for these gentlemen is ready,\xe2\x80\x9d said the host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, bring it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\nThe host obeyed. Athos called Grimaud, pointed to a large basket which\r\nlay in a corner, and made a sign to him to wrap the viands up in the\r\nnapkins.\r\n\r\nGrimaud understood that it was to be a breakfast on the grass, took the\r\nbasket, packed up the viands, added the bottles, and then took the\r\nbasket on his arm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where are you going to eat my breakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat matter, if you are paid for it?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, and he threw two\r\npistoles majestically on the table.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I give you the change, my officer?\xe2\x80\x9d said the host.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, only add two bottles of champagne, and the difference will be for\r\nthe napkins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe host had not quite so good a bargain as he at first hoped for, but\r\nhe made amends by slipping in two bottles of Anjou wine instead of two\r\nbottles of champagne.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Busigny,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cwill you be so kind as to set your\r\nwatch with mine, or permit me to regulate mine by yours?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich you please, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said the light-horseman, drawing from his\r\nfob a very handsome watch, studded with diamonds; \xe2\x80\x9chalf past seven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThirty-five minutes after seven,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cby which you perceive I\r\nam five minutes faster than you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd bowing to all the astonished persons present, the young men took\r\nthe road to the bastion St. Gervais, followed by Grimaud, who carried\r\nthe basket, ignorant of where he was going but in the passive obedience\r\nwhich Athos had taught him not even thinking of asking.\r\n\r\nAs long as they were within the circle of the camp, the four friends\r\ndid not exchange one word; besides, they were followed by the curious,\r\nwho, hearing of the wager, were anxious to know how they would come out\r\nof it. But when once they passed the line of circumvallation and found\r\nthemselves in the open plain, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was completely ignorant\r\nof what was going forward, thought it was time to demand an\r\nexplanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now, my dear Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdo me the kindness to tell me where\r\nwe are going?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you see plainly enough we are going to the bastion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what are we going to do there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know well that we go to breakfast there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why did we not breakfast at the Parpaillot?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause we have very important matters to communicate to one another,\r\nand it was impossible to talk five minutes in that inn without being\r\nannoyed by all those importunate fellows, who keep coming in, saluting\r\nyou, and addressing you.
