Here at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, pointing to the\r\nbastion, \xe2\x80\x9cthey will not come and disturb us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, with that prudence which allied\r\nitself in him so naturally with excessive bravery, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we could have\r\nfound some retired place on the downs or the seashore.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere we should have been seen all four conferring together, so that\r\nat the end of a quarter of an hour the cardinal would have been\r\ninformed by his spies that we were holding a council.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cAthos is right: _Animadvertuntur in desertis_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA desert would not have been amiss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cbut it behooved us\r\nto find it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no desert where a bird cannot pass over one\xe2\x80\x99s head, where a\r\nfish cannot leap out of the water, where a rabbit cannot come out of\r\nits burrow, and I believe that bird, fish, and rabbit each becomes a\r\nspy of the cardinal. Better, then, pursue our enterprise; from which,\r\nbesides, we cannot retreat without shame. We have made a wager\xe2\x80\x94a wager\r\nwhich could not have been foreseen, and of which I defy anyone to\r\ndivine the true cause. We are going, in order to win it, to remain an\r\nhour in the bastion. Either we shall be attacked, or not. If we are\r\nnot, we shall have all the time to talk, and nobody will hear us\xe2\x80\x94for I\r\nguarantee the walls of the bastion have no ears; if we are, we will\r\ntalk of our affairs just the same. Moreover, in defending ourselves, we\r\nshall cover ourselves with glory. You see that everything is to our\r\nadvantage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we shall indubitably attract a ball.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou know well that the balls most to\r\nbe dreaded are not from the enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut for such an expedition we surely ought to have brought our\r\nmuskets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are stupid, friend Porthos. Why should we load ourselves with a\r\nuseless burden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t find a good musket, twelve cartridges, and a powder flask very\r\nuseless in the face of an enemy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, \xe2\x80\x9chave you not heard what D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan said?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did he say?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan said that in the attack of last night eight or ten\r\nFrenchmen were killed, and as many Rochellais.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe bodies were not plundered, were they? It appears the conquerors\r\nhad something else to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, we shall find their muskets, their cartridges, and their flasks;\r\nand instead of four musketoons and twelve balls, we shall have fifteen\r\nguns and a hundred charges to fire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9ctruly you are a great man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPorthos nodded in sign of agreement. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan alone did not seem\r\nconvinced.\r\n\r\nGrimaud no doubt shared the misgivings of the young man, for seeing\r\nthat they continued to advance toward the bastion\xe2\x80\x94something he had till\r\nthen doubted\xe2\x80\x94he pulled his master by the skirt of his coat.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are we going?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he, by a gesture.\r\n\r\nAthos pointed to the bastion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Grimaud, in the same silent dialect, \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall leave our\r\nskins there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos raised his eyes and his finger toward heaven.\r\n\r\nGrimaud put his basket on the ground and sat down with a shake of the\r\nhead.\r\n\r\nAthos took a pistol from his belt, looked to see if it was properly\r\nprimed, cocked it, and placed the muzzle close to Grimaud\xe2\x80\x99s ear.\r\n\r\nGrimaud was on his legs again as if by a spring. Athos then made him a\r\nsign to take up his basket and to walk on first. Grimaud obeyed. All\r\nthat Grimaud gained by this momentary pantomime was to pass from the\r\nrear guard to the vanguard.\r\n\r\nArrived at the bastion, the four friends turned round.\r\n\r\nMore than three hundred soldiers of all kinds were assembled at the\r\ngate of the camp; and in a separate group might be distinguished M. de\r\nBusigny, the dragoon, the Swiss, and the fourth bettor.\r\n\r\nAthos took off his hat, placed it on the end of his sword, and waved it\r\nin the air.\r\n\r\nAll the spectators returned him his salute, accompanying this courtesy\r\nwith a loud hurrah which was audible to the four; after which all four\r\ndisappeared in the bastion, whither Grimaud had preceded them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLVII.\r\nTHE COUNCIL OF THE MUSKETEERS\r\n\r\n\r\nAs Athos had foreseen, the bastion was only occupied by a dozen\r\ncorpses, French and Rochellais.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, who had assumed the command of the expedition,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwhile Grimaud spreads the table, let us begin by collecting the guns\r\nand cartridges together. We can talk while performing that necessary\r\ntask. These gentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, pointing to the bodies, \xe2\x80\x9ccannot hear\r\nus.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut we could throw them into the ditch,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cafter having\r\nassured ourselves they have nothing in their pockets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s Grimaud\xe2\x80\x99s business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cpray let Grimaud search them and throw\r\nthem over the walls.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeaven forfend!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cthey may serve us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese bodies serve us?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are mad, dear friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJudge not rashly, say the gospel and the cardinal,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many guns, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwelve,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many shots?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA hundred.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s quite as many as we shall want. Let us load the guns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four Musketeers went to work; and as they were loading the last\r\nmusket Grimaud announced that the breakfast was ready.\r\n\r\nAthos replied, always by gestures, that that was well, and indicated to\r\nGrimaud, by pointing to a turret that resembled a pepper caster, that\r\nhe was to stand as sentinel. Only, to alleviate the tediousness of the\r\nduty, Athos allowed him to take a loaf, two cutlets, and a bottle of\r\nwine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now to table,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\nThe four friends seated themselves on the ground with their legs\r\ncrossed like Turks, or even tailors.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cas there is no longer any fear of being\r\noverheard, I hope you are going to let me into your secret.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope at the same time to procure you amusement and glory,\r\ngentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI have induced you to take a charming\r\npromenade; here is a delicious breakfast; and yonder are five hundred\r\npersons, as you may see through the loopholes, taking us for heroes or\r\nmadmen\xe2\x80\x94two classes of imbeciles greatly resembling each other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the secret!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe secret is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I saw Milady last night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was lifting a glass to his lips; but at the name of Milady,\r\nhis hand trembled so, that he was obliged to put the glass on the\r\nground again for fear of spilling the contents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou saw your wi\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cYou forget, my dear, you forget that these\r\ngentlemen are not initiated into my family affairs like yourself. I\r\nhave seen Milady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithin two leagues of this place, at the inn of the Red Dovecot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case I am lost,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so bad yet,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cfor by this time she must have quit\r\nthe shores of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan breathed again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut after all,\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwho is Milady?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA charming woman!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, sipping a glass of sparkling wine.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVillainous host!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, \xe2\x80\x9che has given us Anjou wine instead of\r\nchampagne, and fancies we know no better! Yes,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\ncharming woman, who entertained kind views toward our friend\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, on his part, has given her some offense for which she\r\ntried to revenge herself a month ago by having him killed by two musket\r\nshots, a week ago by trying to poison him, and yesterday by demanding\r\nhis head of the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! by demanding my head of the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, pale\r\nwith terror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is true as the Gospel,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cI heard her with my\r\nown ears.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, letting his arm fall with discouragement, \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nis useless to struggle longer. I may as well blow my brains out, and\r\nall will be over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the last folly to be committed,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cseeing it is the\r\nonly one for which there is no remedy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I can never escape,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwith such enemies. First,\r\nmy stranger of Meung; then De Wardes, to whom I have given three sword\r\nwounds; next Milady, whose secret I have discovered; finally, the\r\ncardinal, whose vengeance I have balked.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat only makes four; and we are four\xe2\x80\x94one for one.\r\n_Pardieu!_ if we may believe the signs Grimaud is making, we are about\r\nto have to do with a very different number of people. What is it,\r\nGrimaud? Considering the gravity of the occasion, I permit you to\r\nspeak, my friend; but be laconic, I beg. What do you see?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA troop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf how many persons?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty men.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sort of men?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSixteen pioneers, four soldiers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow far distant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive hundred paces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood! We have just time to finish this fowl and to drink one glass of\r\nwine to your health, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo your health!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Porthos and Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, to my health! although I am very much afraid that your\r\ngood wishes will not be of great service to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cGod is great, as say the followers of Mohammed, and\r\nthe future is in his hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, swallowing the contents of his glass, which he put down close to\r\nhim, Athos arose carelessly, took the musket next to him, and drew near\r\nto one of the loopholes.\r\n\r\nPorthos, Aramis and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan followed his example. As to Grimaud, he\r\nreceived orders to place himself behind the four friends in order to\r\nreload their weapons.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cit was hardly worth while to distribute\r\nourselves for twenty fellows armed with pickaxes, mattocks, and\r\nshovels. Grimaud had only to make them a sign to go away, and I am\r\nconvinced they would have left us in peace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI doubt that,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cfor they are advancing very\r\nresolutely. Besides, in addition to the pioneers, there are four\r\nsoldiers and a brigadier, armed with muskets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s because they don\xe2\x80\x99t see us,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cI must confess I feel a great repugnance to\r\nfire on these poor devils of civilians.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a bad priest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwho has pity for heretics.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cAramis is right. I will warn them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will be\r\nshot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Athos heeded not his advice. Mounting on the breach, with his\r\nmusket in one hand and his hat in the other, he said, bowing\r\ncourteously and addressing the soldiers and the pioneers, who,\r\nastonished at this apparition, stopped fifty paces from the bastion:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, a few friends and myself are about to breakfast in this\r\nbastion. Now, you know nothing is more disagreeable than being\r\ndisturbed when one is at breakfast. We request you, then, if you really\r\nhave business here, to wait till we have finished our repast, or to\r\ncome again a short time hence; unless, which would be far better, you\r\nform the salutary resolution to quit the side of the rebels, and come\r\nand drink with us to the health of the King of France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t you see they are aiming?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cbut they are only civilians\xe2\x80\x94very bad marksmen,\r\nwho will be sure not to hit me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, at the same instant four shots were fired, and the balls were\r\nflattened against the wall around Athos, but not one touched him.\r\n\r\nFour shots replied to them almost instantaneously, but much better\r\naimed than those of the aggressors; three soldiers fell dead, and one\r\nof the pioneers was wounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, still on the breach, \xe2\x80\x9canother musket!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrimaud immediately obeyed. On their part, the three friends had\r\nreloaded their arms; a second discharge followed the first. The\r\nbrigadier and two pioneers fell dead; the rest of the troop took to\r\nflight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, gentlemen, a _sortie!_\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos.\r\n\r\nAnd the four friends rushed out of the fort, gained the field of\r\nbattle, picked up the four muskets of the privates and the half-pike of\r\nthe brigadier, and convinced that the fugitives would not stop till\r\nthey reached the city, turned again toward the bastion, bearing with\r\nthem the trophies of their victory.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReload the muskets, Grimaud,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cand we, gentlemen, will go\r\non with our breakfast, and resume our conversation. Where were we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI recollect you were saying,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthat after having\r\ndemanded my head of the cardinal, Milady had quit the shores of France.\r\nWhither goes she?\xe2\x80\x9d added he, strongly interested in the route Milady\r\nfollowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe goes into England,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith what view?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the view of assassinating, or causing to be assassinated, the\r\nDuke of Buckingham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan uttered an exclamation of surprise and indignation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this is infamous!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to that,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI beg you to believe that I care very little\r\nabout it. Now you have done, Grimaud, take our brigadier\xe2\x80\x99s half-pike,\r\ntie a napkin to it, and plant it on top of our bastion, that these\r\nrebels of Rochellais may see that they have to deal with brave and\r\nloyal soldiers of the king.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrimaud obeyed without replying. An instant afterward, the white flag\r\nwas floating over the heads of the four friends. A thunder of applause\r\nsaluted its appearance; half the camp was at the barrier.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou care little if she kills Buckingham or\r\ncauses him to be killed? But the duke is our friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe duke is English; the duke fights against us. Let her do what she\r\nlikes with the duke; I care no more about him than an empty bottle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd Athos threw fifteen paces from him an empty bottle from which he\r\nhad poured the last drop into his glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA moment,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI will not abandon Buckingham thus. He\r\ngave us some very fine horses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd moreover, very handsome saddles,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, who at the moment\r\nwore on his cloak the lace of his own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cGod desires the conversion and not the death\r\nof a sinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cand we will return to that subject later, if such\r\nbe your pleasure; but what for the moment engaged my attention most\r\nearnestly, and I am sure you will understand me, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, was the\r\ngetting from this woman a kind of _carte blanche_ which she had\r\nextorted from the cardinal, and by means of which she could with\r\nimpunity get rid of you and perhaps of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this creature must be a demon!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, holding out his\r\nplate to Aramis, who was cutting up a fowl.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this _carte blanche_,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cthis _carte blanche_,\r\ndoes it remain in her hands?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, it passed into mine; I will not say without trouble, for if I did\r\nI should tell a lie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Athos, I shall no longer count the number of times I am\r\nindebted to you for my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen it was to go to her that you left us?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have that letter of the cardinal?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere it is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; and he took the invaluable paper from the\r\npocket of his uniform. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan unfolded it with one hand, whose\r\ntrembling he did not even attempt to conceal, to read:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDec. 3, 1627\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is by my order and for the good of the state that the bearer of\r\nthis has done what he has done.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRICHELIEU\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn fact,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cit is an absolution according to rule.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat paper must be torn to pieces,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who fancied he\r\nread in it his sentence of death.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn the contrary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cit must be preserved carefully. I would\r\nnot give up this paper if covered with as many gold pieces.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what will she do now?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the young man.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, carelessly, \xe2\x80\x9cshe is probably going to write to\r\nthe cardinal that a damned Musketeer, named Athos, has taken her\r\nsafe-conduct from her by force; she will advise him in the same letter\r\nto get rid of his two friends, Aramis and Porthos, at the same time.\r\nThe cardinal will remember that these are the same men who have often\r\ncrossed his path; and then some fine morning he will arrest D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nand for fear he should feel lonely, he will send us to keep him company\r\nin the Bastille.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to! It appears to me you make dull jokes, my dear,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not jest,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat to twist that damned Milady\xe2\x80\x99s neck\r\nwould be a smaller sin than to twist those of these poor devils of\r\nHuguenots, who have committed no other crime than singing in French the\r\npsalms we sing in Latin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat says the abb\xc3\xa9?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos, quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI say I am entirely of Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s opinion,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I, too,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFortunately, she is far off,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cfor I confess she would\r\nworry me if she were here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe worries me in England as well as in France,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe worries me everywhere,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut when you held her in your power, why did you not drown her,\r\nstrangle her, hang her?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is only the dead who do not\r\nreturn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think so, Porthos?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Musketeer, with a sad smile which\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan alone understood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have an idea,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo arms!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Grimaud.\r\n\r\nThe young men sprang up, and seized their muskets.\r\n\r\nThis time a small troop advanced, consisting of from twenty to\r\ntwenty-five men; but they were not pioneers, they were soldiers of the\r\ngarrison.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we return to the camp?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think the sides\r\nare equal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible, for three reasons,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cThe first, that we\r\nhave not finished breakfast; the second, that we still have some very\r\nimportant things to say; and the third, that it yet wants ten minutes\r\nbefore the lapse of the hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cwe must form a plan of battle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s very simple,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cAs soon as the enemy are within\r\nmusket shot, we must fire upon them. If they continue to advance, we\r\nmust fire again. We must fire as long as we have loaded guns. If those\r\nwho remain of the troop persist in coming to the assault, we will allow\r\nthe besiegers to get as far as the ditch, and then we will push down\r\nupon their heads that strip of wall which keeps its perpendicular by a\r\nmiracle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cDecidedly, Athos, you were born to be a\r\ngeneral, and the cardinal, who fancies himself a great soldier, is\r\nnothing beside you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cno divided attention, I beg; let each one\r\npick out his man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cover mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I mine,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I _idem_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFire, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\nThe four muskets made but one report, but four men fell.\r\n\r\nThe drum immediately beat, and the little troop advanced at charging\r\npace.\r\n\r\nThen the shots were repeated without regularity, but always aimed with\r\nthe same accuracy. Nevertheless, as if they had been aware of the\r\nnumerical weakness of the friends, the Rochellais continued to advance\r\nin quick time.\r\n\r\nWith every three shots at least two men fell; but the march of those\r\nwho remained was not slackened.\r\n\r\nArrived at the foot of the bastion, there were still more than a dozen\r\nof the enemy. A last discharge welcomed them, but did not stop them;\r\nthey jumped into the ditch, and prepared to scale the breach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my friends,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cfinish them at a blow. To the wall; to\r\nthe wall!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the four friends, seconded by Grimaud, pushed with the barrels of\r\ntheir muskets an enormous sheet of the wall, which bent as if pushed by\r\nthe wind, and detaching itself from its base, fell with a horrible\r\ncrash into the ditch. Then a fearful crash was heard; a cloud of dust\r\nmounted toward the sky\xe2\x80\x94and all was over!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan we have destroyed them all, from the first to the last?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, it appears so!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cthere go three or four, limping away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, three or four of these unfortunate men, covered with dirt and\r\nblood, fled along the hollow way, and at length regained the city.\r\nThese were all who were left of the little troop.\r\n\r\nAthos looked at his watch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwe have been here an hour, and our wager is won;\r\nbut we will be fair players. Besides, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan has not told us his\r\nidea yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the Musketeer, with his usual coolness, reseated himself before the\r\nremains of the breakfast.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy idea?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; you said you had an idea,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I remember,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will go to England a second\r\ntime; I will go and find Buckingham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall not do that, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, coolly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why not? Have I not been there once?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but at that period we were not at war. At that period Buckingham\r\nwas an ally, and not an enemy. What you would now do amounts to\r\ntreason.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan perceived the force of this reasoning, and was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cI think I have an idea, in my turn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence for Monsieur Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s idea!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will ask leave of absence of Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, on some pretext\r\nor other which you must invent; I am not very clever at pretexts.\r\nMilady does not know me; I will get access to her without her\r\nsuspecting me, and when I catch my beauty, I will strangle her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not far from approving the idea of\r\nMonsieur Porthos.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cKill a woman? No, listen to me; I have the\r\ntrue idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see your idea, Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, who felt much deference for\r\nthe young Musketeer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must inform the queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my faith, yes!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, at the same time; \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\nare coming nearer to it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cInform the queen!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cand how? Have we relations with the\r\ncourt? Could we send anyone to Paris without its being known in the\r\ncamp? From here to Paris it is a hundred and forty leagues; before our\r\nletter was at Angers we should be in a dungeon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to remitting a letter with safety to her Majesty,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis,\r\ncoloring, \xe2\x80\x9cI will take that upon myself. I know a clever person at\r\nTours\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis stopped on seeing Athos smile.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, do you not adopt this means, Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do not reject it altogether,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I wish to remind\r\nAramis that he cannot quit the camp, and that nobody but one of\r\nourselves is trustworthy; that two hours after the messenger has set\r\nout, all the Capuchins, all the police, all the black caps of the\r\ncardinal, will know your letter by heart, and you and your clever\r\nperson will be arrested.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithout reckoning,\xe2\x80\x9d objected Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthat the queen would save\r\nMonsieur de Buckingham, but would take no heed of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat Porthos says is full of sense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah! but what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in the city yonder?\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are beating the general alarm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four friends listened, and the sound of the drum plainly reached\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see, they are going to send a whole regiment against us,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t think of holding out against a whole regiment, do you?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nPorthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Musketeer. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel myself quite in a humor for it;\r\nand I would hold out before an army if we had taken the precaution to\r\nbring a dozen more bottles of wine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my word, the drum draws near,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it come,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a quarter of an hour\xe2\x80\x99s journey from\r\nhere to the city, consequently a quarter of an hour\xe2\x80\x99s journey from the\r\ncity to hither. That is more than time enough for us to devise a plan.\r\nIf we go from this place we shall never find another so suitable. Ah,\r\nstop! I have it, gentlemen; the right idea has just occurred to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAllow me to give Grimaud some indispensable orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos made a sign for his lackey to approach.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrimaud,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, pointing to the bodies which lay under the wall\r\nof the bastion, \xe2\x80\x9ctake those gentlemen, set them up against the wall,\r\nput their hats upon their heads, and their guns in their hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, the great man!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI comprehend now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou comprehend?\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you comprehend, Grimaud?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\nGrimaud made a sign in the affirmative.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all that is necessary,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cnow for my idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should like, however, to comprehend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is useless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! Athos\xe2\x80\x99s idea!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Aramis and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, at the same\r\ntime.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis Milady, this woman, this creature, this demon, has a\r\nbrother-in-law, as I think you told me, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I know him very well; and I also believe that he has not a very\r\nwarm affection for his sister-in-law.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no harm in that. If he detested her, it would be all the\r\nbetter,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case we are as well off as we wish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cI would like to know what Grimaud is about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence, Porthos!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is her brother-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord de Winter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe returned to London at the first sound of war.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, there\xe2\x80\x99s just the man we want,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is he whom we\r\nmust warn. We will have him informed that his sister-in-law is on the\r\npoint of having someone assassinated, and beg him not to lose sight of\r\nher. There is in London, I hope, some establishment like that of the\r\nMagdalens, or of the Repentant Daughters. He must place his sister in\r\none of these, and we shall be in peace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ctill she comes out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, my faith!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou require too much, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. I have\r\ngiven you all I have, and I beg leave to tell you that this is the\r\nbottom of my sack.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I think it would be still better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cto inform the\r\nqueen and Lord de Winter at the same time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but who is to carry the letter to Tours, and who to London?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI answer for Bazin,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I for Planchet,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cif we cannot leave the camp, our lackeys may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure they may; and this very day we will write the letters,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Aramis. \xe2\x80\x9cGive the lackeys money, and they will start.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will give them money?\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you any money?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four friends looked at one another, and a cloud came over the brows\r\nwhich but lately had been so cheerful.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook out!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI see black points and red points moving\r\nyonder. Why did you talk of a regiment, Athos? It is a veritable army!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cthere they are. See the sneaks come,\r\nwithout drum or trumpet. Ah, ah! have you finished, Grimaud?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrimaud made a sign in the affirmative, and pointed to a dozen bodies\r\nwhich he had set up in the most picturesque attitudes. Some carried\r\narms, others seemed to be taking aim, and the remainder appeared merely\r\nto be sword in hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBravo!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cthat does honor to your imagination.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll very well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I should like to understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us decamp first, and you will understand afterward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA moment, gentlemen, a moment; give Grimaud time to clear away the\r\nbreakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cthe black points and the red points are visibly\r\nenlarging. I am of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s opinion; we have no time to lose in\r\nregaining our camp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cI have nothing to say against a retreat. We\r\nbet upon one hour, and we have stayed an hour and a half. Nothing can\r\nbe said; let us be off, gentlemen, let us be off!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGrimaud was already ahead, with the basket and the dessert. The four\r\nfriends followed, ten paces behind him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil shall we do now, gentlemen?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you forgotten anything?\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe white flag, _morbleu!_ We must not leave a flag in the hands of\r\nthe enemy, even if that flag be but a napkin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Athos ran back to the bastion, mounted the platform, and bore off\r\nthe flag; but as the Rochellais had arrived within musket range, they\r\nopened a terrible fire upon this man, who appeared to expose himself\r\nfor pleasure\xe2\x80\x99s sake.\r\n\r\nBut Athos might be said to bear a charmed life. The balls passed and\r\nwhistled all around him; not one struck him.\r\n\r\nAthos waved his flag, turning his back on the guards of the city, and\r\nsaluting those of the camp. On both sides loud cries arose\xe2\x80\x94on the one\r\nside cries of anger, on the other cries of enthusiasm.\r\n\r\nA second discharge followed the first, and three balls, by passing\r\nthrough it, made the napkin really a flag. Cries were heard from the\r\ncamp, \xe2\x80\x9cCome down! come down!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAthos came down; his friends, who anxiously awaited him, saw him\r\nreturned with joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome along, Athos, come along!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cnow we have found\r\neverything except money, it would be stupid to be killed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut Athos continued to march majestically, whatever remarks his\r\ncompanions made; and they, finding their remarks useless, regulated\r\ntheir pace by his.\r\n\r\nGrimaud and his basket were far in advance, out of the range of the\r\nballs.\r\n\r\nAt the end of an instant they heard a furious fusillade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat are they firing at now? I hear no\r\nballs whistle, and I see nobody!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are firing at the corpses,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the dead cannot return their fire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly not! They will then fancy it is an ambuscade, they will\r\ndeliberate; and by the time they have found out the pleasantry, we\r\nshall be out of the range of their balls. That renders it useless to\r\nget a pleurisy by too much haste.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I comprehend now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the astonished Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s lucky,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, shrugging his shoulders.\r\n\r\nOn their part, the French, on seeing the four friends return at such a\r\nstep, uttered cries of enthusiasm.\r\n\r\nAt length a fresh discharge was heard, and this time the balls came\r\nrattling among the stones around the four friends, and whistling\r\nsharply in their ears. The Rochellais had at last taken possession of\r\nthe bastion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThese Rochellais are bungling fellows,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9chow many have we\r\nkilled of them\xe2\x80\x94a dozen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOr fifteen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow many did we crush under the wall?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEight or ten.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in exchange for all that not even a scratch! Ah, but what is the\r\nmatter with your hand, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan? It bleeds, seemingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it\xe2\x80\x99s nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA spent ball?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot even that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe have said that Athos loved D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan like a child, and this somber\r\nand inflexible personage felt the anxiety of a parent for the young\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly grazed a little,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cmy fingers were caught\r\nbetween two stones\xe2\x80\x94that of the wall and that of my ring\xe2\x80\x94and the skin\r\nwas broken.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat comes of wearing diamonds, my master,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, disdainfully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a diamond. Why the devil,\r\nthen, do we plague ourselves about money, when there is a diamond?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop a bit!\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell thought of, Porthos; this time you have an idea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUndoubtedly,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, drawing himself up at Athos\xe2\x80\x99s compliment;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cas there is a diamond, let us sell it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cit is the queen\xe2\x80\x99s diamond.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe stronger reason why it should be sold,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cThe queen\r\nsaving Monsieur de Buckingham, her lover; nothing more just. The queen\r\nsaving us, her friends; nothing more moral. Let us sell the diamond.\r\nWhat says Monsieur the Abb\xc3\xa9? I don\xe2\x80\x99t ask Porthos; his opinion has been\r\ngiven.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, blushing as usual, \xe2\x80\x9cthat his ring not\r\ncoming from a mistress, and consequently not being a love token,\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan may sell it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Aramis, you speak like theology personified. Your advice,\r\nthen, is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo sell the diamond,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, gaily, \xe2\x80\x9clet us sell the diamond, and say\r\nno more about it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe fusillade continued; but the four friends were out of reach, and\r\nthe Rochellais only fired to appease their consciences.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, it was time that idea came into Porthos\xe2\x80\x99s head. Here we are\r\nat the camp; therefore, gentlemen, not a word more of this affair. We\r\nare observed; they are coming to meet us. We shall be carried in\r\ntriumph.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn fact, as we have said, the whole camp was in motion. More than two\r\nthousand persons had assisted, as at a spectacle, in this fortunate but\r\nwild undertaking of the four friends\xe2\x80\x94an undertaking of which they were\r\nfar from suspecting the real motive. Nothing was heard but cries of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLive the Musketeers! Live the Guards!\xe2\x80\x9d M. de Busigny was the first to\r\ncome and shake Athos by the hand, and acknowledge that the wager was\r\nlost. The dragoon and the Swiss followed him, and all their comrades\r\nfollowed the dragoon and the Swiss. There was nothing but\r\nfelicitations, pressures of the hand, and embraces; there was no end to\r\nthe inextinguishable laughter at the Rochellais. The tumult at length\r\nbecame so great that the cardinal fancied there must be some riot, and\r\nsent La Houdini\xc3\xa8re, his captain of the Guards, to inquire what was\r\ngoing on.\r\n\r\nThe affair was described to the messenger with all the effervescence of\r\nenthusiasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the cardinal, on seeing La Houdini\xc3\xa8re return.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, monseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cthree Musketeers and a\r\nGuardsman laid a wager with Monsieur de Busigny that they would go and\r\nbreakfast in the bastion St. Gervais; and while breakfasting they held\r\nit for two hours against the enemy, and have killed I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how\r\nmany Rochellais.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you inquire the names of those three Musketeers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, monseigneur.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are their names?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMessieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill my three brave fellows!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured the cardinal. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the\r\nGuardsman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStill my young scapegrace. Positively, these four men must be on my\r\nside.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe same evening the cardinal spoke to M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville of the exploit of\r\nthe morning, which was the talk of the whole camp. M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, who\r\nhad received the account of the adventure from the mouths of the heroes\r\nof it, related it in all its details to his Eminence, not forgetting\r\nthe episode of the napkin.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well, Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cpray let that\r\nnapkin be sent to me. I will have three _fleur-de-lis_ embroidered on\r\nit in gold, and will give it to your company as a standard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonseigneur,\xe2\x80\x9d said M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, \xe2\x80\x9cthat will be unjust to the\r\nGuardsmen. Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan is not with me; he serves under Monsieur\r\nDessessart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, take him,\xe2\x80\x9d said the cardinal; \xe2\x80\x9cwhen four men are so much\r\nattached to one another, it is only fair that they should serve in the\r\nsame company.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat same evening M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville announced this good news to the three\r\nMusketeers and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, inviting all four to breakfast with him next\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was beside himself with joy. We know that the dream of his\r\nlife had been to become a Musketeer. The three friends were likewise\r\ngreatly delighted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan to Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cyou had a triumphant idea! As\r\nyou said, we have acquired glory, and were enabled to carry on a\r\nconversation of the highest importance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich we can resume now without anybody suspecting us, for, with the\r\nhelp of God, we shall henceforth pass for cardinalists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThat evening D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan went to present his respects to M. Dessessart,\r\nand inform him of his promotion.\r\n\r\nM. Dessessart, who esteemed D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, made him offers of help, as\r\nthis change would entail expenses for equipment.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan refused; but thinking the opportunity a good one, he begged\r\nhim to have the diamond he put into his hand valued, as he wished to\r\nturn it into money.\r\n\r\nThe next day, M. Dessessart\xe2\x80\x99s valet came to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\xe2\x80\x99s lodging, and\r\ngave him a bag containing seven thousand livres.\r\n\r\nThis was the price of the queen\xe2\x80\x99s diamond.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter XLVIII.\r\nA FAMILY AFFAIR\r\n\r\n\r\nAthos had invented the phrase, family affair. A family affair was not\r\nsubject to the investigation of the cardinal; a family affair concerned\r\nnobody. People might employ themselves in a family affair before all\r\nthe world. Therefore Athos had invented the phrase, _family affair_.\r\n\r\nAramis had discovered the idea, _the lackeys_.\r\n\r\nPorthos had discovered the means, _the diamond_.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan alone had discovered nothing\xe2\x80\x94he, ordinarily the most\r\ninventive of the four; but it must be also said that the very name of\r\nMilady paralyzed him.\r\n\r\nAh! no, we were mistaken; he had discovered a purchaser for his\r\ndiamond.\r\n\r\nThe breakfast at M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville\xe2\x80\x99s was as gay and cheerful as possible.\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan already wore his uniform\xe2\x80\x94for being nearly of the same size\r\nas Aramis, and as Aramis was so liberally paid by the publisher who\r\npurchased his poem as to allow him to buy everything double, he sold\r\nhis friend a complete outfit.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan would have been at the height of his wishes if he had not\r\nconstantly seen Milady like a dark cloud hovering in the horizon.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, it was agreed that they should meet again in the\r\nevening at Athos\xe2\x80\x99s lodging, and there finish their plans.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan passed the day in exhibiting his Musketeer\xe2\x80\x99s uniform in\r\nevery street of the camp.\r\n\r\nIn the evening, at the appointed hour, the four friends met. There only\r\nremained three things to decide\xe2\x80\x94what they should write to Milady\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbrother; what they should write to the clever person at Tours; and\r\nwhich should be the lackeys to carry the letters.\r\n\r\nEveryone offered his own. Athos talked of the discretion of Grimaud,\r\nwho never spoke a word but when his master unlocked his mouth. Porthos\r\nboasted of the strength of Mousqueton, who was big enough to thrash\r\nfour men of ordinary size. Aramis, confiding in the address of Bazin,\r\nmade a pompous eulogium on his candidate. Finally, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had\r\nentire faith in the bravery of Planchet, and reminded them of the\r\nmanner in which he had conducted himself in the ticklish affair of\r\nBoulogne.\r\n\r\nThese four virtues disputed the prize for a length of time, and gave\r\nbirth to magnificent speeches which we do not repeat here for fear they\r\nshould be deemed too long.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnfortunately,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9che whom we send must possess in himself\r\nalone the four qualities united.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where is such a lackey to be found?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to be found!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cI know it well, so take Grimaud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake Mousqueton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake Bazin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake Planchet. Planchet is brave and shrewd; they are two qualities\r\nout of the four.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cthe principal question is not to know which\r\nof our four lackeys is the most discreet, the most strong, the most\r\nclever, or the most brave; the principal thing is to know which loves\r\nmoney the best.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat Aramis says is very sensible,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cwe must speculate\r\nupon the faults of people, and not upon their virtues. Monsieur Abb\xc3\xa9,\r\nyou are a great moralist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cfor we not only require to be well served in\r\norder to succeed, but moreover, not to fail; for in case of failure,\r\nheads are in question, not for our lackeys\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak lower, Aramis,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s wise\xe2\x80\x94not for the lackeys,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cbut for the\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x94for the _masters_, we may say. Are our lackeys sufficiently\r\ndevoted to us to risk their lives for us? No.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cI would almost answer for Planchet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, my dear friend, add to his natural devotedness a good sum of\r\nmoney, and then, instead of answering for him once, answer for him\r\ntwice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, good God! you will be deceived just the same,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, who\r\nwas an optimist when things were concerned, and a pessimist when men\r\nwere in question. \xe2\x80\x9cThey will promise everything for the sake of the\r\nmoney, and on the road fear will prevent them from acting. Once taken,\r\nthey will be pressed; when pressed, they will confess everything. What\r\nthe devil! we are not children. To reach England\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Athos lowered his\r\nvoice\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9call France, covered with spies and creatures of the cardinal,\r\nmust be crossed. A passport for embarkation must be obtained; and the\r\nparty must be acquainted with English in order to ask the way to\r\nLondon. Really, I think the thing very difficult.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who was anxious the matter should be\r\naccomplished; \xe2\x80\x9con the contrary, I think it very easy. It would be, no\r\ndoubt, _parbleu_, if we write to Lord de Winter about affairs of vast\r\nimportance, of the horrors of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak lower!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x94of intrigues and secrets of state,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, complying\r\nwith the recommendation. \xe2\x80\x9cThere can be no doubt we would all be broken\r\non the wheel; but for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, do not forget, as you yourself said,\r\nAthos, that we only write to him concerning a family affair; that we\r\nonly write to him to entreat that as soon as Milady arrives in London\r\nhe will put it out of her power to injure us. I will write to him,\r\nthen, nearly in these terms.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, assuming in advance a critical look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Monsieur and dear friend_\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, yes! _Dear friend_ to an Englishman,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cwell\r\ncommenced! Bravo, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! Only with that word you would be\r\nquartered instead of being broken on the wheel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, perhaps. I will say, then, _Monsieur_, quite short.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may even say, _My Lord_,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos, who stickled for\r\npropriety.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_My Lord, do you remember the little goat pasture of the Luxembourg?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood, _the Luxembourg!_ One might believe this is an allusion to the\r\nqueen-mother! That\xe2\x80\x99s ingenious,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, we will put simply, _My Lord, do you remember a certain\r\nlittle enclosure where your life was spared?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, you will never make anything but a very bad\r\nsecretary. _Where your life was spared!_ For shame! that\xe2\x80\x99s unworthy. A\r\nman of spirit is not to be reminded of such services. A benefit\r\nreproached is an offense committed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are insupportable. If the letter\r\nmust be written under your censure, my faith, I renounce the task.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will do right. Handle the musket and the sword, my dear\r\nfellow. You will come off splendidly at those two exercises; but pass\r\nthe pen over to Monsieur Abb\xc3\xa9. That\xe2\x80\x99s his province.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cpass the pen to Aramis, who writes theses in\r\nLatin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, so be it,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cDraw up this note for us, Aramis;\r\nbut by our Holy Father the Pope, cut it short, for I shall prune you in\r\nmy turn, I warn you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask no better,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, with that ingenious air of confidence\r\nwhich every poet has in himself; \xe2\x80\x9cbut let me be properly acquainted\r\nwith the subject. I have heard here and there that this sister-in-law\r\nwas a hussy. I have obtained proof of it by listening to her\r\nconversation with the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLower! _sacr\xc3\xa9 bleu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cthe details escape me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd me also,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Athos looked at each other for some time in silence. At\r\nlength Athos, after serious reflection and becoming more pale than\r\nusual, made a sign of assent to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who by it understood he was\r\nat liberty to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, this is what you have to say,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan: \xe2\x80\x9c_My Lord, your\r\nsister-in-law is an infamous woman, who wished to have you killed that\r\nshe might inherit your wealth; but she could not marry your brother,\r\nbeing already married in France, and having been_\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan stopped,\r\nas if seeking for the word, and looked at Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRepudiated by her husband,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause she had been branded,\xe2\x80\x9d continued D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cImpossible! What do you say\xe2\x80\x94that she wanted to\r\nhave her brother-in-law killed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was married?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd her husband found out that she had a _fleur-de-lis_ on her\r\nshoulder?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese three _yeses_ had been pronounced by Athos, each with a sadder\r\nintonation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who has seen this _fleur-de-lis?_\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Aramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and I. Or rather, to observe the chronological order, I and\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd does the husband of this frightful creature still live?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nAramis.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe still lives.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you quite sure of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am he.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a moment of cold silence, during which everyone was affected\r\naccording to his nature.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis time,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, first breaking the silence, \xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan has\r\ngiven us an excellent program, and the letter must be written at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! You are right, Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9cand it is a rather\r\ndifficult matter. The chancellor himself would be puzzled how to write\r\nsuch a letter, and yet the chancellor draws up an official report very\r\nreadily. Never mind! Be silent, I will write.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis accordingly took the quill, reflected for a few moments, wrote\r\neight or ten lines in a charming little female hand, and then with a\r\nvoice soft and slow, as if each word had been scrupulously weighed, he\r\nread the following:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Lord, The person who writes these few lines had the honor of\r\ncrossing swords with you in the little enclosure of the Rue d\xe2\x80\x99Enfer. As\r\nyou have several times since declared yourself the friend of that\r\nperson, he thinks it his duty to respond to that friendship by sending\r\nyou important information. Twice you have nearly been the victim of a\r\nnear relative, whom you believe to be your heir because you are\r\nignorant that before she contracted a marriage in England she was\r\nalready married in France. But the third time, which is the present,\r\nyou may succumb. Your relative left La Rochelle for England during the\r\nnight. Watch her arrival, for she has great and terrible projects. If\r\nyou require to know positively what she is capable of, read her past\r\nhistory on her left shoulder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, now that will do wonderfully well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Aramis,\r\nyou have the pen of a secretary of state. Lord de Winter will now be\r\nupon his guard if the letter should reach him; and even if it should\r\nfall into the hands of the cardinal, we shall not be compromised. But\r\nas the lackey who goes may make us believe he has been to London and\r\nmay stop at Ch\xc3\xa2tellerault, let us give him only half the sum promised\r\nhim, with the letter, with an agreement that he shall have the other\r\nhalf in exchange for the reply. Have you the diamond?\xe2\x80\x9d continued Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have what is still better. I have the price;\xe2\x80\x9d and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan threw\r\nthe bag upon the table. At the sound of the gold Aramis raised his eyes\r\nand Porthos started. As to Athos, he remained unmoved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much in that little bag?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeven thousand livres, in louis of twelve francs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeven thousand livres!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Porthos. \xe2\x80\x9cThat poor little diamond was\r\nworth seven thousand livres?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears so,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9csince here they are. I don\xe2\x80\x99t suppose that\r\nour friend D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan has added any of his own to the amount.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, gentlemen, in all this,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cwe do not think of the\r\nqueen. Let us take some heed of the welfare of her dear Buckingham.\r\nThat is the least we owe her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that concerns Aramis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the latter, blushing, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat must I say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that\xe2\x80\x99s simple enough!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cWrite a second letter for\r\nthat clever personage who lives at Tours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis resumed his pen, reflected a little, and wrote the following\r\nlines, which he immediately submitted to the approbation of his\r\nfriends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_My dear cousin_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, ah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos. \xe2\x80\x9cThis clever person is your relative, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCousin-german.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo on, to your cousin, then!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis continued:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMY DEAR COUSIN, His Eminence, the cardinal, whom God preserve for the\r\nhappiness of France and the confusion of the enemies of the kingdom, is\r\non the point of putting an end to the hectic rebellion of La Rochelle.\r\nIt is probable that the succor of the English fleet will never even\r\narrive in sight of the place. I will even venture to say that I am\r\ncertain M. de Buckingham will be prevented from setting out by some\r\ngreat event. His Eminence is the most illustrious politician of times\r\npast, of times present, and probably of times to come. He would\r\nextinguish the sun if the sun incommoded him. Give these happy tidings\r\nto your sister, my dear cousin. I have dreamed that the unlucky\r\nEnglishman was dead. I cannot recollect whether it was by steel or by\r\npoison; only of this I am sure, I have dreamed he was dead, and you\r\nknow my dreams never deceive me. Be assured, then, of seeing me soon\r\nreturn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos; \xe2\x80\x9cyou are the king of poets, my dear Aramis. You\r\nspeak like the Apocalypse, and you are as true as the Gospel. There is\r\nnothing now to do but to put the address to this letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is easily done,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis.\r\n\r\nHe folded the letter fancifully, and took up his pen and wrote:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_To Mlle. Michon, seamstress, Tours_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe three friends looked at one another and laughed; they were caught.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cyou will please to understand, gentlemen, that\r\nBazin alone can carry this letter to Tours. My cousin knows nobody but\r\nBazin, and places confidence in nobody but him; any other person would\r\nfail. Besides, Bazin is ambitious and learned; Bazin has read history,\r\ngentlemen, he knows that Sixtus the Fifth became Pope after having kept\r\npigs. Well, as he means to enter the Church at the same time as myself,\r\nhe does not despair of becoming Pope in his turn, or at least a\r\ncardinal. You can understand that a man who has such views will never\r\nallow himself to be taken, or if taken, will undergo martyrdom rather\r\nthan speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9cI consent to Bazin with all my heart,\r\nbut grant me Planchet. Milady had him one day turned out of doors, with\r\nsundry blows of a good stick to accelerate his motions. Now, Planchet\r\nhas an excellent memory; and I will be bound that sooner than\r\nrelinquish any possible means of vengeance, he will allow himself to be\r\nbeaten to death. If your arrangements at Tours are your arrangements,\r\nAramis, those of London are mine. I request, then, that Planchet may be\r\nchosen, more particularly as he has already been to London with me, and\r\nknows how to speak correctly: _London, sir, if you please, and my\r\nmaster, Lord D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan_. With that you may be satisfied he can make\r\nhis way, both going and returning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that case,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet must receive seven hundred livres\r\nfor going, and seven hundred livres for coming back; and Bazin, three\r\nhundred livres for going, and three hundred livres for returning\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nwill reduce the sum to five thousand livres. We will each take a\r\nthousand livres to be employed as seems good, and we will leave a fund\r\nof a thousand livres under the guardianship of Monsieur Abb\xc3\xa9 here, for\r\nextraordinary occasions or common wants. Will that do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cyou speak like Nestor, who was, as\r\neveryone knows, the wisest among the Greeks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cit is agreed. Planchet and Bazin shall go.\r\nEverything considered, I am not sorry to retain Grimaud; he is\r\naccustomed to my ways, and I am particular. Yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s affair must\r\nhave shaken him a little; his voyage would upset him quite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPlanchet was sent for, and instructions were given him. The matter had\r\nbeen named to him by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who in the first place pointed out the\r\nmoney to him, then the glory, and then the danger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will carry the letter in the lining of my coat,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nif I am taken I will swallow it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, but then you will not be able to fulfill your commission,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will give me a copy this evening, which I shall know by heart\r\ntomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan looked at his friends, as if to say, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what did I tell\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d continued he, addressing Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have eight days to get\r\nan interview with Lord de Winter; you have eight days to return\xe2\x80\x94in all\r\nsixteen days. If, on the sixteenth day after your departure, at eight\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening you are not here, no money\xe2\x80\x94even if it be but\r\nfive minutes past eight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cyou must buy me a watch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake this,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, with his usual careless generosity, giving him\r\nhis own, \xe2\x80\x9cand be a good lad. Remember, if you talk, if you babble, if\r\nyou get drunk, you risk your master\xe2\x80\x99s head, who has so much confidence\r\nin your fidelity, and who answers for you. But remember, also, that if\r\nby your fault any evil happens to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, I will find you, wherever\r\nyou may be, for the purpose of ripping up your belly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, humiliated by the suspicion, and\r\nmoreover, terrified at the calm air of the Musketeer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, rolling his large eyes, \xe2\x80\x9cremember, I will skin\r\nyou alive.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, with his soft, melodius voice, \xe2\x80\x9cremember that I\r\nwill roast you at a slow fire, like a savage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPlanchet began to weep. We will not venture to say whether it was from\r\nterror created by the threats or from tenderness at seeing four friends\r\nso closely united.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan took his hand. \xe2\x80\x9cSee, Planchet,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthese gentlemen\r\nonly say this out of affection for me, but at bottom they all like\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cI will succeed or I will consent to be\r\ncut in quarters; and if they do cut me in quarters, be assured that not\r\na morsel of me will speak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was decided that Planchet should set out the next day, at eight\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning, in order, as he had said, that he might during\r\nthe night learn the letter by heart. He gained just twelve hours by\r\nthis engagement; he was to be back on the sixteenth day, by eight\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening.\r\n\r\nIn the morning, as he was mounting his horse, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who felt at\r\nthe bottom of his heart a partiality for the duke, took Planchet aside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he to him. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen you have given the letter to Lord de\r\nWinter and he has read it, you will further say to him: _Watch over his\r\nGrace Lord Buckingham, for they wish to assassinate him_. But this,\r\nPlanchet, is so serious and important that I have not informed my\r\nfriends that I would entrust this secret to you; and for a captain\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncommission I would not write it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe satisfied, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet, \xe2\x80\x9cyou shall see if confidence\r\ncan be placed in me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMounted on an excellent horse, which he was to leave at the end of\r\ntwenty leagues in order to take the post, Planchet set off at a gallop,\r\nhis spirits a little depressed by the triple promise made him by the\r\nMusketeers, but otherwise as light-hearted as possible.\r\n\r\nBazin set out the next day for Tours, and was allowed eight days for\r\nperforming his commission.\r\n\r\nThe four friends, during the period of these two absences, had, as may\r\nwell be supposed, the eye on the watch, the nose to the wind, and the\r\near on the hark. Their days were passed in endeavoring to catch all\r\nthat was said, in observing the proceeding of the cardinal, and in\r\nlooking out for all the couriers who arrived. More than once an\r\ninvoluntary trembling seized them when called upon for some unexpected\r\nservice. They had, besides, to look constantly to their own proper\r\nsafety; Milady was a phantom which, when it had once appeared to\r\npeople, did not allow them to sleep very quietly.\r\n\r\nOn the morning of the eighth day, Bazin, fresh as ever, and smiling,\r\naccording to custom, entered the cabaret of the Parpaillot as the four\r\nfriends were sitting down to breakfast, saying, as had been agreed\r\nupon: \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Aramis, the answer from your cousin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four friends exchanged a joyful glance; half of the work was done.\r\nIt is true, however, that it was the shorter and easier part.\r\n\r\nAramis, blushing in spite of himself, took the letter, which was in a\r\nlarge, coarse hand and not particular for its orthography.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried he, laughing, \xe2\x80\x9cI quite despair of my poor Michon; she\r\nwill never write like Monsieur de Voiture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does you mean by boor Michon?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss, who was chatting\r\nwith the four friends when the letter came.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, _pardieu_, less than nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis; \xe2\x80\x9ca charming little\r\nseamstress, whom I love dearly and from whose hand I requested a few\r\nlines as a sort of keepsake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe duvil!\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss, \xe2\x80\x9cif she is as great a lady as her writing\r\nis large, you are a lucky fellow, gomrade!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAramis read the letter, and passed it to Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee what she writes to me, Athos,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nAthos cast a glance over the epistle, and to disperse all the\r\nsuspicions that might have been created, read aloud:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMY COUSIN, My sister and I are skillful in interpreting dreams, and\r\neven entertain great fear of them; but of yours it may be said, I hope,\r\nevery dream is an illusion. Adieu! Take care of yourself, and act so\r\nthat we may from time to time hear you spoken of.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMARIE MICHON\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what dream does she mean?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the dragoon, who had approached\r\nduring the reading.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYez; what\xe2\x80\x99s the dream?\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, _pardieu!_\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cit was only this: I had a dream, and I\r\nrelated it to her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYez, yez,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Swiss; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s simple enough to dell a dream, but I\r\nneffer dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very fortunate,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, rising; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could say as\r\nmuch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNeffer,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the Swiss, enchanted that a man like Athos could envy\r\nhim anything. \xe2\x80\x9cNeffer, neffer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, seeing Athos rise, did likewise, took his arm, and went\r\nout.\r\n\r\nPorthos and Aramis remained behind to encounter the jokes of the\r\ndragoon and the Swiss.\r\n\r\nAs to Bazin, he went and lay down on a truss of straw; and as he had\r\nmore imagination than the Swiss, he dreamed that Aramis, having become\r\npope, adorned his head with a cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s hat.\r\n\r\nBut, as we have said, Bazin had not, by his fortunate return, removed\r\nmore than a part of the uneasiness which weighed upon the four friends.\r\nThe days of expectation are long, and D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in particular, would\r\nhave wagered that the days were forty-four hours. He forgot the\r\nnecessary slowness of navigation; he exaggerated to himself the power\r\nof Milady. He credited this woman, who appeared to him the equal of a\r\ndemon, with agents as supernatural as herself; at the least noise, he\r\nimagined himself about to be arrested, and that Planchet was being\r\nbrought back to be confronted with himself and his friends. Still\r\nfurther, his confidence in the worthy Picard, at one time so great,\r\ndiminished day by day. This anxiety became so great that it even\r\nextended to Aramis and Porthos. Athos alone remained unmoved, as if no\r\ndanger hovered over him, and as if he breathed his customary\r\natmosphere.\r\n\r\nOn the sixteenth day, in particular, these signs were so strong in\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and his two friends that they could not remain quiet in one\r\nplace, and wandered about like ghosts on the road by which Planchet was\r\nexpected.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReally,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos to them, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are not men but children, to let a\r\nwoman terrify you so! And what does it amount to, after all? To be\r\nimprisoned. Well, but we should be taken out of prison; Madame\r\nBonacieux was released. To be decapitated? Why, every day in the\r\ntrenches we go cheerfully to expose ourselves to worse than that\xe2\x80\x94for a\r\nbullet may break a leg, and I am convinced a surgeon would give us more\r\npain in cutting off a thigh than an executioner in cutting off a head.\r\nWait quietly, then; in two hours, in four, in six hours at latest,\r\nPlanchet will be here. He promised to be here, and I have very great\r\nfaith in Planchet, who appears to me to be a very good lad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if he does not come?\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if he does not come, it will be because he has been delayed,\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s all. He may have fallen from his horse, he may have cut a caper\r\nfrom the deck; he may have traveled so fast against the wind as to have\r\nbrought on a violent catarrh. Eh, gentlemen, let us reckon upon\r\naccidents! Life is a chaplet of little miseries which the philosopher\r\ncounts with a smile. Be philosophers, as I am, gentlemen; sit down at\r\nthe table and let us drink. Nothing makes the future look so bright as\r\nsurveying it through a glass of chambertin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s all very well,\xe2\x80\x9d replied D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I am tired of fearing\r\nwhen I open a fresh bottle that the wine may come from the cellar of\r\nMilady.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very fastidious,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos; \xe2\x80\x9csuch a beautiful woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA woman of mark!\xe2\x80\x9d said Porthos, with his loud laugh.\r\n\r\nAthos started, passed his hand over his brow to remove the drops of\r\nperspiration that burst forth, and rose in his turn with a nervous\r\nmovement he could not repress.\r\n\r\nThe day, however, passed away; and the evening came on slowly, but\r\nfinally it came. The bars were filled with drinkers. Athos, who had\r\npocketed his share of the diamond, seldom quit the Parpaillot. He had\r\nfound in M. de Busigny, who, by the by, had given them a magnificent\r\ndinner, a partner worthy of his company. They were playing together, as\r\nusual, when seven o\xe2\x80\x99clock sounded; the patrol was heard passing to\r\ndouble the posts. At half past seven the retreat was sounded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are lost,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in the ear of Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mean to say we _have lost_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, quietly, drawing four\r\npistoles from his pocket and throwing them upon the table. \xe2\x80\x9cCome,\r\ngentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthey are beating the tattoo. Let us to bed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Athos went out of the Parpaillot, followed by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. Aramis\r\ncame behind, giving his arm to Porthos. Aramis mumbled verses to\r\nhimself, and Porthos from time to time pulled a hair or two from his\r\nmustache, in sign of despair.\r\n\r\nBut all at once a shadow appeared in the darkness the outline of which\r\nwas familiar to D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and a well-known voice said, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, I\r\nhave brought your cloak; it is chilly this evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, beside himself with joy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPlanchet!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Aramis and Porthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, yes, Planchet, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is there so\r\nastonishing in that? He promised to be back by eight o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and eight\r\nis striking.
