The lackeys were sent on before with the baggage,\r\nand they set out on the morning of the sixteenth.\r\n\r\nThe cardinal accompanied his Majesty from Surg\xc3\xa8res to Mauzes; and there\r\nthe king and his minister took leave of each other with great\r\ndemonstrations of friendship.\r\n\r\nThe king, however, who sought distraction, while traveling as fast as\r\npossible\xe2\x80\x94for he was anxious to be in Paris by the twenty-third\xe2\x80\x94stopped\r\nfrom time to time to fly the magpie, a pastime for which the taste had\r\nbeen formerly inspired in him by de Luynes, and for which he had always\r\npreserved a great predilection. Out of the twenty Musketeers sixteen,\r\nwhen this took place, rejoiced greatly at this relaxation; but the\r\nother four cursed it heartily. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, in particular, had a\r\nperpetual buzzing in his ears, which Porthos explained thus: \xe2\x80\x9cA very\r\ngreat lady has told me that this means that somebody is talking of you\r\nsomewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt length the escort passed through Paris on the twenty-third, in the\r\nnight. The king thanked M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, and permitted him to distribute\r\nfurloughs for four days, on condition that the favored parties should\r\nnot appear in any public place, under penalty of the Bastille.\r\n\r\nThe first four furloughs granted, as may be imagined, were to our four\r\nfriends. Still further, Athos obtained of M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville six days\r\ninstead of four, and introduced into these six days two more nights\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nthey set out on the twenty-fourth at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the evening, and\r\nas a further kindness M. de Tr\xc3\xa9ville post-dated the leave to the\r\nmorning of the twenty-fifth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood Lord!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, as we have often said, never\r\nstumbled at anything. \xe2\x80\x9cIt appears to me that we are making a great\r\ntrouble of a very simple thing. In two days, and by using up two or\r\nthree horses (that\xe2\x80\x99s nothing; I have plenty of money), I am at B\xc3\xa9thune.\r\nI present my letter from the queen to the superior, and I bring back\r\nthe dear treasure I go to seek\xe2\x80\x94not into Lorraine, not into Belgium, but\r\nto Paris, where she will be much better concealed, particularly while\r\nthe cardinal is at La Rochelle. Well, once returned from the country,\r\nhalf by the protection of her cousin, half through what we have\r\npersonally done for her, we shall obtain from the queen what we desire.\r\nRemain, then, where you are, and do not exhaust yourselves with useless\r\nfatigue. Myself and Planchet are all that such a simple expedition\r\nrequires.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo this Athos replied quietly: \xe2\x80\x9cWe also have money left\xe2\x80\x94for I have not\r\nyet drunk all my share of the diamond, and Porthos and Aramis have not\r\neaten all theirs. We can therefore use up four horses as well as one.\r\nBut consider, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, in a tone so solemn that it made\r\nthe young man shudder, \xe2\x80\x9cconsider that B\xc3\xa9thune is a city where the\r\ncardinal has given rendezvous to a woman who, wherever she goes, brings\r\nmisery with her. If you had only to deal with four men, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, I\r\nwould allow you to go alone. You have to do with that woman! We four\r\nwill go; and I hope to God that with our four lackeys we may be in\r\nsufficient number.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou terrify me, Athos!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cMy God! what do you fear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEverything!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Athos.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan examined the countenances of his companions, which, like\r\nthat of Athos, wore an impression of deep anxiety; and they continued\r\ntheir route as fast as their horses could carry them, but without\r\nadding another word.\r\n\r\nOn the evening of the twenty-fifth, as they were entering Arras, and as\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was dismounting at the inn of the Golden Harrow to drink a\r\nglass of wine, a horseman came out of the post yard, where he had just\r\nhad a relay, started off at a gallop, and with a fresh horse took the\r\nroad to Paris. At the moment he passed through the gateway into the\r\nstreet, the wind blew open the cloak in which he was wrapped, although\r\nit was in the month of August, and lifted his hat, which the traveler\r\nseized with his hand the moment it had left his head, pulling it\r\neagerly over his eyes.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who had his eyes fixed upon this man, became very pale, and\r\nlet his glass fall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter, monsieur?\xe2\x80\x9d said Planchet. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, come, gentlemen, my\r\nmaster is ill!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three friends hastened toward D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, who, instead of being\r\nill, ran toward his horse. They stopped him at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, where the devil are you going now?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is he!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, pale with anger, and with the sweat on\r\nhis brow, \xe2\x80\x9cit is he! let me overtake him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe? What he?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Athos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe, that man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat cursed man, my evil genius, whom I have always met with when\r\nthreatened by some misfortune, he who accompanied that horrible woman\r\nwhen I met her for the first time, he whom I was seeking when I\r\noffended our Athos, he whom I saw on the very morning Madame Bonacieux\r\nwas abducted. I have seen him; that is he! I recognized him when the\r\nwind blew upon his cloak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, musingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo saddle, gentlemen! to saddle! Let us pursue him, and we shall\r\novertake him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cremember that he goes in an opposite\r\ndirection from that in which we are going, that he has a fresh horse,\r\nand ours are fatigued, so that we shall disable our own horses without\r\neven a chance of overtaking him. Let the man go, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; let us\r\nsave the woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur, monsieur!\xe2\x80\x9d cried a hostler, running out and looking after\r\nthe stranger, \xe2\x80\x9cmonsieur, here is a paper which dropped out of your hat!\r\nEh, monsieur, eh!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFriend,\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, \xe2\x80\x9ca half-pistole for that paper!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy faith, monsieur, with great pleasure! Here it is!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe hostler, enchanted with the good day\xe2\x80\x99s work he had done, returned\r\nto the yard. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan unfolded the paper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d eagerly demanded all his three friends.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing but one word!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Aramis, \xe2\x80\x9cbut that one word is the name of some town or\r\nvillage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Armenti\xc3\xa8res_,\xe2\x80\x9d read Porthos; \xe2\x80\x9cArmenti\xc3\xa8res? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know such a\r\nplace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd that name of a town or village is written in her hand!\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nAthos.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome on, come on!\xe2\x80\x9d said D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; \xe2\x80\x9clet us keep that paper carefully,\r\nperhaps I have not thrown away my half-pistole. To horse, my friends,\r\nto horse!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the four friends flew at a gallop along the road to B\xc3\xa9thune.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter LXI.\r\nTHE CARMELITE CONVENT AT B\xc3\x89THUNE\r\n\r\n\r\nGreat criminals bear about them a kind of predestination which makes\r\nthem surmount all obstacles, which makes them escape all dangers, up to\r\nthe moment which a wearied Providence has marked as the rock of their\r\nimpious fortunes.\r\n\r\nIt was thus with Milady. She escaped the cruisers of both nations, and\r\narrived at Boulogne without accident.\r\n\r\nWhen landing at Portsmouth, Milady was an Englishwoman whom the\r\npersecutions of the French drove from La Rochelle; when landing at\r\nBoulogne, after a two days\xe2\x80\x99 passage, she passed for a Frenchwoman whom\r\nthe English persecuted at Portsmouth out of their hatred for France.\r\n\r\nMilady had, likewise, the best of passports\xe2\x80\x94her beauty, her noble\r\nappearance, and the liberality with which she distributed her pistoles.\r\nFreed from the usual formalities by the affable smile and gallant\r\nmanners of an old governor of the port, who kissed her hand, she only\r\nremained long enough at Boulogne to put into the post a letter,\r\nconceived in the following terms:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_To his Eminence Monseigneur the Cardinal Richelieu, in his camp\r\nbefore La Rochelle_.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMONSEIGNEUR, Let your Eminence be reassured. His Grace the Duke of\r\nBuckingham _will not set out_ for France.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMILADY DE \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBOULOGNE, evening of the twenty-fifth.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cP.S.\xe2\x80\x94According to the desire of your Eminence, I report to the convent\r\nof the Carmelites at B\xc3\xa9thune, where I will await your orders.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nAccordingly, that same evening Milady commenced her journey. Night\r\novertook her; she stopped, and slept at an inn. At five o\xe2\x80\x99clock the\r\nnext morning she again proceeded, and in three hours after entered\r\nB\xc3\xa9thune. She inquired for the convent of the Carmelites, and went\r\nthither immediately.\r\n\r\nThe superior met her; Milady showed her the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s order. The\r\nabbess assigned her a chamber, and had breakfast served.\r\n\r\nAll the past was effaced from the eyes of this woman; and her looks,\r\nfixed on the future, beheld nothing but the high fortunes reserved for\r\nher by the cardinal, whom she had so successfully served without his\r\nname being in any way mixed up with the sanguinary affair. The ever-new\r\npassions which consumed her gave to her life the appearance of those\r\nclouds which float in the heavens, reflecting sometimes azure,\r\nsometimes fire, sometimes the opaque blackness of the tempest, and\r\nwhich leave no traces upon the earth behind them but devastation and\r\ndeath.\r\n\r\nAfter breakfast, the abbess came to pay her a visit. There is very\r\nlittle amusement in the cloister, and the good superior was eager to\r\nmake the acquaintance of her new boarder.\r\n\r\nMilady wished to please the abbess. This was a very easy matter for a\r\nwoman so really superior as she was. She tried to be agreeable, and she\r\nwas charming, winning the good superior by her varied conversation and\r\nby the graces of her whole personality.\r\n\r\nThe abbess, who was the daughter of a noble house, took particular\r\ndelight in stories of the court, which so seldom travel to the\r\nextremities of the kingdom, and which, above all, have so much\r\ndifficulty in penetrating the walls of convents, at whose threshold the\r\nnoise of the world dies away.\r\n\r\nMilady, on the contrary, was quite conversant with all aristocratic\r\nintrigues, amid which she had constantly lived for five or six years.\r\nShe made it her business, therefore, to amuse the good abbess with the\r\nworldly practices of the court of France, mixed with the eccentric\r\npursuits of the king; she made for her the scandalous chronicle of the\r\nlords and ladies of the court, whom the abbess knew perfectly by name,\r\ntouched lightly on the amours of the queen and the Duke of Buckingham,\r\ntalking a great deal to induce her auditor to talk a little.\r\n\r\nBut the abbess contented herself with listening and smiling without\r\nreplying a word. Milady, however, saw that this sort of narrative\r\namused her very much, and kept at it; only she now let her conversation\r\ndrift toward the cardinal.\r\n\r\nBut she was greatly embarrassed. She did not know whether the abbess\r\nwas a royalist or a cardinalist; she therefore confined herself to a\r\nprudent middle course. But the abbess, on her part, maintained a\r\nreserve still more prudent, contenting herself with making a profound\r\ninclination of the head every time the fair traveler pronounced the\r\nname of his Eminence.\r\n\r\nMilady began to think she should soon grow weary of a convent life; she\r\nresolved, then, to risk something in order that she might know how to\r\nact afterward. Desirous of seeing how far the discretion of the good\r\nabbess would go, she began to tell a story, obscure at first, but very\r\ncircumstantial afterward, about the cardinal, relating the amours of\r\nthe minister with Mme. d\xe2\x80\x99Aiguillon, Marion de Lorme, and several other\r\ngay women.\r\n\r\nThe abbess listened more attentively, grew animated by degrees, and\r\nsmiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood,\xe2\x80\x9d thought Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cshe takes a pleasure in my conversation. If\r\nshe is a cardinalist, she has no fanaticism, at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe then went on to describe the persecutions exercised by the cardinal\r\nupon his enemies. The abbess only crossed herself, without approving or\r\ndisapproving.\r\n\r\nThis confirmed Milady in her opinion that the abbess was rather\r\nroyalist than cardinalist. Milady therefore continued, coloring her\r\nnarrations more and more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very ignorant of these matters,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abbess, at length; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nhowever distant from the court we may be, however remote from the\r\ninterests of the world we may be placed, we have very sad examples of\r\nwhat you have related. And one of our boarders has suffered much from\r\nthe vengeance and persecution of the cardinal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne of your boarders?\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady; \xe2\x80\x9coh, my God! Poor woman! I pity\r\nher, then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have reason, for she is much to be pitied. Imprisonment,\r\nmenaces, ill treatment\xe2\x80\x94she has suffered everything. But after all,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nresumed the abbess, \xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur Cardinal has perhaps plausible motives\r\nfor acting thus; and though she has the look of an angel, we must not\r\nalways judge people by the appearance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady to herself; \xe2\x80\x9cwho knows! I am about, perhaps, to\r\ndiscover something here; I am in the vein.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe tried to give her countenance an appearance of perfect candor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cI know it is so. It is said that we must not\r\ntrust to the face; but in what, then, shall we place confidence, if not\r\nin the most beautiful work of the Lord? As for me, I shall be deceived\r\nall my life perhaps, but I shall always have faith in a person whose\r\ncountenance inspires me with sympathy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would, then, be tempted to believe,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abbess, \xe2\x80\x9cthat this\r\nyoung person is innocent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe cardinal pursues not only crimes,\xe2\x80\x9d said she: \xe2\x80\x9cthere are certain\r\nvirtues which he pursues more severely than certain offenses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPermit me, madame, to express my surprise,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abbess.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt what?\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, with the utmost ingenuousness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt the language you use.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you find so astonishing in that language?\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady,\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are the friend of the cardinal, for he sends you hither, and yet\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd yet I speak ill of him,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, finishing the thought of\r\nthe superior.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least you don\xe2\x80\x99t speak well of him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is because I am not his friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, sighing, \xe2\x80\x9cbut his\r\nvictim!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut this letter in which he recommends you to me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs an order for me to confine myself to a sort of prison, from which\r\nhe will release me by one of his satellites.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why have you not fled?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither should I go? Do you believe there is a spot on the earth which\r\nthe cardinal cannot reach if he takes the trouble to stretch forth his\r\nhand? If I were a man, that would barely be possible; but what can a\r\nwoman do? This young boarder of yours, has she tried to fly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, that is true; but she\xe2\x80\x94that is another thing; I believe she is\r\ndetained in France by some love affair.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, with a sigh, \xe2\x80\x9cif she loves she is not altogether\r\nwretched.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abbess, looking at Milady with increasing interest, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nbehold another poor victim?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\nThe abbess looked at her for an instant with uneasiness, as if a fresh\r\nthought suggested itself to her mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not an enemy of our holy faith?\xe2\x80\x9d said she, hesitatingly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x94I?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cI a Protestant? Oh, no! I call to witness the\r\nGod who hears us, that on the contrary I am a fervent Catholic!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abbess, smiling, \xe2\x80\x9cbe reassured; the house in\r\nwhich you are shall not be a very hard prison, and we will do all in\r\nour power to make you cherish your captivity. You will find here,\r\nmoreover, the young woman of whom I spoke, who is persecuted, no doubt,\r\nin consequence of some court intrigue. She is amiable and\r\nwell-behaved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is her name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was sent to me by someone of high rank, under the name of Kitty. I\r\nhave not tried to discover her other name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKitty!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat? Are you sure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat she is called so? Yes, madame. Do you know her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady smiled to herself at the idea which had occurred to her that\r\nthis might be her old chambermaid. There was connected with the\r\nremembrance of this girl a remembrance of anger; and a desire of\r\nvengeance disordered the features of Milady, which, however,\r\nimmediately recovered the calm and benevolent expression which this\r\nwoman of a hundred faces had for a moment allowed them to lose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when can I see this young lady, for whom I already feel so great a\r\nsympathy?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, this evening,\xe2\x80\x9d said the abbess; \xe2\x80\x9ctoday even. But you have been\r\ntraveling these four days, as you told me yourself. This morning you\r\nrose at five o\xe2\x80\x99clock; you must stand in need of repose. Go to bed and\r\nsleep; at dinnertime we will rouse you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlthough Milady would very willingly have gone without sleep, sustained\r\nas she was by all the excitements which a new adventure awakened in her\r\nheart, ever thirsting for intrigues, she nevertheless accepted the\r\noffer of the superior. During the last fifteen days she had experienced\r\nso many and such various emotions that if her frame of iron was still\r\ncapable of supporting fatigue, her mind required repose.\r\n\r\nShe therefore took leave of the abbess, and went to bed, softly rocked\r\nby the ideas of vengeance which the name of Kitty had naturally brought\r\nto her thoughts. She remembered that almost unlimited promise which the\r\ncardinal had given her if she succeeded in her enterprise. She had\r\nsucceeded; D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan was then in her power!\r\n\r\nOne thing alone frightened her; that was the remembrance of her\r\nhusband, the Comte de la F\xc3\xa8re, whom she had believed dead, or at least\r\nexpatriated, and whom she found again in Athos\xe2\x80\x94the best friend of\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nBut alas, if he was the friend of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he must have lent him his\r\nassistance in all the proceedings by whose aid the queen had defeated\r\nthe project of his Eminence; if he was the friend of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, he was\r\nthe enemy of the cardinal; and she doubtless would succeed in involving\r\nhim in the vengeance by which she hoped to destroy the young Musketeer.\r\n\r\nAll these hopes were so many sweet thoughts for Milady; so, rocked by\r\nthem, she soon fell asleep.\r\n\r\nShe was awakened by a soft voice which sounded at the foot of her bed.\r\nShe opened her eyes, and saw the abbess, accompanied by a young woman\r\nwith light hair and delicate complexion, who fixed upon her a look full\r\nof benevolent curiosity.\r\n\r\nThe face of the young woman was entirely unknown to her. Each examined\r\nthe other with great attention, while exchanging the customary\r\ncompliments; both were very handsome, but of quite different styles of\r\nbeauty. Milady, however, smiled in observing that she excelled the\r\nyoung woman by far in her high air and aristocratic bearing. It is true\r\nthat the habit of a novice, which the young woman wore, was not very\r\nadvantageous in a contest of this kind.\r\n\r\nThe abbess introduced them to each other. When this formality was\r\nended, as her duties called her to chapel, she left the two young women\r\nalone.\r\n\r\nThe novice, seeing Milady in bed, was about to follow the example of\r\nthe superior; but Milady stopped her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI have scarcely seen you, and you already\r\nwish to deprive me of your company, upon which I had counted a little,\r\nI must confess, for the time I have to pass here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the novice, \xe2\x80\x9conly I thought I had chosen my time\r\nill; you were asleep, you are fatigued.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat can those who sleep wish for\xe2\x80\x94a happy\r\nawakening? This awakening you have given me; allow me, then, to enjoy\r\nit at my ease,\xe2\x80\x9d and taking her hand, she drew her toward the armchair\r\nby the bedside.\r\n\r\nThe novice sat down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow unfortunate I am!\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cI have been here six months without\r\nthe shadow of recreation. You arrive, and your presence was likely to\r\nafford me delightful company; yet I expect, in all probability, to quit\r\nthe convent at any moment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow, you are going soon?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt least I hope so,\xe2\x80\x9d said the novice, with an expression of joy which\r\nshe made no effort to disguise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I learned you had suffered persecutions from the cardinal,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cthat would have been another motive for sympathy\r\nbetween us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat I have heard, then, from our good mother is true; you have\r\nlikewise been a victim of that wicked priest.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady; \xe2\x80\x9clet us not, even here, speak thus of him. All my\r\nmisfortunes arise from my having said nearly what you have said before\r\na woman whom I thought my friend, and who betrayed me. Are you also the\r\nvictim of a treachery?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said the novice, \xe2\x80\x9cbut of my devotion\xe2\x80\x94of a devotion to a woman I\r\nloved, for whom I would have laid down my life, for whom I would give\r\nit still.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who has abandoned you\xe2\x80\x94is that it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been sufficiently unjust to believe so; but during the last two\r\nor three days I have obtained proof to the contrary, for which I thank\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x94for it would have cost me very dear to think she had forgotten me.\r\nBut you, madame, you appear to be free,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the novice; \xe2\x80\x9cand if\r\nyou were inclined to fly it only rests with yourself to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhither would you have me go, without friends, without money, in a\r\npart of France with which I am unacquainted, and where I have never\r\nbeen before?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried the novice, \xe2\x80\x9cas to friends, you would have them wherever\r\nyou want, you appear so good and are so beautiful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat does not prevent,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, softening her smile so as to\r\ngive it an angelic expression, \xe2\x80\x9cmy being alone or being persecuted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHear me,\xe2\x80\x9d said the novice; \xe2\x80\x9cwe must trust in heaven. There always\r\ncomes a moment when the good you have done pleads your cause before\r\nGod; and see, perhaps it is a happiness for you, humble and powerless\r\nas I am, that you have met with me, for if I leave this place, well\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nhave powerful friends, who, after having exerted themselves on my\r\naccount, may also exert themselves for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, when I said I was alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, hoping to make the novice\r\ntalk by talking of herself, \xe2\x80\x9cit is not for want of friends in high\r\nplaces; but these friends themselves tremble before the cardinal. The\r\nqueen herself does not dare to oppose the terrible minister. I have\r\nproof that her Majesty, notwithstanding her excellent heart, has more\r\nthan once been obliged to abandon to the anger of his Eminence persons\r\nwho had served her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust me, madame; the queen may appear to have abandoned those\r\npersons, but we must not put faith in appearances. The more they are\r\npersecuted, the more she thinks of them; and often, when they least\r\nexpect it, they have proof of a kind remembrance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe so; the queen is so good!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you know her, then, that lovely and noble queen, that you speak of\r\nher thus!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the novice, with enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, driven into her entrenchment, \xe2\x80\x9cthat I\r\nhave not the honor of knowing her personally; but I know a great number\r\nof her most intimate friends. I am acquainted with Monsieur de Putange;\r\nI met Monsieur Dujart in England; I know Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed the novice, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you know Monsieur de\r\nTr\xc3\xa9ville?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, perfectly well\xe2\x80\x94intimately even.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe captain of the king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe captain of the king\xe2\x80\x99s Musketeers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, then, only see!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the novice; \xe2\x80\x9cwe shall soon be well\r\nacquainted, almost friends. If you know Monsieur de Tr\xc3\xa9ville, you must\r\nhave visited him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOften!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, who, having entered this track, and perceiving\r\nthat falsehood succeeded, was determined to follow it to the end.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith him, then, you must have seen some of his Musketeers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll those he is in the habit of receiving!\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, for whom\r\nthis conversation began to have a real interest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cName a few of those whom you know, and you will see if they are my\r\nfriends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, embarrassed, \xe2\x80\x9cI know Monsieur de Louvigny,\r\nMonsieur de Courtivron, Monsieur de Ferussac.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe novice let her speak, then seeing that she paused, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou know a gentleman named Athos?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady became as pale as the sheets in which she was lying, and\r\nmistress as she was of herself, could not help uttering a cry, seizing\r\nthe hand of the novice, and devouring her with looks.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter? Good God!\xe2\x80\x9d asked the poor woman, \xe2\x80\x9chave I said\r\nanything that has wounded you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but the name struck me, because I also have known that gentleman,\r\nand it appeared strange to me to meet with a person who appears to know\r\nhim well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, very well; not only him, but some of his friends, Messieurs\r\nPorthos and Aramis!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! you know them likewise? I know them,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, who began\r\nto feel a chill penetrate her heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you know them, you know that they are good and free\r\ncompanions. Why do you not apply to them, if you stand in need of\r\nhelp?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is to say,\xe2\x80\x9d stammered Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cI am not really very intimate with\r\nany of them. I know them from having heard one of their friends,\r\nMonsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, say a great deal about them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the novice, in her turn seizing\r\nthe hands of Milady and devouring her with her eyes.\r\n\r\nThen remarking the strange expression of Milady\xe2\x80\x99s countenance, she\r\nsaid, \xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, madame; you know him by what title?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Milady, embarrassed, \xe2\x80\x9cwhy, by the title of friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou deceive me, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the novice; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have been his\r\nmistress!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is you who have been his mistress, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, in her\r\nturn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI?\xe2\x80\x9d said the novice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you! I know you now. You are Madame Bonacieux!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young woman drew back, filled with surprise and terror.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, do not deny it! Answer!\xe2\x80\x9d continued Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, yes, madame,\xe2\x80\x9d said the novice, \xe2\x80\x9cAre we rivals?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe countenance of Milady was illumined by so savage a joy that under\r\nany other circumstances Mme. Bonacieux would have fled in terror; but\r\nshe was absorbed by jealousy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSpeak, madame!\xe2\x80\x9d resumed Mme. Bonacieux, with an energy of which she\r\nmight not have been believed capable. \xe2\x80\x9cHave you been, or are you, his\r\nmistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, with an accent that admitted no doubt of her\r\ntruth. \xe2\x80\x9cNever, never!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cbut why, then, did you cry out\r\nso?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not understand?\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, who had already overcome her\r\nagitation and recovered all her presence of mind.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I understand? I know nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you not understand that Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, being my friend,\r\nmight take me into his confidence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you not perceive that I know all\xe2\x80\x94your abduction from the little\r\nhouse at St. Germain, his despair, that of his friends, and their\r\nuseless inquiries up to this moment? How could I help being astonished\r\nwhen, without having the least expectation of such a thing, I meet you\r\nface to face\xe2\x80\x94you, of whom we have so often spoken together, you whom he\r\nloves with all his soul, you whom he had taught me to love before I had\r\nseen you! Ah, dear Constance, I have found you, then; I see you at\r\nlast!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Milady stretched out her arms to Mme. Bonacieux, who, convinced by\r\nwhat she had just said, saw nothing in this woman whom an instant\r\nbefore she had believed her rival but a sincere and devoted friend.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, pardon me, pardon me!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, sinking upon the shoulders of\r\nMilady. \xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, I love him so much!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese two women held each other for an instant in a close embrace.\r\nCertainly, if Milady\xe2\x80\x99s strength had been equal to her hatred, Mme.\r\nBonacieux would never have left that embrace alive. But not being able\r\nto stifle her, she smiled upon her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you beautiful, good little creature!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady. \xe2\x80\x9cHow delighted\r\nI am to have found you! Let me look at you!\xe2\x80\x9d and while saying these\r\nwords, she absolutely devoured her by her looks. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes it is you\r\nindeed! From what he has told me, I know you now. I recognize you\r\nperfectly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe poor young woman could not possibly suspect what frightful cruelty\r\nwas behind the rampart of that pure brow, behind those brilliant eyes\r\nin which she read nothing but interest and compassion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you know what I have suffered,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9csince he\r\nhas told you what he has suffered; but to suffer for him is happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady replied mechanically, \xe2\x80\x9cYes, that is happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d She was thinking\r\nof something else.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cmy punishment is drawing to a\r\nclose. Tomorrow, this evening, perhaps, I shall see him again; and then\r\nthe past will no longer exist.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis evening?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady, roused from her reverie by these words.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean? Do you expect news from him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI expect himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHimself? D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHimself!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that\xe2\x80\x99s impossible! He is at the siege of La Rochelle with the\r\ncardinal. He will not return till after the taking of the city.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, you fancy so! But is there anything impossible for my D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan,\r\nthe noble and loyal gentleman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I cannot believe you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, read, then!\xe2\x80\x9d said the unhappy young woman, in the excess of her\r\npride and joy, presenting a letter to Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe writing of Madame de Chevreuse!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady to herself. \xe2\x80\x9cAh, I\r\nalways thought there was some secret understanding in that quarter!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnd she greedily read the following few lines:\r\n\r\nMY DEAR CHILD, Hold yourself ready. _Our friend_ will see you soon, and\r\nhe will only see you to release you from that imprisonment in which\r\nyour safety required you should be concealed. Prepare, then, for your\r\ndeparture, and never despair of us.\r\n    Our charming Gascon has just proved himself as brave and faithful\r\n    as ever. Tell him that certain parties are grateful for the warning\r\n    he has given.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady; \xe2\x80\x9cthe letter is precise. Do you know what that\r\nwarning was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I only suspect he has warned the queen against some fresh\r\nmachinations of the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, that\xe2\x80\x99s it, no doubt!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, returning the letter to Mme.\r\nBonacieux, and letting her head sink pensively upon her bosom.\r\n\r\nAt that moment they heard the gallop of a horse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux, darting to the window, \xe2\x80\x9ccan it be he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady remained still in bed, petrified by surprise; so many unexpected\r\nthings happened to her all at once that for the first time she was at a\r\nloss.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe, he!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured she; \xe2\x80\x9ccan it be he?\xe2\x80\x9d And she remained in bed with\r\nher eyes fixed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas, no!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cit is a man I don\xe2\x80\x99t know, although he\r\nseems to be coming here. Yes, he checks his pace; he stops at the gate;\r\nhe rings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady sprang out of bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are sure it is not he?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, very sure!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you did not see well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, if I were to see the plume of his hat, the end of his cloak, I\r\nshould know _him!_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady was dressing herself all the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, he has entered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is for you or me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy God, how agitated you seem!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I admit it. I have not your confidence; I fear the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9csomebody is coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nImmediately the door opened, and the superior entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you come from Boulogne?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded she of Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she, trying to recover her self-possession. \xe2\x80\x9cWho wants\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA man who will not tell his name, but who comes from the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd who wishes to speak with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho wishes to speak to a lady recently come from Boulogne.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen let him come in, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux. \xe2\x80\x9cCan it be bad news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will leave you with this stranger; but as soon as he is gone, if you\r\nwill permit me, I will return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Permit_ you? I _beseech_ you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe superior and Mme. Bonacieux retired.\r\n\r\nMilady remained alone, with her eyes fixed upon the door. An instant\r\nlater, the jingling of spurs was heard upon the stairs, steps drew\r\nnear, the door opened, and a man appeared.\r\n\r\nMilady uttered a cry of joy; this man was the Comte de Rochefort\xe2\x80\x94the\r\ndemoniacal tool of his Eminence.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter LXII.\r\nTWO VARIETIES OF DEMONS\r\n\r\n\r\nAh,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady and Rochefort together, \xe2\x80\x9cit is you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it is I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you come?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom La Rochelle; and you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBuckingham?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead or desperately wounded, as I left without having been able to\r\nhear anything of him. A fanatic has just assassinated him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rochefort, with a smile; \xe2\x80\x9cthis is a fortunate chance\xe2\x80\x94one\r\nthat will delight his Eminence! Have you informed him of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wrote to him from Boulogne. But what brings you here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis Eminence was uneasy, and sent me to find you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI only arrived yesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what have you been doing since yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not lost my time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know whom I have encountered here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGuess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat young woman whom the queen took out of prison.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mistress of that fellow D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; Madame Bonacieux, with whose retreat the cardinal was\r\nunacquainted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rochefort, \xe2\x80\x9chere is a chance which may pair off with\r\nthe other! Monsieur Cardinal is indeed a privileged man!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImagine my astonishment,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen I found myself face\r\nto face with this woman!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes she know you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen she looks upon you as a stranger?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cI am her best friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUpon my honor,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rochefort, \xe2\x80\x9cit takes you, my dear countess, to\r\nperform such miracles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it is well I can, Chevalier,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cfor do you know what\r\nis going on here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey will come for her tomorrow or the day after, with an order from\r\nthe queen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed! And who?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and his friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, they will go so far that we shall be obliged to send them to\r\nthe Bastille.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy is it not done already?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you? The cardinal has a weakness for these men which I\r\ncannot comprehend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, tell him this, Rochefort. Tell him that our conversation\r\nat the inn of the Red Dovecot was overheard by these four men; tell him\r\nthat after his departure one of them came up to me and took from me by\r\nviolence the safe-conduct which he had given me; tell him they warned\r\nLord de Winter of my journey to England; that this time they nearly\r\nfoiled my mission as they foiled the affair of the studs; tell him that\r\namong these four men two only are to be feared\xe2\x80\x94D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Athos;\r\ntell him that the third, Aramis, is the lover of Madame de Chevreuse\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nmay be left alone, we know his secret, and it may be useful; as to the\r\nfourth, Porthos, he is a fool, a simpleton, a blustering booby, not\r\nworth troubling himself about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut these four men must be now at the siege of La Rochelle?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought so, too; but a letter which Madame Bonacieux has received\r\nfrom Madame the Constable, and which she has had the imprudence to show\r\nme, leads me to believe that these four men, on the contrary, are on\r\nthe road hither to take her away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil! What\xe2\x80\x99s to be done?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did the cardinal say about me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was to take your dispatches, written or verbal, and return by post;\r\nand when he shall know what you have done, he will advise what you have\r\nto do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must, then, remain here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, or in the neighborhood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot take me with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, the order is imperative. Near the camp you might be recognized;\r\nand your presence, you must be aware, would compromise the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I must wait here, or in the neighborhood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly tell me beforehand where you will wait for intelligence from the\r\ncardinal; let me know always where to find you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cObserve, it is probable that I may not be able to remain here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou forget that my enemies may arrive at any minute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true; but is this little woman, then, to escape his Eminence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBah!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, with a smile that belonged only to herself; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nforget that I am her best friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, that\xe2\x80\x99s true! I may then tell the cardinal, with respect to this\r\nlittle woman\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat he may be at ease.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will know what that means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will guess, at least. Now, then, what had I better do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReturn instantly. It appears to me that the news you bear is worth the\r\ntrouble of a little diligence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy chaise broke down coming into Lilliers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, _capital?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I want your chaise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how shall I travel, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn horseback.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou talk very comfortably,\xe2\x80\x94a hundred and eighty leagues!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne can do it! Afterward?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfterward? Why, in passing through Lilliers you will send me your\r\nchaise, with an order to your servant to place himself at my disposal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have, no doubt, some order from the cardinal about you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have my _full power_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow it to the abbess, and tell her that someone will come and fetch\r\nme, either today or tomorrow, and that I am to follow the person who\r\npresents himself in your name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t forget to treat me harshly in speaking of me to the abbess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo what purpose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a victim of the cardinal. It is necessary to inspire confidence\r\nin that poor little Madame Bonacieux.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true. Now, will you make me a report of all that has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I have related the events to you. You have a good memory; repeat\r\nwhat I have told you. A paper may be lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are right; only let me know where to find you that I may not run\r\nneedlessly about the neighborhood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s correct; wait!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want a map?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I know this country marvelously!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou? When were you here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was brought up here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is worth something, you see, to have been brought up somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will wait for me, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me reflect a little! Ay, that will do\xe2\x80\x94at Armenti\xc3\xa8res.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is that Armenti\xc3\xa8res?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little town on the Lys; I shall only have to cross the river, and I\r\nshall be in a foreign country.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital! but it is understood you will only cross the river in case of\r\ndanger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is well understood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd in that case, how shall I know where you are?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou do not want your lackey?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he a sure man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the proof.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive him to me. Nobody knows him. I will leave him at the place I\r\nquit, and he will conduct you to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you say you will wait for me at Armenti\xc3\xa8res?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Armenti\xc3\xa8res.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite that name on a bit of paper, lest I should forget it. There is\r\nnothing compromising in the name of a town. Is it not so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEh, who knows? Never mind,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, writing the name on half a\r\nsheet of paper; \xe2\x80\x9cI will compromise myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rochefort, taking the paper from Milady, folding it, and\r\nplacing it in the lining of his hat, \xe2\x80\x9cyou may be easy. I will do as\r\nchildren do, for fear of losing the paper\xe2\x80\x94repeat the name along the\r\nroute. Now, is that all?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet us see: Buckingham dead or grievously wounded; your conversation\r\nwith the cardinal overheard by the four Musketeers; Lord de Winter\r\nwarned of your arrival at Portsmouth; D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and Athos to the\r\nBastille; Aramis the lover of Madame de Chevreuse; Porthos an ass;\r\nMadame Bonacieux found again; to send you the chaise as soon as\r\npossible; to place my lackey at your disposal; to make you out a victim\r\nof the cardinal in order that the abbess may entertain no suspicion;\r\nArmenti\xc3\xa8res, on the banks of the Lys. Is that all, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth, my dear Chevalier, you are a miracle of memory. _A propos_,\r\nadd one thing\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI saw some very pretty woods which almost touch the convent garden.\r\nSay that I am permitted to walk in those woods. Who knows? Perhaps I\r\nshall stand in need of a back door for retreat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think of everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you forget one thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo ask me if I want money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s true. How much do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll you have in gold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have five hundred pistoles, or thereabouts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have as much. With a thousand pistoles one may face everything.\r\nEmpty your pockets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight. And you go\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn an hour\xe2\x80\x94time to eat a morsel, during which I shall send for a post\r\nhorse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapital! Adieu, Chevalier.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, Countess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommend me to the cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommend me to Satan.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady and Rochefort exchanged a smile and separated. An hour afterward\r\nRochefort set out at a grand gallop; five hours after that he passed\r\nthrough Arras.\r\n\r\nOur readers already know how he was recognized by D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, and how\r\nthat recognition by inspiring fear in the four Musketeers had given\r\nfresh activity to their journey.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter LXIII.\r\nTHE DROP OF WATER\r\n\r\n\r\nRochefort had scarcely departed when Mme. Bonacieux re-entered. She\r\nfound Milady with a smiling countenance.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat you dreaded has happened. This\r\nevening, or tomorrow, the cardinal will send someone to take you away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho told you that, my dear?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard it from the mouth of the messenger himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and sit down close to me,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere I am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait till I assure myself that nobody hears us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy all these precautions?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady arose, went to the door, opened it, looked in the corridor, and\r\nthen returned and seated herself close to Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9che has well played his part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho has?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe who just now presented himself to the abbess as a messenger from\r\nthe cardinal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was, then, a part he was playing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, my child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat man, then, was not\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, lowering her voice, \xe2\x80\x9cis my brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour brother!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one must know this secret, my dear, but yourself. If you reveal it\r\nto anyone in the world, I shall be lost, and perhaps yourself\r\nlikewise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen. This is what has happened: My brother, who was coming to my\r\nassistance to take me away by force if it were necessary, met with the\r\nemissary of the cardinal, who was coming in search of me. He followed\r\nhim. At a solitary and retired part of the road he drew his sword, and\r\nrequired the messenger to deliver up to him the papers of which he was\r\nthe bearer. The messenger resisted; my brother killed him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, shuddering.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember, that was the only means. Then my brother determined to\r\nsubstitute cunning for force. He took the papers, and presented himself\r\nhere as the emissary of the cardinal, and in an hour or two a carriage\r\nwill come to take me away by the orders of his Eminence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand. It is your brother who sends this carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExactly; but that is not all. That letter you have received, and which\r\nyou believe to be from Madame de Chevreuse\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a forgery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can that be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, a forgery; it is a snare to prevent your making any resistance\r\nwhen they come to fetch you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it is D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan that will come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo not deceive yourself. D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and his friends are detained at\r\nthe siege of La Rochelle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother met some emissaries of the cardinal in the uniform of\r\nMusketeers. You would have been summoned to the gate; you would have\r\nbelieved yourself about to meet friends; you would have been abducted,\r\nand conducted back to Paris.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God! My senses fail me amid such a chaos of iniquities. I feel,\r\nif this continues,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, raising her hands to her\r\nforehead, \xe2\x80\x9cI shall go mad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hear a horse\xe2\x80\x99s steps; it is my brother setting off again. I should\r\nlike to offer him a last salute. Come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady opened the window, and made a sign to Mme. Bonacieux to join\r\nher. The young woman complied.\r\n\r\nRochefort passed at a gallop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdieu, brother!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady.\r\n\r\nThe chevalier raised his head, saw the two young women, and without\r\nstopping, waved his hand in a friendly way to Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe good George!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, closing the window with an expression of\r\ncountenance full of affection and melancholy. And she resumed her seat,\r\nas if plunged in reflections entirely personal.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cpardon me for interrupting you; but\r\nwhat do you advise me to do? Good heaven! You have more experience than\r\nI have. Speak; I will listen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the first place,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, \xe2\x80\x9cit is possible I may be deceived,\r\nand that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan and his friends may really come to your\r\nassistance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, that would be too much!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cso much happiness\r\nis not in store for me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you comprehend it would be only a question of time, a sort of\r\nrace, which should arrive first. If your friends are the more speedy,\r\nyou are to be saved; if the satellites of the cardinal, you are lost.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, yes; lost beyond redemption! What, then, to do? What to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere would be a very simple means, very natural\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me what!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo wait, concealed in the neighborhood, and assure yourself who are\r\nthe men who come to ask for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where can I wait?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, there is no difficulty in that. I shall stop and conceal myself a\r\nfew leagues hence until my brother can rejoin me. Well, I take you with\r\nme; we conceal ourselves, and wait together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I shall not be allowed to go; I am almost a prisoner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs they believe that I go in consequence of an order from the\r\ncardinal, no one will believe you anxious to follow me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell! The carriage is at the door; you bid me adieu; you mount the\r\nstep to embrace me a last time; my brother\xe2\x80\x99s servant, who comes to\r\nfetch me, is told how to proceed; he makes a sign to the postillion,\r\nand we set off at a gallop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! if he comes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall we not know it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing easier. We will send my brother\xe2\x80\x99s servant back to B\xc3\xa9thune,\r\nwhom, as I told you, we can trust. He shall assume a disguise, and\r\nplace himself in front of the convent. If the emissaries of the\r\ncardinal arrive, he will take no notice; if it is Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan\r\nand his friends, he will bring them to us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe knows them, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless. Has he not seen Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan at my house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, yes; you are right. Thus all may go well\xe2\x80\x94all may be for the\r\nbest; but we do not go far from this place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeven or eight leagues at the most. We will keep on the frontiers, for\r\ninstance; and at the first alarm we can leave France.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what can we do there?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWait.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut if they come?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother\xe2\x80\x99s carriage will be here first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I should happen to be any distance from you when the carriage comes\r\nfor you\xe2\x80\x94at dinner or supper, for instance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo one thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell your good superior that in order that we may be as much together\r\nas possible, you ask her permission to share my repast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill she permit it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat inconvenience can it be?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, delightful! In this way we shall not be separated for an instant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go down to her, then, to make your request. I feel my head a\r\nlittle confused; I will take a turn in the garden.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo; and where shall I find you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, in an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, in an hour. Oh, you are so kind, and I am so grateful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I avoid interesting myself for one who is so beautiful and so\r\namiable? Are you not the beloved of one of my best friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! Oh, how he will thank you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so. Now, then, all is agreed; let us go down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going into the garden?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo along this corridor, down a little staircase, and you are in it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExcellent; thank you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the two women parted, exchanging charming smiles.\r\n\r\nMilady had told the truth\xe2\x80\x94her head was confused, for her ill-arranged\r\nplans clashed one another like chaos. She required to be alone that she\r\nmight put her thoughts a little into order. She saw vaguely the future;\r\nbut she stood in need of a little silence and quiet to give all her\r\nideas, as yet confused, a distinct form and a regular plan.\r\n\r\nWhat was most pressing was to get Mme. Bonacieux away, and convey her\r\nto a place of safety, and there, if matters required, make her a\r\nhostage. Milady began to have doubts of the issue of this terrible\r\nduel, in which her enemies showed as much perseverance as she did\r\nanimosity.\r\n\r\nBesides, she felt as we feel when a storm is coming on\xe2\x80\x94that this issue\r\nwas near, and could not fail to be terrible.\r\n\r\nThe principal thing for her, then, was, as we have said, to keep Mme.\r\nBonacieux in her power. Mme. Bonacieux was the very life of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\nThis was more than his life, the life of the woman he loved; this was,\r\nin case of ill fortune, a means of temporizing and obtaining good\r\nconditions.\r\n\r\nNow, this point was settled; Mme. Bonacieux, without any suspicion,\r\naccompanied her. Once concealed with her at Armenti\xc3\xa8res, it would be\r\neasy to make her believe that D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan had not come to B\xc3\xa9thune. In\r\nfifteen days at most, Rochefort would be back; besides, during that\r\nfifteen days she would have time to think how she could best avenge\r\nherself on the four friends. She would not be weary, thank God! for she\r\nshould enjoy the sweetest pastime such events could accord a woman of\r\nher character\xe2\x80\x94perfecting a beautiful vengeance.\r\n\r\nRevolving all this in her mind, she cast her eyes around her, and\r\narranged the topography of the garden in her head. Milady was like a\r\ngood general who contemplates at the same time victory and defeat, and\r\nwho is quite prepared, according to the chances of the battle, to march\r\nforward or to beat a retreat.\r\n\r\nAt the end of an hour she heard a soft voice calling her; it was Mme.\r\nBonacieux\xe2\x80\x99s. The good abbess had naturally consented to her request;\r\nand as a commencement, they were to sup together.\r\n\r\nOn reaching the courtyard, they heard the noise of a carriage which\r\nstopped at the gate.\r\n\r\nMilady listened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you hear anything?\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, the rolling of a carriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the one my brother sends for us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come! courage!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe bell of the convent gate was sounded; Milady was not mistaken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to your chamber,\xe2\x80\x9d said she to Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9cyou have perhaps\r\nsome jewels you would like to take.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have his letters,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, go and fetch them, and come to my apartment. We will snatch some\r\nsupper; we shall perhaps travel part of the night, and must keep our\r\nstrength up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, placing her hand upon her bosom, \xe2\x80\x9cmy\r\nheart beats so I cannot walk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourage, courage! remember that in a quarter of an hour you will be\r\nsafe; and think that what you are about to do is for _his_ sake.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, everything for him. You have restored my courage by a single\r\nword; go, I will rejoin you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady ran up to her apartment quickly; she there found Rochefort\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlackey, and gave him his instructions.\r\n\r\nHe was to wait at the gate; if by chance the Musketeers should appear,\r\nthe carriage was to set off as fast as possible, pass around the\r\nconvent, and go and wait for Milady at a little village which was\r\nsituated at the other side of the wood. In this case Milady would cross\r\nthe garden and gain the village on foot. As we have already said,\r\nMilady was admirably acquainted with this part of France.\r\n\r\nIf the Musketeers did not appear, things were to go on as had been\r\nagreed; Mme. Bonacieux was to get into the carriage as if to bid her\r\nadieu, and she was to take away Mme. Bonacieux.\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux came in; and to remove all suspicion, if she had any,\r\nMilady repeated to the lackey, before her, the latter part of her\r\ninstructions.\r\n\r\nMilady asked some questions about the carriage. It was a chaise drawn\r\nby three horses, driven by a postillion; Rochefort\xe2\x80\x99s lackey would\r\nprecede it, as courier.\r\n\r\nMilady was wrong in fearing that Mme. Bonacieux would have any\r\nsuspicion. The poor young woman was too pure to suppose that any female\r\ncould be guilty of such perfidy; besides, the name of the Comtesse de\r\nWinter, which she had heard the abbess pronounce, was wholly unknown to\r\nher, and she was even ignorant that a woman had had so great and so\r\nfatal a share in the misfortune of her life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, when the lackey had gone out, \xe2\x80\x9ceverything is\r\nready. The abbess suspects nothing, and believes that I am taken by\r\norder of the cardinal. This man goes to give his last orders; take the\r\nleast thing, drink a finger of wine, and let us be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, mechanically, \xe2\x80\x9cyes, let us be gone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMilady made her a sign to sit down opposite, poured her a small glass\r\nof Spanish wine, and helped her to the wing of a chicken.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cif everything does not second us! Here is night\r\ncoming on; by daybreak we shall have reached our retreat, and nobody\r\ncan guess where we are. Come, courage! take something.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux ate a few mouthfuls mechanically, and just touched the\r\nglass with her lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, come!\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, lifting hers to her mouth, \xe2\x80\x9cdo as I do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut at the moment the glass touched her lips, her hand remained\r\nsuspended; she heard something on the road which sounded like the\r\nrattling of a distant gallop. Then it grew nearer, and it seemed to\r\nher, almost at the same time, that she heard the neighing of horses.\r\n\r\nThis noise acted upon her joy like the storm which awakens the sleeper\r\nin the midst of a happy dream; she grew pale and ran to the window,\r\nwhile Mme. Bonacieux, rising all in a tremble, supported herself upon\r\nher chair to avoid falling. Nothing was yet to be seen, only they heard\r\nthe galloping draw nearer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is that noise?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat of either our friends or our enemies,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady, with her\r\nterrible coolness. \xe2\x80\x9cStay where you are, I will tell you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux remained standing, mute, motionless, and pale as a\r\nstatue.\r\n\r\nThe noise became louder; the horses could not be more than a hundred\r\nand fifty paces distant. If they were not yet to be seen, it was\r\nbecause the road made an elbow. The noise became so distinct that the\r\nhorses might be counted by the rattle of their hoofs.\r\n\r\nMilady gazed with all the power of her attention; it was just light\r\nenough for her to see who was coming.\r\n\r\nAll at once, at the turning of the road she saw the glitter of laced\r\nhats and the waving of feathers; she counted two, then five, then eight\r\nhorsemen. One of them preceded the rest by double the length of his\r\nhorse.\r\n\r\nMilady uttered a stifled groan. In the first horseman she recognized\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is the uniform of the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guards. Not an instant to be lost!\r\nFly, fly!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, let us fly!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mme. Bonacieux, but without being able\r\nto make a step, glued as she was to the spot by terror.\r\n\r\nThey heard the horsemen pass under the windows.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, then, come, then!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady, trying to drag the young woman\r\nalong by the arm. \xe2\x80\x9cThanks to the garden, we yet can flee; I have the\r\nkey, but make haste! in five minutes it will be too late!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux tried to walk, made two steps, and sank upon her knees.\r\nMilady tried to raise and carry her, but could not do it.\r\n\r\nAt this moment they heard the rolling of the carriage, which at the\r\napproach of the Musketeers set off at a gallop. Then three or four\r\nshots were fired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor the last time, will you come?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God! you see my strength fails me; you see plainly I\r\ncannot walk. Flee alone!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFlee alone, and leave you here? No, no, never!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Milady.\r\n\r\nAll at once she paused, a livid flash darted from her eyes; she ran to\r\nthe table, emptied into Mme. Bonacieux\xe2\x80\x99s glass the contents of a ring\r\nwhich she opened with singular quickness. It was a grain of a reddish\r\ncolor, which dissolved immediately.\r\n\r\nThen, taking the glass with a firm hand, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cDrink. This wine\r\nwill give you strength, drink!\xe2\x80\x9d And she put the glass to the lips of\r\nthe young woman, who drank mechanically.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is not the way that I wished to avenge myself,\xe2\x80\x9d said Milady,\r\nreplacing the glass upon the table, with an infernal smile, \xe2\x80\x9cbut, my\r\nfaith! we do what we can!\xe2\x80\x9d And she rushed out of the room.\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux saw her go without being able to follow her; she was\r\nlike people who dream they are pursued, and who in vain try to walk.\r\n\r\nA few moments passed; a great noise was heard at the gate. Every\r\ninstant Mme. Bonacieux expected to see Milady, but she did not return.\r\nSeveral times, with terror, no doubt, the cold sweat burst from her\r\nburning brow.\r\n\r\nAt length she heard the grating of the hinges of the opening gates; the\r\nnoise of boots and spurs resounded on the stairs. There was a great\r\nmurmur of voices which continued to draw near, amid which she seemed to\r\nhear her own name pronounced.\r\n\r\nAll at once she uttered a loud cry of joy, and darted toward the door;\r\nshe had recognized the voice of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, \xe2\x80\x9cis it you? This way! this way!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConstance? Constance?\xe2\x80\x9d replied the young man, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere are you? where\r\nare you? My God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the same moment the door of the cell yielded to a shock, rather than\r\nopened; several men rushed into the chamber. Mme. Bonacieux had sunk\r\ninto an armchair, without the power of moving.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan threw down a yet-smoking pistol which he held in his hand,\r\nand fell on his knees before his mistress. Athos replaced his in his\r\nbelt; Porthos and Aramis, who held their drawn swords in their hands,\r\nreturned them to their scabbards.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, my beloved D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan! You have come, then, at last!\r\nYou have not deceived me! It is indeed thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes, Constance. Reunited!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, it was in vain she told me you would not come! I hoped in silence.\r\nI was not willing to fly. Oh, I have done well! How happy I am!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt this word _she_, Athos, who had seated himself quietly, started up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_She!_ What she?\xe2\x80\x9d asked D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, my companion. She who out of friendship for me wished to take me\r\nfrom my persecutors. She who, mistaking you for the cardinal\xe2\x80\x99s Guards,\r\nhas just fled away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour companion!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, becoming more pale than the white\r\nveil of his mistress. \xe2\x80\x9cOf what companion are you speaking, dear\r\nConstance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf her whose carriage was at the gate; of a woman who calls herself\r\nyour friend; of a woman to whom you have told everything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer name, her name!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cMy God, can you not remember\r\nher name?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, it was pronounced in my hearing once. Stop\xe2\x80\x94but\xe2\x80\x94it is very\r\nstrange\xe2\x80\x94oh, my God, my head swims! I cannot see!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp, help, my friends! her hands are icy cold,\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is ill! Great God, she is losing her senses!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile Porthos was calling for help with all the power of his strong\r\nvoice, Aramis ran to the table to get a glass of water; but he stopped\r\nat seeing the horrible alteration that had taken place in the\r\ncountenance of Athos, who, standing before the table, his hair rising\r\nfrom his head, his eyes fixed in stupor, was looking at one of the\r\nglasses, and appeared a prey to the most horrible doubt.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9coh, no, it is impossible! God would not permit such\r\na crime!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWater, water!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. \xe2\x80\x9cWater!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, poor woman, poor woman!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Athos, in a broken voice.\r\n\r\nMme. Bonacieux opened her eyes under the kisses of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe revives!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the young man. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, my God, my God, I thank thee!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadame!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cmadame, in the name of heaven, whose empty glass\r\nis this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMine, monsieur,\xe2\x80\x9d said the young woman, in a dying voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who poured the wine for you that was in this glass?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut who is _she?_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I remember!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Comtesse de Winter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe four friends uttered one and the same cry, but that of Athos\r\ndominated all the rest.\r\n\r\nAt that moment the countenance of Mme. Bonacieux became livid; a\r\nfearful agony pervaded her frame, and she sank panting into the arms of\r\nPorthos and Aramis.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan seized the hands of Athos with an anguish difficult to be\r\ndescribed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do you believe?\xe2\x80\x9d His voice was stifled by sobs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe everything,\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, biting his lips till the blood\r\nsprang to avoid sighing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan, D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Mme. Bonacieux, \xe2\x80\x9cwhere art thou? Do not\r\nleave me! You see I am dying!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan released the hands of Athos which he still held clasped in\r\nboth his own, and hastened to her. Her beautiful face was distorted\r\nwith agony; her glassy eyes had no longer their sight; a convulsive\r\nshuddering shook her whole body; the sweat rolled from her brow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the name of heaven, run, call! Aramis! Porthos! Call for help!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUseless!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, \xe2\x80\x9cuseless! For the poison which _she_ pours there\r\nis no antidote.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes! Help, help!\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mme. Bonacieux; \xe2\x80\x9chelp!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen, collecting all her strength, she took the head of the young man\r\nbetween her hands, looked at him for an instant as if her whole soul\r\npassed into that look, and with a sobbing cry pressed her lips to his.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConstance, Constance!\xe2\x80\x9d cried D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan.\r\n\r\nA sigh escaped from the mouth of Mme. Bonacieux, and dwelt for an\r\ninstant on the lips of D\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. That sigh was the soul, so chaste\r\nand so loving, which reascended to heaven.\r\n\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan pressed nothing but a corpse in his arms. The young man\r\nuttered a cry, and fell by the side of his mistress as pale and as icy\r\nas herself.\r\n\r\nPorthos wept; Aramis pointed toward heaven; Athos made the sign of the\r\ncross.\r\n\r\nAt that moment a man appeared in the doorway, almost as pale as those\r\nin the chamber. He looked around him and saw Mme. Bonacieux dead, and\r\nD\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan in a swoon. He appeared just at that moment of stupor which\r\nfollows great catastrophes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was not deceived,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9chere is Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan; and you\r\nare his friends, Messieurs Athos, Porthos, and Aramis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe persons whose names were thus pronounced looked at the stranger\r\nwith astonishment. It seemed to all three that they knew him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed the newcomer, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are, as I am, in search of a\r\nwoman who,\xe2\x80\x9d added he, with a terrible smile, \xe2\x80\x9cmust have passed this\r\nway, for I see a corpse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three friends remained mute\xe2\x80\x94for although the voice as well as the\r\ncountenance reminded them of someone they had seen, they could not\r\nremember under what circumstances.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the stranger, \xe2\x80\x9csince you do not recognize a man\r\nwho probably owes his life to you twice, I must name myself. I am Lord\r\nde Winter, brother-in-law of that _woman_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three friends uttered a cry of surprise.\r\n\r\nAthos rose, and offering him his hand, \xe2\x80\x9cBe welcome, my Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou are one of us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI set out five hours after her from Portsmouth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord de Winter.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI arrived three hours after her at Boulogne. I missed her by twenty\r\nminutes at St. Omer. Finally, at Lilliers I lost all trace of her. I\r\nwas going about at random, inquiring of everybody, when I saw you\r\ngallop past. I recognized Monsieur d\xe2\x80\x99Artagnan. I called to you, but you\r\ndid not answer me; I wished to follow you, but my horse was too much\r\nfatigued to go at the same pace with yours. And yet it appears, in\r\nspite of all your diligence, you have arrived too late.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see!\xe2\x80\x9d said Athos, pointing to Mme.
